HEADLINE: U.S. Juries Grow Tougher On Those Seeking Damages

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
In this land of big lawsuits, the growth of multimillion-dollar jury awards has been halted: juries nationwide have become markedly tougher on people who sue doctors, insurance companies and other deep-pockets defendants, siding less often with plaintiffs. And there is evidence that the size of the awards has leveled off, too.
In 1992, plaintiffs won 52 percent of the personal injury cases decided by jury verdicts, down from 63 percent in 1989, according to Jury Verdict Research, a legal publishing firm in Horsham, Pa., that is the only one nationally to compile such data. And there are indications that the downward trend continued last year. 
 The firm's research also indicates that despite the occasional colossal award that generates great publicity and revives assertions that juries have run amok, the average award has remained constant during the 1990's.
Theories abound as to why the shift has occurred, but the most widely accepted seems to be that criticism leveled at juries and their perceived largesse by two of the most affluent defendants -- the medical profession and the insurance industry -- has sunk in.
"There's been such a campaign by the insurance industry, by people like Dan Quayle, saying these big awards are killing our society," said Brian Shenker, editorial director of Jury Verdict Research. "People see this in the media, and when they get on juries they think, 'I'm not going to contribute to this.' "
James F. McHugh, an associate justice of the Massachusetts Superior Court, said, "There's less of a sense among juries that it's other people's money we're dealing with." Jurors, he added, "are aware that we all pay these costs" in the form of insurance premiums.
The acid test of this attitude, lawyers and judges say, is in personal injury cases, in which individual plaintiffs are often pitted against corporate defendants and, almost invariably, against the defendants' insurance companies. By contrast, practitioners say, jurors' attitudes have not changed in cases of contract disputes or fraud suits, for example, that tend to pit one company against another.
Some lawyers, like Stephan Peskin, president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, say they have seen no evidence of greater jury skepticism regarding plaintiffs' claims. "Jurors still do what's right," he said. "I think the insurance industry message is being filtered through some very observant eyes."
But the numbers point to a determined shift. From 1961 to 1991, a plaintiff's chances of prevailing at trial in personal injury suits changed remarkably little, never rising above 63 percent or falling below 57 percent in any year. Then came the drop to 52 percent in 1992.
"I've seen a kind of conservatism among jurors, and you get defendants' verdicts that you might not have a few years ago," said Justice Helen E. Freedman of New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan. "Jurors say they're very concerned about the high verdicts you read about in the newspaper -- though they don't ever hear about the verdicts for the defendant -- and they're very concerned about the high costs of health care and insurance."
Stephen H. Mackauf, chairman of the medical malpractice committee of the New York County Lawyers Association, said, "Now when I question jurors, I find they come in with strong negative opinions about lawsuits, where they didn't used to."
Mr. Mackauf, a partner at Gair, Gair, Conason, Steigman & Mackauf, and other trial lawyers said the change is most noticeable among middle-class jurors, many of whom pay health insurance premiums and are aware of rising medical costs and jury verdicts.
 
Offended by TV Ads
 Michael Mone, president of the Massachusetts Bar Association, said that television advertisements for personal injury lawyers may have enhanced the trend.
"I think jurors are offended by some of that advertising," he said. "It makes them tend to look askance at the cases that are in front of them."
Several trial lawyers also suggested that people who were hit hard by the recession might have become less sympathetic to personal injury plaintiffs.
But people in the legal profession agree that the shift in jury sentiments is not the result of an increase in frivolous lawsuits.
"In medical malpractice, if anything, the quality of cases has gotten better," said Justice Freedman, who has tried numerous medical malpractice and products liability cases. "Plaintiffs know that these cases are very costly and time-consuming, and I think they've become more reluctant" to sue.
G. Marc Whitehead, a Minneapolis trial lawyer who was co-chairman of a Brookings Institution conference in 1992 on the future of the civil jury, said the sense among lawyers "is that litigation is actually down overall," and added, "People find it's too expensive, slow and difficult."
As has long been the case, jury awards average slightly more when government agencies are the defendants, but the size of that gap has not changed in recent years.
Jury Verdict Research's figures show an especially stark shift in juries' sympathies in cases involving premises liability and medical malpractice, which in recent years have accounted for 25 percent of all personal injury trials. Premises liability, including slip-and-fall cases, is invoked when someone is injured on someone else's property.
 
Plaintiffs Losing Ground
 A plaintiff's chances of winning a premises liability trial fell to 42 percent in 1992 from 65 percent in 1987. In medical malpractice cases, which involve some of the largest awards, the winning rate dropped to 31 percent in 1992 from 48 percent in 1989.
All the data for 1993 have not yet been compiled, but there is no sign that plaintiffs gained ground over the previous year, Mr. Shenker said.
In products liability, the one major area for which 1993 figures are available, he said, a plaintiff's chances of winning at trial, having dropped to 43 percent in 1992 from 59 percent in 1989, slipped to 41 percent last year.
It is harder to draw conclusions from the size of damage awards, which vary broadly. Categorizing all personal injury awards by amount -- for example, under $50,000, $200,000 to $400,000 and more than $1 million -- the Jury Verdict figures show virtually no change in recent years.
A look at both the median and average size of products liability awards shows a similar constancy from 1988 to 1992. The median medical malpractice award -- $350,000 in 1992 -- showed no consistent pattern. The average, which can be greatly increased by a few large verdicts and so fluctuates more wildly than the median, rose from an average of about $1.1 million in the late 1980's to about $1.7 million in the early 1990's.

HEADLINE: Clinton May Add G.I.'s in Korea While Remaining Open to Talks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
President Clinton met with top advisers today to consider Pentagon recommendations to bolster American forces in South Korea, but he later held out the possibility that a new diplomatic offer by North Korea might lead to a resolution of the crisis over the North's suspected nuclear weapons program.
At a news conference after a day of meetings, Mr. Clinton said his Administration would be willing to participate in high-level talks with the North Koreans if they agreed to freeze their nuclear weapons program. 
 Mr. Clinton made his offer after President Kim Il Sung told former President Jimmy Carter today in Pyongyang that North Korea was willing to allow international inspectors to continue work at a nuclear site at Yongbyon and wanted to discuss replacing its plutonium-producing complex with technology that yields less bomb-grade material. [Page A10.]
"If today's developments mean that North Korea is genuinely and verifiably prepared to freeze its nuclear program while talks go on, and we hope that is the case, then we would be willing to resume high-level talks," Mr. Clinton said. "In the meantime, we will pursue our consultations on sanctions."
While officials insisted that Washington had not changed its goals, Mr. Clinton's statement contained an important policy shift.
Previously, the Administration had insisted that it would not resume high-level talks with North Korea unless the North suspended efforts to develop nuclear weapons. Washington also insisted that the North make it possible to determine in the future whether it had ever diverted plutonium, a fissionable byproduct of the Yongbyon generator.
Administration officials defended Mr. Clinton's decision to drop the precondition on tracing past diversions of plutonium, saying that North Korea's new diplomacy hinted at flexibility and that this issue could be taken up later at high-level talks.
North Korea has alrady destroyed some evidence of its past diversion by rapidly removing spent fuel rods from the Yongbyon reactor without supervision.
"You can't go off and pout in a corner and say, now that they have done things we did not want them to do, there is no solution," a senior Administration official said. "It is incumbent on the North Koreans to do something to restore the basis for a dialogue, and we will wait and see whether they have done that."
Mr. Clinton made his offer after meeting with his top aides, including Defense Secretary William J. Perry and Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to discuss the Defense Department's recommendations.
Officials said Mr. Perry had offered Mr. Clinton a three-tiered plan, calibrating the options on military force to different levels of international sanctions against North Korea, the North's behavior and other indicators of the risk of war.
 
The Stages of Involvement
 Mr. Perry did not endorse a specific option, but sees some reinforcement as necessary to deter North Korea from launching an attack if sanctions are imposed, Pentagon officials said.
At the low end is the deployment of mostly support personnel to ease the dispatch of reinforcements in the event of a North Korean attack.
Under another option, the United States would send 30 to 40 aircraft to the region, including F-117 Stealth fighter-bombers and long-range bombers. Tactical fighters would be stationed in Korea; the bombers might be based in Guam. Two aircraft carriers would be stationed in the region, instead of the single carrier that is routinely kept there. The Army and the Marines would also strengthen their forces.
Administration officials said the recommendations reflected the views of Gen. Gary E. Luck, the United States commander in Korea.
 
A Decision Within Days
 Administration officials said a decision on reinforcements was possible in the next several days. But the White House has to weigh a number of considerations.
General Luck has told Congress that he would need 400,000 troops to supplement the 37,000 in South Korea if there were a second Korean war, and that it would take up to 60 days to deploy them. So if the Administration wants to deter the North Koreans from attacking, it has to begin taking steps now.
But by taking steps to strengthen its forces, the Administration risks provoking the North Koreans or giving them an excuse to scuttle their diplomatic efforts.
 
Seeking Help on Sanctions
 Mr. Perry's view is that since it is difficult to determine exactly what might prove provocative, Washington should emphasize not how North Korea might react, but on the steps needed to protect American forces, officials said.
Another concern for Washington is its effort to mobilize support for economic sanctions if the diplomatic efforts fall short.
The Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, complained today that Moscow had not been consulted adequately about the draft resolution seeking United Nations sanctions.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher spoke with Mr. Kozyrev this morning and plans to meet with him to assuage the Russian concerns, an Administration official said.
 
Reinforcements Backed
 Reflecting concern over North Korea's threats, the Senate approved today, 93 to 3, a measure urging the Administration to immediately strengthen United States forces in South Korea "to deter and if necessary repel an attack from North Korea."
But with the risks of war, and with the prospects for winning Security Council support for sanctions uncertain, the Administration is stressing the diplomatic approach.
Indications that North Korea is prepared for a diplomatic accommodation came when former President Carter reported on his talks in Pyongyang.
The North Korean leaders told Mr. Carter that monitors from the International Atomic Energy Agency could stay at the Yongbyon site as long as Washington made "good faith efforts" to end the dispute.
The North Koreans also repeated a long-standing offer to scrap some reactors that are useful in producing plutonium if the United States and other countries would provide billions of dollars to help the North to build light-water reactors that use more modern technology, presumably solely for energy use.
 
Conditions on Diplomacy
 Administation officials said that for diplomacy to be successful, North Korea would have to permit monitoring of the spent fuel they recently removed from the Yongbyon reactor, refrain from reprocessing new plutonium and agree not to refuel the reactor. They would not be expected to stop work on a second reactor or on expanding their plutonium reprocessing.
But top Administration officials acknowledged that the North Korean position needed to be clarified. "It depends on what the Koreans actually meant by what they said today," Mr. Clinton said. "There is a great deal at stake."
Mr. Clinton's news conference seemed to be intended not only to send a message to the North Koreans, but to rebut criticism that the President is detached and vacillating on foreign policy.
But when asked directly about the military situation on the Korean peninsula, Mr. Clinton sidestepped the issue of whether additional forces were needed. "We will take appropriate steps, as we should, as we must. So there's nothing to be concerned about."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. IN THE HOUSE IS TRYING TO BLOCK HEALTH CARE BILL

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
At the urging of Representative Newt Gingrich, their deputy leader, House Republicans are trying to keep health care legislation from reaching the floor in a form that could pass.
Despite criticism from Democrats and even from one Republican who accused him of putting partisan politics first, Mr. Gingrish said today that Republicans should vote against amendments that might broaden the support for a bill that the House Ways and Means Committee is considering. 
 A few hours later, Republican committee members followed that prescription; all 14 opposed an amendment to soften the bill's impact on small businesses by providing tax credits to offset their new insurance costs.
But Mr. Gingrich's hardball strategy backfired when previously divided Democrats closed ranks and voted unanimously for a series of amendments, even though some made clear that they did not like them and might alter some later. Several said Mr. Gingrich's move had unified them.
Mr. Gingrich's comments confirmed in part accusations of obstructionism that Democrats had leveled at Republican leaders, saying they were muzzling moderates in their party and blocking compromise on any health care bill. But the Democrats had never provided specifics.
"It's becoming clearer and clearer that they are interested in frustrating action," Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said today. Although Republicans have often said they desired bipartisan cooperation, he said, "their real intention is to, unfortunately, not do anything." He said Republicans were acting like "robots."
In an interview today, Mr. Gingrich, of Georgia, responded, "I think it is very sad to see Gephardt reduced to a Clinton level of dishonesty." He said that Republicans had repeatedly offered to work with Democrats on health care legislation but that "what they mean by bipartisan is us caving in." He said members of his party were resisting "selling out your principles to pass one bill."
Mr. Gingrich said he had told Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee that "they should do what they think is effective in minimizing the prospect that the Gibbons bill will pass." The committee's bill was proposed by its acting chairman, Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida.
The Gibbons bill would seek to provide health insurance for all Americans by requiring employers to pay most of the cost of premiums for their workers and by creating a new form of Medicare, the existing health program for the elderly, to include the unemployed and others not reached through employment.
"There is no point in improving it so it will pass," Mr. Gingrich said. "It's a bad bill, and it's wrong." He said the bill would cause "bigger government, bigger bureaucracy and higher taxes for worse health care."
Mr. Gingrich, who is all but certain to become minority leader after the November elections, confirmed a complaint made on Wednesday by Representative Fred Grandy, Republican of Iowa. In a meeting of the committee, Mr. Grandy said Mr. Gingrich had urged that an amendment suggested by Mr. Grandy not be offered because the taxes it involved might be used as an issue against Republican candidates.
Mr. Grandy agreed not to propose the amendment in the committee meeting, but he said today, "To see health care pre-empted by politics, even in the short run, is unsettling."
Senators have not made similar complaints in public. But if they are guaranteed anonymity, some senators of both parties say Presidential politics and a desire to deny Mr. Clinton success have driven Republicans to oppose compromising on health care.
Others insist that they merely feel very strongly that Mr. Clinton's proposal for national health insurance and the spinoffs offered by Mr. Gibbons and Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York would be bad for the country. They usually focus on the damage to small business they foresee if employers are required to buy insurance for their workers, an element these bills have in common.
 
Unity Above All
 But at least one important player, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, cited Republican unity as a reason for going against his own preference. Mr. Packwood, the senior Republican on Mr. Moynihan's Finance Committee, said today that while he personally favored an employer mandate, for example, he would not vote for one.
"If you're going to go against your party, you do it either out of conscience or constituency," he said. "You do not do it over a matter of convenience." He said that he thought requiring contributions from employers would enable the nation to insure all Americans but that it could be done, though more slowly, without that requirement. Republican unity is worth a little delay, he said.
A group of Democrats held a news conference today to try to rally support for Mr. Clinton's call for universal insurance coverage and required employer payments to achieve it. Mr. Kennedy, chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, said he was confident the full Senate would support employer payments once it had debated the issue, because "you don't get to universal coverage without an employer contribution."
The Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, told reporters this morning, "We will be on the Senate floor with a health care bill in July." He said he was not dismayed by the disagreements that had stalled action in the Finance Committee. "I've been through dozens and dozens of bills where you start with disagreement and end up with agreement," he said.
The embattled Finance Committee held two closed meetings today, discussing what benefits should be included under any national health insurance plan. It also discussed what sort of national board should deal with changes in the package. The committee will meet, again in a closed meeting, next Tuesday.
 
Grandy Would Tax Benefits
 The Grandy amendment that started the House dispute is actually one that Democratic leaders like Mr. Gephardt oppose bitterly, though some members of both parties like the idea. It would tax health care benefits above those in a minimum insurance plan, both to discourage wasteful use of health care resources and to raise money to subsidize insurance for the poor. Labor unions have made the defeat of any version of this idea a top priority.
Mr. Gingrich told Mr. Grandy that his amendment could hurt Republican candidates, because Democrats could label it a tax increase on the middle class. Mr. Grandy said he understood, though he was disappointed.
This afternoon the Ways and Means Committee's Democrats, who were bickering last night over a patchwork series of amendments that would reduce proposed tobacco taxes, give tax credits to small businesses and delay the availability of long-term-care benefits, stood together and voted without dissent for each of them.
In a caucus this morning, Democrats encouraged one another to stand against the Republican enemy.
Mr. Gingrich's title is Republican whip, which means it is the Republicans whom he is supposed to keep united. But Representative Jim McDermott, a Washington Democrat who swallowed his unhappiness with details of the amendments and voted for them, said Democratic antagonism toward the Republican leader meant that "Mr. Gingrich was our whip today."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Following the leadership of Newt Gingrich, the Republicans are trying to keep legislation on health care from going before the full House if it has a chance of passing. Mr. Gingrich worked in his office yesterday. (Kirsten Bremmer for The New York Times) (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: Moscow Is Miffed by U.S. Draft on Sanctions

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 16

 BODY:
Complaining that Washington has again neglected to consult adequately with Moscow on a vital issue of international security, Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev refused today to support a Security Council resolution drafted by the United States that would impose sanctions on North Korea.
It was the second time this week that Mr. Kozyrev had lashed out at the United States. On Tuesday, he warned Congress that its vote to end the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government could ignite "a new world war." 
 The statements underscore increasing strains as Russia tries to reconcile its new relationship to the United States with surging anti-Western politics at home.
 
Russia's View of Russia
 Russia wants to continue to play a major role in world politics. It wants to be a full partner in NATO, to mediate the war in Bosnia and to dispatch troops to the increasingly troubled former Soviet republics. It feels it should share responsibility with the United States for policing the spread of nuclear weapons.
Yet when Russian leaders appear to follow Washington's lead in international diplomacy, angry domestic opponents rise up to denounce them.
This has increasingly put Mr. Kozyrev and his colleagues in the hot seat. Today he declined to say flatly that his Government would veto the resolution. But, addressing himself more to a perceived lack of communication than to the decision itself, he warned that a veto was possible.
"I think presenting the draft unilaterally will seriously complicate Russian consideration of the document," Mr. Kozyrev told reporters. "In any case, we will not support a set of sanctions worked out without our cooperation."
 
Missed Signals Over Bombing
 Moscow also protested loudly last March when NATO planes bombed Bosnian Serb positions without specifically notifying Russia ahead of time. Bewildered officials in Washington responded that Moscow had given its general consent to such a military response, and therefore should not have been surprised.
After that misunderstanding, American diplomats devoted considerable energy to calming Moscow's nerves, but they also noted that given nationalist sentiment in Russia and its ethnic ties to the Bosnian Serbs, it suited Moscow to seem indignant.
Similarly, it was not clear how much Mr. Kosyrev's statement today was driven by internal politics and how much by genuine anger.
Whatever its causes, the increased tension is not likely to help discussions over Russia's role in a new loose alliance that offers a kind of junior partnership in NATO to members of the former Warsaw Pact.
 
Talks About Talks With NATO
 Last week, after many delays and complaints about Russia's status with NATO, President Boris N. Yeltsin said he would sign the agreement, and on Wednesday NATO urged Russia to begin immediate talks in Brussels to improve relations. Russian officials said they would probably accept the invitation, and Mr. Kozyrev said today that he would go to Brussels next week.
Moscow does not have a close relationship with North Korea, but it is nevertheless reluctant to surrender whatever influence it still has there. In Soviet times, Moscow helped develop North Korea's nuclear industry, and Russia still nurtures commercial and diplomatic ties.
Thus Moscow has been reluctant to go along with the United States, South Korea and Japan in seeking United Nations sanctions to press North Korea to allow full United Nations inspection of its nuclear installations.
Mr. Kozyrev said that in a telephone conversation with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, he had been assured that Washington would not move unilaterally on sanctions, but would consider Moscow's proposal to hold an international conference on North Korea's nuclear build-up. Moscow had said that if North Korea were found to be in violation of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, it would consider sanctions as a last resort.
For now, Moscow proposed an international conference that would seek to ban nuclear weapons from both North and South Korea. While the Russian Government has always shown a predeliction for such conferences -- it proposed a similar one to resolve the Mideast conflict -- Washington views them with disfavor.
Mr. Kozyrev is to appear before the lower house of Parliament on Friday to explain the Government's position on North Korea.
However unwelcome in Washington, his harsh warning against sanctions can only please many members of Parliament, who have increasingly accused Mr. Yeltsin's Government of being too compliant to the United States.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
 The head of AT&T's multimedia efforts will join the Creative Artists Agency, Hollywood's most powerful talent agency. The hiring is an example of how the entertainment, information and communications businesses have converged. [Page D1.] 
 The Nebraska Furniture Mart continues to grow, while staying in the same place. The retailer, sprawled across 64 acres in Omaha, is on track to generate $240 million in sales this year. [D1.]
Bertelsmann's U.S. publishing arm has agreed to acquire a group of magazines from The New York Times Company that are directed primarily at the women's market. [D1.]
Hasbro's stock fell sharply after the toy maker said it expected revenues for the second quarter to fall as much as 15 percent. [D3.]
I.B.M. has formed a new division to develop applications and services for both consumer and business computer networks. [D3.]
Lotus Development will acquire a maker of switches that link many forms of electronic messaging. [D3.]
Top executives of Baxter International bought $122 million of the company's stock in a move aimed at appeasing critics. [D3.]
E. W. Scripps and Capital Cities/ABC announced a 10-year affiliation that covers television stations in five of the largest markets in the United States. [D3.]
Brown & Williamson Tobacco made a good-faith effort to develop a safer cigarette in the 1960's. But researchers were blocked at almost every turn, company documents show. [A1.]
General Mills stopped shipping Cheerios and other oat products after learning that oats stored in some of its grain elevators had been treated with the wrong pesticide. [A20.]
 
The Economy
 Consumers are cutting back their spending because of higher interest rates, declining savings and the evaporation of pent-up demand after families splurged on cars and other goods during the last year. The cutback in spending is now slowing the rate of the economy's expansion. [D1.]
Despite higher mortgage rates, building starts on homes rose 2.6 percent. The gain, however, came entirely from apartment construction. In a separate report, the number of claims for state unemployment benefits fell for the week. [D2.]
 
International
 Leaders of Latin America's 19 largest nations met and saidthey would try to merge the region's various free trade pacts into one free trade zone. [D2.]
A dispute within OPEC erupted over the selection of a new leader. Venezuela complained that Iran had been the only member to vote against its candidate. [D2.]
 
Markets
 Blue-chip stocks climbed in restrained trading. The Dow industrials posted a 20.93-point gain, to 3,811.34. [D4.]
Treasury prices rose modestly after an afternoon drop in commodity prices calmed investors' inflation worries. [D12.]
Oil and grain prices eased after surging on Wednesday. Precious metals slumped, helping to push the Commodity Research Bureau's index down 1.33 points. [D11.] The dollar gained against the yen but fell against the mark and the Swiss franc. [D11.]
 
Today's Columns
 Procter & Gamble and Syntex will spend more than $100 million to market a new pain reliever, Aleve. It is the first new brand in the analgesic market since ibuprofen brands were first offered a decade ago. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D1.]
A biotechnology discovery by Genentech and Zymogenetics has left Wall Street underwhelmed. Analysts estimate a $1 billion market for the discovered hormone, which stimulates the production of the cells that make blood clot. But investors see a marketable drug as too far off in the future. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Yellowstone Will Shelter Wolves Again

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DENVER, June 16

 BODY:
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt has given final approval to a plan to reintroduce about 30 gray wolves into Yellowstone National Park and central Idaho, a decision that is being hailed by some environmentalist groups as a victory for wildlife but is being denounced by ranchers who fear for their livestock.
Other groups, like the Sierra Club, have expressed disappointment with the policy, which does not give the wolves protection as an endangered species even though wolves elsewhere have that protection. 
 Like the debate over grazing fees and hard-rock mining on public lands, the wolf issue pits the New West against the Old West, urban values versus rural: on one side are people who see the wilderness as a place mostly for recreation, and on the other side are people who see it as an economic resource.
The plan, which was given final approval on Wednesday, aims to restore the wildlife balance in the northern Rocky Mountains, where wolves thrived until the 1920's, when they were killed off by ranchers. Wildlife biologists say a shortage of predators has resulted in a population explosion for elk and deer, which are damaging the grasses.
 
Canadian Imports
 Under the plan, the wolves will be removed from Canada and reintroduced into Wyoming and Idaho as soon as December. There have been sightings of wolves in Yellowstone recently, as well as in northern Montana. Perhaps the largest number of wolves live in northern Minnesota.
While 30 wolves will be reintroduced initially, the aim is to have at least 100 wolves at each location by the year 2002, The Associated Press reported. About 60 wolves have already been found in northwestern Montana; they have migrated from Canada. Under the Government's plan, that wolf population will also be increased.
Roger Schlickeisen, the president of Defenders of Wildlife, a Washington group, hailed the move as "a turning point in the annals of wildlife conservation."
But Betsy Buffington, a spokeswoman for the Sierra Club, said that while the move was "a step in the right direction," the Clinton Administration had gone too far in its efforts to appease Western farmers and ranchers.
"The Administration was a little too eager to compromise," she said. "This action reduces the protection for wolves."
Michael Robinson, a spokesman for Sinapu, a group in Boulder, Colo., that pushes for the reintroduction of wolves, also criticized the plan for giving ranchers too much leeway in managing the predators.
 
Killing Will Be Allowed
 Under the plan, a wolf can be killed if it is found attacking livestock on private land. The plan also allows ranchers to harass, but not injure, wolves found in their grazing areas, officials said.
Ranchers fear that the wolves will multiply and attack lambs, calves and even pets. "We spend a lot of time and money to protect our lambs from predators: mountain lions, coyotes," said Julie Hansmire, who, with her husband, Randy Campbell, raises 4,000 head of Rambouillet sheep in western Colorado. "And now there's one more."
She said urban people had a "warm and fuzzy feeling" about wolves but had never walked into a pasture to see a lamb with its nose chewed off or its throat cut.
Wildlife advocates, on the other hand, say the losses will cause only slight losses of livestock. Wolves have suffered because of misconceptions about their viciousness, they say.
"A wolf will occasionally chew on a lamb or calf," said Mr. Schlickeisen. "But the numbers are very small."
He also said misconceptions came from legends about wicked wolves, as in "Aesop's Fables" and "Little Red Riding Hood." He said, "There is not a single recorded case of a healthy wolf attacking a healthy human in all of North America."
But Mr. Schlickeisen defended the decision not to include the endangered-species designation in the Government's plan as a way to make it more palatable to ranchers. "I suppose this could have been just rammed down their throats," he said. "But all that would have done is created a lot of anger."
He added: "Our perspective is this: The objective was to get a viable population of wolves into the Yellowstone ecosystem as quickly as possible. And that's going to be done."
The group has raised about $100,000 to compensate ranchers for losses to predators like wolves.
The wolves will wear collars so they can be monitored. They will initially be enclosed in pens, so they can become accustomed to their new surroundings.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Administration plans to give gray wolves a second chance at life in Yellowstone National Park and central Idaho, but the animals will not get special protection under the endangered-species law. (Buddy Mays/Black Star)

HEADLINE: A Health Care Finance Plan: Ingenious, or Impenetrable?

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
To finance universal health insurance without additional income or payroll taxes, the new head of the House Ways and Means Committee has devised a method of raising money so complex and intricate that few members of Congress have been able to explain it.
Supporters of the proposal describe it as an ingenious way to raise money from companies that, they say, are evading their social responsibility to contribute to the cost of health care. Critics say the proposal is just a hidden tax, and a big one. 
 Under the proposal, offered by the acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, all employers would have to contribute to the cost of insurance for their workers. In a two-career family, these contributions would amount to somewhat more than needed for the family's coverage. The Government would then "skim" the excess to help finance health care for people who are poor, unemployed or uninsured.
Congressional analysts said this would raise $118 billion for the Government from 1998 to 2002.
 
Balancing Act
 The proposal is meant to balance the concerns of big companies and small businesses. Nonetheless, both are denouncing it.
Under current law, private employers are not required to provide health insurance to their workers, though most do. President Clinton, and most Democrats in Congress, wants to require all employers to help buy insurance for their workers, a concept called the employer mandate.
Under Mr. Gibbons's proposal, all employers would have to offer coverage. When a husband and a wife worked for different companies, the family would enroll in the plan offered by one employer, who would be designated as the enrolling employer. That company would pay 80 percent of the "family premium," estimated at $4,785 a year.
The other company would pay 80 percent of the individual premium of $2,140, though it would provide no direct health benefits to the family. This payment would be collected by the Government and distributed to the enrolling employer to help offset the cost of covering an employee's spouse who worked elsewhere.
 
Declining Need
 But the Federal Government would retain some of the money, or skim it, in the phrase widely used on Capitol Hill. In 1998 and 1999, the Government would keep 75 percent of all the money collected; it would distribute 25 percent to the enrolling employers. The Government would retain 60 percent of the money in the year 2000 and 40 percent in 2001.
After that, the Government would, in theory, distribute all the money to employers. By 2002, supporters of the proposal say, the Government would no longer need this money to subsidize coverage for the poor and uninsured because health costs would have been controlled.
But Frank B. McArdle, manager of the Washington research office of Hewitt Associates, a consulting firm that specializes in benefits, said, "Many people doubt that this provision would ever cease, especially if it turns out that health care reform is underfinanced."
 
Getting a Free Ride
 Big companies usually provide more generous fringe benefits than do small companies. If one spouse works for a big company and the other for a small company, the family often gets its health insurance from the big company. The small company may get a free ride, paying little or nothing. Even when a small business provides coverage to its workers, it often pays nothing toward coverage of children and spouses.
Big companies and President Clinton say small businesses should pay their "fair share." But Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, a Maryland Democrat who is on the Ways and Means Committee, said he saw no need to make employers buy health insurance for workers who already had coverage through spouses.
"I wanted to continue the free ride as a break for small business," Mr. Cardin said. "But I ran up against a brick wall from legislators who are very interested in trying to help large industrial companies."
So Mr. Cardin came up with a compromise, now incorporated in Mr. Gibbons's proposal. Under that plan, Mr. Cardin said, if a husband chose to get coverage through his wife's health plan, the husband's employer would have to pay something, but it would be substantially less than the cost of full family coverage.
And rather than give "a windfall" to companies that now provide such family coverage, Mr. Cardin said, the Government should keep some of the money and put it into a trust fund for a new Part C of Medicare, available to poor people and the uninsured.
 
'Worse Than Clinton's Plan'
 James A. Klein, the executive director of the Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans, a trade group composed mainly of Fortune 500 companies, is skeptical. "This is nothing more than a grab by the Federal Treasury of money that's intended to help equalize the cost of providing health insurance coverage," he said. It's highly unlikely that the Government would ever relinquish such an enormous stream of revenue."
Small-business lobbies are equally dissatisfied. "The Gibbons plan is worse than Clinton's plan," said Kim F. McKernan, a lobbyist for the National Federation of Independent Business. "It provides less assistance for small firms than the President did. The employer-mandate scheme in the Gibbons bill operates just like a payroll tax. Its devastating, a real job killer."
Dallas L. Salisbury, the president of the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a private nonpartisan group, said: "The Ways and Means Committee plan has far less semblance of equity than the Clinton proposal. It would be extraordinarily complex to administer, compared with simply having employers pay a tax."

HEADLINE: A.M.A. Tries New Math to Fight Image of Dollar-Gouging Doctors

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 16

 BODY:
Tired of watching its members portrayed as patient-gouging money machines, the American Medical Association is changing the way it calculates doctors' median incomes.
The association, which last year stopped issuing annual press releases about doctors' median incomes, decided this week that in the future it would lump the salaries of private practitioners with those of Federal Government doctors and young doctors in training, who make considerably less. 
 Dr. Nancy W. Dickey, the association's secretary-treasurer, said that historically when the group released its annual calculations of doctors' incomes, "the press leaves out the footnotes" explaining which doctors are included and excluded.
"Therefore our only choice is to make a change so the numbers show the whole picture," Dr. Dickey said. "Now the physician looks less like he's gouging America."
 
$253,300 for Radiologists
 The latest calculations, based on 1992 data, show that the mean income of American doctors in private practice is $177,400 a year, ranging from $111,800 for general practitioners to $253,300 for radiologists.
In contrast, doctors in training earn only $22,000 to $30,000 a year. The medical group has not previously collected information on the incomes of Government doctors, but they are known to earn much less than doctors in private practice.
The association adopted the accounting change at its annual meeting, which ended on Thursday. The first reports reflecting the change are expected in two or three years.
Dr. Dickey argued that the current figures reflected only doctors' prime earning years. Only after spending 3 to 10 years as residents in training, working 80 to 100 hours a week, can their incomes soar, she said, and often only in return for 60-hour weeks.
But Dr. Sidney Wolfe, director of Public Citizen's Health Research Group in Washington, called the accounting change "unabashed deception."
"It sounds like the kind of snake oil that the A.M.A. is very fond of criticizing others for," Dr. Wolfe said. "The A.M.A. is, at the bottom of it, a trade association representing the economic interests of doctors. The more moves the A.M.A. makes like this, the more they earn the scorn of people in this country."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
I.B.M. Forms Networking Division

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
I.B.M. said yesterday that it had formed a new division to develop applications and services for both business and consumer computer networks.
The new division, which will be called Networked Application Services, brings together many of I.B.M.'s existing development projects in such varied realms as multimedia, electronic trading, Internet services, video teleconferencing, software for use by networked groups, interactive information kiosks and electronic publishing. 
 It also signals the International Business Machines Corporation's intent to take a more aggressive role in providing not just the technical infrastructure of the so-called information superhighway, but also in developing core products and software services that the network will carry.
 
Gerstner Goals Seen
 "This is probably one of the most important things I.B.M. is going to do this year," said Mark Stahlman, president of New Media Research in New York. "It gives a hint of what Gerstner's new I.B.M. might look like," he added, referring to the company's chairman, Louis Gerstner.
John B. Jones Jr., vice president of equity research for Saloman Brothers Inc. in San Francisco, agreed. "It's clearly a high-profile business opportunity with great growth possibilities," he said.
Fernand B. Sarrat was named general manager of the new division, which will have headquarters in Thornwood, N.Y. In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Sarrat said the division would intitially have at least five self-contained operating units and several hundred employees culled from other I.B.M. operations. He said more units would be announced as soon as general managers were selected.
 
Budget 'Not Insignificant'
 Mr. Sarrat declined to disclose the new division's operating budget, saying only that it was "not insignificant."
Asked for examples of the types of products that the Networked Application Services division would offer, Mr. Sarrat rattled off a broad and varied list.
"In the public access kiosk business, we're developing a system for state governments where you could go register yourself for unemployment, or use the kiosk for motor vehicle registration instead of standing in a queue," Mr. Sarrat said. "We're working with Blockbuster to download audio and video into stores."
Mr. Sarrat, a veteran I.B.M. manager who has been working on the network services task force for a year and a half, said other services included collaborative software that would allow, for example, doctors in remote areas to consult with voice, data and illustrations as they looked at a shared image of an X-ray.
I.B.M. announced the new division late yesterday. Its stock closed at $62.875, down 75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Consumers Put a Brake on Economic Expansion

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
America's consumers are starting to cut back their spending, slowing the rate of the economy's expansion.
The drop in consumer spending, economists say, is the result of higher interest rates, declining savings and the evaporation of pent-up demand as families have splurged on cars and other goods over the last year. 
 The Federal Reserve has contributed to the drop with its four increases this year in short-term interest rates, which have pushed up mortgage and other borrowing rates. This has put an end to windfalls for homeowners who had been taking advantage of low interest rates late last year and early this year to refinance their mortgages. The slowdown in spending increases comes after a year in which the growth in consumer spending outstripped the growth in income.
 
 
Big-Ticket Items
 Weakening consumer spending on big-ticket purchases like cars and household appliances is already beginning to hurt some sectors of the economy, although no one is predicting a recession.
At the 45-employee Hiwasse Manufacturing Company in Jacksonville, Ark., for example, overtime has suddenly disappeared. Just two months ago, Hiwasse put everyone on overtime and and hired five new workers, but still accumulated an eight-week backlog of orders for brand name plates that manufacturers like Maytag put on washing machines and dryers. Now, that backlog has shrunk to four weeks, and management is beginning to worry.
"We're talking current events here -- things have kind of taken a nose dive in the last two weeks," said J. Richard Derickson, the president and chief executive of Hiwasse.
Weak sales can be traced to people like Edward J. Manus, a 44-year-old former factory production supervisor in Stratford, Conn. Although Mr. Manus recently found work as a teacher after two factories closed and put him out of work, he is still trying to rebuild his savings and decided last month not to buy a new $189 outdoor barbecue grill.
"I took the one I had apart and fixed it," he said.
Recent Government data showing falling retail sales in April and May, a drop in overall personal consumption spending in April, a slight rise in business inventories in April and a yearlong fall in household savings rates are also reflecting the erosion in consumer spending.
As a result, some economists are trimming slightly their estimates of economic growth for the rest of the year. A survey of corporate economists earlier this month, before the Government released statistics providing some of the strongest evidence of slackening consumer spending, found that the consensus estimate for economic growth in the fourth quarter of this year had dropped by a tenth of a percentage point, to an annual pace of 2.8 percent.
The change was significant not because of its size but because of the direction of the revision, said Robert J. Eggert, who conducted the survey for Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter in Sedona, Ariz. The fear that sparked inflationary concerns in both financial markets and at the Federal Reserve was that economic growth would continue at the much faster pace of the last half of last year, when the economy grew at a 5 percent rate.
 Economic growth of 3 percent is still not bad, said Alan Blinder, a member of the White House Council of Economic Advisers whom President Clinton recently nominated to become the next vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. "The economy is moving uphill at a steady but not torrid pace," he said.
The new evidence of slowing -- if it continues -- could finally begin to reassure Wall Street and the Federal Reserve that the economy will not overheat, feeding inflation. That new confidence could send the stock market higher and long-term interest rates lower.
The economic indicators also suggest that there will be little pressure for immediate further interest rate increases by the Fed. "The growth of activity is downshifting to a more sustainable pace after the more rapid pace that we had at the end of last year," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said in an interview. "I don't see any pressure on the Fed to increase those rates."
That sustainable pace is supported by other sectors of the economy -- like business spending on new factory equipment -- that are still doing well, suggesting that any drop in growth will not be dramatic. The housing industry is also holding up well despite higher interest rates, with the Commerce Department announcing today that housing starts rose 2.6 percent in May.
 
 
Impact on Jobs
 But slower growth may also be bad news for Main Street, meaning fewer jobs available in the coming months for the nation's eight million unemployed. Slower spending could mean that goods pile up in manufacturers' warehouses and car dealerships begin looking less bare -- and that could prompt factories and other businesses to slow a little.
Consumers are important because their spending has been the backbone of the current economic recovery. Increased consumption has accounted for 77 percent of the nation's economic growth since the start of last year, compared with 68 percent of growth during the economic expansion from 1982 to 1990.
One reason why consumers may now be feeling less prosperous is that higher interest rates have virtually halted the wave of mortgage refinancings that had put extra money in their pockets. By borrowing money at low interest rates and using it to pay off higher-rate mortgages, millions of American households have managed over the last several years to reduce their monthly payments.
While some families have invested the savings, others, like Jim Rice, a veterinarian in Cynthiana, Ky., have gone out and bought new cars. But now these gains from refinancings are disappearing, as higher interest rates make these deals less attractive and also raise the monthly payments of people with adjustable rates mortgages.
Refinancings reached $650 billion last year but are likely to total just $100 billion to $125 billion this year, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, a Washington trade group.
 
 
Saving Less
 At the same time, consumer spending has been rising faster than consumers' incomes. This means consumers are saving less. Average personal savings fell to 3.6 percent of after-tax income this spring, from a high of 4.9 percent in April of last year.
Without the windfall reductions in monthly debt payments from refinancings, which made consumers fell richer, people are likely to resume saving more money, said Lyle Gramley, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, one of the five sitting Federal Reserve governors, said in an interview on Tuesday that it was unrealistic to expect the savings rate to continue to fall, and that falling retail sales in April and May showed that consumer spending was beginning to lose speed.
"There's a little more evidence that probably we're out of money," he said, while cautioning that, "You can't judge these things definitively even after two months."
Mr. Blinder of the Clinton Administration said that no one should be surprised that consumer spending was slowing.
"That's not necessarily a bad thing in the sense that in the last three quarters consumer spending has been growing at 4.5 percent," he said. "It can't continue that fast in a 3 percent economy; it should be growing at 3 percent."
 
 
Contrary Indicators
 As usual, a few contrary economic indicators muddy the picture. Strong growth in jobs this spring suggests that many families are earning more money and will have more to spend. Two commercial surveys of retail stores this month suggest that sales may be bouncing back from the drops in April and May -- which came, in any case, on the heels of very strong sales in March.
Most of the weakness in retail sales comes from a slackening in new car sales, one of the main engines of the current economic expansion. But the auto industry is hard to judge right now because dealerships have run short of popular models. Another important contributor to the current expansion, residential construction, has not yet slowed down.
Economists who believe that the growth in consumer spending is slowing, like Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers, have ready explanations for all these contrary indicators. Some rebound in retail sales was inevitable, Mr. Sinai said. Housing starts tend to turn down later than the rest of the economy because they result from business decisions made one to three months earlier. And the drop in car sales showed the evaporation of pent-up demand rather than short supplies, Mr. Sinai said, as many families had bought new vehicles in the last few months after postponing such a step in the early 1990's when the economy looked weaker.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Gain as Prices Of Commodities Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday after a drop in commodity prices. The session was a reverse play of the previous day, when bond prices fell in the afternoon, erasing morning gains as investors grew concerned about inflation on a surge in commodities.
Yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond rose 15/32 , to 8628/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 7.35 percent, from 7.39 percent on Wednesday. Before posting gains in the afternoon, the long bond had fallen as much as a half-point, to yield 7.45 percent. 
 The bond market has been greatly influenced by the commodities market this week, so when the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodity futures, a closely watched indicator of inflation, rose to a three-and-a-half-year high of 239.35 on Wednesday, the market fell. When the index fell yesterday, to 237.28, the bond market rallied.
Peter McTeague, a market analyst with MCM MoneyWatch, said it was a better trading session than some traders thought. "Today dealers were getting far too negative and short on bearish news," he said. "For the most part dealers were selling, and not the customers, while the buy and hold, or large institutional investors, remained steadfast and have not been shaken out of the market."
"Looking at price action today, a yield decline in face of negative news is a bullish statement," he continued. "It means that the market has a chance to move higher in price going into next week's Treasury auction of $28 billion in new two-year and five-year notes."
 
When-Issued Trading
 In when-issued trading yesterday, the new two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.84 percent, down from 5.94 percent on Wednesday, and the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.63 percent, down from 6.69 percent the previous day.
"The yield on the long bond is still in the middle of its trading range of past few months and nothing has changed," Mr. McTeague said. "It is a market just jogging in place, waiting for that break. So bears will get short at the low end of the range, and the bulls will get long at the range high."
He said the market would continue to move within that range until there was a sharp move in commodities prices or in the dollar.
Market participants said trading was thin yesterday. The release yesterday of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's survey of regional business activity for June failed to sway the market. The Philadelphia Fed's index based on the survey rose slightly in June, but many of the price components were weaker than expected.
The Philadelphia Fed index climbed to 16.1 for June from 14.8, in line with expectations and reflecting steady forward momentum in the manufacturing sector.
Bond prices slipped in the morning after the release of the housing starts report for May and the weekly initial jobless claims data. Analysts said that while the data were not particularly alarming, a skittish market overcompensated.
 
Starts of Housing Up
 Weekly initial claims fell to 348,000 from 359,000, while May housing starts were up 2.6 percent, to an annual rate of 1.51 million units. Although the growth was entirely in apartment construction, the gain suggested to some analysts that rising interest rates had not slowed housing demand.
Comments by Edward W. Kelley Jr., a Federal Reserve governor, on a morning Birmingham, Ala., radio program helped bonds slip further, Mr. McTeague said.
The Fed governor said that he was heartened by the decline in inflation over the last several years, but that there was still work to be done as the Fed aimed for zero inflation.
The market was also weighed down by rumors early in the day, and later denied by the Pentagon, that a United States helicopter had been downed near the North Korean border.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Strengthens vs. Yen But Declines Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed yesterday, advancing against the Japanese yen on concern about a conflict between the United States and North Korea, but falling to its lowest level of the year against the German mark and the Swiss franc.
Much of the day's activity centered on trading among European currencies. A selloff in some of the Continent's smaller bond markets sent the mark higher as investors fled other currencies. 
 The Canadian dollar steadied at nearly 72 United States cents, after approaching an eight-year low, on intervention by the Bank of Canada.
A rumor that a United States helicopter had been shot down over South Korea helped bolster the dollar against the yen, as nervous investors fled the Japanese currency. The State Department denied the rumor.
"It was a flimsy rumor, but it came against the backdrop of nervousness over Korea," said Amy Smith, a currency strategist for IDEA, a market analysis firm.
The dollar also gained from comments by the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, indicating progress in trade talks between Washington and Tokyo, lowering the prospects of United States pressure for a higher yen to cut Japan's trade surplus.
In New York, the dollar ended at 103.45 yen, up from 102.75 late Wednesday. In late trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.6334 German marks, down from 1.6364 marks late Wednesday.
Government data released yesterday indicating economic strength were in line with the market's expectations and had little impact on currency trading, said Jack Griffin, a vice president of the Fuji Bank office in New York.
The Commerce Department said housing starts rose by 2.6 percent in May, while the Labor Department reported that weekly first-time jobless claims fell to the lowest level in nearly two months.
The currency market also shrugged off modest gains in American stock and bond prices. In recent months, the dollar has followed volatile United States financial markets as investors moved funds in and out of dollar-denominated investments.
In other trading, the British pound was quoted at $1.5205, down from $1.5215 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.3700 Swiss francs, down from 1.3705, and 1,604 Italian lire, up from 1,597.

HEADLINE: Starts of Housing in May Showed Slight Increase

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
Building starts on homes rose modestly in May despite higher mortgage rates, the Commerce Department said today, but the growth came entirely from apartment construction.
The annual rate of housing starts rose 2.6 percent, to an annual rate of 1.51 million units, following a revised drop of 3.1 percent in April. The seasonally adjusted figures surprised economists, who had expected a decline in May. Housing is one of the first economic sectors to feel the impact of changes in interest rates. 
 "The fact that consumer confidence is rising and that jobs are a little easier to get is softening the blow" on the housing market, Stan Duobinis, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders, said.
 
 
Jobless Claims Fall
 Also today, the Labor Department reported an improvement in the jobs outlook. The number of claims for jobless benefits fell to 348,000 in the week ended June 11. It was the lowest level since April 23, when 336,000 claims were filed.
The agency revised its previous week's totals to 359,000 claims from the 358,000 reported earlier.
The latest total was less than what had been expected by many economists, who had forecast claims to edge down to 355,000.
"It caught people a little bit by surprise," Anthony Chan, a senior economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said. "This breathes fresh air into signs of improvement in labor market."
The department's closely watched four-week moving average, considered a more reliable barometer than the more volatile weekly number, declined to 357,750 last week from 362,500 a week earlier.
Despite economic improvement, there were signs of a slowdown in housing. Mr. Duobinis said that surveys of builders indicated the number of visitors to model-home sites was falling. Most are planning, he said, for "a gentle drift downward" in construction activity to about 1.38 million new homes for all of 1994.
 
 
Single-Family Starts Off
 All the strength in housing construction last month was in new apartment building. There were fewer single-family homes started than in April, which analysts said suggests the market had peaked.
"It's a little troubling," said David Lereah, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, because May is typically the beginning of the spring buying season for families considering a new home or a move.
Construction of single-family homes fell five-tenths of 1 percent in May, to an annual rate of 1.20 million units, after falling by 5 percent in April. Starts on apartments were up 16.7 percent in May, to a rate of 308,000.
Mortgage rates have risen sharply since touching bottom in October at a 25-year low of 6.74 percent. The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today that the rate on 30-year mortgages rose this week to 8.33 percent from 8.25 percent a week earlier.
Most of the building increase in May occurred in the South, where starts rose 11.2 percent, to an annual rate of 694,000. The only other region where they rose was in the West, up 4.1 percent, to a rate of 355,000. Home construction fell 8.2 percent, to a rate of 134,000, in the Northeast, and dropped 9.4 percent, to 327,000 a year, in the Midwest.

HEADLINE: Poor Mother, Poor Child

 BODY:
Every year nearly 400,000 Americans are born to girls with no high school diplomas, no husbands and few prospects. Eighty percent of those babies will know poverty and, more likely than not, be cruelly affected by its pathologies. Many of them will replicate their mothers' lives -- and become single parents themselves. Soon they will be responsible for one out of every three children born in this country.
But not financially responsible. Last year benefits for families begun by poor teen-agers cost the United States $34 billion. The price those young mothers and their children have paid for being born into poverty is beyond counting. 
 This week President Clinton introduced his plan to "end welfare as we know it" and get such youngsters off the dole and into jobs. But how can they be persuaded not to become pregnant in the first place? The solution is as easy to state as it is hard to execute: Give them a good reason not to.
Most adolescents know how to avoid pregnancy. According to a report from the Alan Guttmacher Institute, the pregnancy rate among sexually experienced teen-agers actually fell 19 percent between 1972 and 1990. But because the proportion of teen-agers who have had intercourse grew during this time, the overall number of pregnancies stayed the same, about one million a year.
Two-thirds of teen-agers use some method of contraception the first time they have sex. But because there is a gap between sexual initiation and marriage (if, indeed, they do marry), they run a big risk of out-of-wedlock pregnancy. Making contraceptives easily available to adolescents, then, may help -- but it is not enough. Neither, clearly, is preaching abstinence. Neither, so far, is preaching responsibility -- especially to people whose own parents have taken little responsibility for them.
Going after absentee fathers for child support, as President Clinton proposes, is one way to impose responsibility. Providing grants to schools and community programs so they can institute teen pregnancy prevention programs, as he also proposes, is also promising. But what this nation's poorest teen-agers need most is a fervent, and well-grounded, belief that postponing pregnancy can mean an education, a job and, above all, a way out of poverty and into the American mainstream.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Don't Exaggerate North Korean Military Threat;
The Wider Context

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your sterling June 4 editorial calling for United Nations sanctions against North Korea shows how even the most reasonable people can be misled by righteous indignation. Unfortunately, such a sentiment is wholly misplaced when dealng with a situation as complicated -- and explosive -- as that on the Korean peninsula. 
 It is impossible to gain a realistic appreciation of the North Korean nuclear issue unless we see it in its political and strategic context. The two Korean regimes find themselves in a fluid environment, caught up in sweeping changes in internal politics and foreign relations. They are insecure and confused, not sure whether to move toward reunification or stay divided, whether to make peace or continue their conflict.
The 1991 accord committed the two sides to a path of reconciliation. But its premature signing instigated backlash, reviving old fears and creating new mistrust, which plunged the peninsula into another round of arms race. The South has stepped up its purchase of state-of-the-art weapons, using its abundant financial resources. The North, being without such economic resources, appears to have settled on nuclear weapons as the cheap but effective equalizer.
Although the political dynamics of the renewed conflict between the two Koreas is fraught with danger, there are positive developments:
No one -- least of all, Koreans -- is interested in fighting another war in Korea. Everyone agrees that the peninsula should remain denuclearized. The 1991 North-South Agreement for Reconciliation and the North-South Declaration for Denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula are both still in place. The United States and North Korea are continuing bilateral talks. South Korea is on record as committed to a "broad and thorough" review of its relations with the North. That is, it is ready to consider far-reaching changes in all areas of their relations, economic, political and strategic.
Together, these developments form a framework of peace in Korea, in which to find a workable solution of the current crisis.
Put another way, the solution to North Korea's nuclear issue can be best found through amelioration of two sets of relations: North-South relations and United States-North Korean relations. Unfortunately, the international community's preoccupation with North Korea's alleged nuclear program distracts from that task.
While it is highly doubtful that United Nations sanctions would have the desired effect on North Korea, they are virtually guaranteed to wreak havoc with reconciliation between the two Koreas. (Already, loose talk coming out of South Korea's Blue House has done enough damage.)
A more constructive approach, as well as a more interesting one, is that suggested by Russia, which involves the convening of an eight-power conference (five permanent members of the Security Council plus Japan and the two Koreas).
Such a conference, addressing Pyongyang's nuclear problem in a wider political context, holds the prospect of producing a comprehensive settlement that would facilitate North Korea's cooperation in nuclear nonproliferation.
 
KWAN HA YIM
Professor of Political Science
Manhattanville College
Valley Cottage, N.Y., June 8, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: What Illegal Aliens Cost the Taxpayer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Stop Benefits for Aliens? It Wouldn't Be That Easy" (front page, June 8) is bold in its attempt to profile the entire problem of illegal aliens receiving taxpayer benefits through the experience of one mother of three. 
 Your article states that taxpayers at all levels of government spend $7 billion a year on illegal aliens. (Others estimate twice that.) Two-thirds of the cost, you state, go to education and medical care. You also focus on such other costs as welfare, which you estimate totals roughly $2.3 billion a year.
Readers (that is, taxpayers) could be forgiven for finding your article's analysis as porous as our national borders.
In support of your claim that illegals do not enter the United States for benefits, you quote Laura C. as saying she came to the United States to work. But she now exists in a one-bedroom apartment on private charity and public benefits.
In positing that illegals are not eligible for many welfare programs, you note that Laura C. (meaning in this case her children) receives only food benefits totaling $46.50 a week.
What the article does not say is whether Laura C. receives any benefits illegally. The Immigration and Naturalization Service estimates that 40 percent of illegal aliens do.
You report that Laura C.'s youngest child, born in Texas at taxpayer cost in a public hospital, and thus a United States citizen, has the rights to welfare of any native-born American. But you do not venture any cost. Nor do you mention the public or private costs of criminal aliens, displaced legal residents on welfare and unemployment insurance.
The result? You have by this means transformed a multibillion-dollar-a-year problem into a $46.50-a-week problem.
In closing, your article attempts to demonstrate that even if government benefits are cut off, illegal aliens will remain in the United States, rather than return home.
Your evidence: Laura C.'s resounding declaration, "I don't think I would leave."
Inquiring minds must wonder why it is that your article consistently tags those who support the rights of legal residents first as "politicians," while at the same time you label as "experts" those who support the unlimited right of illegal aliens to cut in line ahead of those millions of people around the world who have waited years to enter the United States legally.
 
(Rep.) LAMAR SMITH
Washington, June 10, 1994
The writer leads the House Republican illegal immigration task force.

LENGTH: 825 words

HEADLINE: Arafat Appears Reluctant to Shift Base to Jericho

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERICHO, West Bank, June 16

 BODY:
With each passing day, it seems, a new reason is added for the delay in Yasir Arafat's arrival to formally take over the administration of Palestinian rule in the Gaza Strip and in Jericho.
This morning Khalid Musmar, identified as the press officer of the Palestinian embassy in Amman, said the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman may further delay his much anticipated arrival in Jericho because Israel is preventing Palestinians from completing an airfield that would allow his helicopter to land and take off. 
 A couple of weeks ago, the 65-year-old Mr. Arafat said he would delay his arrival if international financial aid pledged by the World Bank and many other donors, including the United States and the European Union, was not forthcoming.
 
Is Jericho Too Hot?
 In the grocery downstairs from the Jericho municipal offices, the proprietor, a middle-aged bearded man with a pleasant disposition, thinks the problem is that Soha, Mr. Arafat's 34-year-old wife, "doesn't like the idea of living here in the summer." Sultry Jericho, 820 feet below sea level, has summer temperatures that are already edging past 100 degrees and are bound to climb further.
Some say Mr. Arafat is avoiding Jericho because it is not just hot, but ugly, too. Others mention security concerns.
But the most likely reason emerges in conversations with some of the P.L.O. officials here and in Gaza who have been acting as advance scouts for Mr. Arafat in the past six weeks. They say he is delaying the moment when he must abandon the secretive, somewhat glamorous life of a guerrilla leader and adopts the much more mundane role of leader of a small and impoverished country.
 
A 'Banana Republic'
 "Let's face it," said a top P.L.O. official in Gaza. "The moment he enters Palestine, he is going to be the head of the smallest banana republic in the world, which has more problems than he has ever had to face."
Jericho, where Mr. Arafat is expected to live initially, is indeed the West Bank's banana capital, producing and exporting large amounts of the fruit.
Outside of that it has few attractions. There are a few tourists, largely from October to May, when its warm climate is welcome. There is little to see; the biggest attractions on the tiny central square are the rooftop satellite dishes and high-tech equipment set up by the television networks waiting for Mr. Arafat.
A senior Western diplomat in Tel Aviv said his embassy has reached the conclusion that the P.L.O. chairman is wary of the reaction of Palestinians here to his arrival.
 
Repairing an Image
 Virtually all pictures of Mr. Arafat hanging in the offices of the police force and elsewhere in Palestinian National Authority offices show him with two other leaders of the P.L.O. who died a few years ago, but whose popularity easily rivals Mr. Arafat's. They are Salah Khalaf, who was killed in Tunis in 1988, and Khalil al-Wazir, killed there in 1991. Their deaths stripped the movement of likely heirs to Mr. Arafat.
The association with dead heroes of the Palestinian movement is meant to buttress Mr. Arafat's image, which has suffered heavily in the past few months from a growing perception that he is disconnected from his people and their concerns.
"He wants all his security and police people firmly in place before he lands in Jericho or Gaza," the diplomat said.
Over the past two weeks, a new breed of Palestinian security people have been streaming into Gaza and Jericho. They are Palestinian men in civilian clothes who bear the no-nonsense looks of intelligence operatives and have authority that transcends that of the uniformed police and security forces who have been, by and large, rather friendly and indecisive.
In order to insure the best reception possible, Mr. Arafat is trying to build a pool of money to be spent upon arrival to win favors and pacify people, but P.L.O. officials say the cash has been slow to materialize.
Although some $2.4 billion has been pledged by world donors over the next five years to jump-start the process, little more than $50 million has reached the P.L.O. so far. Much of the money is committed for projects of one kind or another, not for operating expenses like the salaries of the Palestinian police and bureaucrats.
 
No Pay for the Police
 Most of the estimated 8,000 or so police officers who have moved into Gaza and Jericho still have not been paid and their mood is souring. "I have been here nearly two months and have yet to receive a salary," said Lieut. Col. Hamdi el-Rifi, head of the criminal investigation division of the Gaza police force.
"Europe and America talk about peace on television but they are not fulfilling their financial commitments," he said. "I have World War II-vintage cars here to chase after criminals who have much better vehicles. These clips on my desk, the desk itself, are gifts for which we have yet to pay. This is no way to run a state."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 18, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Yasir Arafat's delay in going to Jericho to assume formal control of Palestinian self-rule there and in the Gaza Strip reversed the dates on which two Arafat deputies were killed. Khalil al-Wazir was killed in 1988 and Salah Khalaf in 1991.
