HEADLINE: A Shift on North Korea

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
North Korea's latest offer to resolve the crisis over its nuclear program appears to include little that is new, but President Clinton's willingness to seize it as an opportunity to avoid a confrontation reflects an abrupt shift of policy.
The change says less about the prospects for a diplomatic resolution than it does about the Administration's apprehensions over a showdown and its difficulties in marshaling an international coalition for tough sanctions. 
 The White House got to the precipice of economic sanctions and sending military reinforcements, was nervous about what it saw and decided to take another crack at diplomacy, even though that meant backing away from a key condition for high-level negotiations. The condition was its insistence that North Korea insure that monitors be allowed to take measurements to determine whether Pyongyang had ever diverted plutonium for a nuclear weapon.
Administration officials say they are merely exploring new signs of flexibility on the part of the North Koreans, and they argue that any agreement in which North Korea would freeze its nuclear weapons program while high-level talks proceed would be a good bargain for the United States.
"As the President said yesterday, our policy has not changed one iota," said Anthony Lake, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser.
But the officials also acknowledged that the details of the North Korean proposal, which would allow international monitors to remain in North Korea as long as Washington made "good-faith efforts" to negotiate, remain to be clarified.
And they acknowledge that former President Jimmy Carter complicated the picture by asserting wrongly that Washington had stopped "sanction activity" in the United Nations, where the officials said the United States is still consulting with other nations on the possibility of sanctions.
But even supporters of the Administration's new approach say it represents a major change in Washington's stance.
Representative Gary L. Ackerman, the Queens Democrat who visited North Korea in October, said the Administration was right to try to follow up any opening that might have been created by Mr. Carter's diplomacy in Pyongyang. But Mr. Ackerman added that the North Korean statements, which the White House has hailed as signs of a new policy, reflected longstanding positions.
Mr. Ackerman said "almost everything" that the North Koreans had proposed had been floated before. "They have sold it to somebody new at a different time," he said, referring to Mr. Carter.
Some experts were more critical.
"There has been a clear change in our position. We put our markers down, and now we are doing the very thing that we said was unacceptable," said Zalmay Khalilzad, the head of the Pentagon's office of policy planning in the Bush Administration. "When you state you won't do something and then you do it, it undermines your credibility."
 
Dispute Began Last Year
 The controversy arose last year, when the International Atomic Energy Agency determined that North Korea had produced more plutonium than it had acknowledged when it shut down its nuclear reactor at Yongbyon in 1989. The agency then sought to carry out additional inspections to confirm its findings.
The inspections were important because the Central Intelligence Agency believes that the North Koreans diverted enough plutonium for one or two bombs, while Pyongyang says it produced only a minute quantity of plutonium.
But the North Koreans balked at allowing the inspections.
That put the ball in the Administration's court, and officials debated how to respond. Pentagon officials argued that it was more important to limit the North Korean program in the future than to resolve the mystery of the past diversion, but they were overruled.
Taking a resolute stance, the Administration vowed not to engage in high-level talks unless the North Koreans took steps to freeze their plutonium production and insure that monitors could take future measurements to determine whether and how much plutonium was diverted when the reactor was shut down in 1989.
 
U.S. Demands Ignored
 But the North Koreans ignored the American demands.
In April, they shut down the Yongbyon reactor yet again and withdrew its fuel rods, destroying the evidence that inspectors needed to determine its past plutonium diversion.
In response, the Administration announced that it would seek economic sanctions and that it would not engage in high-level talks.
"This act undercuts the basis for our dialogue with North Korea," Robert L. Gallucci, the Assistant Secretary of State for Politico-Military Affairs, told the House Foreign Affairs on June 9. "We will not continue that dialogue until a reasonable basis for it can be re-established."
Until Thursday, the Administration held to its position that North Korea had not offered a sufficient basis to resume high-level talks. But when North Korea repeated its interest in holding high-level talks to Mr. Carter, Washington's stance changed.
Mr. Clinton announced that American officials were willing to engage in talks if North Korea would freeze its nuclear program by refraining from future processing of plutonium and from refueling the reactor at Yongbyon and by allowing international inspectors to stay at Yongbyon.
By exclusion it dropped its condition on making it possible to trace past plutonium diversion.
In effect, Washington went for the most risk-free approach. It put aside the policies that were difficult, that required the painful building of international coalitions and that raised the prospect of military intervention.
 
 
Any Headway Unclear
 By today, it was unclear whether headway had been made. Pak Gil Yon, North Korea's representative to the United Nations, denied that North Korea would ever allow monitors to inspect its waste sites to try to determine the extent of its past plutonium diversion.
If the Administration's diplomatic gambit works, Washington will have succeeded in the short run in limiting -- but not erasing -- the North Korean nuclear menace.
But if it fails, the credibility of the Administration's foreign policy, already under question for flip-flops over China, Haiti and Somalia, may come under fire.
"I am not surprised that the North Koreans took the opportunity of the visit of a former President of the United States to 'send a message,' " Mr. Gallucci said today. "What we don't know really is the meaning of that message, and particularly what we don't know is whether the message they intend to send is really one in which one can see a desire in fact to re-establish a dialogue."

HEADLINE: Hoboken Council Votes to Close Bars at 1 A.M.

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J., June 17

 BODY:
The Hoboken City Council voted today to crack down on the raucous night life here, moving up the closing time for bars to 1 A.M. in an effort to tame the crowds of young people whose drunken antics often make some historic avenues seem like fraternity row during rush week.
The new ordinance was the latest salvo in a long-running battle between local leaders and more than 100 bar and restaurant owners in Hoboken, which in recent years has become increasingly popular among suburban college students eager to avoid the hassle of traveling to New York City. 
 Mayor Anthony Russo and other officials acknowledged that the thousands of visitors who descend upon Hoboken on Friday and Saturday nights had helped to revive this once-moribund Hudson River port, but they said they could no longer tolerate the unruly behavior of some revelers.
"I am very much concerned about the safety of the citizens here," Mayor Russo said in an interview before the council voted 7-0 to push forward the closing time, which is currently 3 A.M. on weekends and 2 A.M. on weekdays. "We need something to protect them."
Carmen LaBruno, the Hoboken police chief, said drinking-related offenses had become so common that he no longer thought that the bars were an economic boon.
"When you do a cost-benefit analysis, we lose," he said. "We have had to significantly increase our law-enforcement, our fire department and our public works staff. If we didn't have the bar problems, I could cut my police force by 25 percent. My highest concentration of manpower is on the 8 P.M. to 4 A.M. shift, Thursday, Friday and Saturday. All in the area of the bars."
 
Bar Owners Angered
 But bar and restaurant owners said they were angered by the change, contending that it would kill their business and hurt the many Hobokenites who earn their paychecks working the beer taps, waiting on tables, driving taxis or otherwise tending to the needs of visitors.
The owners criticized local officials for refusing to compromise and insisted that they were taking steps to control the drunken young people who often stagger from bar to bar in the early morning hours, waking up residents with their shouts, vandalizing property and urinating in public. The police issue dozens of summonses for drinking-related violations each weekend.
"Hoboken has come back in large measure because of the entertainment and restaurant business," said Dennis Oury, a lawyer for the Hoboken Tavern, Restaurant and Businessmen's Association. "My people understand that there are problems they have to address, but they don't think that throwing out the baby with the bathwater is the answer."
The new ordinance, to go into effect on Saturday, capped weeks of legal wrangling during which the City Council first tried to require that bars and restaurants institute a "one-way door" policy. Under this rule, these establishments could close at 3 A.M. on weekends, but would have to stop admitting patrons at 1 A.M.
But after Mr. Oury challenged that ordinance in Superior Court a few weeks ago, it was thrown out by a judge on a technicality. The City Council then decided it needed the stricter regulation in force during the World Cup, which begins at the Meadowlands in nearby East Rutherford on Saturday.
The council has also reintroduced the one-way door ordinance. James Fitzsimmons, the council president, and other members said they would seek to repeal the tougher rule in favor of the one-way door policy after the World Cup ends in late July.
"My feeling from the beginning has been that I would prefer to experiment with the less drastic measure than an early closing," Mr. Fitzsimmons said. "We do have some fears about the negative impact from the one o'clock closing."
Long-time residents say Hoboken began its ascent after bars took over the site of the landmark Clam Broth House a few years ago and started advertising heavily to attract college students from around the New York region.
But some bar owners say they should not be punished for the supposed sins of the rowdier watering holes.
"We are literally going out of business, and we don't understand why," said Paula Reilly, owner of Pipe Dreams Cafe, a small neighborhood bar at 239 Bloomfield Street.
"The fine people that were coming here, they are reading all this, and they are saying, 'Gee, we better not go to Hoboken,' because it appears that there is this terrible problem," she said. "But Hoboken has never been safer. New York would love to have the petty problems we have."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Hoboken City Council voted yesterday to move up the closing time of bars to 1 A.M., amid protests from tavern and restaurant owners who said the change would severely damage their businesses. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Oil Surges Past $20 a Barrel, Depressing Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Nervous financial markets were thrown into confusion yesterday, and prices declined sharply after the price of oil surged past $20 a barrel for the first time in more than a year.
A prolonged rise in oil prices, coming just before the peak of the summer driving season, would have broad inflationary implications, analysts said. The rise may also signal a significant tightening of supplies after 13 years of falling prices and varying degrees of glut. It would also further unnerve financial markets that have been obsessed with the course of inflation that, so far, has been unexpectedly mild. 
 "My, it was a messy day," said Dudley Eppel, managing director in charge of listed trading at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "Oil sent commodities way up, took a big bite out of bonds, took down all the leading stock indexes and sent the dollar down."
Crude oil for July delivery rose 80 cents, to $20.71 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a 14-month high.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 34.56 points, to 3,776.78; for the week, it declined 3.33.
Bond prices fell sharply yesterday, and the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 7.44 percent, from 7.35 percent on Thursday.
The dollar fell against most currencies, reaching an eight-month low against the German mark. In New York, the dollar dropped more than two pfennigs, to 1.6105 marks.
Despite the turmoil in the currency markets, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said at a news conference in San Antonio that the dollar would stabilize because the economy was sound. "The underlying fundamentals are excellent," Mr. Bentsen said. "I'm comfortable with the economy. Inflation is low, and the numbers are the best I've seen in 20 years."
A quarterly phenomenon, known as the "triple-witching hour," in which traders buy or sell stocks in accordance with expiring options, led to unusually large trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange. The larger number of shares changing hands probably accelerated the price decline. Trading volume totaled 387 million shares, more than 30 percent more than this year's average of 295 million shares.
The most widely cited reasons for the rise in oil prices were falling crude supplies for Midwest oil refineries and a belief that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would not increase production for the year.
A growing number of speculators may also be contributing to the increase in oil prices.
But some analysts say commodities traders are only now realizing that the refining capacity of the United States is nearing its upper limits, raising the possibility of supply shortages in the Midwest.
Matthew R. Simmons, founder and head of Simmons & Company, an investment bank in Houston that specializes in the oil-services industry, said about 96 percent of nationwide refining capacity was being used last week, compared with a rate in the low 90's in the comparable period a year ago and a rate of 65.8 percent in 1982, the historic low.
"Without anybody really noticing all that much," Mr. Simmons said, "it's been creeping up and up, until we're up to full capacity, then we need to build more capacity, and that will take time." Mr. Simmons said an oil shortage could not be ruled out, but that it was difficult to estimate its potential magnitude at this time.
"What's important to realize is that the world needs about 68 million barrels a day, and OPEC produces less than 40 percent of that," Mr. Simmons said. "Everyone else is producing everything they can, except for the United States and Russia, which are in decline."
Along with the rise in oil prices, unleaded gasoline gained 1.73 cents, to 55.20 cents a gallon, and heating oil rose 1.50 cents, to 52.02 cents a gallon.
Unlike other increases in the closely watched Commodity Research Bureau index, which has gyrated mainly because of fears of a drought in the Midwest and its impact on wheat, corn and soybeans, the rise in the index yesterday was dominated by the increases in oil prices. The C.R.B. rose 2.1 points to 239.38 yesterday, the highest since August 1990, when the most recent recession started taking hold.
A key indicator of the markets' concern was a steep rise in gold, a barometer of traders' concern about inflation. Gold for August delivery rose $6.20, to $393.70 an ounce.
"Clearly, the market now has a wider basis for concern over these numbers," said Bernard C. Savaiko, a senior analyst who follows the C.R.B. index for Paine Webber Futures. "A C.R.B. that's moved by oil has a greater ripple effect on the economy than a C.R.B. that's moved by soybeans."
Yesterday morning, bonds and the dollar registered the first impact of the rising oil prices. Bondholders fear that inflation will erode the underlying value of bonds, and investors in the dollar fear that inflation will weaken its purchasing power.
The stock market followed. Its opening was affected by the first phase of frenetic "triple-witching" trading, when three sets of options and futures contracts, particularly those based on indexes like the Standard & Poor's 500, simultaneously expire each quarter.
Blue-chip stocks like Boeing and Sears & Roebuck, retailers like Wal-Mart and oil companies like Chevron, as well as over-the-counter stocks like Oracle and Microsoft, were hurt in the fall.
Quaker Oats rose 7 3/8, to 78 1/2, amid market speculation that it could be a takeover target, possibly by Nestle of Switzerland. Both Quaker Oats and Nestle declined comment.
The most active stock, at 15.9 million shares, was Cheyenne Software, which fell 8 3/8, to 8, following an announcement by the company that its fourth-quarter earnings would be lower than expected.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 3.48 points yesterday, to 458.45, and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell 5.62 points, to 729.35. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.70 points, to 253.29, with advancing stocks lagging declining stocks by 769 to 1,429. The American Stock Exchange market value fell 1.52 points, to 440.26.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 23 fell, led by Boeing, which dropped 1 1/2, to 48 3/8, after the company announced that its helicopter business would lay off 2,200 workers because of a delay in a Pentagon contract for Osprey helicopters.
Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 323 fell, led by Wal-Mart, which was down 7/8, to 24 1/8.

HEADLINE: First Rulings For Haitians: Yes to 6 of 35

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ABOARD THE COMFORT, Kingston Harbor, Jamaica, June 17

 BODY:
This huge white hospital ship, the U.S.S. Comfort, which has been turned into a floating immigration bureaucracy, meted out its first judgments today as the instrument of the latest shift in President Clinton's Haiti policy.
Now, when fleeing Haitians are plucked from their rickety wooden sailboats by one of a dozen United States Coast Guard cutters on patrol in the Caribbean, they are brought to a shipboard world of computers, interviews, forms and files. That leads to the difficult decision by an Immigration and Naturalization Service officer on whether each individual will be allowed into the United States. 
 This afternoon, 29 Haitians -- including two pregnant women and a baby -- from the first group of 35 taken from three boats by the Coast Guard on Wednesday slumped silently on the Comfort's upper decks.
They were to be sent back to Haiti.
 
Six Were Accepted
 Six young men, found to be qualified for refugee status, strode buoyantly to an Air Force C-130 at Norman Manley airport at 9 A.M. today, each swinging a small plastic bag of belongings. They had arrived in a white tour bus bearing the word "Smile."
The difference lay in the credibility immigration officials placed in the reasons the Haitians gave for claiming the "well founded fear of persecution" should they return to Haiti and its brutal military dictatorship.
Haitians have fled their homeland in fear since a military coup in September 1991 unseated the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country's first democratically elected President. Since then, he has remained in exile and the United States and other countries have attempted to oust the military rulers by applying diplomatic and economic pressure.
The decision on whether a Haitian is sent back or is granted refugee status is based on an interview with the Immigration inspectors, a process that finally rests on individual judgment and is somewhat amorphous or, as Kathleen Thompson, director of the I.N.S. Refugee Division, put it: "squishy."
"There are intrinsic difficulties," she said. "There can be human rights violations that are truly horrific, but don't fall under the five categories."
 
A Focus on Politics
 The categories are a fear of persecution based on race, on nationality, on religion, on membership in a social organization or on a political opinion, although Ms. Thompson said that for Haitians, political opinion was the most likely claim.
"We take into account the whole circumstances of an individual case," she said. "We try to evaluate each claim in its entire context and credibility. Geographical area, for example, can be important because we know certain areas are hotbeds of resistance activity or have repression, and this could affect credibility."
Still, she added, "a person can have embellished his claim and still be a refugee."
When running for President, Mr. Clinton was sharply critical of what he called the Bush Administration's "immoral" policy of returning all Haitians picked up at sea. But once in office, responding largely to political pressures against the influx of black Haitian refugees, he reversed himself and kept sending Haitians back.
Civil rights groups and immigration advocates have denounced the Administration policy as "racist." Responding to the mounting pressure, the Administration set up the shipboard interviewing process, which has mobilized a task force of slightly over 1,000 military and civilian personnel, and is working on setting up a processing center on the Turks and Caicos Islands.
 
A United Nations Role
 The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which has been critical of the policy of returning refugees, has 11 lawyers aboard the Comfort to monitor the processing. The United Nations representatives also deliver a 20-minute orientation lecture to the Haitians.
"There are a lot of hard-working people on that boat," Barbara Francis, a spokeswoman for the refugees commission, said after conferring with the shipboard observers this afternoon. "But the system will really be tested when the pressure of numbers comes along."
Haitians intercepted at sea are brought onto the ship, a converted supertanker, from a ramp into the starboard hull. Almost immediately, each Haitian is fitted with a plastic identification bracelet, similar to those given to hospital patients, but these are equipped with an electronic chip inscribed with their identity and background information.
Cases of water are stacked ready for the Haitians, who are likely to be dehydrated from their rides on small boats under the hot sun, and workers who speak Creole are on hand to provide reassurance to people who have grown wary of uniforms and authority.
 
Avoiding Intimidation
 "We are very concerned about having the refugees feel comfortable and not intimidated," Lieut. Pete Mitchell of the United States Marines explained to journalists brought aboard the ship for a tour this afternoon.
About 200 marines are on the ship as a security detail as well as U.S. Navy doctors and nurses and military personnel from other branches.
Deep inside the ship, in a compartment filled with computers and makeshift interview booths, the immigration inspectors review the files assembled by interpreters for each incoming applicant and then conduct the critical final interview. Some of the computers have records of violent episodes in Haiti, which are to be updated each week, to help confirm the charges made by the Haitians who fled their country.
 
Taking Their Time
 "We had the luxury of time," said the chief of the shipboard immigration inspectors, Arthur Nieto, saying the interviews for this group each lasted about an hour and forty-five minutes.
"We try to get as much information as we can," Mr. Nieto said.
"We would like them to be at ease. We are always reinforcing, telling them, 'Is there anything else you would like to say?' "
The journalists brought aboard the ship were not allowed to speak to the Haitians who had been rejected. Nor would immigration officials give examples of what might or might not be a successful case, saying they did not want to provide a how-to for future applicants.
For those approved for refugee status -- the fortunate six today -- the final stop on the ship is for a medical exam, and then interpreters let them know they have made it. Then they are flown to Guantanamo Bay Navy Base for further processing.
"They were actually very excited," said Commander David Barnette, the head of the medical section. "They were high-fiving."

HEADLINE: G.M. Dealt Setback On Hughes

BYLINE: By By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
A Federal judge ruled today that the Hughes Aircraft Company was entitled to only a small fraction of the $3 billion in royalties and back interest that it had sought from the Government in a 21-year-old legal dispute over a satellite-technology patent.
The decision marked a setback to the parent company of Hughes, the General Motors Corporation, and could prevent the wave of patent claims against the Government that patent experts had predicted if Hughes had won a larger settlement. 
 Hughes officials estimated that the decision would be worth $114 million, and said they had not decided whether to appeal the ruling to the United States Court of Appeals.
 
'Good-Sized Sum'
 "It's still $114 million -- it's a good-sized sum," said Richard Dore, a spokesman for Hughes.
Judge James Turner of the United States Court of Federal Claims had ruled last year that the Government owed Hughes royalties for having used the technology for steering satellites during the last quarter century.
But Judge Turner decided that Hughes was entitled to royalty payments of only 1 percent of the value of 81 Government satellites that used the disputed technology, rather than the 15 percent royalty that Hughes had sought. Hughes was not entitled to any more money because it had offered to license the patent to other companies in the 1970's for less than 3 percent of the value of satellites, Judge Turner ruled.
 
'Supported by the Evidence'
 Judge Turner awarded back interest according to a method proposed by Hughes and based on the interest rate applied by the Internal Revenue Service to overdue tax rebates. Hughes calculated that the verdict was worth nearly $36 million, plus $78 million in back interest; the Justice Department did not have an immediate estimate tonight.
Government lawyers had argued that a royalty of 1 percent was appropriate, and welcomed today's ruling. "It's really the rate that is supported by the evidence -- it's still a lot of money," said Vito J. DiPietro, a senior Justice Department lawyer who worked on the case.
Many patent lawyers had anticipated that Judge Turner would split the difference between the Government's royalty figure and the Hughes figure, producing a verdict of at least $1 billion.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Air Force and the Navy have all used satellites that incorporated the Hughes system. The Justice Department represented them in the case.
Mr. DiPietro said he was not aware of any decision among the three agencies on how to divide the responsibility for paying the royalties, or where the money would come from. Hughes said in a statement that 68 of the 81 satellites were military.
Mr. Dore of Hughes said it was also unclear whether the money would be paid directly to Hughes or to General Motors.
Today's decision is the latest chapter in one of the longest and most complex patent cases in the country.
At the core of the dispute is a satellite system invented in 1959 by a Hughes engineer, Donald Williams. He developed a simple method to control the position and spin of a satellite relative to the earth and the sun. The system made it possible to thrust a satellite from an orbit several hundred miles up into a geosynchronous orbit 22,300 miles in space, where a satellite appears to maintain a fixed position over the rotating earth.
Mr. Williams's invention was used in 1963 on the first geosynchronous satellite successfully launched, Syncom 2, and on some satellites used in low-earth orbits, like the Atmospheric Explorers.
The system proposed by Mr. Williams called for two slits in the shape of a "V" on one side of a satellite. Ground controllers would measure the frequency with which each slit was exposed to the sun as the satellite spun so as to determine its position and order it to fire thruster rockets accordingly.
The Government issued a patent to Mr. Williams in 1973, after Hughes had fought a seven-year battle with NASA in a patent appeals process. Hughes then filed suit seeking payment for the Government's use of the technology. Mr. Williams has since died.
The Government contended that it did not owe Hughes anything because the company had won a Government contract to develop the technology in 1961. But Judge Turner ruled on Aug. 17, 1993, that the Government would have to pay royalties. Today's decision determined the amount of those royalties as a percentage of the satellites' value, which Judge Turner set at $3.58 billion in another decision on last April 29.
Hughes based its claim of 15 percent royalties on a 1965 agreement with the Communications Satellite Corporation that used that figure. But Judge Turner ruled today that the agreement was not a good precedent because it was reached at a time when Hughes was the only company that had successfully launched a geosynchronous satellite, and so had a strong grip on the market. The 15 percent figure also applied to two technologies, not just Mr. Williams's system, Judge Turner wrote.
Hughes later asked for more modest royalties from other satellite builders. Judge Turner asked in his decision today that if the system was worth 15 percent royalties, "why was Hughes offering to license the Williams invention to its major commercial competitors early in the patent term -- the time of maximum value -- for less than 3 percent of total spacecraft cost (making no mention of the 1965 Comsat agreement), and why were there no takers among three of the world's leading satellite manufacturers, not even a counter-offer from two of them."

HEADLINE: Bonds Tumble as Fears Focus Anew on Inflation

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The bond market sold off sharply yesterday, pushing interest rates to their highest point in more than a month as the plunging dollar and climbing commodity prices raised investors' fears of more inflation and even higher interest rates.
The Federal Reserve may increase interest rates as early as July 5, when its policy-making Federal Open Market Committee meets again, said William Stevens, a top executive at Montgomery Asset Management. 
 The Treasury's 30-year bond fell nearly a point, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.44 percent, from 7.35 percent on Thursday. Yields on shorter-term and intermediate Treasury issues also jumped.
Ian MacKinnon, who heads $54 billion in fixed-income investments at the Vanguard Group, attributed much of the market's nervousness to the dollar's selloff. "Continued weakness in the dollar filters into import prices and the Fed has got to be concerned," about inflation, he said.
 
Dollar Down, Oil Up
 The dollar dropped more than 2 pfennigs in New York yesterday, ending at 1.6105 German marks. It also fell against most other leading currencies.
Meanwhile, oil surged above $20 a barrel for the first time in more than a year, pushing the Commodity Research Bureau's index up 2.10 points, to 239.38, its highest close in more than three and a half years.
Rising prices and a falling dollar are a lethal combination that "smells like inflation," said James Hale, senior fixed-income strategist at MMS International in San Francisco.
Mr. Stevens of Montgomery Asset Management agreed, noting that the dollar's weakness "implies that our rates aren't high enough to attract all the dollars going overseas."
Faster economic growth is generating concern that inflation will accelerate even though the latest Government reports do not show it. This year, consumer prices have increased at an annualized rate of 2.3 percent, down from 2.7 percent last year, the Labor Department said.
An inflation rate of 2.3 percent this year would be the lowest since 1986, when consumer prices rose 1.2 percent. Less inflation enhances the value of fixed-income securities.
The divergence between commodity prices and the Government's inflation indexes leaves investors with little reason to make a big bet on bonds, said Charles Quigley, a trader at Chemical Securities Inc. That means bond yields should stay in the 7.20 percent to 7.5 percent range that has persisted for five weeks, he said.
 
Consumer Confidence Rises
 Adding to concern about faster economic growth leading to inflation was an increase in a closely watched consumer sentiment index.
The University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index for June rose to 94.5 from 92.8 in May, its highest since September 1989, people with access to the survey said.
Consumer confidence climbed even as interest rates have risen, reflecting an economy that should maintain its strength, said Steven Saslow, executive managing director at HSBC Securities Inc.
"The economy is improving" and prospects for lower inflation "are deteriorating," Mr. Saslow said. "By August, we'll be back in the soup, as we were in May," when bond yields reached 7.66 percent%, the highest since November 1992.
"On balance, I think the market has a problem," he said.
"There's still a lot of bearish sentiment out there," said Ray Goodner at IDS Financial Services in Minneapolis.

HEADLINE: At the Gay Games, Giuliani Takes Step To Forge New Ties

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Across six months in office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has had a strained relationship with gay-rights advocates, parting ways with them on a range of issues from his long refusal to condemn a supporter who spoke out against the Gay Games to his decision to march in the St. Patrick's Day parade despite the exclusion of a group of homosexual marchers.
But tonight at a Columbia University stadium, Mr. Giuliani is scheduled to deliver a formal welcoming speech at the Gay Games. The Mayor's aides helped pave the way for closing ceremonies to be held at Yankee Stadium. And an interview with Mr. Giuliani is featured on the cover of the current issue of The Advocate, which describes itself as the national gay and lesbian news magazine. 
 The Mayor and his aides have largely portrayed his welcoming remarks as a routine civic duty at a sporting event that will bring in several hundred million dollars from tourists. But Mr. Giuliani's appearance at the Gay Games is also another step in his political self-definition and his effort to forge a Republicanism that can appeal to both "family-value" conservatives and homosexuals.
"The Mayor of New York City should be capable of protecting everyone and reaching out to everyone and saying, 'If this is your sexual orientation, then you shouldn't have to live your life thinking you're less worthy than someone else,' " Mr. Giuliani said yesterday, describing the message he wanted to send through his appearance.
"And we should be a big enough city -- and we are and we have always been -- to have people who have different sexual orientations live together with respect and understanding of each other."
Mr. Giuliani and his aides say there is no reason to be surprised by his embrace of the Gay Games. "This is a major sporting event that New York City is proud and happy to have," said Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, who has been the administration's chief liaison with the organizers. "This is exactly the kind of event the Mayor of New York is always going to participate in."
The Mayor just this week appeared at a news conference in support of an anti-bias bill blocked by the Republican-led state Senate, which would increase penalties for bias crimes, including those whose victims were selected because of sexual orientation. And he noted that during the mayoral campaign, he marched in the Gay Pride parade.
But although Mr. Giuliani's campaign reached out to gay voters, it also took energy from the conservative rebellion on the Board of Education against a curriculum that discussed homosexuality and AIDS and against the school system's condom distribution effort. The Mayor recently used his two appointments to the board to keep the same conservative bloc in place.
 
No Condemnation of Minister
 Moreover, a Bronx organizer for the Giuliani mayoral campaign, the Rev. Ruben Diaz, has been one of the city's most outspoken opponents of the Gay Games, suggesting that they would lead to an increase in AIDS cases and to wide acceptance of homosexuality by young people.
When Mr. Diaz first denounced the Gay Games in Spanish-language publications, Mr. Giuliani said he disagreed with him, but he refused repeated requests by gay-rights advocates and liberals that he condemn the Pentecostal minister. He said Mr. Diaz's views were based on "moral theology developed over thousands of years."
"It isn't my job to condemn people," he said. "I'm not a bishop or rabbi or a priest. I'm not a moralist. I'm the Mayor of New York City. People in New York City disagree on this subject."
Only last month, when Mr. Diaz took his crusade against the Gay Games to the steps of City Hall, did Mr. Giuliani adopt a harsher tone, saying that his comments were "unwarranted and probably contribute to misunderstanding and prejudice."
How Mr. Giuliani responded to Mr. Diaz reflected his attempt in office to preach tolerance for both homosexuals and those opposed to homosexuality -- a stretch that has often left conservatives and liberals alike dissatisfied.
Mr. Giuliani gave a fuller explanation of his vision of tolerance in April, when he delivered a speech about the importance of religious values. He pointed to the controversy over whether homosexuals could march in the annual St. Patrick's Day parade, and quoted from the St. Patrick's Day homily of John Cardinal O'Connor. He repeated the Cardinal's question, "Is it bigotry for the Ancient Order of Hibernians to celebrate its values without being required to celebrate the values of others?"
 
Core Backers Likely to Stay
 "The Cardinal makes an important distinction," Mr. Giuliani said, "one that is difficult to understand. And sometimes because of emotion, difficult to accept. But it is at the heart of what it means to be an American, and it is why this city with respect and tolerance and good cheer also celebrates the Gay Pride parade, why we are home to the Gay Games."
Republican strategists say Mr. Giuliani's welcome of the Gay Games is very likely to sit poorly with some of his core supporters, but not drive them from his camp. After all, George Marlin, the Conservative candidate for Mayor, who ran to the right of Mr. Giuliani in last year's mayoral race drew less than 1 percent of the vote.
"The reservoir of good will and credibility that Rudy Giuliani has with his base is such that no single event, certainly not this one, is likely to damage it in any substantial way," said Jay Severin, a Republican political strategist.
But whether his appearance at the Gay Games can expand his political base among gay people is also unclear.
"There are people who will support his presence and people who will boo him," said Ann Northrop, one of the board members of the Gay Games and a member of Act Up. "And I don't think anyone's opinion will be affected by the fact he's there." City Councilman Thomas K. Duane, who is gay, called the Mayor's appearance "a good grade on his report card, but he mostly still has a lot of incompletes."
In his interview in The Advocate, Mr. Giuliani spoke out for an inclusive Republican party, saying, "There is no reason why the party shouldn't appeal to gays and lesbians in the same way it does to all Americans."
He criticized the anti-abortion, anti-homosexual oratory of Patrick J. Buchanan at the 1992 Republican National Convention as a mistake and held up Gov. William Weld of Massachusetts as a model of more tolerant Republicanism.
And yesterday he noted that he believed in a Republicanism that preaches an economic philosophy of limited government. If Republicans "were consistent -- and some are and some aren't," he said, "then they'd come to the same view about someone's sexual orientation or sexual preferences, that this is not something the government was designed to get deeply involved in."

HEADLINE: Reluctantly, Mayor Lets Tennis Deal Go Through

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
After complaining before and after the mayoral election about the deal that the administration of David N. Dinkins negotiated to expand the National Tennis Center in Queens, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has agreed, with no public notice, to approve the lease for the expansion.
Mayor Giuliani had suggested after taking office that he would try to find a way to squash the deal, which will keep the United States Open tennis tournament in New York until at least the year 2020.
 
 But a review of the contract ordered by the Mayor has concluded that there is no basis to challenge the lease with the United States Tennis Association, which holds the tournament at the center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park each summer.
The Mayor told the group of his decision this week. "It's a contract agreement, and we're going to abide by it," Paul A. Crotty, the city's Corporation Counsel, said yesterday.
Mr. Giuliani had often criticized parts of the deal reached by Mr. Dinkins, especially a requirement that the city pay fines up to $325,000 if planes from La Guardia Airport disrupt matches during the tournament.
 
42 Acres of Parkland
 But Mr. Dinkins, an avid tennis player who attends the United States Open each year, finished the contract in the waning days of his administration, calling it "the best deal for a municipal stadium in the nation."
Under the agreement, the association will receive an added 21 acres of parkland, doubling the size of the tennis center to 42 acres, and will get city help in financing its expansion. In exchange, it will pay for the $172 million expansion, including a new stadium with 23,000 seats and renovation of the existing arenas. In addition, the association promised to keep the prestigious tournament in New York City for at least a quarter century and possibly as long as 99 years.
The association also agreed to maintain the center, although the city will continue to own it. In addition, the association will pay the city $400,000 a year in rent and 1 percent of all revenues over $25 million.
The expansion of the center won broad support from elected officials in the city, but some officials and residents in Queens objected to the deal as a sweetheart package for the tennis association at the expense of open space and quiet skies.
 
'What Fools We Were'
 State Senator Emanuel R. Gold, a Democrat from Forest Hills who has been one of the deal's most forceful critics, expressed disappointment yesterday that the Mayor had not found a way to reopen negotiations.
He called the deal a "bonanza" for the tennis association that for example did not include an increase in base rent over the life of the contract.
"We're all at some point -- eight or nine or ten years from now -- going to say what fools we were," Mr. Gold said. "Now we're stuck with it."
Mr. Crotty said the Mayor's office reviewed three areas of the agreement: the loss of parkland, the economics of the deal and the possible fines the city would have to pay if airplanes disrupt matches, even though the city cannot dictate air traffic, which is controlled by the Federal Aviation Administration.
The Mayor objected to the provision for fines because the "city could be penalized even when it's done all it can do," Mr. Crotty said. The Mayor's office asked the association to consider changing the provision on fines, offering some form of financial bonus other than fines, Mr. Crotty said.
But the association refused, and the Mayor's office relented this week. The decision not to challenge the lease further was first reported in The Daily News on Thursday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Jumps $6.20 as Prices Of Oil and Other Basics Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gold prices surged yesterday as traders became increasingly concerned that sharply higher prices for oil and other commodities would increase inflationary pressures in the economy.
At the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery jumped $6.20, to $393.70 an ounce, the metal's highest price since late March. 
 "Everybody was watching the Commodity Research Bureau index and soybeans and crude oil were higher, fanning the fears of inflation," said Jon Nader, a vice president of the Bank of America.
The index of 21 commodities rose 2.10 points, to close at 239.38, its highest point in more than three and a half years.
"The C.R.B. is everybody's heart index," said John O'Connell, an analyst for Refco Inc. in New York. "The bottom line is there's so much going on that finally funds are turning to gold. They own beans, they own coffee. They see that the market is still bullish on commodities, so why not go to gold."
Other precious metals also posted sharp gains. July silver rose 13.3 cents, to $5.593 an ounce on the Comex. July platinum gained $5.20, to $411.10 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 
Oil Prices Over $20
 Also on the Mercantile Exchange, crude oil prices surged above $20 a barrel, pushing gasoline prices higher.
"We're hitting highs we haven't seen in over a year," Bob Baker, an energy analyst with Prudential Securities Inc. in New York, said of crude oil futures. "There was no new news today or yesterday but the market seems to feel that OPEC has an agreement that's good for oil prices."
Meeting earlier this week in Vienna, OPEC ministers decided to keep oil production unchanged throughout the year.
July crude oil soared 80 cents, to $20.71 a barrel, a 14-month high. Unleaded gasoline gained 1.73 cent, to 55.20 cents a gallon, and heating oil rose 1.50 cents, to 52.02 cents a gallon.
Elsewhere, corn and soybean prices continued to climb in reaction to the hot, dry weather in the Midwest. On the Chicago Board of Trade, July corn was 1 1/2 cents higher at $2.83 1/4 a bushel, while July soybeans were up 9 1/2 cents at $7.11 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar, Still on a Slide, Hits 8-Month Low Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The slide in the dollar worsened yesterday as it hit an eight-month low against the German mark. It also dropped to its weakest level in a year and a half against the Swiss franc.
The dollar's latest drop did not appear to be based on any significant news or economic data, but it unnerved other financial markets, pulling down bond and stock prices. 
 Traders said the currency's weakness reflected a foreign exchange market test to see how far the dollar must fall before the Clinton Administration would support it. Analysts said the market was doubting the strength of the American economy and the Administration's currency policies, while focusing on gaps between German and American interest rates that were pulling capital away from the United States and weakening the dollar.
In late New York trading, the dollar dropped more than two pfennigs, to 1.6105 German marks, from 1.6334 marks on Thursday. It also hit 1.3545 Swiss francs, down from 1.3700. Moreover, it also relinquished all of Thursday's gains against the Japanese yen, falling to 102.70 from 103.45.
Currency trading was quiet through the morning, with no releases of new Government data on the economy, as the dollar drifted below 1.6280 marks, seen by dealers as a key technical support level. But the dollar plunged around midday after Gail Fosler, chief economist for the Conference Board business research group in New York, predicted that the dollar would fall 10 percent against the mark in the next 18 months.
Ms. Fosler based the forecast, which was carried on several news services, on economic fundamentals, including lower inflation and higher interest rates in Germany.
"The headlines and the thrust of the story pulled the rug out from under the dollar," said Bob Near, a vice president at the Bank of New York.
But many analysts said traders had taken Ms. Fosler's report as an excuse to sell dollars, pointing to an underlining lack of confidence in the currency.
"The markets don't generally respond to this kind of thing," said Lisa Finstrom, currency analyst for Smith Barney & Company. "It hit a vulnerable market. In thin trading, everybody rushed for the door. It just greased the wheels of something already in motion, that is, a generalized dollar retreat."
John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said the decline was simply an extension of a weeks-old slide for the dollar, set off by doubts about the strength of the American economy and expectations of pickups in Europe and Japan.
In recent days, Mr. Lipsky added, the market has started to test the Clinton Administration's resolve to continue the change toward a dollar-supporting policy that started with an enormous currency-market intervention in early May, when the dollar was approaching postwar lows.
"The pressure on the dollar is unlikely to be resolved without another round of intervention," he said.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Discount Brokers: The Cheap Get Cheaper

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:
Price battles are breaking out in the deep-discount broker business, leaving some firms shell-shocked, some on the attack and some posing as noncombatants. Through all the smoke, savvy investors will discern one thing: the spoils of war.
 The first shot was fired in January by National Discount Brokers, based in New York. A new subsidiary of the Sherwood Group, an investment and research firm with $80 million in 1993 sales, National heavily advertised a flat fee of $30 a trade, topped by a $3 handling charge. The fee applied to all over-the-counter trades and to trades of fewer than 5,000 shares of listed stocks. For larger listed deals, the firm tacked on a penny a share on the whole order. 
 The $33 fee undercut many discounters, particularly on larger trades. The industry's average fee for trading 1,000 shares of a $5 stock was $72 last year, according to the American Association of Individual Investors.
 National's debut -- plus a skittish stock market that may slow the broker business -- has prompted "aggressive competition" among deep discounters, said Mark D. Coler, president of Mercer Inc., a New York research firm.
 "It's like a gas war, with a station on each corner and a new price every day," said Kenneth Kraska, president of the R. J. Forbes Group, a deep- discount broker in Melville, L.I.
 For investors, the benefits extend beyond falling prices to flat fees that vastly simplify the search for the least expensive deep-discount broker. And, while service counts, too, price is of high importance in this economy-minded industry.
 Several of these very cheap brokers -- who handle about 20 percent of a discount market dominated by Charles Schwab, Fidelity and Quick & Reilly -- have sharply dropped their minimum transaction fee, which is the lowest price charged regardless of trade size. On April 1, Forbes dropped its minimum from $45 to $35, and a month later, E-Trade, a computer-only discounter in Palo Alto, Calif., reduced its minimum from $35 to $25.
 These fee reductions, at 22 percent and 28 percent, are big bites. And shrinking minimums are just one front in the war.
 Brown & Company, a large deep discounter based in Boston, used to charge $25 plus 3 cents a share for trading listed stocks, and $25 and 2 cents a share for unlisted ones. As of June 1, the fee is a flat $29, for listed and unlisted trades, up to 5,000 shares. To trade 1,000 shares of a listed equity, Brown will now get $29, not $55 -- a 47 percent drop.
 Do the cuts hurt the brokers? "Anybody who says they like competition is a liar," said George Brown, president of the company bearing his name.
 At Fidelity's Spartan Brokerage, trading 500 shares at $50 cost $64 until yesterday. Now, the Boston-based discounter charges $55 -- a 14 percent difference. These percentage savings vary with trade size, even within the same company.
 The guy who set the fire is feeling the heat, too. Two days after Brown moved to $29, National dropped its price for unlisted trades from $30 to $25 -- and dispensed with the $3 handling charge.
 Prices are getting simpler as well as lower. Traditionally, discounters use intricate fee formulas that include many aspects of a trade -- share number, dollar value, share price. But some discounters, reacting to National's opening salvo, are adopting flat fees.
 For listed stocks at E-Trade and National, and for listed and unlisted stocks at Brown, the new flat fees cover all trades of fewer than 5,000 shares. And for unlisted trades at National, E-Trade and Forbes, the sky's the limit. "You can do a billion shares" at the flat rate, said Mr. Kraska of Forbes.
 Of course, as its rivals hasten to point out, National did not invent the flat fee. Many discounters use per-share prices, usually 1 to 3 cents, subject to overall deal minimums. Combined, these features act as a flat fee.
 At 2 cents a share and a $34 transaction minimum, investors at Lombard Institutional Brokerage, based in San Francisco, will pay an effective flat rate of $34 for all trades of listed stocks between 1 and 1,700 shares.
 However, given the range of minimums and per-share charges, these formulas usually operate as flat fees only up to about 2,300 shares, and often fewer. The new, National-inspired flat rates simplify much larger trades.
 Clarity is coming elsewhere, too. At Spartan, the old fee schedule had 28 pages listing 1,400 transactions. The new one needs just a few phrases: $40 plus 3 cents a share for trades under 5,000 shares, and $40 plus 2 cents a share for trades over 5,000 shares. All subject to a $45 minimum.
 For investors, this simplicity may have more value than falling prices. With straightforward fees, they can find the cheapest broker without laborious calculation. And who the cheapest broker is will change much less with trade size.
 But the new pricing at Spartan won't help all investors equally. "People who trade in large amounts get a bigger discount" under the new fees, said Donna Morris, a Fidelity senior vice president. Some smaller traders may even pay more under the new method, and small trades are broadly defined.
 Trading 300 shares at $30 -- a $9,000 deal -- costs $44 under the old system, and $49 under the new. Spartan further segments the market by requiring 40 trades a year and an account minimum of $20,000.
 Similarly, investors may like National's $25 flat fee for over-the-counter trades, but, for listed trades, they may find a better deal than its $33 fee. (Why the $8 difference? Because National can execute unlisted orders in-house through an affiliate, Sherwood Securities.)
 Investor wariness will still pay off, too. Lombard's $34 minimum may look cheaper than Forbes's $35. But Lombard has a $2.50 handling charge. Forbes has none.
 And brokers quickly remind salivating investors that service still counts. "If it were all about price, we'd all have Yugos," said Lombard's president, V. Eric Roach. Lombard offers such benefits as real-time stock prices and a ratio of one customer-service person for every two brokers.
 Ms. Morris likes service, too. Spartan may cost more than some, but it is "a service-intensive deep-discount broker" that is open around the clock and has Fidelity's big resources behind it.
 Computer and telephone trading, no-load mutual fund investing and interest payments on cash balances are other valuable services some discounters provide.
 But lower prices, not service, are today's news. Will they be tomorrow's? "I think we'll see more," Mr. Brown said.
 Large players like Brown and National may fear this prospect. But small ones are even grimmer. "We're fine now," Mr. Kraska said. "But I can't see going any lower."

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Combining Varied Stock-Picking Styles

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
The New England Star Advisers Funduses leading money managers from four fund groups to manage an equity portfolio. They are William M. B. Berger and Rodney L. Linafelter of Berger 100; Edward F. Keely, Founders Growth; Warren B. Lammert, Janus Mercury, and Barbara C. Friedman and Jeffrey C. Petherick, Loomis Sayles Small Cap. The idea of combining equity managers with different stock-picking styles is great for diversification. But with a load of 5.75 percent, the price is steep. You can re-create the same fund at no charge, using a discount brokerage account to minimize paperwork.
The growing reluctance of investors to pay sales charges has inspired several fund groups with excellent track records to convert to no-loads. The latest example is Heartland, known primarily for its top-performing Value and U.S. Government Securities funds. The group dropped its 3 percent sales charge June 1. 
 The Alliance Worldwide Privatization Fund aims for long-term capital appreciation by buying shares of former state-owned companies. Its allocation is slightly different from the Global Privatization Fund, a closed-end fund recently started by Alliance. To gain the needed liquidity, the open-end fund will invest roughly 70 percent in established economies, mostly in Western Europe. Its closed-end cousin invests about 60 percent there, and is now selling for a discount -- a tempting bargain.

HEADLINE: World Cup '94;
Defending Its Title, Germany Slips by Bolivia

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 17

 BODY:
They came by the thousands, Bolivians blowing whistles and carrying oversized flags, Germans beating drums and dancing in conga lines, Americans trying to plug into this unfamiliar festive celebration.
The World Cup arrived here today with the first of 52 games, but the locals still have much to learn about football played with the feet instead of the hands. Oprah Winfrey, the emcee for the opening ceremonies, fell off a platform just after she welcomed a worldwide audience of 750 million television viewers to Soldier Field and appeared to twist an ankle. Then Diana Ross skipped down the slick turf lip-synching a song, kicked a waiting soccer ball and missed the net wide left. 
 Germany, the defending champion, using three forwards, also botched its share of scoring chances, but still dominated for a 1-0 victory over Bolivia with a goal that conformed with the new, relaxed offside rule in international soccer.
The match was played before 63,117 spectators and 63,117 bottles of sunscreen under a cloudless sky; the temperature breached 90 degrees on the field. At one point, both teams simply stopped playing in the second half and went to the sideline, where they were handed bottles of water, lest the players melt into a puddle like the Wicked Witch of the West.
The lone goal came in the 61st minute when Germany's Lothar Matthaus, who has switched from midfield to sweeper, chipped a long pass from near midfield and the Bolivian defense pushed forward, apparently attempting an offside trap. Instead, the Bolivians found themselves snared in a new rule designed to increase scoring after an inelegant World Cup four years ago in Italy.
According to the new offside rule, an offensive player can be positioned even with the last defender when a pass is made to him. Previously, the offensive player had to be stationed in front of the last defender to remain onside. Referees have been instructed not call offside unless they are certain the rule has violated.
Matthaus's teammates Thomas Hassler and Jurgen Klinsmann waited under the pop-fly pass like center fielders as the Bolivians moved forward. Four years ago, offside undoubtedly would have been called. Today, Referee Arturo Brizio Carter of Mexico swallowed his whistle.
Standing outside the penalty box, Hassler brilliantly deflected the pass with his chest to a waiting Klinsmann, Germany's star striker. Bolivian goalkeeper Carlos Trucco made a desperate foray upfield, but he was left stranded and Klinsmann simply had to punch the ball into an empty goal.
"Once I got the ball, there was almost nothing I could do wrong," Klinsmann said.
Xabier Azkargorta, the Basque doctor who is Bolivia's coach, said he thought offside should have been called and that Hassler had appeared to touch the ball with a forbidden hand. Naturally, Berti Vogts, the German coach, saw nothing resembling offside.
"The referee followed the new instructions to the letter," Vogts said.
The defeat spoiled Bolivia's first appearance in the World Cup since 1950. Eight thousand Bolivians traveled to Chicago from one of Latin America's poorest country for today's game, using soccer to promote a nascent democracy and economic equilibrium.
"This is our chance to overcome our loser mentality," said Ricardo Pereyra, 29, who works for the Bolivian national chamber of commerce. "This is the most historic day in this century for our country."
 
'A Universal Language'
 President Clinton attended the game and greeted Bolivian President Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozado, as well as German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, proclaiming that "the love of soccer is a universal language that binds us all together." But it was clear from the beginning Germany had not only love, but the discipline and precision to prevail.
Given the unfamiliarity of soccer to most Americans, organizers used the country's most familiar host, Winfrey, to welcome the game to the United States. She recovered quickly from her spill to emcee a tasteful pregame show that featured a parade of the national costumes of the 24 participating nations. Even a cacophony of fireworks could not distract spectators for long from the oppressive heat, which Klinsmann, the German star called "brutal."
 
Etcheverry Sent Off
 With one final attempt to equalize the score, Bolivia sent its star striker, Marco (El Diablo, the Devil) Etcheverry, onto the field with 11 minutes remaining. Etcheverry suffered a severe knee injury last fall and has not recovered sufficiently to play a full game. Today, four minutes after he entered the game he was ejected for kicking at Matthaus after the German sweeper had leveled Etcheverry with an elbow. Bolivia then had to play with 10 men. Etcheverry is suspended for Bolivia's next game, Thursday against South Korea.
"I went in and I was nervous; these things happen," Etcheverry said. "I'm sorry to Bolivia. If I did kick him, it's part of the game."
Whatever the heat had not sapped from Bolivia's determination, Etcheverry's red card did.

HEADLINE: Graduate Students Give Grades a Boost

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Making the Grades" (editorial June 5) identifies causes of college grade inflation, including promotion of student self-esteem, professors who are reluctant to make waves and administrators who want to satisfy the customers. But you omit one reason of major proportions. 
 At many universities, grading in most undergraduate lecture courses is done not by the professors, but by graduate students.
Lacking in experience and preoccupied with their own studies, these graders are often even more reluctant than professors to face indignant recipients of C's, D's or F's. The temptation is therefore strong to follow the path of least resistance by awarding inflated grades.
Professors can guard against this academic hazard by engaging themselves in grading sufficiently to insure that grades in their courses reflect their own standards and by dealing with student complaints themselves, instead of leaving them to graders.
 
HENRY ASHBY TURNER JR.
Bass Professor of History
Yale University
New Haven, June 8, 1994

HEADLINE: Church, in an Era of Change, Is Misunderstood;
Women in Priesthood

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Pope John Paul II's statement that "the church has no authority whatsoever to confer priestly ordination on women" is an admission of impotence unacceptable to many devoted Catholics. That statement, of course, bespeaks the papal posture, reflecting his wisdom and will on the topic. 
 "To the Altar," Anna Quindlen's June 4 column, offers another wisdom: Many women are serving as priests without benefit of sacramental ordination and without the common titles. Sister Virginia Welsh, she observes, is pastoring a Roman Catholic parish in Ohio, but with the title of "pastoral administrator." Similar positions are held elsewhere. Many parishes in New York City have women in charge of pastoral programs. They minister directly to people with profound needs -- the impoverished, abandoned, abused, unemployed and homebound elderly, and they do this with exquisite determination and tenderness.
Without official recognition, they are spending their lives in "imago Dei," the image of God.
In their personalized caring for people, they hear confessions, but cannot give sacramental absolution. Although many work to beautify the mass, they do not preside in public.
The "church" that the Pope sees from his seat at the Vatican may not seem able to ordain women. The church in many other places would have little difficulty in so doing. It is from the traditional domain of the Holy Spirit known as "sensus fidelium" that affirmation comes. The sense of the faithful has engendered other changes thought unacceptable by other pontiffs.
What is ominous within the Pope's statement is the condemnation of discussion. For the women who believe God is calling them to priesthood, silence is not acceptable. The command to be silent is a command to be unfaithful both to call and conscience. This conversation must continue.
 
(Sister) CAMILLE D'ARIENZO
Brooklyn, June 8, 1994

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Nonprofit Beneficiary
Q. If a nonprofit organization is the beneficiary of an individual retirement account or a Keogh account, must the organization pay taxes on the proceeds?
C. RICHARD BECKER, Manhattan
 
A. When a tax-exempt organization is the beneficiary of an I.R.A., the distribution is taxable in the same manner as if it had been made to the deceased owner.
 But when a tax-exempt organization receives a Keogh account, some portions may not be taxable, depending on several factors, including the participant's nondeductible contributions.
 "A nonprofit beneficiary of a Keogh account may be able to use special tax treatments for lump-sum distributions, such as five-year or 10-year averaging and capital gain treatment," said Ronald L. Noll, head of a Malvern, Pa., accounting firm bearing his name. "And if the distribution is due to the employee's death, the nonprofit organization may be able to treat the payment as a lump-sum distribution, whether or not he or she had five years of participation in the plan."

Medigap Abroad
Q. What are the economics of a medigap policy when retiring to a foreign country?
Anna-Liisa Rintala, Manhattan
 
A. The purpose of a medigap policy, private insurance that supplements Medicare, is to pay costs not covered by the Federal Medicare program. Medicare generally does not cover health services outside the United States, the primary exception being when a hospital in Canada or Mexico is more accessible than an American hospital.
 "Most medigap plans provide some coverage for people who are out of the country on a temporary basis," said Rebecca Moore of the American Association of Retired Persons. "Medigap plans do not offer coverage for people who are living out of the country permanently."

I.R.A. Into Fixed Annuity
Q. Can I transfer an individual retirement account to a fixed annuity so I will not be required to pay taxes until the money is withdrawn?
DORIS BROWN, Manhattan
 
A. Yes, you can. One of the categories of tax-deferred accounts established by the law creating individual retirement accounts is an individual retirement annuity.
 But many financial advisers say you should not switch your I.R.A. into an annuity, because it represents an unnecessary duplication of the tax deferral. Money invested in an I.R.A. grows on a tax-deferred basis, as does money invested in an annuity, explained Avery E. Neumark, a partner of Weber Lipshie & Company, a New York accounting firm. Other types of investments probably make more sense.
 "If you wish to roll your account over," Mr. Neumark said, "you must do so within 60 days of the distribution from the original plan. And only one such rollover may be made in any one-year period."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 2, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An answer in the Q & A column of the Your Money pages on June 18, for a question about the beneficiaries of individual retirement accounts and Keough accounts, misstated the tax implications for some beneficiaries. A beneficiary that is a tax-exempt organization does not have to pay income taxes on distributions from such accounts.

LENGTH: 597 words

HEADLINE: 'Looking at the Sun'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I feel obliged to set the record straight about F. M. Scherer's comments on my book "Looking at the Sun: The Rise of the New East Asian Economic and Political System" (May 8). 
 A reader of this review would have little idea what the book concerned, since Mr. Scherer devoted most of his comments to factual quibbles with three or four pages of the book. The points he makes would not be worth resurrecting except that his "corrections" to my argument are wrong.
Mr. Scherer says that I exaggerate in claiming that Japan had "virtually no semiconductor industry in 1970." In the book, this comes at the end of a long section detailing what Japan had accomplished in semiconductors by 1970. It will be obvious to any reader that it is meant to highlight how much more Japan achieved afterward. Mr. Scherer says, moreover, that the discoveries of the Japanese scientist Leo Esaki demonstrate Japan's pioneering efforts in the semiconductor business. He does not point out that Mr. Esaki spent virtually his whole professional life (1960 through 1992) working in the United States, for I.B.M., precisely because Japanese companies offered such limited opportunities early in his career.
Mr. Scherer says that I exaggerate in claiming that economists believe "there can never be too much competition in a market." The sentences immediately before and after this one make clear that it is being presented as an overstated, straw-man view. For instance, the next sentence says, "In practice everyone recognizes the limits of these theories."
Mr. Scherer says that I err in dating a memory-chip shortage to 1985, rather than 1988. My book says, accurately, that the shortage occurred in 1988 but that the first warnings of it came in 1985.
None of these points is of real importance, and yet they were the only issues Mr. Scherer chose to deal with in his review. The larger question is why a reviewer would concentrate on minor issues and neglect to say anything about the main arguments in a very long book. The explanation may lie in the book's fundamental point: that economic theories are the wrong tools to use for understanding modern Asia's development. Instead, the book says, we should emphasize the effect of Asia's history and the realities of daily life there. Mr. Scherer is an economic theorist who (as he states in the review) knows very little about Asia's history or current realities. That he would disagree with the book is not surprising; why he would be considered the right reviewer is harder to say.
 
JAMES FALLOWS
Washington
 
F. M. Scherer replies:
The first quarter of my review summarized James Fallows's main argument; the remainder was critical. My "factual quibbles," all supportable in a longer reply, were illustrative. Numerous similar but unreported quibbles underlay my central point: that Mr. Fallows characterizes simplistically and inaccurately what real-world economic analyses teach and the semiconductor industry's history. One cannot formulate sound economic policy on the basis of a travelogue, however fascinating.
My review was not so modest as to state that I know very little about Asia's history or current realities. It said that I was an infrequent traveler to Asia. Building upon high-technology industry research extending back to 1958, I have followed (and taught and written about) Japanese industrial development with intense interest since my first interviews with companies there in 1973. To paraphrase Yogi Berra, if you understand the game, looking even from a distance, you can see a lot.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

TITLE: LOOKING AT THE SUN (BOOK)

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Laurel Graeber 

 BODY:
FATHERHOOD IN AMERICA: A History
By Robert L. Griswold. Basic Books, $13.
The author documents the evolving role of fathers, from the aloof disciplinarian of earlier days to the nurturing New Age dad. Interestingly, demographic trends have resulted in fewer opportunities for male parenting just at a time when it has also gained status. Mr. Griswold "persuasively charts all sorts of attitudinal changes," Michael Kammen said here last year. 

THE LYING DAYS
By Nadine Gordimer. Penguin, $10.95.
Originally published in 1953, this Nobel Prize-winning author's first novel, written in the first person, focuses on the adolescent experiences of a white South African girl and her growing awareness of racial injustice. The New York Times's reviewer, James Stern, called it "as original and as beautifully written as a novel by Virginia Woolf." Penguin has also reissued Ms. Gordimer's OCCASION FOR LOVING ($10.95), a novel that revolves around the illicit love affair between an upper-class married white woman and a black South African painter. Their story is "a painfully clear mirror for the brutalities" surrounding them, Martin Levin said here in 1963.
AT THE HIGHEST LEVELS:
The Inside Story of the End of the Cold War
By Michael R. Beschloss and Strobe Talbott.
Back Bay/Little Brown, $12.95.
The authors analyze the relationships among the top officials in the United States and the Soviet Union between 1989 and 1991, arguing that President George Bush supported Mikail S. Gorbachev for too long and Boris N. Yeltsin not soon enough. Last year our reviewer, Godfrey Hodgson, called the book "a useful and readable account." THE UNITED STATES AND THE END OF THE COLD WAR: Implications, Reconsiderations, Provocations, by John Lewis Gaddis (Oxford University, $11.95), presents the postwar period as actually a time of great peace, and indicates the challenges the future presents. The author's "skill . . . is a quality we need much more of," Alan Tonelson said here in 1992.
THE PROFESSOR OF DESIRE
By Philip Roth. Vintage International, $10.
Just restored to print, this novel concerns the romantic adventures of David Kepesh, teacher of literature. His experiences demonstrate that desire and happiness, though powerfully linked, rarely coexist. In 1977 our reviewer, Vance Bourjaily, described it as "a fine display of literary skills . . . moving when it needs to be."
THE NEANDERTALS: Of Skeletons, Scientists, and Scandal
By Erik Trinkaus and Pat Shipman. Vintage, $15.
The prehuman Neanderthals -- and their ultimate contributions to modern man -- have been the subject of endless debate. These scholars assert that they were actually closer to us, in genes and temperament, than is usually supposed. The book offers a "detailed historical perspective," Malcolm W. Browne said here last year.
THE VIRGIN SUICIDES
By Jeffrey Eugenides. Warner, $10.99.
Several men describe their lifelong obsession with five young women, the Lisbon sisters of Grosse Pointe, Mich., whose sexually repressive Roman Catholic household drove the girls to suicidal extremes. Last year our reviewer, Suzanne Berne, said, "Mr. Eugenides is blessed with the storyteller's most magical gift."
NEW YORK, NEW YORK: How the Apartment House
Transformed the Life of the City (1869-1930)
By Elizabeth Hawes. Owl/Holt, $16.95.
Every New Yorker knows that his city is unlike anywhere else in the United States, but this book explains why: the advent of high-rise living, which helped boost the metropolis's economic fortunes. The author is "an engaging stylist," Kenneth T. Jackson said here last year. The fate of a New York commercial building is discussed in HIGH RISE: How 1,000 Men and Women Worked Around the Clock for Five Years and Lost $200 Million Building a Skyscraper, by Jerry Adler (Harper Perennial, $13). At issue is the developer Ian Bruce Eichner's creation of 1540 Broadway (now the Bertelsmann Building). Last year our reviewer, David W. Dunlap, called the book "a valuable postscript to the latest boom-and-bust cycle." Just as synonymous with Manhattan as the skyscraper is its one island of green, the subject of THE PARK AND THE PEOPLE: A History of Central Park, by Roy Rosenzweig and Elizabeth Blackmar (Owl/Holt, $19.95). The authors argue that the landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted deserves less credit for the park than the workers and common citizens who remolded its uses. The result is "a deeply felt celebration," Robert Fishman said here in 1992.
A CALCULATED RISK
By Katherine Neville. Ballantine, $5.99.
Verity Banks, an aptly named heroine, decides to teach her ungrateful employers at the Bank of the World a lesson by showing them just how easily their computer system can be sabotaged. In 1992 our reviewer, Newgate Callendar, said her adventure "churns up wave after wave of excitement."
THE CHILD GARDEN: Or, A Low Comedy
By Geoff Ryman. Orb/Tom Doherty Associates, $13.95.
This science fiction novel by the author of "Was" imagines a future filled with virus-induced learning, genetic engineering and early death. Milena Shibush puts her stamp on this world, and in doing so, "painfully and even heroically matures," Gerald Jonas said here in 1990.
FOLLY
By Susan Minot. Washington Square/Pocket Books, $10.
The two decades following the outbreak of World War I are the setting for this novel, which explores the thwarted passions of upper-crust Bostonians who let propriety rule over their hearts. In 1992 our reviewer, Anthony Bailey, described it as "a smartly written book."
 LAUREL GRAEBER

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review
