HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
When a Prussian King Played Decorator

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
CAST-IRON OBJECTS WERE never glamorous -- even when they were new at the beginning of the 19th century. So King Friedrich Wilhelm III of Prussia decided he would try to make his nation, if not rich, at least solvent by encouraging their sale. An assortment of the weighty trinkets was prominently installed in a parlor in one of his Potsdam palaces. No one knows which pieces he chose or how long the room was left intact. But the style remained popular in decorating for decades, the iron foundries flourished, and production spread throughout Central Europe.
Today such exquisitely detailed matte-black objects are little in fashion beyond the borders of where they were produced, in the lands now known as Germany, Austria, the Czech Republic, Hungary and Slovakia. Many gimmicky if charming curiosities abound among the diverse artifacts assembled in "Cast Iron From Central Europe, 1800-1850," an exhibition at the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts in Manhattan, through Aug. 7. 
 Based in part on a smaller show presented in 1992 by the Austrian Museum of Applied Arts in Vienna, the Bard exhibition was organized by Elisabeth Schmuttermeier, curator of metalwork at the Austrian museum, and Derek Ostergard, dean of the Bard Graduate Center. While the majority of the objects are from Vienna, 80 were lent by the Birmingham Museum of Art in Alabama.
The show's 230 items -- chairs, tables, candlesticks, incense burners, jewelry, clocks, desk accessories, fans, buttons, pincushions and perfume-bottle holders -- were designed to appeal to the growing middle class. Absent from this show are more utilitarian iron articles -- pots, pans and stoves -- that were made in volume at the same time elsewhere and have never gone out of style.
Why, then, did cast-iron objects multiply in some but not all of the ore-rich regions of continental Europe?
For one thing, says Mr. Ostergard, the Prussian and Austrian rulers gave iron a political spin. Crippled by Napoleon's 1806 victory over the Prussian army and the seven-year occupation by French forces that followed, Prussia under Friedrich Wilhelm began to fight back on the economic front. In 1813, the King urged his people to end Napoleonic oppression by exchanging their gold, silver and other precious materials for ornamental cast iron, donating their valuables to the fatherland.
The response was overwhelming: in Berlin alone, 160,000 rings were turned in and exchanged for cast-iron ones suitably engraved "I gave gold for iron." And during the Wars of Liberation that ended in 1815, blackened iron statuary replaced many bronzes in the public monuments of Berlin, thanks mostly to the efforts of Karl Friedrich Shinkel, the German architect.
During the period, nationalist fervor surged and was even seen on the postcard-size cast-iron plaques depicting German military heroes or town scenes that were the New Year's greeting cards of the time. While nostalgia seems to have inspired the night light shaped like a miniature Gothic tower, the inkstands cast in the forms of a sleeping cherub, Shakespeare's Falstaff or Napoleon's tomb are examples of early German kitsch. When a design is superbly wrought, as is the potted iron sunflower with realistically veined and bent leaves, its outmoded purpose as a watch holder seems anything but trivial.
AN OUTGROWTH OF THE innovative technology that had spearheaded the Industrial Revolution in the 18th century in Britain, the cast-iron style took many forms. The English, French and Russians concentrated on engineering marvels -- bridges, tunnels, pavilions, gates and railroad fittings -- limiting the production of smaller items to stoves and hardware.
Nevertheless, the look of the Central European iron objects exhibited at Bard owes much to another late-18th-century British development -- Josiah Wedgwood's basaltlike ceramics. To match them, the gray metal was given an ink-black flat finish, which became standard for all cast-iron artifacts.
In fact, basalt-toned busts of German rulers or writers decorated table tops, lacy black metal tiaras and necklaces were worn to balls, and candlesticks the color of tar were seen everywhere in homes. Not the least of the attractions of these decorations, with their vaguely funereal look, was thrift: they represented good design at a moderate price.
Mr. Ostergard cites another reason: "Cast iron was probably more appropriate in German interiors, because they were not as opulently colored as those in Britain and France," he says.
"Then, its simplicity and heaviness, which were part of its basic appeal, caused its demise. Groups of iron objects certainly seem somber, which may have quickened the style's end by mid-century."
Today, cast iron is enthusiastically collected in Central Europe. And reproductions are sold in the gift shops of German museums, a development Mr. Ostergard applauds. "Anything that was good the first time around," he says, "can be good again."

HEADLINE: Brazil Inflation

 BODY:
To the Editor: We returned in March from three weeks in Brazil. Travelers should be aware of the chaotic situation of the currency. The official rate of inflation exceeded 40 percent in February, and the exchange rate of the dollar more or less follows inflation, climbing 1 or 2 percent daily. As a result it becomes necessary to change money daily. Another consequence is that many stores, hotels and restaurants do not accept credit cards. And if they do, they charge a premium of over 40 percent. This makes it necessary to deal in large amounts of cash.
A final difficulty is that not all banks will even change traveler's checks. We found plenty of cambios in Rio and Sao Paulo, but in Florianop olis, a vacation center for Brazilians in the southern state of Santa Catarina, the American Express office was unable to cash its own traveler's checks. 
 Because inflation is so rapid we found that hotel rates were quoted in United States dollars, but were to be paid in Brazilian cruzeiros calculated at the rate of exchange on the day you check out. This meant changing money at the last minute.
 
PHILIP H. SMITH JR.
Chapel Hill, N.C.

BYLINE: By JANET PIORKO 

 BODY:
SAVING ON EIRE Citing a stronger dollar, two tour companies have reduced the prices of Ireland trips from last summer's levels. C.I.E. Tours International has a one-week driving tour that starts at $921 a person through August; last year the same tour started at $1,038. It includes round-trip air fare from New York or Boston on Aer Lingus; a minimum-category rental car with unlimited mileage; six nights' accommodation at farmhouses and bed-and-breakfasts throughout the country; Irish breakfast daily, local tax and service charge. Contact (800) 243-8687.
For those who prefer a group tour, Cosmos Tourama has reduced its 10-day Scenic Ireland itinerary by $129; this year the program costs $629 to $664 a person. Prices include bus transportation, superior tourist-class hotels with private bath, daily Irish breakfast, five dinners and some sightseeing. Air fare is extra. Destinations include Dublin, the Cliffs of Moher, the Ring of Kerry, Donegal and Connemara. There are weekly departures to Oct. 7; space is limited on peak summer dates. Information: (800) 851-0728, extension 518. 
 HOTELS IN EUROPE Travelers who fly British Airways round trip to any of seven European cities this summer can get six nights' lodging for the price of three at selected hotels. To qualify, passengers must purchase a round-trip British Airways published air fare in economy class. They must leave Sunday through Wednesday from one of eight cities in the United States (including New York). Travel to Europe must begin before Aug. 28 and the hotel stay must be completed by Sept. 4. There are 14 participating hotels in London, 10 in Paris, 3 each in Amsterdam and Brussels and 2 each in Geneva, Madrid and Munich. For example, a six-night stay for two people at the Chesterfield Hotel in London would cost $336; at the Mercure Munich in Germany it would cost $366. Information: (800) 247-9297.

SUMMER IN SPAIN The 445-room Hotel Arts Barcelona, the first hotel in Europe to be managed by Ritz-Carlton, has two packages for summer visitors, good from July 1 to Sept. 5. The three-night Mediterranean Escape starts at $472 for two people in a double room, plus 15 percent tax; a seven-night Mediterranean Experience starts at $1,050. The hotel, which opened in January, is situated in the Olympic Village area of the city. Information: (800) 241-3333.
SEASONAL SAVINGS During summer in the Northern Hemisphere, when it is winter in Australia, Orient Flexi-Pax Tours is offering 10-day tours to that country starting at $1,399 a person, double occupancy. The price includes air fare from the West Coast of the United States, all transportation within Australia, hotels, daily buffet breakfast and sightseeing. (Air fare from the East Coast is $325 additional.) The itinerary includes four nights in Sydney and three in Cairns. The July 27 departure is $1,399; Sept. 7 is $1,499, and Sept. 28, $1,599. The company also offers a five-night Sydney-only package starting at $899, including air fare from the West Coast. (Air fare from the East Coast is $275 a person extra.) The $899 price is good for departures July 18, Aug. 1 and 22; September departures are $100 more. Call (800) 545-5540 or (212) 692-9550.

HEADLINE: The Lazy, Hazy Vacation-Home Market

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
A WEEKEND house in the Hamptons. A condominium in Vermont. A place at the Jersey Shore. A cabin in Maine. A cottage upstate New York. A country home in Connecticut.
Before the crash of the residential real estate market in the Northeast in the late 80's, a second home was often considered an affordable luxury among the affluent and a not unreachable dream for many in the middle class. 
 Since then, a weak economy, demographic trends, changing tastes and new tax laws have depressed much of the second-home market in the Northeast.
To be sure, many brokers report sales slightly ahead of last year's pace, in part because of the recent increase in interest rates and a fear among prospective buyers that rates will continue to rise.
Inventories, however, are still high in many popular locales, and home construction is only a fraction of what it was a decade ago. Sale prices are also, in many cases, flat or falling, especially for properties in the middle of the market, the $200,000 to $400,000 range. In many places, they remain about 30 percent off their 1987 highs.
"We have had a lot of lookers, but no takers," said Scott Hutchins of Rhinebeck, N.Y., who this summer reduced the price on his three-bedroom Dutch colonial home on three-quarters of an acre to $204,000 from $234,000. "The main issue seems to be money. Someone who buys it has to be able to not only swing a second mortgage, but also pay the maintenance and the taxes."
Such buyers still exist, of course. Joseph and Judith Dirnfeld of the Upper East Side of Manhattan, for example, recently bought a three-bedroom cottage on half an acre in Bridgehampton, L.I., south of Montauk Highway, for $310,000.
The Dirnfelds, however, paid cash. He is a commodities broker; she is an investment banker. "It's a good deal when you compare it with the $60,000 that you would have to pay to rent out here," Ms. Dirnfeld said, referring to the seasonal rate.
Precise sales statistics on second homes are difficult to come by because second homes are defined by use rather than construction. Moreover, the best studies, by the Bureau of the Census and the National Association of Realtors, have not been updated in several years.
For the most part, though, second homes are the domain of wealthy people like the Dirnfelds. While about 65 percent of the nation's households own a primary residence, only about 4 percent own a second home, according to a 1990 report by the National Association of Home Builders, a trade organization in Washington. Further, because of the high cost of land and housing, the Northeast, except for northern New England, has the lowest percentage of second homes in the nation; the Upper Midwest has the most.
"There has been a substantial decline in the rate of construction of second homes and homes for seasonal and occasional use," said Gopahl Ahluwalia, director of research for the National Association of Home Builders. "It fell to about 50,000 a year in 1991 from a high point of 125,000 in the 80's."
Mr. Ahluwalia says that there are about 5.2 million second homes and that they are being built at a current rate of about 75,000 a year. "It is on the upswing somewhat," he said.
Brokers in the New York metropolitan area believe that the dearth of construction will start to reduce the glut of homes on the market. Shrinking inventories will then lead to price increases.
In the meantime, the region's second-home market appears to be, for the most part, in a holding pattern.
"WE are busier than we were in 1992 and 1993, but the pricing is off, probably about 10 percent," said Paul Spera, a real estate agent in Stowe, Vt., and a former regional vice president of the National Association of Realtors.
In the Hamptons, Peter Hallock, president of Allan M. Schneider and Associates in East Hampton, said that the sales volume was higher this year and that prices had climbed back almost to mid-80's levels.
"They are not as extreme as they were in the 80's, but they are high," he said. "In the 80's, prices were inflated, now they are full."
He said that the high end of the market, homes selling for over $1 million, and those at the low end, under $500,000, were moving. Homes priced in between were having more difficulty selling.
Elsewhere, on Cape Cod, a popular vacation home location for Connecticut and New Jersey residents, the average price of a home, $144,419, is 26 percent less than it was five years ago. "Sales are up, prices are down, still declining," said Charles F. Lockhart, executive vice president of the Cape Cod and Islands Board of Realtors in South Yarmouth, Mass. "There has been some new construction going up, though, and that's good to see."
On Long Beach Island, on the Jersey Shore, Jean Luedtke, a manager with HCH Real Estate in Harvey Cedars, said that her company had sold 57 homes in the first four months of 1992 and 61 in 1993, but 53 in the first four months of this year. "The weather was bad," she said. "People couldn't get out of their homes to come down."
She added that the average sale price had probably increased, but only because of the sale of a few high-end properties. "The expensive homes are moving," she said. "We had one listed for $3.85 million in Loveladies, and seven brokers said they had buyers for it."
Much of the decline in the second-home market can be attributed to the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which took away the deductibility for passive losses that had allowed investors to deduct losses from other forms of investments.
Second-home owners can still deduct their mortgage interest and taxes, provided the mortgages don't add up to more than $1 million.
The income is also tax free if the home is rented out for only 14 days or less. If the house is rented for more than 14 days it can be classified as a rental property, which allows deductions -- up to the amount of rental income generated -- for a variety of expenses, including insurance, maintenance, utilities and improvements, during the period when the house is considered a rental.
In the aftermath of the tax change, it was believed that second homes would start to sell briskly again when the Baby Boom generation, whose ranks are now, roughly, people 32 to 48 years old, reached their peak earning years of about 45 to 54 and had young children and teen-agers who would enjoy a beach house or a ski condo.
Though some brokers and demographers are still forecasting this trend, the average second-home buyer in the Northeast since 1992 hasn't been a typical Baby Boomer but, like the Dirnfelds, a DINK -- a couple (usually of Baby Boomer age) but with a double income (usually large) and no kids.
"When we qualify buyers, we find that 80 percent of them are DINKs," Mr. Spera said.
Ms. Luedtke added that her clients rarely include retirees or families with children. "What we are getting are young and middle-aged professional couples without kids who need an escape," she said.
SUCH high-income households, many brokers believe, may be the only ones able to afford a second home in today's cost-conscious economy.
"There is a lack of appetite out there," Mr. Spera said. "People are really assessing whether they want to have a second home or vacation property. The central issue seems to be whether they will have a use for it." "A lot of people say, 'We like it, but will we use it? Why not rent for two weeks?' "
Vacation homes generally rent for $800 to $2,000 a week during the high seasons, although some areas, like the Hamptons, are more expensive.
Mr. Spera said that potential buyers today were balking at paying two mortgages and sometimes three; it is not uncommon to make a down payment on a second home by taking out a second mortgage against the equity in a primary home.
Indeed, for many of these buyers, an additional mortgage makes it difficult to meet the standard for the maximum amount of mortgage debt, relative to income, that is acceptable to a lender. Generally, lenders insist that buyers pay no more than 28 percent of their gross income in total mortgage payments.
Then there are local property taxes, which can cost thousands of dollars a year; utility bills, landscaping and annual repairs.
"People are not jumping back into a highly leveraged household budget," Mr. Spera said. "They are very cautious shoppers."
Lenders are just as leery of the second-home market, so much so that owners often provide financing. With seller financing, the buyer makes a down payment and monthly payments at an agreed-upon interest rate to the seller, not to a bank.
Richard Clow, a financial planner from Berkeley Heights, N.J., recently bought a four-bedroom contemporary home on the bay side of the highway in Harvey Ceders with seller financing. He bought the home for $320,000 with a $70,000 down payment; it had been listed for $500,000.
Mr. Clow and his wife, Susan, a caterer, intend to rent the house during the 12-week summer season at $2,000 to $2,400 a week and use it themselves the rest of the year. Mr. Clow also plans to use the home year-round in about four or five years.
"I anticipate having grandchildren and I think it will be a great place for them to go," he said.
Although he is considering the property for use rather than investment, Mr. Clow also believes that second-home prices have bottomed out.
"I would anticipate getting a 4 percent growth on my investment each year," he added.
Many potential vacation-home buyers these days, however, do not want to go back to the same summer home year after year. They also want to take short three-day and four-day weekend holidays instead of the month-long vacations that second homes accommodate.
ALTHOUGH places within a day's drive remain popular for vacation homes, New Yorkers are increasingly buying second homes outside the Northeast, especially in areas like Florida (Orlando, South Miami Beach, the Keys, the Southwest Coast around Naples) and South Carolina (Hilton Head and Kiawah Islands).
"The average age of someone coming into Naples now is 43, and a lot of them are from New York," said A. J. Fischer, owner of Century 21 AAdvisors in Naples.
Besides the warm weather, a prime attraction is the price of housing. An average two-bedroom condominium unit in Naples, furnished, about six miles from the Gulf of Mexico, costs about $65,000.
"They rent their homes out for $2,000 a month in January and February and use it the rest of the time for long weekends and vacations," Ms. Fischer said.
In the last few years, vacation homes have also become primary residences for people who are self-employed or able to "telecommute." For some, the appeal is moving away from the high housing costs of the city and the suburbs; for others, quality of life is a major factor.
MR. HALLOCK noted that more and more New Yorkers were seeking to make a home in the Hamptons their year-round residence and that, if they did not have to be in the city five days a week, were keeping a small apartment in the city as a second home.
Others plan to keep one residence in a second-home area and make an occasional long commute. "This is more of a trend than anything else I have seen," said Cindy A. White, a broker with Rhinebeck Realty Ltd. in Rhinebeck, N.Y.
"I had two people last week, a graphic artist and a writer, both from New York, who are looking to move up here and commute into the city one or two days a week."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Subdivisions Make a Comeback After 4-Year Hiatus

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
IN recent months Connecticut developers have been plunging back into the business of building new homes in multi-unit residential communities, ending a hiatus of more than four years.
"At least two dozen subdivisions of 16 to more than 200 units are under construction or breaking ground," said Joanne Carroll, a director of both the Connecticut Association of Home Builders and the parallel national organization. "Developers are picking the best locations in towns with good transportation and good schools." 
 And no one, she added, is building without signed-up buyers in hand.
"It's still a very volatile market," said Sandy Bergin, research supervisor for the state's Department of Housing. Housing permits, accurate to 95 percent of actual starts, were down to 1,955 in April 1994 compared with 2,314 in April 1993 -- the latest available year-to-year figures -- but permits for April this year were up 30.8 percent from March.
Most homes in the new projects are priced from the mid $100,000's to the low $200,000's, competing favorably with resales that frequently require additional fix-up costs. Increases in mortgage interest rates and in the costs of lumber and sheetrock have been reflected in price rises of up to $10,000 a house, shutting out some low-end buyers, but sales are flourishing, particularly in the central part of the state.
The busiest areas, Ms. Carroll said, are Glastonbury, Wallingford, Cheshire, Newington and Milford, where property taxes run from a low of $24 per $1,000 of assessment in Cheshire to a high of $41.80 in Milford.
Two of the largest subdivisions being built, with more than 200 units, are in Milford and Cromwell. Houses and the land under them will be owned and maintained by the buyers, but common outdoor areas will be owned and maintained by a residents' association. Homeowners will pay monthly association fees, and additions or other changes to the homes may be prohibited or subject to approval under association bylaws.
"Milford is one of the hottest housing markets in the state," Ms. Carroll said, because it is at the Fairfield County border of New Haven County and has access to Metro North's commuter railroad and Interstates 95 and 91, the Merritt Parkway and Route 8.
Lexington Green, a 100-acre subdivision, is rising there near I-95 Exit 37, developed by Baker Firestone of Pleasantville, N.Y. Six house plans designed by EDI Architects of New York and Houston range from 1,338 square feet at $161,900 to 2,256 square feet at $209,900. Baker Firestone bought the land and the approved site plan from a former developer in 1993. Since September, when sales began, 110 homes have been sold, mostly to young families and largely from plans. Three furnished models opened in May.
BY 1996 a total of 261 houses will have been built on approximately 8,000-square-foot level lots fanning out from a green. Standard features include great rooms with cathedral ceilings, fireplaces, all appliances except refrigerators; basements, 3 and 4 bedrooms, and 1- or 2-car garages. Air-conditioning and upgrades could bring the price of the largest model to $250,000.
The Cromwell subdivision, under way on the 220-acre grounds of the Tournament Players Golf Club at River Highlands, will have a model open for inspection in August. The exterior of the model was completed in time for the annual Greater Hartford Open, to be played tomorrow through Saturday.
Building homes at golf courses is nothing new -- about 50 private residences surround the Westchester Country Club in Harrison and 24 are off the ninth hole of the Silvermine Golf Club in Norwalk -- but the Cromwell homes will be clustered on an aggregate of 64 acres within the golf course grounds, on knolls overlooking greens or ponds, nestled in wooded areas or set on a cliff with broad views of the Connecticut River and the Meshomasic State Forest beyond.
The complex, River Highlands, will have 202 homes priced from the mid-$200,000's to the high $300,000's. It is being developed jointly by PGA Golf Course Properties, based in the Sawgrass Country Club in Ponte Vedra, Fla., and Daylor River Properties Inc., based in Stamford, a limited partnership headed by Harry and Jerry Day.
"Our market will be empty-nesters, soon-to-be empty-nesters, dual-income couples and some weekend golfers from New York," said Harry Day. Young families generally are put off by the juxtaposition of children and flying golf balls.
Up to 30 percent of buyers are expected to be golfers attracted to the course, ranked No. 3 in Connecticut by Golf Week Magazine. Residents can become full members at a 10 percent discount from a low-five-figure initiation fee, or for a lower sum may become house members and use the dining rooms and clubhouse, or simply exercise their automatic free access to the club's swimming pool and tennis courts. The management of the club declined to give information on dues and other fees.
NINETY-EIGHT units will be detached one-family houses of 2,450 to 3,000 square feet. The rest will be side-by-side duplexes of 1,800 to 2,450 square feet, all air-conditioned, with 2-car garages and decks, and all conforming to three attached and three detached styles designed by the Martin Architectural Group of Philadelphia.
Living rooms and master bedrooms will have large windows and the more spectacular views will be reflected in the house's cost. Fireplaces will be open to living and dining rooms, or dining and family rooms; master bedrooms may be on the first or second floor, kitchens will have up-to-the minute appliances, bathrooms will have Jacuzzis and there will be large dressing-room-closets.
Since 1980, PGA Golf Course Properties, a subsidiary of PGA Tours, based in Ponte Vedra Beach, has built 14 such joint-venture developments with local partners across the country and one in Japan. "Most of them are larger than the one in Cromwell and more expensive," said Vernon Kelly, president of the corporation. Piper Glen in Charlotte, N.C. has 3,000 homes, Sawgrass has almost 4,000.
"These are definitely not starter homes," said Mr. Kelly, noting that "prices at Cromwell are an anomaly because the golf course was already there, with the land available at a good price." The other courses and homes were built together from scratch.
"It's very difficult to pay for land and a golf course purely out of golf revenues," Mr. Kelly said. "You have to have some of the cost assumed by another entity like a developer who can sell houses."
The Daylor partnership bought its land in 1990 for around $3 million but began building the first model home only last month.
"We feel that now is the time to start," said Harry Day. "This project has a five- to eight-year period for completion and we have done exhaustive market studies to identify a special buyer. It's a different horizon than a one-year project for the general market, where you might still want to wait."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Cutting Costs in A Condo

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
JUST as the budgets of so many condominiums and co-ops seem to have been pared to the very marrow to avoid an increase in monthly charges, new ideas are emerging for continued cost savings.
No wonder. Either because they fear for their jobs or the value of their units, residents are becoming as cutthroat as corporate chieftains. "At my conference last year the most heavily attended workshops were the ones on controlling costs," said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives. 
 The resulting pressure is thus speedily becoming the mother of ingenuity. Ken Budd, editor of the bimonthly magazine of the Community Associations Institute (C.A.I.), the national network of elected officials and professionals working in the community ownership field, recently asked 20 managers around the country for cost-saving ideas. There were so many suggestions that he couldn't find space to use all of them.
Since the most obvious cutbacks have no doubt already been made, the experts suggest starting by re-examining the tried-and-true approach to seemingly fixed costs.
Take insurance, for example. As the senior vice president of Condominium Insurance Specialists of Arlington Heights, Ill., Barbara Wick monitors hundreds of associations. She maintains that certain aspects of coverage viewed for years as sacred -- and therefore rarely tinkered with during any insurance review -- may not be so sacred after all.
Among her favorites is the service-insurance contract on boiler machinery and other mechanical equipment. Routinely renewed year after year, the money might better be spent adding to reserves, says Ms. Wick. Figured over the life of any item, she has estimated that these particular premiums often exceed the cost of replacing components or even the item itself.
Ms. Wick has also noticed that although inflation has been minimal in the construction trades, many insurance companies still routinely add 10 percent a year as an inflation guard for structural coverage.
"What you did 10 years ago may not be needed anymore," she said. To avoid overpayment, an accurate reassessment should instead be made of current replacement costs.
She further warned against carrying a low deductible -- a technique still favored by many associations, she said. While it allows certain repairs to be covered by insurance, she said, it increases the cost of insurance over the long haul because it tempts an association to file claims more often. A high claims history, she said, can then increase premiums even if the carrier is regularly changed.
Conversely, maintaining a higher deductible -- her favored size is $1,000 -- eliminates the temptation to file smaller claims, thus lowering the risk rating of the association in addition to the immediate premium savings.
Itemized lines she recommends dropping for further savings include special coverage for the loss of cash on hand (it rarely happens in large numbers, she contends) and forgery ("if you've got an efficient setup it's virtually impossible.").
A favorite new cost-saving "toy" of James Cachine, senior vice president at Legum & Norman, managing agents of McLean, Va., is a new kind of emergency exit light. It replaces the customary 40-watt bulb normally used to illuminate these exits with an LED fixture that requires only 1.2 watts.
Mr. Cachine figures that the payback on the light, costing around $90 apiece and newly available from most lighting suppliers, takes about three years, assuming an energy savings of $35 per light bulb for each year. The new light bulb never needs replacing, he added, offering further savings in staff time.
In high-rise buildings with central heat, hot water and air-conditioning systems, he recommends the wider use of computer-aided thermostat controls that allow for more accurate and complex temperature changes.
"And don't just stay with the times of day you think are right for turning things up or down," he said. "Experiment." Even a half hour here or there can add up.
If regularly rising utility costs, such as gas, electricity and water, are folded into monthly charges it might also be time to reconsider submetering.
When installed, these meters permit utility costs to be billed separately based on individual use.
"People become far more careful when they have to pay themselves," said Mark Stauffer, a representative at American Meter Sales of Audubon, Pa., a company that sells, installs and maintains submeters and also handles the individual billing needs of its clients. A result, he insists, is normally a drop of about 25 percent in everyone's utility expenditures.
But a capital outlay will be required. On average a water, gas or electric submeter costs about $500 to install, he said, with town house and garden-apartment complexes less costly than high-rise buildings.
Another useful tool is the "Comparative Study of Building Operation Costs" published each year by the Council of New York Cooperatives. It analyzes data from 500 buildings in a format that permits boards to see where their own costs might be re-examined. "Say your fuel bills are out of line," said Ms. Rothman. "You know it's time to look for a leak in the pipes -- or in the delivery."
A multiple-year service contract is a technique favored by Stanley Rothenberg, president of the New Jersey chapter of the C.A.I. He recommends them for such services as lawn mowing and landscaping.
At Cross Creek, a 339-unit condominium on 35 acres in Englewood, N.J., he said he held the line on further increases for the next three years by signing a three-year agreement. "After what we paid last winter it made sense," said Mr. Rothenberg, who is also executive vice president at C & R Realty and Mangement of Teaneck, N.J.
In doing so, he added, it may also be possible to get some extras thrown in, such as cleaning sand off roads at the end of winter or planting annuals.
Gil Cross, president of Metro Community Management of Roseville, Minn., said that certain associations were saving money by decreasing the number of dumpster pickups, following the success of recycling efforts. Changing from grass to ground cover under trees, thereby reducing lawn area that needs watering and mowing, offers further savings, he said.
In New York City, the watchwords are "eternal vigilance" in co-ops, which have been shaken by recent allegations of bribery among suppliers and building managers -- and even board members. The best way for co-ops to save money, penny by penny, say the experts, is simply to watch every bill and question every expenditure.
It's hardly glamorous. "But it's amazing how much you can save by doing your homework," said Harry Grier, treasurer of the 92-unit co-op at 800 West End Avenue.
His co-op implemented a 2 percent maintenance decrease in January, having previously changed to electric and water submetering; required every capital expenditure over $10,000 to have shareholder approval and used the proceeds from the sale of three apartments to pay off its underlying mortgage.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Change of Location for Water-Tunnel Shaft;
A Bigger Queens Corporate Center Made Possible

 BODY:
It is not clear when the Bulova Corporate Center in Jackson Heights, Queens, will expand. But one big obstacle -- 750 feet deep -- has been removed.
On June 10, Marilyn Gelber, the Commissioner of Environmental Protection, withdrew a plan to build Shaft 17B of the city's third water tunnel on the Bulova property. She said she was responding to concerns that "the shaft could interfere with plans for future development at the site" and "was too close to schools and residences." 
 Instead, Ms. Gelber said, engineers found a more suitable, city-owned site at 46-01 37th Avenue, south of the Sunnyside rail yards in Woodside, Queens.
Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens noted that the new site had "no residential pattern around it" and was next to a rail line that could be used to remove excavated material.
She said she was happy that city officials had changed course. "The Bulova site really has a future for economic development," Mrs. Shulman said. "This would have delayed or killed it."
In 1986, the Blumenfeld Development Group of Syosset, L.I., began converting the Bulova Watch Company's former home into a 483,000-square-foot office building. Tenants now include British Airways, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association. Elsewhere on the 23-acre parcel, bordered by the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and 25th Avenue, Blumenfeld plans a four-story office building, a 10-story hotel, a shopping arcade and a movie theater.
It was on that development site that the city first proposed putting Shaft 17B as part of an 11-mile leg of the new tunnel in Queens and Brooklyn. Later, the shaft site was moved to the parking lot for the Bulova center. Construction was to take six and a half years.
The president of the Bulova Center, Edward Blumenfeld, said that if the shaft had been built, "the quality of life for our residential neighbors, the 2,000 employees who work at our building and the very future of this key economic anchor would have been at risk."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
A Rise in Rates Lifts Money Funds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
BOND prices have fallen markedly in 1994, but a silver lining is the increase in money market fund yields. Since Feb. 4, when the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time this year, the seven-day average yield on taxable money funds has risen to 3.59 percent, from 2.68 percent, the highest in two years.
While economists disagree on when and how much, many believe the Fed will raise rates again, and that's further good news for money fund investors. 
 "The anticipation of further rate hikes means that yields will continue to increase," said Teresa Redinger, who edits The Money Fund Report, published by IBC/Donoghue in Ashland, Mass.
As rates creep up, investors are starting to slowly move back into money funds. Since February, taxable funds have gained $22.8 billion and tax-free funds have added $5.5 billion. Over all, the cash-flow figures "show significant inflows from retail investors," Ms. Redinger said.
A recent survey found that cash is becoming increasingly attractive. Asked how they would invest their money this month, respondents said they would put an average 32.2 percent of their portfolios into cash, compared with 30.4 percent in November, according to the American Capital Index of Investor Intentions, a national monthly survey of 1,000 people chosen at random.
Given the revived interest in cash, where is the best place to keep it? While bank money market accounts are insured, they generally offer lower yields than money market mutual funds, and the gap is growing.
"The spread in yields between money market mutual funds and bank money market accounts rises as interest rates increase because money funds own investment instruments that tend to rise more quickly in up cycles," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, in North Palm Beach, Fla.
Money market funds yielded 2.75 percent in January, for example, compared with 2.32 percent for bank money market accounts. By June 14, the 0.43 point spread had grown to 1.19 percentage points, with bank accounts yielding 2.40 percent.
But experts advise investors to be wary of money funds that have dabbled in derivative securities in the scramble for competitive advantage amid rock-bottom rates. These investments were intended to raise yields, but did not work as planned when interest rates began rising.
The most recent instance came to light early this month, when the BankAmerica Corporation disclosed that it had injected $17.4 million into its Pacific Horizon Prime Fund in May to preserve the fund's $1 share price.
There have been "a handful" of instances since February in which other fund sponsors have used their own money to make up losses from investments in exotic securities, said Barry Barbash, director of the division of investment management of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Fund companies are quick to preserve their funds' $1 share price because investors use them as if they were insured bank accounts. While S.E.C. regulations on the funds' investments have been aimed at keeping fund prices stable, Wall Street financial engineers have invented new instruments that are not covered by existing rules.
"The rules are so explicit that the funds should not be operated so differently," Mr. Barbash said.
For now, investors who are evaluating money funds should be suspicious of yields that seem too high, experts say. If, after reading the prospectus, you don't understand the fund's investments, ask questions. And if the fund uses derivatives, ask how volatile share prices can be expected to be, Mr. Barbash said.
There are better ways for money fund sponsors to let their investors pocket bigger yields than relying on questionable investing tactics. The best way: lowering expenses.
In fact, price is the chosen battlefield today. In the first quarter of 1994, 60 percent of money market funds waived all or part of their expenses, the highest percentage since IBC/Donoghue began tracking expense waivers in 1988. Moreover, "the trend is continuing as a technique to attract investors even as short-term rates move higher," Ms. Redinger said.
The average charged expenses are 0.59 percent for taxable money funds and 0.58 percent for tax-free funds. Nine funds absorbed all expenses in the first quarter and 578 more, out of 973 total, waived a portion.
Expense waivers are temporary, and investors are well advised to keep close watch. But fund companies have discovered how important they are today. When the top-performing United Services Government Securities money fund reinstituted some fees early this month, it dropped out of the top 10 and promptly restored the waiver.
Investors who can meet high minimum investment amounts can shave expenses even more. The Fidelity Spartan money market, with a $20,000 minimum, yields 3.93 percent, and the Dreyfus Basic money fund, with a $25,000 minimum, yields 3.94 percent. A caveat: Both funds are waiving expenses but could resume them.
A fund with a yield almost as high (3.83 percent) on which fees are not being waived is the Vanguard Admiral U.S. Treasury money fund ($50,000 minimum).

HEADLINE: Detroit Struggles to Learn Another Lesson From Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: SMYRNA, Tenn.

 BODY:
CLOSE to half a million times a year, a freshly minted, glistening Altima sedan, Sentra subcompact or pickup truck rolls out the northern doors of the mammoth Nissan assembly plant here.
But to understand the continuing impact that Nissan and other Japanese transplants have on American auto making, it helps to start elsewhere, on the northeast side of the plant, where grimy tractor trailers back up to unload transmissions, truck frames, wiper blades and bucket seats. 
 Detroit has made great strides in catching up to its Japanese rivals in production efficiency, partly by studying and learning the lessons of Japanese car-assembly techniques. Today, though, the focus is farther down the manufacturing chain -- the payoff Japanese companies get from close relationships with their suppliers. The companies believe the benefits will include improved quality, faster development of new models and lower costs.
Yet changing the old, arms-length relations between car companies -- Japanese or American -- and American suppliers is proving to be a gradual process at best. In the traditional model, dating back the 1920's, the Big Three held control, designing their own parts and treating their suppliers as second-class industrial citizens competing for their business based on price.
But the car makers want to target their investment on engines, assembly and new-model design, while farming out the design of parts to the some 6,000 suppliers who sell to the American auto industry.
For suppliers, the new arrangement means investing more money and acquiring new skills, especially the engineering expertise needed to design parts. For the car makers, it means giving up some control, sharing their skills and treating suppliers as partners and equals.
"What you've got is a massive cultural change," said David C. Eisenhart, a partner at Coopers & Lybrand, who heads the accounting firm's automotive industry group.
Mr. Eisenhart recently surveyed more than 140 Midwest automotive suppliers who sell both to the Big Three and the Japanese transplants. The American companies in general, he says, remain more focused on squeezing their suppliers for price concessions. The transplants, by contrast, show more patience and work to eliminate the forces that push up costs for their suppliers and prices for them.
"The Japanese have been willing to work with their vendors much more closely," Mr. Eisenhart said.
The Japanese plants in America have plenty of reason these days to work closely with American suppliers. Politically, they are under pressure to increase the domestic content of the cars they assemble here. Several plants claim to have slowly raised the share of components produced in North America to more than 60 percent. Nissan said its purchases of parts and materials in America for the fiscal year ended in March 1993, the most recent calculation, rose 67 percent to $2.35 billion from a year earlier.
The Japanese are being pushed in Washington for further progress. Toyota last week told its American suppliers at a gathering in San Francisco that their quality ratings were below the levels of Japanese suppliers. And the company also said that additional purchases in America will depend on improvements in quality, cost and development-time on the part of the suppliers.
Economically, the strong yen raises the price of cars and parts imported from Japan. So the Japanese companies must make the difficult choice of raising car prices sharply or absorbing big losses. Last month, Nissan reported a pretax loss of nearly $2 billion in the fiscal year ended last March.
THE strong yen places a greater burden on Nissan's Tennessee transplant. "Because of the change in the environment, our vehicles have to carry a lot more of the load," said Jerry L. Benefield, president and chief executive of the Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A.
Still, despite the political and economic incentives to buy made-in-America parts, Nissan has found that nurturing Japanese-style supplier relationships in America is slow going.
Nissan started hunting for American suppliers even before it opened in Smyrna in 1983. Repeatedly, Mr. Benefield said, Nissan was disappointed because most prospective suppliers lacked the engineering skills the Japanese company had grown to expect. Again, auto industry traditions in America were to blame. For decades, Mr. Benefield explained, "the Big Three handed them a set of designs and said, 'Do it this way. Don't vary.' "
Detroit's centralized design programs slowed the development of new cars and trucks. While Japanese producers, like Nissan, developed new vehicles in four years, the Big Three typically operated on five-year cycles. Not until the late 1980's did the American companies really start to close that gap.
Nissan and the other transplants had prodded their American suppliers to build up the needed research and development skills in-house.
The Big Three, once again, are following Japan's lead. And suppliers point to the Chrysler Corporation as the American company that has made the most progress. For its new compact sedans, the Chrysler Cirrus, due in showrooms this fall, and Dodge Stratus, due early next year, 95 percent of the parts were "presourced." That is, the suppliers were chosen before the parts were even designed, which meant Chrysler virtually eliminated traditional supplier bidding. By contrast, for Chrysler's line of LH cars -- the vehicles for which Chrysler began using a Japanese-style development approach -- only 50 percent of the parts were presourced.
Chrysler is also adopting the traditional Japanese form of price pressure on its suppliers -- lengthy contracts, extending at least the life of the model, that call for step-by-step price reductions. The contracts assume that suppliers, helped by the car makers, will steadily find ways to improve efficiency and reduce waste. Such contracts are one of the tenets of so-called lean manufacturing, a system developed by Taiichi Ohno, Toyota's longtime chief production engineer, during the postwar years.
AT Nissan's plant here, imported parts and components still represent more than 30 percent of the total value of the company's cars and trucks. Yet Nissan has steadily increased its use of American suppliers like the Davis Tool and Engineering Company, a privately owned, $80 million-a-year producer of oil pans and other metal stampings.
The Davis Tool experience with Nissan shows how the transplants work with their suppliers. When Davis Tool bid five years ago to supply parts to the Smyrna plant, Nissan sent engineers from Smyrna and Japan to examine the Davis Tool factory in Detroit, before awarding the company a contract.
Then, as it has done with two dozen suppliers across the United States, Nissan dispatched a pair of engineers from Smyrna for five days to help workers at Davis Tool's factory rethink their jobs.
THE results astounded the managers at Davis Tool. At the end of five days, two workers were churning out 800 oil pans each shift, where four workers used to make 500 each shift. At Nissan's urging, Davis Tool assured its workers that they would not lose their jobs because of efficiency gains. Any displaced workers would be moved elsewhere in the Detroit plant.
Some of the changes seemed obvious, like raising parts bins to hip level so that workers were not forever bending all the way over and straining their backs. The team broke down each workers job, timing each activity to identify any waste. The company then was able to combine tasks, saving time and space. The company had never before been prodded into such thorough scrutiny of its practices, explained Richard L. Davis 2d, president of Davis Industries, the parent for Davis Tool. The Japanese, he said, are "bringing these skills to their new supply base." He added, "Nissan encouraged us to apply the techniques to our other customers."
To help suppliers, Nissan has also created a training program in Smyrna. Managers from supplier companies are brought in for courses that last about 16 days and range from problem solving to W. Edwards Deming techniques for improving quality. And Nissan has divided its suppliers into regional groups. Suppliers from each region tour each other's factories to examine efficiency-enhancing tactics on everything from layout to lighting.
Yet working with companies that ship their parts and components directly to the Nissan plant is really the last leg of the supply chain. For every so-called first-tier supplier shipping straight to the auto makers, there are several second- and third-tier suppliers whose quality is also crucial to the vehicle, and whose efficiency is critical to the auto makers' financial performance.
Here again, the Japanese companies appear to have an edge over the Big Three, partly because the transplants brought some of their Japanese suppliers with them.
Grand Rapids Spring and Wire Products Inc. is one of the second-tier American suppliers that has managed to adapt to the Japanese methods. The $13 million-a-year, Michigan company sells springs and clips to the Calsonic Corporation, an American subsidiary of one of Nissan's stable of Japanese suppliers. The Calsonic plant, near Smyrna, makes air-conditioners, heaters and exhaust systems used in Nissan cars and trucks.
While tiny, Grand Rapids Spring and Wire considered itself a high-quality producer. So it was confident when it approached Calsonic in 1987, recalled Larry Beurkens, the company's general manager. Its performance ratings from its American customers were consistently high. So when Calsonic gave Grand Rapids a marginal score, "we were in a state of shock," he said.
Still, Calsonic offered the company a contract in 1988. But Grand Rapids Spring and Wire, despite its big investment in production for Calsonic, kept falling short of the company's quality and other standards. Finally, by 1990, Mr. Beurkens was frustrated with trying to satisfy Calsonic, which only accounted for a tiny proportion of its business. "I just said, 'Let's get rid of them -- it's not worth it,' " he recalled.
But then, he said, Calsonic did something unusual. The day after Mr. Beurkens's company called and said it wanted out, Calsonic officials were at his Grand Rapids plant, coaching Mr. Beurkens and others, and the company's scores began to rise. Since then, Grand Rapids's business with transplants has risen to 15 percent of its annual revenue.
Calsonic's approach, Mr. Beurkens said, was a sharp break from his experience with American suppliers to the Big Three. "If I've got a problem," he said, "They say, 'Yeah? What are you going to do about it?' "
And when it came to pricing, Mr. Beurkens added, his company has a real partnership with Calsonic, far more so than with domestic companies. "In the other world, it's domination," he said. " 'If you don't like what I say, there are a hundred suppliers just like you.' The hammer, we call it."

HEADLINE: Business Diary: June 12-17

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
At Simon & Schuster, a Pawn in the Corporate Game
Publishing sometimes seems a world apart, exempt from big-money corporate chess games. But the outside world crashed in on this literary island last week when Viacom, which recently acquired Simon & Schuster as part of its Paramount package, swooped into the publishing house and sacked the man who'd built it into a powerhouse in recent decades, Richard E. Snyder. The publishing world's reaction: shock, mystification -- and jitters about the fate of various authors. Viacom gave a well-worn explanation: a difference in styles. But it soon spied a gathering storm, and moved quickly to calm it, going out of its way to state its "commitment to literature and the printed word." Of course, not everyone at Simon & Schuster mourned, as some were glad to bid farewell to what they called Mr. Snyder's explosive temper. They expected his successor, Jonathan Newcomb, to set a softer tone. 

Exxon's Bill Isn't Paid Yet
Exxon has already spent $3.4 billion in response to the Valdez oil spill more than five years ago, mostly in its huge cleanup effort -- a huge amount, yes, but finite. Exxon, whose revenues last year were close to $111 billion, could handle it. But now an even bigger, open-ended bill could be coming due. Last week a Federal jury ruled that Exxon had been reckless in putting the time bomb of a tanker full of oil in the hands of a man known for alcohol abuse. Now the jury must decide on damages, and the plaintiffs are asking for more than $15 billion, which even for Exxon starts to sound like real money. Exxon's stock, which stood at $42 soon after the spill, has since risen strongly, but this ruling gave it a jolt of reality, knocking it down nearly $5, or 8 percent, in three days before it steadied itself at $58.75 by week's end.
 
A Key Recruit for New World
A few weeks ago, New World Communications shook up the television industry by switching 12 of its stations to Fox (8 were CBS affiliates). And in case that didn't put New World on the map, this certainly will: last week it named Brandon Tartikoff to head its production. It was Mr. Tartikoff who turned NBC into such a power in the mid-80's, so his presence could quickly make New World a strong source of programming. And that means the Fox network would have to be taken a lot more seriously, too.
 
Next Flavor: You and Jerry's?
Look at it this way: What if Ben & Jerry's, in need of a chief executive, had soberly chosen from a bunch of plain-vanilla dynamos? It could be enough to send you back to Breyer's. But Ben & Jerry's, the oddest corporate flavor around, didn't disappoint. When Ben Cohen said last week that he was looking for a successor as chief (though he'll stay on as chairman), he did it with style: he invited customers to write essays telling why they should get the job. But even as he spoke, one drop of the Ben & Jerry's myth melted away: the company scrapped its policy of limiting a top executive's pay to seven times the salary of the lowest-paid worker.
 
Another Painkiller? Oh, My Head!
Let's face it: the rest of this stuff matters little if you have a headache. And you probably do, given the frantic way most people live. Pain relief is big business in America -- as in $2.5 billion a year, just for nonprescription drugs -- so it's big news when a new type of analgesic appears. No, make that: Procter & Gamble and Syntex want it to be big news. Last week they introduced Aleve (pronounced a-LEAVE, as in "alleviate"; get it?), an over-the-counter version of Anaprox, and they plan to spend fully $100 million to sell it in its first year. But how much can drugstore shelves take? And do those who came of age on aspirin, and who've finally learned to spell acetaminophen and ibuprofen, have the strength to add "naproxen sodium" to their vocabulary? It could give you a headache.
 
A Data Highway Crossover
Normally the mileposts in the information revolution are seen in technologies; sometimes they're visible merely in the jobs people take. Last week there was a vivid example of the latter. Robert Kavner, a top AT&T executive who at 50 was a possible contender to run the company one day, made what just a few years ago would have seemed a bizarre career leap: he joined the Creative Artists Agency, the mighty Hollywood talent shop run by Michael Ovitz. The message? Simple: Hollywood intends to play a big role on the data highway; entertainment, information and communications are becoming one. Anyway, heading a great company is not "the ultimate in life," Mr. Kavner said. "I wanted to put myself on the fun meter."
 
Score One for AT&T
AT&T, meanwhile, scored a victory in the Supreme Court last week. The F.C.C. had tried to liven up long-distance competition by letting AT&T's rivals, but not AT&T itself, bypass an advance listing of rates and services. But the Court, which has been hostile to various deregulatory moves, ruled that it lacked the authority to do so. A big loser was MCI, which had used the F.C.C. policy to cut custom-made deals with big companies.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Robert Brennan's Day in Court
Robert Brennan is back. You remember: First Jersey Securities; a fit-looking Mr. Brennan, with helicopter as high-status backdrop, urging you to "come grow with us"; charges of defrauding penny-stock customers. Mr. Brennan quit as First Jersey chairman in 1986 and sold its retail branches, and in 1987 the firm paid $10 million to settle a class action suit. But not until last week did Mr. Brennan go to trial, with the S.E.C. now seeking repayment of what it says are $27 million in illegal profits (with interest: $78 million). Does Mr. Brennan, a boy wonder now 50, seem repentant? Hardly. He coolly testified that First Jersey had maintained "the highest standards." And the S.E.C. assertions? "Hogwash."
 
When in Doubt, Reform Welfare
Health care is what it's all about this year, but just to spice things up, President Clinton threw his "end welfare as we know it" plan into the hopper last week too. Most details of the $9.3 billion plan are old news -- expanded training; two years to join a work program or you're out; a get-tough approach to child support -- but Mr. Clinton apparently decided to put it forward now so he could have something tough to point to if political realities demanded. But Mr. Clinton may yet achieve the goal he just outlined -- make welfare "a stepping stone, not a way of life."
 
Mr. D'Amato's Magic Touch
Speaking of one-day trading profits -- which a lot of Republicans have been doing lately -- it now appears that Al D'Amato, one of the most vocal Hillary-bashers, had a nice piece of good fortune himself last year. Mr. D'Amato's 1993 financial disclosure form, made public last week, shows that last June the Senator invested $18,000 in an initial stock offering of a California company called Computer Marketplace and sold the shares that same day for more than $55,000. Since then, the shares have dropped sharply. The underwriter (which awarded Mr. D'Amato the right to buy at the offering price): Stratton Oakmont, which Federal regulators say is a boiler-room outfit that defrauds investors. The firm's founder has contributed to Mr. D'Amato's campaign and to the Republican Party.
 
All for One in Latin America
As the world teams up into trading blocs, Latin America has no intention of being left out. Yes, there's a scattering of smaller groups -- one includes Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay; another, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela -- but last week Latin nations moved to join forces. The region's 19 largest nations agreed to form a single free-trade zone. "Our union is fundamental," said President Eduardo Frei of Chile. And this is good news for United States exporters, for tariffs should plummet.
 
Oil Prices Head Up Again
Don't look now, but oil prices have been rising steadily for several months now, and last week jumped to their highest point in a year. The culprit, as usual, was a mix of scattered fears feeding on one another: tensions over North Korea, new signs that Iraq's oil will not be flowing into the world pool any time soon, and a show of OPEC resolve to keep a lid on output. But what it added up to was a barrel of oil costing more than $20, last topped in June 1993. That's the kind of thing that makes people start talking about inflation.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Surprise: Bigger Isn't Always Better

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

 BODY:
MANY companies continue to make health insurance available to their employees, but coverage is declining, a Labor Department study has found. The overall percentage of workers receiving coverage through their employers dropped to 61 percent last year from 65 percent in 1988. The drop in coverage occurred mostly in the private sector, where it went to 58 percent from 62 percent over the last five years. Public sector coverage dropped by only 1 percentage point. About 37 million workers receive no insurance through their employers and 16 million of them have no coverage at all.
"This report makes clear that employer-provided health insurance is still the bedrock of America's health care system, but it's ailing," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said when he announced the findings late last month. Not surprisingly, Mr. Reich said the research underscores the "urgent need" for health care reform. 
 The explanation for the drop in coverage -- cost -- isn't surprising either. Employers are dropping sponsorship of plans and employees are more likely to decline coverage.
What is most surprising, however, is that the decline appeared at companies of all sizes, not just at the small businesses supposedly at risk of oblivion if, under a new health insurance order, they were required to provide coverage. From 1979 to 1993, coverage in businesses with fewer than 25 employees dropped 2 percentage points, to 31 percent.
IN companies with more than 100 workers, the comparable decline was 10 percentage points: to 73 percent from 83 percent. Theoretically, the smaller base of smaller companies offering coverage could account for the disparity: There's more room to cut in the big-company category. But apparently it doesn't. "The lower base accounts for some of it, but it's a pretty significant change," said Richard Hinz, director of research and economic analysis at the Pension and Welfare Benefits Administration, the Labor Department agency that sponsored the research. "One of the myths is that erosion of coverage is erosion of small-business coverage. In fact, it's across the board."
Large companies are still more likely to provide health coverage in retirement. Last year just over half of the companies with more than 1,000 workers made coverage available to retirees, a jump from about a third for businesses of the next-largest size. The startling finding was the proportion of people older than 45 -- 25 percent to 40 percent, depending on company size -- who didn't know if they would be covered, despite the fact that by that age most people have had inklings of mortality. "That's a remarkable finding," Mr. Hinz said. "The 'don't knows' don't seem to be associated with any particular characteristic." Of course, perhaps it is better to be oblivious since retiree insurance at many companies may soon go the way of Robespierre's head.
The report, which is based on questions asked during the Census Department's April 1993 Current Population Survey, provides more detailed information than usual on pensions and health benefits in companies of all sizes around the country.
 
Women at Risk
 A study published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute last week suggested that women electrical workers may be at a higher risk for developing breast cancer than women in other jobs. Previous research has indicated a possible connection between exposure to electromagnetic fields and increased risk for certain types of cancers.
Researchers from the School of Public Health at the University of North Carolina compared the death certificates of women exposed to extremely low-frequency electromagnetic fields -- the kind produced by high-voltage power lines, for example -- and women in nonelectrical jobs. Of 267 cases of women in traditional electrical occupations, 68 had died of breast cancer -- a rate 38 percent higher than expected, the study said.
The higher mortality rates occurred among women who had worked as electrical engineers, telephone installers, repairers and line workers. The researchers found no "excess of breast cancer" among telephone operators, data entry clerks or computer operators and programmers, though they, too, often have more exposure to electricity than other workers.
 
 
 
A CREATIVE OUTLOOK ON WELFARE
IS welfare a dependency that promotes what sociologists used to call "serial monogamy" even while it saps the individual's will to work? Or is it a coping strategy poor people use intermittently and rather creatively to stave off disaster?
Continuing studies from the Institute on Women's Policy Research in Washington suggest the latter. Contradicting the image of the welfare population as inert and irresponsible, the institute found that only one-third of a sample of single mothers on Aid to Families With Dependent Children from 1984 through 1990 relied exclusively on their grants and benefits to get by. Forty percent "package" wages from work with grants and benefits to achieve a livable income, either moving back and forth over time between work and welfare or simultaneously combining income from several sources.
The information that nearly half the single-mother welfare population is working at least part time does not seem to have contaminated the debate on reform, which is no longer about labor force participation but about preventing teen-age pregnancy. The institute's research indicates that a "two years and you're out" plan like the one proposed last week by President Clinton would leave most women on welfare at the mercy of the low-wage labor market. "Dependency," in other words, can be a rational choice.

HEADLINE: POLL FINDS A LACK OF FAITH IN POLICE

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
New Yorkers express anxiety about the Police Department's ability to protect them, and many say there is widespread corruption in the force, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.
The survey and follow-up interviews suggest a serious lack of confidence in the department because of a fear of crime and concern over revelations of corruption in several precincts. 
 Despite police reports of a slight though steady decrease in crime over the last four years, the poll found a general perception that crime has increased or remained at the same levels as last year. More than a third of those polled said that because of their fear of crime they had moved to new neighborhoods or were planning to. Many, especially in Hispanic and black neighborhoods, say they have taken measures like riding the subway less, staying home at night or avoiding places that they used to go to.
The telephone poll of 1,189 adult residents conducted from June 12 to June 15 is just a snapshot, and the extent to which opinions might have changed recently is uncertain, because many questions were asked for the first time. But the findings suggest that the image of the department is badly bruised just when it is introducing new crime-fighting strategies that rely on community cooperation, like having beat officers seek intelligence on drug dealers and gun traffickers from residents.
The worries about crime and police performance span racial, economic and ethnic lines. But skepticism about the Police Department is expressed most strongly by minority-group residents. A majority of black and Hispanic New Yorkers and a sizable minority of whites say the police are generally tougher on minority members.
The poll and subsequent interviews with participants etch a picture of New Yorkers who live in fear, especially fear of teen-agers. Thirty-six percent of those polled said they had seen people selling drugs near their homes in recent months, and 23 percent said they or members of their immediate families had been victims of crime in the last year. Those levels are similar to numbers from other polls in the last four years.
"In Brooklyn, at least, the police are overwhelmed by the amount of crime and the lack of money, equipment and facilities to deal with it," said Loren K. Popkoff, 31, a high school teacher who lives in Midwood and was mugged for the second time in five years, in May 1993. Ms. Popkoff and her husband bought a guard dog after vandals began taping large fireworks to windows in the neighborhood. "I think things are getting worse," she said.
Of all the problems facing the city, 41 percent said, crime was the one that they wanted Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to concentrate on. Education came in second, with 10 percent. Fifty-seven percent said they approved of how Mr. Giuliani was handling the crime problem. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Fifty-eight percent of those polled said the crimes most likely to involve them were assault, mugging or robbery. For more violent crimes, 9 percent fear being shot and 3 percent fear being murdered. But twice as many blacks as whites and five times as many Hispanic residents as whites said the crime they thought that they would be a victim of was a shooting.
Although comparable percentages in each racial category reported having been crime victims, black and Hispanic New Yorkers have generally been more prone than whites to change behavior to counter crime.
 
A Widespread Malaise
 The broad level of anxiety, follow-up interviews found, sometimes appeared stirred more by a lack of confidence in the Police Department and by vandalism than any concrete evidence that violence is increasing in their neighborhoods.
"I think crime is getting worse all over -- not just here in Brighton Beach -- from reading the newspapers and talking to people," said Seymour Friedman, 78, a retired tool maker, despite never having been a victim and despite police findings that reported crimes in most felony categories in his Brooklyn neighborhood had declined significantly in recent years.
"You get more of a feeling that something bad can happen to you than you used to," said Barry Welch, 52, a cabinetmaker who lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He attributed that sense to increased noise made at night by reveling teen-agers and the "tremendous increase in car vandalism."
"Windows are smashed, which I didn't see when I first came here in 1988," Mr. Welch said.
Ronald Henderson, 50, a building superintendent in Morris Park, the Bronx, said he became convinced that patrols in his neighborhood were insufficient when he found the nuts screwed off the wheels of his Honda Accord two months ago. "This was done in daylight hours," he recounted. "It was, like, I felt there was nobody to protect my belongings. You are always in danger."
By every measure, a substantial percentage of New Yorkers polled are unhappy with the performance of the Police Department, even though 40 percent said they thought that more officers were patrolling their neighborhoods than a year ago. A full 50 percent said they did not feel adequately protected by the police, compared with 42 percent who said they were adequately protected.
Fifty-one percent said the department was doing a fair or poor job compared with 48 percent who said the police were doing a good or excellent job. Whites had the most positive view of the police, with 63 percent saying the department was doing good or excellent work. Fewer than a third of blacks, on the other hand, viewed the force as performing well, with 67 percent saying it was doing a fair or poor job.
Some experts said the public's negative perceptions were a consequence of the widely reported corruption case in the 30th Precinct, where more than 20 officers have been arrested or are being investigated for drug trafficking or other felonies.
Police Commissioner William J. Bratton predicted that New Yorkers would feel better about crime and the police force after several of new anticrime strategies took hold. Of the strong concerns about police corruption, he said: "These are perceptions being shaped by the reporting, the investigations and the attention the department has been paying to it. We have not been running away from this issue."
Milton Mollen, the former Deputy Mayor who is leading a panel on police corruption, said: "Our investigation indicates to us that the facts and reality are somewhat different than the perception that has followed from the revelations. We are convinced that most police officers are honest, and not corrupt."
Most people say the officer on the beat is very or somewhat honest, but 43 percent said corruption was widespread through the department. Broken down by race, 58 percent of blacks said corruption was ingrained, compared with 51 percent of Hispanic residents and 32 percent of whites.
Aaron Purdue, 38, an unemployed office worker who lives a few blocks from the 30th Precinct station house, in Harlem, said that he "was not surprised at all" about reports that many officers in the precinct were implicated in drug dealing or other crimes. "I've heard stories of cops' taking money from people," Mr. Purdue said. "The combination of inadequate policing and corruption go hand in hand."
 
'You Get a Different Look'
 Like a large majority of black and Hispanic New Yorkers polled, Mr. Purdue, who is black, complained that the police treated minority members in tougher ways than they treated whites. "Even just coming on the subway, you get a different look," he said.
Samuel Correa, 19, of the Bushwick, Brooklyn, and a son of Puerto Rican and Dominican parents, said: "It depends on the cop. It depends on his race. The cop is going to favor his race."
Marianne Alarcon, 54, an immigrant from Colombia and a secretary who lives in Corona, Queens, said she was unhappy with the police when she called her precinct last week to complain that teen-agers were awakening her at 2 A.M. by smashing glass in the street. The line was continually busy and she could not get through she said, "leaving me feeling weak in these conditions."
"I don't feel safe," she added.
Mrs. Alarcon was recently forced to change where she shops for food because drug dealers were hanging out in front of the old store. "I can't say how much police corruption there is, but I saw with my own eyes the police were on the corner," she said. "What is that? Are they not paying attention?"
White and more affluent residents viewed the police more favorably. "I think the police are pretty good," said Helen Arminas, 62, a retired executive of a coffee brokerage who lives in Fort Wadsworth, Staten Island. Although she lives no more than a five-minute drive from Park Hill, where Ernest Sayon died in police custody in a case being investigated, Mrs. Arminas said, "That's very rare." Expressing confidence that the department would clean up any corruption problems, she said, "If policemen are not doing their job I'm sure they are going to pay for it."
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 12 to 15 in all parts of New York City with 1,189 adults. Interviews were conducted in English or Spanish.
The telephone exchanges called were selected by a computer from a complete list of city exchanges. The exchanges were chosen to ensure that each area in the city was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus including both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated at random to respond to the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to borough, race, sex, age and education.
In theory in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples would differ by no more than three percenatge points in either direction from a poll of all adult New Yorkers.
For smaller subgroups, the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is 6 percentage points for all blacks and 6 percentage points for all Hispanics.
Besides sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any opinion survey may introduce other errors. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can cause results to vary somewhat.
