HEADLINE: Two Koreas Plan Summit Talks on Nuclear Issue

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, June 18

 BODY:
For the first time since the Korean peninsula was divided five decades ago, the Presidents of North and South Korea agreed today to hold a summit meeting, which is likely to focus on defusing tensions over the North's suspected effort to build a nuclear weapon.
The agreement was brokered by former President Jimmy Carter, who delivered the offer from North Korea's 82-year-old leader, Kim Il Sung, after returning to Seoul this morning from a three-day visit to Pyongyang. 
 South Korea's President, Kim Young Sam, immediately met Mr. Carter at Blue House, the presidential mansion in the mountains ringing Seoul, and told him that "the sooner the better," aides said.
But South Korean officials acknowledged that there was reason to question whether a summit meeting between the two countries, still technically at war, would ever take place. They noted that many agreements between North and South have been thrown onto the scrap heap.
The state-run Korean Broadcasting System suggested in a television analysis tonight that "this could be another attempt by the North to buy time and escape from a tense situation."
Mr. Carter also used his visit to deliver a stinging critique of the Clinton Administration's strategy of seeking United Nations sanctions against the North as part of an effort to force Mr. Kim to give up his nuclear weapons program.
At a news conference outside the American Ambassador's house here, Mr. Carter said he believed that economic sanctions were doomed to failure and would do nothing but further poison relations between the North and the rest of the world.
"The declaration of sanctions by the U.N. would be regarded as an insult by them, branding it as an outlaw country," he said. It would also constitute "a personal insult to their so-called Great Leader," Kim Il Sung, Mr. Carter said, "by branding him as a liar and a criminal.
"This is something in my opinion which would be impossible for them to accept," he added.
He did not mention the North's frequent threats to regard any sanctions as an act of war.
Mr. Carter's criticism and the prospect of a Korean summit meeting may take much of the steam out of the Administration's push for sanctions, which may be exactly what the North Korean leader wanted.
Seoul sought a North-South summit meeting as early as 1981, when South Korea was ruled by the military strongman Chun Doo Hwan. When Kim Young Sam took office last year as the South's first civilian President in decades, he repeated the offer.
But posturing and the imposition of conditions on both sides have always scuttled hopes of a meeting before one was ever scheduled.
Some experts on North Korea here believe that now the situation may be different because both men stand to gain politically from a meeting.
Mr. Carter traveled to North Korea as a private citizen, not as an envoy of Mr. Clinton, a point he made repeatedly today. But the former President's frequent contacts with the White House -- and his description of a still-vague offer from the North to freeze its nuclear program temporarily if high-level talks began with the United States -- have clearly changed the dynamics of the standoff.
 
Differences With Clinton
 On the one hand, it has given the Administration another opening to try to make diplomacy work, just as the White House is pressing for sanctions and weighing reinforcement of the 37,000 American troops here. But Mr. Carter's sharp differences with the White House over sanctions and his seeming embrace of Mr. Kim also threaten to unravel the Administration's effort to keep up the pressure by building a consensus for economic sanctions in the United Nations Security Council.
The sanctions issue became a point of dispute on Friday at the White House after Mr. Carter, in comments broadcast by CNN, appeared to tell his North Korean hosts that the Administration had agreed to suspend its drive to punish the North. Mr. Clinton and his aides quickly said they had done nothing of the sort.
Mr. Carter insisted today that his words had been misinterpreted. The sanctions, he said, would be held in abeyance only if Mr. Kim agreed to open the nuclear program to full inspection.
 
'Reverence' to Leader
 But he made clear that he viewed the sanctions drive as a misguided effort that would only harden the North Koreans' will to confront the United States. He said this view was confirmed "after observing their psyche and their societal structure and the reverence with which they look upon their leader."
Mr. Carter said that Mr. Kim had assured him that North Korea was not building nuclear weapons.
Mr. Carter heaped praise on Kim Il Sung, the aging warrior who started the Korean War 44 years ago. "I found him to be vigorous, intelligent, surprisingly well informed about the technical issues and in charge of the decisions about this country," he said.
There are frequent rumors that Mr. Kim's health is declining. But in television coverage of Mr. Carter's visit, the North Korean leader appeared alert and active.
One of the surprises of the trip is that Mr. Carter met Mr. Kim's wife, who is rarely seen in public. South Korean press reports indicate that Mr. Carter was also offered an opportunity to meet Kim Jong Il, the 52-year-old son and heir apparent of Kim Il Sung, but turned it down.
The younger Mr. Kim almost never sees foreign visitors, and experts on North Korea have often speculated that he lacks an ability to lead and to command respect from the military.
 
No Nuclear Freeze
 Ever since Mr. Carter crossed into North Korean territory on Wednesday, he has prompted a trans-Pacific debate over whether he was sending the North the right signals, and whether Mr. Kim's offers to him stand up to scrutiny.
The most important was an offer by Mr. Kim to freeze his nuclear program as long as high-level talks with the Administration are initiated and continue. Mr. Carter cautioned, however, that Mr. Kim "did not agree to a permanent freeze."
Such a freeze, he quoted the North Korean leader as saying, would have to be negotiated in another round of high-level talks. It would also be linked to fulfillment of Mr. Kim's oft-stated goal to replace North Korea's old graphite-moderated reactors with newer light-water reactors. The old reactors have a greater chance of producing bomb-grade plutonium that could be used in nuclear arms.
Mr. Kim's other condition, he said, was a guarantee from the United States that North Korea will never be the target of a nuclear attack.
 
Repackaging Old Offers?
 Mr. Carter seemed to acknowledge that his trip had touched off arguments over whether Mr. Kim was offering new openings, or simply rephrasing and recombining old offers.
The Administration has said that before it goes ahead with talks, the North must commit itself to a three-part "verifiable freeze" on its nuclear activities.
The first condition is that international inspectors, now at the North's main nuclear reactor in Yongbyon, are permitted to stay. Mr. Carter said Mr. Kim gave him that assurance.
The second condition is that none of the fuel rods removed from the reactor last month are reprocessed into weapons-grade material. That is a more difficult choice for the North Koreans: unless they reprocess those rods relatively soon, they will develop impurities, harming their best source of bomb material in years.
The third condition, officials say, is that the reactor must not be filled with new fuel rods that could be used to make more weapons fuel. The North claims that the reactor is for research into power production.
American officials here say the North's decision whether to abide by a freeze will probably determine whether the Administration goes ahead with talks with the North.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Official to Meet Carter
 WASHINGTON, June 18 (Special to The New York Times) -- White House officials said today that the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, would meet with Mr. Carter on Sunday to discuss his trip.
The White House issued a statement that mentioned neither the proposed meeting of Korean Presidents nor Mr. Carter's criticism of sanctions proposals. It said the Administration would seek to confirm the "preliminary reports" of North Korean offers with Mr. Carter and through diplomatic channels.
The statement said that "U.S. policy remains unchanged" and that the Administration is "continuing to consult on a sanctions resolution at the U.N. Security Council."

HEADLINE: Opponents of Disney Park Find Allies in Congress

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
A festering dispute between advocates and foes of a theme park that the Walt Disney Company is planning to build near important Civil War battlegrounds has spilled out of Virginia and into Congress, turning what began as a local spat into a national debate.
Largely at the urging of environmentalists and historians who want to protect the region from urban sprawl, a bipartisan group of 16 House members this week introduced a resolution opposing the park, Disney's America, which would be built in Prince William County about 35 miles west of Washington. In addition, a Senate subcommittee has been persuaded to hold a hearing, which is set for Tuesday. 
 It remains unclear just how disruptive this additional layer of opposition will be to the $650 million project, scheduled for completion in 1998. While the House opponents called on Disney to build elsewhere and urged Federal agencies to insure that development complied with laws governing air quality, transportation and historic preservation, their step was only a call to arms, not a threat of legislative action.
Disney officials say they are not worried.
"I don't see anything anywhere that would impede forward progress," Michael D. Eisner, Disney's chairman, said in an interview this week. "I would have thought that if we could do something in a celebratory way, people would be enthusiastic."
 
Backers See a Boon
 In fact, many Virginians are enthusiastic, among them Gov. George Allen, Senator John W. Warner and seven of the eight members of the Prince William Board of Supervisors. Like them, thousands of county residents see the 3,006-acre theme park as a boon to development, employment and the local tax base. Mr. Allen was the driving force behind a $163 million bond issue for the Disney project; most of the proceeds will pay for improving roads in the area.
Robert Singletary, chairman and president of the Welcome Disney Committee, a coalition of 11 organizations, hailed the benefits projected by Disney: 19,000 permanent jobs, 2,800 construction jobs, $48 million a year in new state taxes and up to $12 million for Prince William County.
"People are interested in seeing Prince William grow economically and grow soundly," Mr. Singletary said. Those who raise environmental and historical concerns, he said, are speaking nonsense.
 
'Issues Are Now Elevated'
 But his is not a universal view in Congress, and the project's opponents predict that the interest of Federal lawmakers will dramatically widen the focus of debate and perhaps force Disney to choose an alternative site.
"The issues are now elevated and really joined for the first time," said Neil Proto, a lawyer representing a group of authors and historians fighting the project. "Once they're elevated, I think they will be taken very seriously. To now, there has been no detached, objective analysis of the project. The facts have only come from Virginia and Disney. The process now will yield disclosure of the real facts, hopefully, early enough to affect all major decisions made about this."
With so many of Virginia's political leaders supporting the Disney plan, which envisions hotels, shops, two golf courses and 2,281 residential units, opponents see Federal involvement as their best and perhaps only chance to force Disney to build elsewhere.
They argue that the theme park and other Disney plans would spur so much commercial and residential development that traffic would choke roads, spoil the air quality and overwhelm existing neighborhoods.
And they assert that it would endanger what many historians consider some of the most hallowed grounds of American history. One group has identified 13 historic towns, 16 Civil War battlefields, including Manassas, and 17 historic districts within an hour's drive of Haymarket, the town nearest the site of the proposed park.
 
'More Than a Local Issue'
 In announcing the House resolution, Representative Michael A. Andrews, a Texas Democrat who led a fight six years ago against development of a shopping center near the Manassas National Battlefield Park, called the Disney project "far more than a local issue" and said the impact on Manassas and the Shenandoah National Park "would be devastating."
In a letter to Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, Mr. Andrews implored that Disney be held to regulatory environmental standards, and he urged that Interior do what it can to delay the project.
But given the deliberate pace of Washington and the complexity of the debate, opponents say, they are not sure that the Government can act swiftly or forcefully enough to force Disney to build elsewhere.
For the project to be affected, they say, lawmakers would have to insist that Disney's plans strictly meet the standards of Federal statutes like the Clean Air Act of 1991 and the Inter-Modal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991, which determines whether a particular transportation system is adequate for the region it serves.
They also say that Interior could determine that the project would have negative effects on national parklands. Mr. Andrews's letter to Mr. Babbitt raises questions about plans to widen two roads that run through the Manassas battlefield park.
Historians say these are the same roads used by troops during the Civil War, and the fields they traverse are virtually unchanged from a century ago. Widening the roads would mean using land that is part of the battlegrounds, and that could give Interior the right to intercede.
"The department has the authority to declare an impact on national parklands, and that would make development very difficult or impossible," said Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat who was a co-sponsor of the resolution.
The project's foes say that the population explosion in Prince William County in the last decade has already had adverse effects on air quality and transportation. Since 1980, the population has grown to 238,000 from 100,000.
 
The Problem of Traffic
 Sandy Hillyer, director of the National Growth Management Leadership Project, said that even with the planned road improvements and Disney's own projection that traffic volume in the area would no more than double once the park opened, compliance with Federal regulations would be impossible.
Residents already complain that Interstate 66 west of Washington is clogged beyond reason. Many residents of Prince William County who work in Washington say the one-way trip in rush-hour traffic can take an hour or longer.
"We already have a smog problem in the D.C. metropolitan area," Mr. Hillyer said. "At the minimum, we have to reduce smog-creating emissions 24 percent by 1999. That is a staggering burden when you have trends for greater automobile use."
It is also, he added, a shared burden: if one area in the region is generating higher fuel emissions, others have to cut back to comply with regulations. Failure to meet the standards could lead to a cutoff of funds from the Federal Highway Administration and higher parking taxes or higher gasoline taxes.
State and county officials, as well as Disney executives, have repeatedly argued that the project would enhance the area and that the groups opposed to Disney's America have no cause for alarm.
Mr. Eisner, nonetheless, praised their tactics. "Their strategy to try to delay us is a smart one," he said. "To delay costs money. Many companies would throw in the towel."
But whatever the opponents do, he quickly added, "will certainly not stop us."

On Thursday, Tony Urso 3d of Haymarket, holding placard, led a protest at the Washington premiere of Disney's new film, "The Lion King." (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Two Koreas: 5 Decades of Division

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, June 18

 BODY:
The division of the Korean peninsula, which may be breached slightly if the Presidents of North and South Korea meet for the first time, was invented by the Americans with Soviet help.
The divide was established on Sept. 3, 1945, shortly after the Japanese, who ruled Korea as a colony for 35 years, surrendered, ending World War II. The Americans would run the South, it was decided, and the Russians the North. 
 But it was not until 1948 that the North Korean Communists founded the Democratic People's Republic of Korea and installed Kim Il Sung as its leader. Today he is the world's longest-surviving ruler. For its part, the United States installed a seemingly pliable President, Syngman Rhee.
Two years later the Korean War began, with Communist forces pouring across the 38th parallel. The war lasted for three years, ending with an armistice but no official end to hostilities. Since then both sides have steadily increased their military preparedness, the North gathering together an army of 1.1 million, the South upgrading equipment and training.
Mr. Kim developed a personality cult, which boomed when the country came into periodic conflict with the West during the cold war.
In 1972 the North and South announced an agreement to end hostility and work toward "peaceful unification of the nation." That led to the so-called Red Cross talks between the two countries, but the negotiations collapsed and South Korea soon entered a period of martial law, coups and assassinations of its leaders.
In the 1970's and 80's, a series of provocations and terrorist acts seemed aimed at sabotaging the Seoul Government and its American protector. Two American Army officers were hacked to death by North Korean guards at the border village of Panmunjom in 1976. Several years later, North Korean agents are believed to have planted a bomb that killed many members of the South Korean Cabinet during a trip to Rangoon, Burma, now called Yangon, Myanmar. In 1987 a South Korean aircraft disappeared over Burma, and investigators said it had been destroyed by a bomb. Later, a woman who was involved in the bombing said she had acted under instructions from Kim Jong Il, the son of Kim Il Sung.
It was not until the end of the cold war that on-again, off-again peace talks began to show some results. In 1991 an accord was reached that called for a Korean peninsula free of nuclear weapons and for the opening of roads, rail links and regular family exchanges between North and South. Almost none of it has been put into effect. By last year, the question of the North's nuclear weapons project had taken center stage. In May, after 18 months of talks, Mr. Clinton decided to seek sanctions.
The two Koreas have grown apart economically at an ever-faster pace. The South, once the weaker of the two, now has a gross domestic product that is 15 times greater than the North's; at current rates, it grows a new North Korea every year. The South's greatest fear is of a flood of refugees when the North finally collapses. So the watchword now is a "soft landing" for the North that puts off the day when South Korea is sent the bill.

HEADLINE: Canada Rebuffs Veterans of U.S. Forces in Vietnam

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 16

 BODY:
During the Vietnam War, as thousands of young Americans sought refuge in Canada to avoid the conflict, thousands of young Canadians were recruited by the United States to fight in that same war.
Some 20,000 American draft dodgers and 12,000 deserters are estimated to have fled to Canada, while 40,000 Canadians, the majority of them volunteers, served in the American armed forces, and at least 12,000 fought in Southeast Asia. 
 Most went for adventure. Many from Quebec and French-speaking parts of New Brunswick say they signed up chiefly to learn English. Some were drafted, young men who happened to be living and working in the United States and as residents were subject to conscription.
Some call these Canadians the unknown warriors, men who for years have not called attention to themselves because of the war's unpopularity. Now they are seeking some national recognition, in the form of a memorial to their dead on a few square feet of federal land in Ottawa. But the Canadian Government will not give them the land.
"We're not trying to say the war was right or wrong," said Lee Hitchins, president of the Canadian Vietnam Veterans Coalition. "We just want to put up something for the people who gave their lives."
 
Canada Wasn't in the War
 The Government's reason for saying "no" is that Canada did not officially take part in the war, and does not memorialize people who fought in wars in which it was not a participant.
"The people who chose to participate did so on their own," said Marie Christine Lilkoff, spokeswoman for Prime Minister Jean Chretien.
But that may not be the end of the story. Early this month, Canada's Senate authorized a memorial and called on the House of Commons to unite with it and urge the Government to provide the federal land.
"It's time to accept that Canadian Vietnam War veterans are a part of our history," said Senator Jack Marshall, a Conservative from western Newfoundland. "They cannot and should not be ignored or forgotten any longer."
Senator Marshall, a World War II veteran, was the prime mover behind the resolution, which was supported by many veterans groups here.
 
'Wanted to See the World'
 Mr. Hitchins, a 49-year-old mobile home industry official, joined the United States Navy in 1963 at age 18. He enlisted with two buddies in Buffalo -- "we were young and wanted to see the world" -- and ended up as an electrician on the destroyer Charles S. Sperry in the South China Sea and the Gulf of Tonkin.
He estimates that about 40 percent of the Canadian veterans were draftees. American draft laws at the time applied to Canadians and other aliens, who between the ages of 18 and 26 had to register within six months of their entry into the United States.
Fred Gaffen, senior historian at the Canadian War Museum, said a "couple of thousand" young men returned to Canada to avoid being called up. But he noted that "most who were drafted served."
Mr. Gaffen, author of a book about the Canadian Vietnam experience called "Unknown Warriors" (Dundern Press), said many Canadians, especially those who fled Hungary and other Soviet satellites, were motivated by a desire to fight Communism.
"You have to see it as a product of the times," he observed.
The Canadian Government did nothing to stem the flow, even though a law on the books since the Spanish Civil War, the Foreign Enlistment Act, specifically banned enlistments in foreign armies.
 
Billions Sold to Pentagon
 "The Government made a political decision to turn a blind eye to that law," said Mr. Gaffen, pointing to Canada's heavy economic involvement in the war. Canadian companies sold the Pentagon $2.5 billion of war materiel, including ammunition, napalm, aircraft engines and explosives.
About $10 billion more was exported in food, beverages, berets and boots for the troops, as well as nickel, copper, lead, brass and oil for shell casings, wiring, plate armor and military transport, according to an entry in the Canadian Encyclopedia. During the war period, Canada's unemployment rate fell to a record low of 3.9 percent.
The Canadian veterans are eligible for most of the United States benefits available to American veterans, including treatment for exposure to Agent Orange, the chemical defoliant thought to be responsible for cancerous tumors and other severe medical complications experienced by some who served in Vietnam. Every Remembrance Day, comparable to Veterans Day in the United States, the men of the Ottawa chapter of the Vietnam Veterans Coalition hold a service for Gordon P. Eadie, a draftee from their area killed in action and buried in the small town of Carp, 10 miles west of Ottawa. He had lived in Detroit, where his father worked.
The 58,132 names engraved in the black granite of the Vietnam Memorial in Washington include Canadians, but just how many is still open to question. Many Canadians were identified from towns in the United States where they enlisted or were drafted. Gordon Eadie is listed from Detroit on the Vietnam memorial.
 
At Least 113 Killed
 The current official count is 113 Canadians killed, including 7 missing in action who are presumed dead. The Vietnam veterans group, which is now going through a painstaking check of all the names on the memorial in Washington, believes that it will find as many as 400 born in Canada. There is no accurate count of the number of wounded, but estimates range up to 1,000.
The veterans coalition, composed of 5,000 members in 14 chapters across the country, already has its memorial, an 11-foot-high structure, also of black granite, which will list the names of the Canadian dead and where they fell in Vietnam -- with room to add more names as they are confirmed.
The monument, built at a cost of $100,000, was donated by members of the Michigan Association of Concerned Veterans as a tribute to Canadian comrades.
With their memorial already in hand, the Canadian veterans expected that the Government would readily agree to a site. "We just wanted to bring our brothers home to a respected place in Ottawa," said Mike Ruggiero, who was with the First Marine Air Wing in Danang and Chulai in 1963 and is now director of the Toronto chapter of the coalition.
The veterans point out that Canada has dedicated a memorial at Arlington National Cemetery across the Potomac from the White House to the thousands of Americans who volunteered to fight with Canada and the other Allies in World War I and World War II, before the United States joined the conflicts.
 
'To Respect Canadian Ways'
 But in early May the Chretien Government turned down the request for a site on federal land. Questioned about the rejection in the House of Commons, Michel Dupuy, the Minister of Canadian Heritage, said, "We are going to respect Canadian ways."
Quebec has now gone its separate way. For five years it has had its own memorial, a slab of granite flanked by two blocks of marble, honoring its soldiers in Vietnam, many of them Mohawk Indians who volunteered. Moved once, the memorial is now in a park near the St. Lawrence Seaway in the town of Melocheville, about 20 miles west of Montreal.
Jacques Gendron, who served in the 330 Transportation Unit outside Saigon in 1964 and 1965 and is now president of the Quebec chapter of the coalition, said there was no controversy in Quebec.
"We decided to do it, and it was done," he said.

HEADLINE: First Out of the Chute: Bob Dole

 BODY:
Guess who's talking about running for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996? Bob Dole. Mr. Dole has come in for plenty of criticism here for sabotaging President Clinton's economic stimulus package and for his purblind opposition to campaign finance reform. Still, the Kansas Senator is a serious public servant and a warrior. We welcome his interest.
To which we add this thought: Let the Republican games begin. If nothing else, Mr. Dole's decision to hire political strategists and start raising money should awaken his party and force other potential candidates to show their hands. Moreover, it might concentrate the attention of the White House on the fact that Mr. Clinton does not look exactly like a lock for re-election. 
 Mr. Dole is a maddening figure. Few people possess his energy, mordant humor, legislative skills, command of complex issues and gifts for political deal-making. Conversely, few share his talent for self-destruction, traceable mainly to a bad temper and a reflexive instinct for the jugular.
His campaigns for the nomination in 1980 and 1988 were essentially one-man shows, poorly organized. As Gerald Ford's running mate in 1976, he managed to blame the Democrats for all of America's 20th-century war casualties. Many people still attribute Mr. Ford's narrow loss to Bob Dole's strident behavior.
Even his fellow Republicans find him abrasive. In 1971, Senator William Saxbe of Ohio described Mr. Dole as a "hatchetman who couldn't sell beer on a troop ship." One suspects, however, that their distemper is also related to Mr. Dole's ideological unpredictability. Make no mistake: he is a partisan Republican and a mainstream conservative on issues like spending and defense. Still, despite a generalized hostility to costly programs, he has shown flashes of compassion for society's outcasts.
He has regularly supported increases in food stamps and child nutrition, for instance, and he worked hard for passage of the Americans With Disabilities Act. "I don't see too many people in wheelchairs showing up at our meetings," he once told his Republican colleagues. He can also claim substantial credit for saving the Social Security system from bankruptcy in the mid-1980's.
Bob Dole won two Bronze Stars and permanently lost the use of his right arm during a firefight in World War II. He is one of the few remaining politicians from a Depression-era generation that produced the Mondales, the Humphreys, the Carters, the Nixons and the Reagans of this world.
Mr. Dole will be 71 next month and would be 73 on Inauguration Day. Too old? "You can be old at 50," Mr. Dole says. The younger contenders in his party -- Jack Kemp, Phil Gramm and Dan Quayle, to name a few -- would be foolish to take him lightly. This is a man who got so mad at his political consultant in 1980 that he sued him.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Straight At Stonewall

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
In which New York newspaper or magazine gay-people-are-everywhere story did you read the following last week? "They acquired unprecedented prominence throughout the city. . . . They became the subject of newspaper headlines, Broadway dramas, films and novels."
None. The passage was written by George Chauncey, a historian at the University of Chicago, in an extraordinary new book, "Gay New York." And Mr. Chauncey is not talking about the New York of 1994, where as many as a million gay men and lesbians are gathering for this weekend's Gay Games and next weekend's 25th anniversary of the fabled Stonewall rebellion, the politically liberating Greenwich Village riot prompted by a police raid on a gay bar. 
 No, Mr. Chauncey is instead describing the city's "forgotten gay world" of the years before World War II -- where anti-gay laws were "enforced only irregularly," and where many heterosexual New Yorkers regarded their gay neighbors with "indifference or curiosity, rather than hostility or fear."
That was New York in 1930? Then what happened between 1930 and 1969 to make Stonewall and the modern gay and lesbian movement it fostered necessary?
This is a question I find inescapable this week, as I join millions of other New Yorkers in accepting the lowly role of straight wallflower at New York's nonstop gay ball. Even if it's not our party, heterosexuals might wrest our own meaning from the Stonewall anniversary if only we try to understand why and how our world made a gay revolution inevitable.
There is no more eye-opening spur to such reflection than "Gay New York," which is one of the most fascinating works of American social history I've ever read. Because his subject was long ignored by professional historians, Mr. Chauncey had to begin his anthropological dig into the gay New York of 1890 to 1940 almost from scratch -- by mining mountains of court records and district attorney files, forgotten periodicals, diaries and oral histories to reconstruct detail by detail a thriving gay world reaching from Harlem to the Bowery, from the intellectual elite to the immigrant working class.
The bygone urban landscape he scrupulously documents, gay and straight, is as vivid as E. L. Doctorow's. But entertaining as it is to read about what once really went on in Automats or about how some popular gay vaudeville gags resurfaced unabashedly in Bugs Bunny-Elmer Fudd cartoons, "Gay New York" is not nostalgia. It takes us back not to a past we remember but to a past that was erased from history. Who knew that straight and openly gay American men long ago shared bars and friendship?
Mr. Chauncey's revelations about this century match the bombshells in "Same-Sex Unions in Premodern Europe," the new book by the Yale historian John Boswell offering proof that churches performed ceremonies sanctifying same-sex unions of some sort (if not definitively a sexual sort) as early as the eighth century. No sooner were Mr. Boswell's findings given widespread circulation by Garry Trudeau in "Doonesbury" than two Illinois newspapers banned the comic strip.
Why are some heterosexuals still so threatened not just by homosexuality but even by the revelation that their ancestors might have tolerated homosexuals? Why do we have so much invested in this particular bigotry? In "Gay New York," Mr. Chauncey finds an economic motive for straight New York's abrupt increase in its efforts to segregate and persecute gay New York in the 1930's: men of the Depression, psychologically emasculated by unemployment, felt they could bolster their masculine self-image by demonizing that of others.
And that legacy lingered. Almost every straight boy of my post-Depression generation tormented a gay person on the way to adulthood. The new scholars of gay history show that such cruel behavior can't easily be blamed on historical or religious precedent but only on our own minds and hearts; it is we who stigmatized gay people to shore up our own, embattled definitions of manhood.
Those days are not yet over. But if the Stonewall party belongs to those who escaped the closet over the past 25 years, it is also a timely invitation for those heterosexuals who built the closet to escape their own past. Must we wait a quarter-century to commemorate the liberation of straight New York?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: How the Federal Reserve Sets Policy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "History Upholds Fed's Rate Moves" (Viewpoints, May 29), Stuart E. Weiner fixes the natural rate of unemployment at a remarkably precise 6.75 percent. This figure neatly justifies the four interest rate increases made by the Federal Reserve the last few months despite any evidence of inflationary movement. 
 But Mr. Weiner has not seen fit to enlighten us as to what factors enter into his calculation or how long any unemployment rate in the complex and constantly changing American economic kaleidoscope can be regarded as "natural."
Mr. Weiner acknowledges that appreciable unemployment "represents substantial economic, social and human costs." His proposed remedy is that "policy makers should try to lower those costs through education and job training programs and reductions in employer mandates." But the job market is a shifting sand dune, and job openings do not wait for the completion of such efforts. Instead, the Fed ought to do some benefit-cost research to compare the relative costs of joblessness versus inflation of less than runaway proportions and to identify what groups bear the heaviest burdens.
 
SAMUEL M. GREENHOUSE
Boca Raton, Fla., June 1
 
The writer is a retired Government economist, who specialized in inflation and benefit-cost analysis.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

INDUSTRY: SIC6011 MONETARY AUTHORITIES - CENTRAL BANK;

HEADLINE: How the Federal Reserve Sets Policy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Next to national security, nothing affects Americans as much as decisions by the Federal Reserve. Nothing has a more universal and compelling impact on the cost of living than do interest rates, but it is difficult to comprehend the Fed's decision-making process concerning rates. 
 When the Fed pushed down short-term interest rates in 1992, a big reason was to help the banking industry recover from tremendous losses on real estate loans. Low short-term rates widened the spread between the rates the banks paid depositors and the rates they charged borrowers. The low cost of funds also enabled banks to invest in medium-term securities. Banks were able to restore their battered balance sheets, even though the total amount of loans on their books stopped growing.
I cannot understand why the Federal Reserve would reduce interest rates in the Reagan-Bush years, when the debt and deficit increased, yet raise rates in the Clinton term, when the President is trying to trim entitlements and spending and raise taxes.
The history of the Fed is not one of successful economic policies. Where was the watchful eye of the Fed when the stock market crashed in 1929? Where was the Fed in the early 1930's when the banks were closed because of abuse and the lack of effective controls? How could the Fed permit the interest rate on the long bond to increase to 14 1/2 percent in 1981? Has the Fed supplied any convincing evidence that it was not substantially at fault in the recent savings and loan crisis? The Fed has an entire arsenal of weapons to use against irresponsible and dangerous banking practices; has it effectively used approaches other than interest rates to monitor and stabilize the monetary system and the economy?
 
CHARLES A. VANIK
Washington, June 1
 
The writer retired from the House of Representatives in 1981 after 26 years representing the Cleveland suburbs.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST VILLAGE;
Christopher Street: Changes Sweep the Gay Mecca

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
IT was once known as Skinner Road, hewing to an ancient dirt path that Indians used to carry lobsters and oysters inland from a cove on the Hudson. By 1799, it had been renamed Christopher Street.
For most of its modern existence, Christopher Street was a working-class enclave, filled with longshoremen and their families. 
 But long before the police raided the Stonewall Inn in Sheridan Square in the summer of 1969, the street had a thriving, though largely unseen, gay night life. As early as the 1940's, some longtime residents say, a bar called the Colony catered to a gay clientele at Christopher and Gay Streets, attracting a crowd that had migrated from night-time pick-up areas like Washington Square West.
Since the mid-1970's, the street has been known virtually worldwide as the mecca of gay life in New York City and, indeed, in the United States, rivaled only by Polk Street in San Francisco.
"If you wanted to be on a street with other gay people, Christopher Street was it," says Eric Marcus, 35 years old, who has written several books about gay life. "There was nothing like it."
Now, mirroring changes in the gay community as a whole, the street is in transition.
Thousands of people who once packed its bars and stores have died as a result of AIDS. The disease has likewise hit the ranks of those who ran gay-oriented businesses, meaning that the storefronts have a less outwardly gay character than they had a decade ago.
But the street has changed most dramatically, many say, because much of gay culture no longer has to cloister, or ghettoize, itself, a development embodied by the Gay Games and Stonewall celebration this week. Perhaps nothing is more emblematic of the wider acceptance than the tour buses that show out-of-towners the more popular gay bars.
"As society at large has accepted homosexual patterns and people, the need for a secluded gay cruising area has sort of gone away," says Terry Miller, author of "Greenwich Village and How It Got That Way" (Crown, 1990).
What that means for Christopher Street is that, increasingly, gay people in their 20's and 30's are living and socializing in Chelsea and other areas, and gay businesses are following them.
But even as these people gravitate to other areas, others keep coming for the same reasons the earlier generation came: refuge. A wave of younger gay people -- mostly male, minority teen-agers from outside Manhattan -- is discovering Christopher Street, congregating toward the western end and claiming it as their own.
"White gay men can go to a lot of other places -- Park Slope, Chelsea -- and blend in very well with their dinner parties and couples walking to the Laundromat and everything," said Wade Hanley, 21, who is from Harlem. "But we can't really hang out on the corner where we live, so we come here. This is where I feel comfortable."
But whether their presence takes hold depends on economics and an emerging tension with the surrounding community.
"Christopher Street seems to me to be a street looking for an identity, a street that doesn't know what it's going to be in 10 or 20 years," Mr. Marcus says. "It will be interesting to watch."

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Wedding Band

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER 

 BODY:
AFTER 27 years of playing at countless weddings, Stuart White has confronted every type of nuptial disaster.
"I've had a family member drop dead on the dance floor, serious fights with people flying over tables, even two nuns slugging it out at the table," Mr. White said. "My one rule when disaster strikes is: Play music!" 
 His rule came in handy several years ago when a young groom broke a promise to his bride that he would not smoke marijuana on their wedding day. During the cake-cutting, she smelled the telltale smoke.
"The next thing I heard was somebody shout, 'Oh my God, she slugged him!' " With bride fleeing, groom reeling, parents palpitating and guests gawking, Mr. White had the band strike up "Get on Your Feet," an uptempo dance song by Gloria Estefan, while he persuaded the bride to return.
A percussionist by trade and vice chairman of Steven Scott Productions, a consortium of 30 bands and event producers, Stuart White attends more June weddings than the average priest or rabbi. The company, a musical McDonald's of the matrimonial set,will provide entertainment for at least 142 weddings this month.
In the last few weeks, he has conducted a 12-piece orchestra at a Greek-Venezuelan wedding reception at the St. Regis; a 25-piece band at a 300-person reception in Port Chester, N.Y., and an 18-piece group at a reception in Smithtown, L.I., complete with a flashing fiber-optic curtain.
"If you do weddings you have to be able to provide every possible kind of music," said Mr. White, whose own appearance bespeaks differing styles: from the front, his gray hair is cropped short; the back is worn in a braided pony tail. "The wrong music, the wrong song, can ruin the party for a lot of people."
Mr. White tries to make certain that nothing of the sort occurs at his events. "I'm a detail freak," he said during a conversation the other day at his sleek West 57th Street office. He interviews couples several times before the wedding and even goes so far as to provide samples of classical music for the ceremony.
Couples trying to economize might do better with individual orchestras, but the risks are higher and the opportunities for different music more limited. Steven Scott Productions employs more than 300 professional musicians, representing everything from classical to Cajun. There are no average prices for wedding music: it can be as low as $600 for a jazz trio or as high as the $275,000 spent for a Manhattan wedding last summer that involved a 50-piece orchestra, three full rehearsals, custom outfits and lighting that rivaled a rock concert.
If a couple yearns for Sinatra, Mr. White, in the name of "personal service," reaches into his musical bullpen and produces a vocalist, say Tom Smith of Queens, who sounds eerily like the original (although there is no physical resemblance). Salsa? No problem. He might send out a nine-piece Latin troupe called Fiesta.
Mr. White, the son of a percussion player, joined the company in 1967, six years after it was founded by two bandleaders, Marvin Kurz and Sy Menchin, whose children were named Steven and Scott. The company is now run by a bandleader, Joey Mills, along with Mr. White and 14 partners, all musicians.
While Steven Scott Productions specializes in weddings and bar mitzvahs in the New York area, it also takes on bigger, more prestigious projects. Its bands participated in President Clinton's inaugural parties, the Statue of Liberty Centennial and numerous Super Bowls. The company expects to send bands to about 4,500 events in 1994, with billings of more than $10 million.
On a recent Saturday night, Mr. White assembled a big band for a 300-guest Italian wedding at the Rye Town Hilton, up in Westchester. Mr. White, in white jacket and bolo tie, led the three singers (plus "Mr. Sinatra," five horns, nine violins, keyboard, percussion, guitar, bass, congas and harp).
The band performed a peppy set of top-40 tunes from the last 20 years, moving fluidly from Michael Jackson to Andrew Lloyd Webber. The crowd streamed onto the dance floor. John and Margaret Retoske, waving their arms above their heads while remaining still from the knees down as if glued to the wood floor, gave the band high marks.
"We've been married 56 years," he said. "This is great, just great."
Most Steven Scott musicians interviewed said they enjoyed the weddings almost as much as the guests did, not only for the good pay (from $300 to $500 a party, up to $60,000 a year), but also for the receptive audiences.
"At weddings you have to play all kinds of music -- jazz, standards, R and B -- and it really keeps your chops up," said John-Martin Green, a vocalist with long braided hair and a quick smile. "And the audience is always rooting for you. They always want to have a good time."
Any musician who has worked weddings for some time would probably say that musical trends last about as long as the average American marriage. "In the 70's, it was very contemporary, with a lot of disco," Mr. White said. "In the 80's, it got more mellow, and now there is a big return to classics like Nat Cole, Tony Bennett and Sinatra."
Mr. Smith, the Sinatra singer, added, "To see young artists doing those old songs makes it legitimate for many people." The most popular wedding song this year, the musicians said, is Nat King Cole's version of "It Had to Be You."
At 10 P.M., the party was rocking, black ties yanked off, well-coiffed hair tumbling down. The band was churning out a 70's disco medley while the two female singers jogged in place as if they were on a treadmill.
"I've been doing this for 22 years," said Steve Goldstein, the sound man. "At this time in the party they always go for this disco stuff."
At half past midnight, the horns were finally packed away. Mr. White took a deep breath, and the honeymoon couple started to get ready for the long flight to Hawaii.

GRAPHIC: Photo: For 27 years, Stuart White, center, has been providing 'every possible kind of music' and otherwise working hard to keep people happy at wedding receptions. (Photograph by Susan Harris for The New York Times)

Can band stay overtime?
What is band's attire?

HEADLINE: Organizing a City: A Celebration From A to Z

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
LAST month, Mayor Giuliani asked his Labor Commissioner to have a quiet talk with George M. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' owner, about what was good for the city.
What was good for the city, the Mayor wanted Mr. Steinbrenner to know, was to let 10,400 gay and lesbian athletes parade through Yankee Stadium for the closing ceremonies of the Gay Games IV and Cultural Festival, an eight-day Olympic-style competition meant to break down stereotypes about homosexuality. 
 Mr. Steinbrenner had rejected requests from Gay Games organizers for months, arguing that he could not risk harming the field during the baseball season and that the Yankees, who lease the stadium from the city, had already promised it that weekend to the Catholic High Schools Baseball Championship.
But after some gentle pressure from the Commissioner, Randy L. Levine, who until a few months before had represented the Yankees as a private lawyer, the combative baseball boss suddenly changed his mind, city and Yankee officials said. (No one will say why Mr. Steinbrenner had a change of heart, though it cannot be ignored that angering the Mayor would not be in Mr. Steinbrenner's interest while the Yankees are negotiating with the city about a host of financial issues.)
The unexpected intervention by a Republican Mayor who prides himself on being a diehard Yankee fan and a product of Catholic schools was but one of an incalculable number of political and diplomatic efforts, logistical maneuvers, business deals and intellectual and artistic enterprises that will coalesce this week in what organizers are billing as the largest tribute to homosexuality in the history of the city, if not the world.
Beginning last night, and for the next seven days, the city will become a playing field not only for the Gay Games but for the celebration of the 25th anniversary of the Stonewall uprising, the 1969 clash between transvestites and the police that marked the beginning of the gay-rights movement. From this base, the prodigious talents and resources of New York's gay world have spun off a vast array of performances, fairs, parties, exhibitions and dances that will turn lower Manhattan into something akin to a weeklong festival of gayness, culminating next Sunday in the Stonewall march and rally in Central Park.
These celebrations, in turn, will coincide with the opening local matches of the 1994 soccer World Cup just across the Hudson in the New Jersey Meadowlands.
If all goes as planned, about 1.2 million people from across the nation and from more than 60 countries -- a crowd that would rival those that gathered for the Bicentennial in 1976 and Liberty Weekend a decade later -- will be feted, fed, domiciled and entertained in an operation that would challenge Napoleon Bonaparte's talents.
Much is at stake for Mr. Giuliani's administration and for the city itself. Not only is New York's vaunted reputation for keeping order and handling vast events on the line, but also its reputation as the most tolerant and diverse metropolis in the world. Organizers of the Goodwill Games, to be held in New York in 1998, are watching closely.
How all this came to pass is not, of course, simply a lesson in logistics, albeit logistics of imperial proportions. The history of the making of this event -- a gay festival that seems certain to rouse much of the nation's largest city, and many of its "straight" citizens, from the routines of daily life -- is also a social, political and economic statement subject to a variety of interpretations.
Asked about Mr. Giuliani's actions on behalf of the games, his press secretary, Cristyne Lategano, said they had not been motivated by politics.
"He's treating them as he would treat anyone else," Ms. Lategano said. "His motivation is to showcase New York. He's not a moralist."
But it is certainly true that Mr. Giuliani has had to balance his desire to win supporters among gay men and lesbians against a possible backlash from some of his core supporters, some of whom are religiously or morally opposed to homosexuality. Gay men and lesbians voted 2 to 1 against Mr. Giuliani in the last election, according to exit polls. Late last week, the administration announced that the Mayor had decided to give a short speech at the opening ceremonies of the games last night.
For gay men and lesbians, the months of preparations have revealed divisions within their body politic. There have been bitter disagreements between different gay-rights groups about the route of the Stonewall march, and debates have sprung up about the importance of the games, which some more radical homosexuals feel have commercialized their movement.
In these debates, a deeper disagreement has emerged about the future of a movement that began with Stonewall. Should it mobilize to fight human-rights abuses against gay people around the world, or should it seek to escalate the fight against AIDS?
Beyond this divide, though, all but the most radical participants would probably share a common cry, organizers say -- that the floods of gay people will send an indisputable message to the world through its media capital that gay people are everywhere, look much like everyone else and should be accepted, protected by law and treasured.
"We are your mothers, fathers, sisters, brothers and grandmothers and your cousins," said Pat Norman, a co-chairman of the march organization, Stonewall 25. "Believe me, we are family."
The games were begun in San Francisco in 1982 by a former Olympic decathlete, Tom Waddel. The first games were relatively modest, with about 1,300 athletes, but they have grown steadily. This year's games will bring in 10,400 athletes from 40 countries for 30 sports, from billiards and bowling to traditional Olympic endeavors like track and wrestling.
From the beginning, one of the driving purposes of the games, which are open to heterosexuals as well, has been to show the world a different image of homosexuals than the limp-wristed and fey stereotype.
The push to bring the Gay Games to New York began humbly enough in 1989, when Thomas Cracovia, a bodybuilder and a lifetime competitor in amateur track and field, had lunch with a soccer enthusiast named Karen Merbaum, at the Rio Grande restaurant in Manhattan.
Both had competed in the second Gay Games in 1986 in San Francisco, and both say the experience of performing as openly gay athletes before thousands of accepting fans had changed their lives. But Mr. Cracovia had something else he wanted to talk about, just the spark of an idea really.
"I thought, this thing has become more international," Mr. Cracovia remembered. "Why not bring it to New York?"
"We never thought it would grow to these proportions," Ms. Merbaum recalled.
The two formed a seven-member committee and put together a proposal to sell the Federation of Gay Games on New York when the federation met in Denver in early 1990. They sought out the Mayor at the time, David N. Dinkins, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and armed with letters of support, easily beat out Sydney, Australia, in large part because the Stonewall anniversary would coincide with the 1994 games, they said.
Since winning the nod for this year's games, the Gay Games organization in New York has done an impressive job raising money, gaining sponsors and negotiating with the city for high-profile venues. It has grown from a handful of volunteers with a staff of two to an organization that has a paid staff of 70 and occupies three floors of a Chelsea office building.
Much of that expansion was the handiwork of the tenacious and impassioned executive director, Jay Hill, a former sportswriter for Newsweek and ABC News who took over the group in December 1992. "We're a disenfranchised group, so it has been tooth and nail every step of the way," Mr. Hill said.
Under Mr. Hill's leadership, the games raised about $4 million of their $6.5 million budget through a series of fund-raising events across the country. The most successful were a posh dinner last August at the Puck Building, with Martina Navratilova as host, and a "fantasy auction" in January, where contributors bid on donated art or bought things like dinner with Joan Rivers.
But the games also drew about $1.3 million from corporate sponsors and merchandisers who are selling everything from Gay Games T-shirts to candy bars. The biggest corporate sponsors are Miller Brewing, Continental Airlines and Nora Beverages U.S.A., which sells Naya Spring Water. Mr. Hill said many corporations had been leery of a gay stigma, but said he had concentrated on those that had already shown an interest in the market.
The corporate support is a measure of a growing recognition that gay people represent an important and untapped market, the companies' spokesmen said. A recent market survey suggested that gay men and lesbians make up at least 5.7 percent of the nation's population. They also tend to be well-educated, self-employed, and concerned with fitness, and are likely to have more disposable income for luxury items and vacations than heterosexuals with children do.
"You've got a group of people with a certain profile who are as attractive as all get-out to certain clients," said Gunnar Jordan, who heads a marketing firm that represents Naya, which has been advertising in gay magazines since the late 1980's.
Gay groups had boycotted Miller Brewing several years ago for contributing to conservative politicians. But Sophia Nieves, a Miller spokeswoman, said the decision to endorse the games was "pretty cut and dried," a matter of "good business sense" rather than fence-mending. "Our decision doesn't stem from any desire to send out a political message," she said.
But the corporations may also be attracted to the relatively innocuous image of the Gay Games, said some gay advocates in more radical New York City circles. For instance, the logo for the games that appears on Miller Beer banners and ads is a stylized torch with the slogan Unity '94 beneath it. Nowhere does the word "gay" appear.
In addition to corporate sponsors, Mr. Hill and his staff racked up an impressive list of parks, gyms, pools, tennis courts, auditoriums and athletic fields for the events. The games rented Columbia University's Wien Stadium for its opening ceremonies last night and hired facilities at New York University and Hunter and Lehman Colleges. The Paramount Theater was rented for the body- building competition.
With some help from the Dinkins administration, Mr. Hill also managed to obtain several quasi-public facilities, including the National Tennis Center in Queens.
But the vast majority of venues were provided free by the Parks Department, most notably the tumbledown but serviceable Downing Stadium on Randalls Island, for track and field. The last time the parks were used for such a large athletic event was for the 1964 Olympic trials. Parks Commissioner Henry Stern said the Gay Games organization had easily met every requirement for using the venues, including posting bonds and providing sanitation and security.
"We're sort of excited about the games," he said. "It could be a dry run for the Goodwill Games in 1998."
 
FOR THE STONEWALL MARCH, A MUCH ROCKIER PATH
 If the relationship between the city and the Gay Games has been smooth and cooperative, much the opposite has been true of the city's dealings with the organizers of the Stonewall march.
Planning for the march began in 1989 at an international conference of gay-pride organizers in Vancouver. From the beginning, national and international gay-rights groups played a role in shaping the march, and the organizers saw it as an opportunity to throw a spotlight on international human-rights abuses against gay people and to call for their inclusion in the United Nations universal declaration of human rights.
But New York gay-rights groups have tried to shift the focus of the march to the fight against AIDS. They have also argued about the route of the march, saying it should begin at the site of the Stonewall rebellion, on the north side of Sheridan Square, not at the United Nations.
"Stonewall is where it all began," said City Councilman Thomas G. Duane, echoing the views of others in the dissident group. "I wouldn't be on the City Council if there wasn't a Stonewall. There wouldn't be a million openly gay and lesbian peole coming to New York if it wasn't for Stonewall."
But even as the committee organizing the march, Stonewall 25, was riven by internal disputes, it was also plagued by chronic shortages of cash. Organizers said the aggressive fund-raising by the Gay Games had hurt their efforts.
"There has been some confusion out there as people who have given to the Gay Games think the money also benefited us," said Franklin Fry, a co-chairman of the march who was at the center of the negotiations over the route.
Against this backdrop, negotiations with the city did not begin in earnest until early February, Mr. Fry said. At first, the organizers sought four separate march routes to the rally in Central Park, including the one past the U.N., but the city refused, saying such a scheme would paralyze Manhattan.
Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor who has largely overseen the city's plans, said the city had raised objections to blocking First Avenue and had concerns about using Central Park, since the Great Lawn could hold no more than 250,000 people, far fewer than the organizers' predicted one million. The administration suggested leading the march south on the F.D.R. Drive to a rally in Battery Park, which the Stonewall 25 committee rejected vehemently.
After two months of failed negotiations, the organizers called in Ethan Geto, a well-known lobbyist and gay-rights advocate, who helped the two sides fashion a compromise.
Shortly after Mr. Geto entered the talks, Mr. Giuliani agreed to give the organizers Central Park and to make every effort to let them march past the United Nations, city officials said. But having ceded those points, the city insisted on a single route.
So, in late May, the organizers reluctantly agreed to a route that would pass up First Avenue, across 57th Street and up Sixth Avenue into Central Park, and to sacrifice Fifth Avenue, the traditional path of annual Gay Pride marches. This concession brought down the ire of the AIDS protest group ACT-UP and several other organizations.
Last Monday, the Stonewall organizers responded to the outcry by proposing a second route beginning at the United Nations, moving west across 42d Street, then north on Fifth Avenue, entering the park at 57th Street. The Giuliani administration rejected the proposal Friday.
To complicate matters further, ACT-UP and dozens of smaller groups have vowed to stage a march along an unauthorized route from the Village to Central Park, prompting suggestions of arrests by the police. The New York Civil Liberties Union has threatened to file a lawsuit tomorrow, saying that to deny the Village gay groups an alternative route is a violation of First Amendment rights.
There has also been friction about the rally itself. Arguing that performances by celebrities could draw larger crowds, the administration has demanded a list of who will speak and insisted that big-name performers not give full-length performances. The organizers have accused the city of trampling their First Amendment rights; the Civil Liberties Union has supported their case.
But city officials say more practical problems are threatening to derail the march. The financial difficulties have made it unclear whether the Stonewall group will be able to post a $50,000 bond for the use of Central Park. And last week, the organizers missed a deadline for finalizing contracts with vendors to provide a stage, portable toilets, security, and a sound system for the rally. Without these, the city had still not issued a permit on Friday.
 
FASHIONING A MECHANISM FROM AN ARRAY OF MOVING PARTS
 The city's planning for the events began more than two years ago and intensified in recent months as the new administration took over and June loomed nearer.
The two thorniest issues have been the route of the Stonewall march and obtaining Yankee Stadium for the Gay Games ceremony. But beyond those negotiations, the logistical choreography has had myriad mundane parts that could spell the difference between disaster and a smooth operation.
For the most part, responsibility for the city's plans was placed in the hands of Ms. Reiter, who in turn oversaw a small cadre of longtime civil servants with experience running special events from the Police, Emergency Medical Service, and Parks, Fire and Sanitation Departments.
"You really want to take every possibility into account," Ms. Reiter said. "This has been a serious exercise so that people can have a lot of fun."
Ms. Reiter would not speculate about how much the events would cost the city, though it is safe to say overtime will reach into tens of millions of dollars. The Stonewall march alone will require 4,600 police officers. But officials expect more than $500 million to be spent by visitors to the city, Ms. Reiter said.
To begin with, the Police Department took unusual measures to diminish the chance of a clash between officers and gay advocates or between gay tourists and soccer enthusiasts.
The police were so worried about conflicts between soccer fans and the Gay Games spectators that they have assigned extra patrols in Manhattan all week. And in March, the police called a meeting to ask consuls from World Cup countries to educate their citizens about New York's gay-bashing laws, Inspector Thomas Mullen said.
"We told them they might see things that they think are obnoxious and that what might be hijinks in one country could be a bias crime in New York," Inspector Mullen said.
From the middle of June until mid-July, the police will establish safe corridors on 23d Street and Eighth Avenue in Chelsea, with an officer on every block to provide secure passage to gay clubs. The department also trained and equipped seven special mobile riot units to back up regular officers in case of bar fights or riots, Inspector Mullen said.
For the rank and file, the department produced a special training film intended to explain gay life styles and compelled all officers to watch it at roll call in the last two weeks. In addition, each officer was given a new booklet with answers to questions gay visitors might ask, like the locations of gay community groups.
Besides public safety, perhaps the biggest logistical headache has been to keep the city moving. While the Transit Authority has dedicated extra trains and buses, the Transportation Department plans to have at least 150 extra traffic agents and other officials monitoring for backups and traffic jams.
Transportation officials are also trying to find ways to minimize the congestion in Manhattan on July 26, the day of the Stonewall march. And general traffic problems may be worsened should the strike on the Long Island Rail Road continue.
"The month of June is not a month to drive your car into Manhattan," said Gregory Perrin, the Transportation Department's director of special events.
Even in the preparations, not everything has gone smoothly. At the last minute, the city refused to grant a permit to the Gay and Lesbian Vistors Center, a Chelsea tourist company, for a street fair next Saturday on Eighth Avenue between 14th and 23d Streets. The center had already spent tens of thousands of dollars preparing for the event, which had the support of the local community board and businesses and had attracted sponsors like Coors Beer and Coca Cola.
But city officials decided that it would cost too much to police yet another fair, and that blocking off Eighth Avenue when much of the Village was already closed to cars would create a traffic disaster.
In the end, officials said, the entire week has an air of uncertainty about it. Many gay groups are planning wildcat marches and demonstrations. For instance, the Church Ladies for Choice, a transvestite organization, plans to march Friday night from Tompkins Square to Sheridan Square. And a radical feminist group, the Lesbian Avengers, is vowing to hold an unauthorized "International Dyke March" down Fifth Avenue from 42d Street to Washington Square on Saturday night. Neither has a permit.
"The nightmares that develop are usually the ones you don't anticipate," said Mr. Stern, the Parks Commissioner, as he reflected on the uncertainty surrounding the Stonewall rally. "Anything you do is likely to be distorted by some group, so you might was well try to do the right thing."

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS VIEW;
A Brash Kid No More: The Maturing of a Maestro

BYLINE: By DAVID SCHIFF; David Schiff is a composer who teaches at Reed College in Portland, Ore.

 BODY:
IF YOU THINK MICHAEL Tilson Thomas is still that brash kid looking over Leonard Bernstein's shoulder, you probably have not kept up with his recordings. But it hasn't been easy to do so. Mr. Thomas's recorded output is scattered on six different labels, and many of his fine early recordings are out of print or have been reissued in confusing repackagings. Mr. Thomas has recorded with many orchestras -- though mainly with the London Symphony, of which he has been principal conductor since 1988, and the New World Symphony, his superb training orchestra in Miami Beach.
An overview of his recordings reveals that the "kid," who turns 50 in December and is soon to become music director of the San Francisco Symphony, has become a mature and distinctive maestro. 
 Mr. Thomas is audibly American in his style of conducting and his choice of repertory. More than 20 years ago, he established his national credentials with impressive recordings of Ives and Ruggles (on Deutsche Grammophon). He has since recorded the complete orchestral music of Ruggles (CBS; sadly out of print) and nearly all of Ives's orchestral works (Sony).
At the pop end of the American spectrum his high-spirited recordings of Gershwin include the first performance of "Rhapsody in Blue" to use Gershwin's piano roll and the original Whiteman arrangement, and a rapturously celebratory album of songs with Sarah Vaughan, which could serve as a definition of American music (CBS). "Tangazo," Mr. Thomas's recent album of Latin American classical music with the New World Symphony (Argo), shows his prescient awareness of the ever-changing mix of American culture.
But what has always set Mr. Thomas apart is his dual allegiance to modernist music, particularly the American avant-garde, and Broadway. His theatrical bent comes from his family heritage -- the famed Yiddish actor Boris Thomashevsky was his paternal grandfather -- but also from his close associations with Ira Gershwin and Bernstein.
His flair for reconciling the diverse stylistic strains of the Broadway idiom is clear in his recordings of Gershwin's "Of Thee I Sing" and the less familiar "Let Them Eat Cake" (CBS) and of Bernstein's "On the Town" (Deutsche Grammophon). Mr. Thomas has a superb sense of the period flavor of these works, and he brings out the naive worldliness of the Gershwin shows and the big-band swagger and wartime anxiety of the Bernstein.
Mr. Thomas's modernist roots are equally distinctive. He grew up in the Los Angeles of Arnold Schoenberg and Igor Stravinsky. He was present at many of Stravinsky's recording sessions, and even before he studied with Bernstein, he served as Pierre Boulez's assistant at the Ojai Festival in California. In the 70's he conducted the Buffalo Philharmonic when that orchestra was synonymous with avant-garde experiment. Two of his early recordings were a literally smashing performance of the piano duet version of "The Rite of Spring," and the proto-Minimalist "Four Organs" by Steve Reich, then unknown, whose work Mr. Thomas continues to champion (EMI/Angel).
Although he has remained remarkably faithful to these roots, the conductor who emerges on the recent recordings has a wider range of repertory and a greater subtlety of interpretation than the young Thomas. Recent Sony recordings of works by Brahms, Debussy and Stravinsky (with the London Symphony) reveal the mature Thomas at his most distinctive. These recordings share a luminous sound quality, a fresh attention to details of sonority and texture, and an unstoppable rhythmic verve.
Much the way Brahms waited until middle age to write his First Symphony, Mr. Thomas has so far recorded all the Brahms orchestral music except the warhorse symphonies and concertos. He makes a strong case for approaching the more familiar works through the two youthful serenades (SK 45932, 47195). They are really symphonies in disguise, or to put it another way, they announce Brahms's intention to redefine the symphony in terms of chamber music.
Mr. Thomas respects the belated Classicism of these Romantic works. His approach is spacious and unhurried yet flavorsome. He brings out the rich undertones of stylistic allusions, a little Hungarian here, a little Viennese there, echoes of Haydn, Schubert and Mendelssohn, which give these works their particular charm. But the sonority of the wind instruments gives the most pleasure here, for they carry most of the melodic burden.
Both as soloists and as an ensemble, the wind section of the London Symphony plays with warmth, elegance and superb intonation. Who said Brahms couldn't orchestrate?
Sonority is also the focus of Mr. Thomas's recording of Debussy's "Martyrdom of St. Sebastian" (SK 48240); indeed, a listener may want to spend a weekend or two just wallowing in the physical seductiveness of the sound. This work, written as incidental music for an erotically charged mystery play by Gabriele d'Annunzio, has long been the ugly duckling among Debussy's works, rejected by many of his admirers as an economically motivated reversion to the ersatz religion of Wagner's "Parsifal." At best, it has been praised for its stained-glass orchestration; it has most often been performed as an orchestral suite without its controversial text.
Charles Munch's haunting narration on his 1956 recording with the Boston Symphony revealed the dramatic power behind the orchestral glow, but Mr. Thomas, who uses every scrap of music Debussy wrote for the play, finally unveils the full emotional range of this anguished yet tender masterpiece.
The powerful presence of Leslie Caron in the speaking role of Sebastian is the key to Mr. Thomas's success here. As in Strauss's "Rosenkavalier," composed at the same time, the music is saturated by the giddy sound of women's voices, most notably in the shining high soprano of Sylvia McNair. Restoring Sebastian to its original trouser -- or rather, loincloth -- role further brings out the free-floating sexual ambiguity of the play and the music, and underscores its symbolic nature. "The Martyrdom" is less a martyrology than a great elegy for the death of beauty. From its opening woodwind chord, more beautifully organlike than any organ, to its ecstatic closing "Alleluia," the music is a glory of sound.
A quite different "Alleluia" concludes Stravinsky's "Symphony of Psalms," heard with his Symphony in C and Symphony in Three Movements on Mr. Thomas's most recent Sony release (SK 53275). With Stravinsky, Mr. Thomas returns to his musical childhood, and the performances appear at first to follow Stravinsky's own recordings very closely.
Yet a comparison soon reveals important differences. Many of Stravinsky's performances, though perfectly paced and sharply articulated, were, well, sloppy. His Symphony in Three Movements is full of bloopers and splats that for this listener become more distracting with every passing year. Mr. Thomas's performances offer a Stravinskian rhythmic panache with a fine finish.
Whether these recordings will finally place all three works in the symphonic repertory is another question. The Symphony in C, even as beautifully played as it is here, remains strangely reticent. Stravinsky himself pointed to the stylistic split between its European and American movements (the work was begun in France and finished in the United States), but the music is perhaps covertly Russian. The first and last movements begin with allusions to Tchaikovsky's first and last symphonies, and despite its Classical title, the symphony does not really engage the Classical tradition but often sounds like a private conversation between Stravinsky and Tchaikovsky.
The Symphony in Three Movements, by contrast, is Stravinsky's most American work and also one of the few that according to the composer, engages with contemporary historical events, in this case World War II. Much of the third movement in particular seems to anticipate "West Side Story." (Or is it echoing "Fancy Free," written the year before?) Mr. Thomas captures the postwar euphoria of the last movement, yet the work, which was cobbled together out of several unused film scores, continues to sound more like a great ballet -- as Balanchine realized -- than a symphony.
DESPITE THE RICH inventiveness of the two instrumental symphonies, the "Symphony of Psalms" remains the only one of Stravinsky's later works to win over the concert audience. Listeners have felt that here Stravinsky dropped the masks and manners through which he distanced much of his music.
Mr. Thomas fully takes advantage of the opportunity to get beneath the stylistic surface. His performance is tensely dramatic, following Stravinsky's very precise progress of religious moods from despair through hope to peace.
The opening of the third movement captures a feeling I had never heard in Stravinsky's performances. In Hebrew the word "kavanah" signifies a spiritual readiness for prayer. At the beginning of the third movement, a setting of Psalm 150, the chorus prepares itself for an ultimate song of praise. Mr. Thomas imbues this music with "kavanah." It sounds both anticipatory and calm, as if the singers already knew the goal of the purgatorial struggle that would lead them to the paradise of the final "Alleluia."
