SECTION: Section 6; Page 36; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1731 words

HEADLINE: REAGAN'S REVENGE -- AS INVENTED BY HOWARD JARVIS

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley is a professor of American history at Columbia University and the author of "The Transformation of New Deal Liberalism," to be published next year by Knopf.

 BODY:
Presodent Clinton no doubt remembers 1978 as the year he was first elected Governor of Arkansas. But historians may well point to another event that year with an even more important impact on the President's subsequent career: a tax revolt in California that continues, 16 years later, to haunt the American political landscape.
The impact of the tax revolt -- and of the fiscal crisis it helped create -- is particularly visible in the Clinton Administration's two major domestic initiatives of 1994. The fate of the President's health care reform may well rest on his ability to persuade Congress and the electorate that employer mandates are not a tax. And the Administration's welfare reform plan is being crippled by Congressional requirements that new expenditures be accompanied by new revenues (something the President is unlikely to request after the trauma of the 1993 budget fight) or equivalent reductions in related programs. 
 And so Administration officials astonish themselves by contemplating a kind of social cannibalism: raids on such hitherto sacrosanct liberal programs as food stamps, Medicare, public assistance to legal immigrants and aid for the homeless. The first Administration in nearly 30 years with an expansive view of Government's power to do good finds itself imprisoned within a fiscal environment that makes it difficult for Government to do anything.
THE MOST VISIBLE ORIGINS OF CLINTON'S predicament lies in the fiscal policies of the Reagan Administration and the enormous structural deficits they helped produced. But the Reagan policies themselves had their origins in an important shift in conservative strategy in the 1970's, when a talented group of right-wing organizers channeled the widespread economic and political frustrations of their time into a revolt against taxes. For a short time, the most prominent figure in that effort was Howard Jarvis, a retired California businessman who orchestrated the stunning 2-to-1 victory of Proposition 13 -- the 1978 ballot initiative requiring a significant reduction of his state's property taxes.
Jarvis had spent more than a decade leading futile antitax crusades in California before 1978. Like other right-wing figures, he fought against taxes not just because he thought they were too high but because he opposed the Government programs they supported. At various times he had called for ending public financing for such services as parks, libraries, garbage collection and schools. He had opposed Social Security and Medicare. Because of these stands, he remained on the fringes of mainstream politics. But in the late 1970's -- as property tax levies in California soared and as popular cynicism about politics grew -- Jarvis and others adopted a new strategy. They separated the issue of taxes from the issue of what taxes support. That became the key not only to the success of Proposition 13 but to much of the "Reagan Revolution" of 1981.
For generations, American conservative leaders -- from Herbert Hoover to Barry Goldwater -- had appealed for support by warning of the dangers Government programs posed to individual freedom. But attacking Government programs had failed to topple the liberal order. Almost everyone had a stake in some of them. The biggest and most expensive programs -- Social Security, Medicare, veterans' benefits and others -- had the strongest support. In 1978, therefore, the supporters of Proposition 13 prudently de-emphasized their hostility to Government services. They refrained from attacking the public schools, parks and libraries. They even largely spared the welfare system.
They based their crusade instead on two related complaints. First, they emphasized the cost to individuals of high taxes. In his self-congratulatory 1979 memoir, "I'm Mad as Hell," Jarvis described friends and acquaintances whom he claimed had literally died as a result of their tax burdens -- among them a woman who dropped dead of a heart attack in the city office in Los Angeles "in the very act of pleading about the prohibitive level of property taxes on her home."
Second, and more significantly, they attacked the governing class -- and its supposed extravagance, inefficiency and corruption. Satirical cartoons showed public works employees idling away the day, sitting on the curb next to their work sites or filling in a hole they had pointlessly dug the week before. "There is more than enough money to pay for services," Howard Jarvis insisted shortly after his victory in 1978 (somewhat hypocritically, since he himself did not really believe in many of the services he was citing). "The bureaucrats have just squandered it."
The overwhelming victory of Proposition 13 spawned successful tax reduction campaigns in nearly a dozen other states. But its most important impact was probably on the thinking of some national conservative leaders, who found in the tax revolt a vehicle for ending their nearly 50 years in the political wilderness. What if you could attack taxes (and the politicians who spend them) without engaging in Barry Goldwater's self-destructive questioning of widely admired programs like Social Security? What if you could, in effect, promise voters something for nothing: substantial tax relief without a reduction of services? That, essentially, is what Proposition 13 had promised Californians in 1978. Two years later, it was what Ronald Reagan promised the nation.
The tax revolt moved rapidly, and along many fronts, from local to national politics. Articulate economic commentators like George Gilder and Jude Wanniski provided an intellectual rationale. They created a new, inverted version of Keynesianism ("supply side economics"), dressed it up in academic language and published it in best-selling books and on The Wall Street Journal's editorial page. By cutting taxes on the wealthy, they claimed, Government would help produce so much economic growth that tax revenues would not decline. They might even increase.
In 1980, Ronald Reagan -- who through most of his career had been more interested in opposing Communism than in attacking taxes -- made a major tax reduction one of the economic centerpieces of his Presidential campaign. The other centerpiece was an attack on the Federal deficit ($59 billion in 1980) and the national debt (then $914 billion).
The magnitude of Reagan's victory cowed skeptical members of Congress into supporting a program that many of them had recently dismissed as economic nonsense. The new Administration quickly won approval of virtually everything it wanted: a 25 percent reduction in tax rates, substantial cuts in supposedly wasteful domestic programs and an enormous increase in the military budget. Concern about budget deficits, still a staple of Reagan's oratory, receded deep into the background of actual policy. As Reagan's budget director, David Stockman, indiscreetly conceded to the journalist William Greider in late 1981, the leaders of the Reagan Administration never made a serious effort to tackle the deficit once they realized, as they did very early, that their original assumptions about the impact of tax cuts were wrong. Twelve years later, the annual deficit had grown to over $300 billion and the national debt to over $3 trillion.
THE TAX CUT WAS NOT SUPPOSED TO increase the deficit. But many of its supporters were not very troubled when it did. Major figures in the Reagan Administration, unlike many of the people who had voted for them, had no faith in Government and no love for its programs. Some began quietly to see real advantages in the skyrocketing debt. The fiscal crisis became a back door for doing what many on the right had been unable to achieve with their frontal assaults in the 1950's and 1960's. It undercut support for starting new Government programs, and even for sustaining old ones, less by discrediting the programs than by pitting them against the need to reduce a huge and growing national debt.
The legacy of the tax revolt, and of the stupefying public debts it helped generate, is a fiscal world in which the boundaries of the possible have been dramatically constricted. But there is another legacy, too. The tax revolt was a product, in part, of a growing cynicism about politics and politicians. Its results, ironically, have greatly increased that cynicism.
Voters endorsed the implausible promise that Government could simultaneously cut taxes, sustain services and reduce the deficit. Supply-siders told them that tax cuts would increase, not diminish, public revenues. Others predicted that eliminating "waste, fraud and abuse" would compensate for the shrunken tax base. The intractable fiscal crises of the 1980's and 1990's have proved both those arguments to be fantasies. But rather than recognizing the claims of the tax revolt as the false promises they were, voters have heaped even more opprobrium on politicians for failing to deliver the impossible.
President Clinton evidently thought that a serious effort to address the fiscal crisis would open some political space for new policy initiatives. Events may yet prove him right. It seems likely, however, that whatever space there may be will be very small and that whatever initiatives may emerge from this Administration will be shaped fundamentally by fiscal constraints.
As a result, the President faces an unenviable set of choices. He can continue proposing such important and ambitious new programs as health care and welfare reform without asking for significant new taxes to support them -- a course that has already begun to pit cherished liberal goals against one another. He can ask for new revenues to pay for his ideas -- a frontal challenge to the political orthodoxy of the 1980's, which seems unlikely to succeed. Or, as appears most probable, he can make enough concessions and compromises to get greatly weakened versions of his proposals passed, claim victory and hope that they can become the basis (as the Social Security Act of 1935 did) of more generous and comprehensive programs later on.
The President wants his Administration to be a dramatic break with the Republican past. It took more than 30 years for conservatives to shake the grip of Franklin Roosevelt and the New Deal. President Clinton has considerably less time than that to shake the grip of the legacy of Ronald Reagan and Howard Jarvis.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 454 words

HEADLINE: In Death of Rain Forests, We're All Accomplices

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Last Rain Forest: Timber vs. a Culture," your special report on Papua New Guinea (front page, June 5), provides an excellent overview of threats to that remote Pacific island country's forests and communities. You also identify community-based efforts to use forests in an ecologically responsible way as an alternative to the corrupt and destructive practices of foreign loggers.
Unfortunately, you leave the mistaken impression that the reforms supported by the Minister for Forests, Tim Neville, will remedy the situation and create space for more community-based, ecologically sustainable forest management. 
 But Mr. Neville and the National Forest Authority model their proposals on industrial Canadian forestry practices that are not ecologically sound or socially equitable. Central to these reforms is establishment of timber supply areas, which guarantee investors access to timber in return for investments in downstream processing facilities such as plywood, veneer and pulp mills.
Adopting such a model will again restrict cash-poor customary landholders from using and benefiting from their own resources, and place Papua New Guinea on the same centralized, revenue-driven development track that has led to destruction of forests and the livelihood of forest people throughout the world.
Your article aptly demonstrates how this destructive trend is moving from Southeast Asia to Papua New Guinea. However, it does not highlight the need for industrialized countries, the major consumers of wood products, to take responsibility for a role in fueling such unsustainable development. It is unfortunate that here in the United States efforts to take such responsibility are not a priority.
The United States Agency for International Development recently shut down its offices for the South Pacific region in Papua New Guinea and Fiji, cutting off our Government's ability to support community-based, ecologically responsible forest management. Also, Vice President Al Gore's meeting with Mr. Neville this year appears to have resulted in few concrete actions to redirect the course of forest management in Papua New Guinea.
When Mr. Gore was a senator, he sponsored a bill requiring labeling of wood products so consumers could base their purchasing on sound information. This bill never passed. Now Mr. Gore should follow up his efforts by having the Administration fully back legislation that mandates the inclusion of consumer information on wood origin and species, as well as on the ecological and social impacts of the production of wood products.
 
LAFCADIO CORTESI, KENA'E KA'AU
San Francisco, June 10, 1994
 
The writers are campaigners for Greenpeace Pacific.

HEADLINE: U.S. Treasury to Offer $68.5 Billion in Debt This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's financings this week are scheduled to bring a large supply of Government paper to market, but analysts said on Friday that they did not expect the move to weigh too heavily on prices. On the contrary, the analysts noted, during the last month investors had shown interest in the short to intermediate maturities, as yields were down as much as 15 basis points on some maturities and nearly unchanged on the longer end.
The total amount of Government debt being offered this week is $68.5 billion, including today's $24 billion auction of three- and six-month bills. On Tuesday, the Treasury will auction $17 billion of two-year notes, and on Wednesday it will auction $11 billion in five-year notes. On Thursday, $16.5 billion of one-year bills will complete the week's supply of new issues. 
 At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.10 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 4.45 percent, with a one-year issue at 4.89 percent. In when-issued trading last week, ahead of this week's auction, the new two-year issues were offered at a price to yield 5.91 percent, while the five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.71 percent.
The following taxable and tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

HEADLINE: In Poor, Decolonized Africa, Bankers Are New Overlords

SERIES: Survival Test: Can Africa Rebound? -- Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ACCRA, Ghana

 BODY:
For more than a decade the economies of Africa have been caught in a relentless downward spiral. As a result, countries that are proud of their independence and prickly about sovereignty are finding themselves more than ever under the thumb of outside powers.
Only now the powers are not the old colonial masters -- Britain, France and the other would-be exploiters who carved up Africa in European drawing rooms and conference halls in the 1880's. 
 Nor are they the United States and the Soviet Union, which cast covetous eyes upon the continent in the mid-1970's and turned it into an arena for cold war confrontation by proxy.
Now the external superpowers are the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. These institutions, founded half a century ago at the Bretton Woods Conference to serve the needs of the industrialized world, have become the overlords of Africa in the 1990's.
Gone are the days 10 and 15 years ago when socialism was "on the march" and powerful leaders from the despotic to the high-minded gave it lip service. They embraced it because a controlled economy fit well with one-man rule that brooked no opposition, because egalitarianism seemed progressive and right for Africa and because only the Communist countries were backing liberation movements in the south.
"Today you won't find a single African head of state who stands on a podium and declares: 'I'm a Marxist,' " observed Tei Mante, a Ghanaian who heads the African office of the International Finance Corporation, an affiliate of the World Bank. "Instead all the talk is about floating currency, private enterprise, and getting hold of capital."
The I.M.F. and the World Bank are the purveyors of the new orthodoxy. They come in to bail out a country that is bankrupt. They do so by drawing up a "structural adjustment program," a tight package of economic prescriptions designed to bring about free market enterprise and minimize governmental interference.
Because the package is tied to millions of dollars in aid from Western donor countries, it is an offer that can't be refused. And so the I.M.F. and the bank end up calling the shots on a broad range of issues -- even political matters like calling multiparty elections -- that affect the lives of millions.
Through its structural adjustment programs, the I.M.F. and the bank now effectively oversee and supervise the economies of some 30 countries in sub-Saharan Africa.
It is hard to exaggerate the depth of Africa's economic crisis.
Consider this fact: Excluding South Africa, the 1991 gross national product of all countries south of the Sahara -- a swath of the globe that is home to almost 600 million people -- was about the same as the gross national product of Belgium, with a population of 10 million.
Eighteen of the world's 20 poorest countries are African, and 30 of the poorest 40. Caught in a downward cycle that began with the oil price explosion of the 1970's and then accelerated with the plunge of the commodities markets, they are getting poorer still. Per capita G.N.P. declined by 2 percent a year throughout the 1980's.
Their debt, tripled since 1980, now amounts to over $180 billion. The debt burden -- caused by borrowing to keep budgets afloat and to pay for imports -- is so gigantic (amounting to 110 percent of G.N.P. in 1991) that virtually no one thinks the sum can ever be repaid. Just servicing it costs the countries $10 billion every year -- four times more than they all spend on health and education.
Africa's share of world trade has fallen below 4 percent and is now closer to 2 percent. That is so marginal it is almost as if the continent has curled up and disappeared from the map of international shipping lanes and airline routes that rope together Europe, North America and the booming Far East. Direct foreign investment in Africa is so paltry it is not even measured in the latest World Bank study.
 
The Cure
Harsh Medicine For a Sick Region
 Despite the evident need for resuscitation, the role of the I.M.F. and World Bank, as might be expected, is controversial. The medicine they dole out means currency devaluations, slashing government payrolls and cutbacks on subsidies, even for food. The burden of the long climb back to fiscal respectability falls mainly on the poor, though experts contend that in the long run the poor will benefit when the economies improve.
A main object of the program is to reduce inflation in order to improve the balance of trade, attract investment and give farmers and entrepreneurs an incentive to grow produce and make products. In the short run this means lower wages and rising unemployment, but these are necessary evils to achieve real growth, most economists and experts say.
There are dissidents. Kevin Watkins, the senior policy adviser for Oxfam, the British relief agency, attacked the bank and the I.M.F. two months ago in an article in The New Statesman. He argued that structural adjustment and its "preoccupation" with monetary discipline was failing to generate economic recovery in Africa and instead was simply imposing unbearable social costs on the poor.
Bank officials point to Ghana as a laboratory for their policies. Under the sway of its charismatic leader, Jerry Rawlings, who hung up his flight lieutenant's uniform and easily got himself elected President two years ago, Ghana subscribes to the new orthodoxy more than any other country.
Now, its streets are congested with traffic, its balance of trade figures are improving, its stock market id bubbling along and attracting foreign investors. The famous 100-year-old Ashanti Goldfields are a case in point. Two decades ago the mines were in a slump. Now, after careful management, outside investment and major refurbishing, gold production has tripled since 1986, surpassing cocoa as the chief export earner. The company was just privatized, with the Government selling half of its 55 per cent ownership -- a controversial move delayed by a lawsuit on the grounds that too much was being given over to foreigners.
Despite the signs of progress, however, many miners say they skip lunch below ground because they cannot afford the meal. Like other Ghanaians, they have been hurt because the spending power of the cedi, the nation's currency, has not really improved. The per capita income -- about $420 a year -- stubbornly remains among the lowest in Africa.
 
The Reaction
Africans Divided Over Austerity
 Leaders like Kenya's demagogic President, Daniel arap Moi, publicly rail against the I.M.F. and the bank -- "We cannot continue swallowing their medicine all the time," he thundered several weeks ago -- while privately caving in to their terms. Every day Africans from taxi drivers to schoolteachers argue knowledgeably -- and heatedly -- about the bank's stand in forcing a currency devaluation or abolishing a corn marketing board.
"I think of the World Bank as some kind of monster," said Monique Ilboudo, a 27-year-old lawyer, writer and ardent feminist, sipping a drink in the parched shade of a baobab tree in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso. "It sits on top of Africa like an octopus, sucking us dry. It never looks to see the effects on the lives of the people. It treats us like numbers, economic agents."
Others defend the bank as a necessary evil, something to shoulder the blame for decisions too painful for the governments to make themselves. It is at least a lifeline, they say.
"Yes, at times you feel you are giving away your sovereignty and your independence," said Tsatsu Tsikata, chairman of the Ghana National Petroleum Corporation, as he sat on a hotel balcony within earshot of six-foot-high waves crashing down on Ghana's Gold Coast.
"You wonder if it's not going too far," he said, "especially when some of their staff take on this patronizing approach to Africa -- the impression that we can't get our act together and that they have to step in and set everything right. So it's easy to denounce the bank. Even the right-wing opposition does it. But that kind of jingoism doesn't work in our situation when you're desperate and you need external resources. We have to live in the real world."
 
The Prognosis
Great Potential, Puzzling History
 And yet, despite its desperation, Africa has great riches. It has the gushing oil fields of Nigeria, the thick veins of copper of Zambia, diamonds that flow down the rivers of Angola to settle in the alluvial seabed. Most of all, it has the world's largest reservoir of arable land -- almost 2.5 billion acres, of which only one-fifth is cultivated.
How to reconcile the utopian potential with the hard realities of declining growth is the obsession of almost every African government and the preoccupation of the World Bank and the I.M.F. The reasons cited for failure are many and endlessly debated, ranging from corruption and mismanagement to built-in trade inequities, a legacy of colonial relationships.
But the challenge is vexing because other third world countries manage to achieve growth. In 1965 Indonesia's per capita G.N.P. was lower than Nigeria's and today it is three times higher. Virtually no strategy adopted by any African country -- whether encouraging foreign companies or taking over their assets, whether trying to force industrialization or relying mainly on agriculture -- has succeeded.
Until now, perhaps.
In a report published in March, the most comprehensive one on Africa it has yet produced, the World Bank suggested that not all was hopeless. It studied 29 countries, dividing them into those that more or less faithfully carried out austerity measures and economic reforms and those that dragged their feet. It concluded that the high performers were beginning to see modest growth.
It put Ghana at the head of a list of six countries that it said were gradually rolling back the red ink through their I.M.F.-inspired economic policies. The others were Tanzania, Gambia, Burkina Faso, Nigeria and Zimbabwe (though Nigeria's military government has since abandoned the program).
The World Bank report cautioned not to expect miracles. Even if Ghana manages to keep going at the current rate -- squeezing out a per capita growth rate of about 2 percent a year -- then "the average Ghanaian will not cross the poverty line for another 50 years," it said.
In more general terms, if the most optimistic growth forecasts prove accurate, it will take 40 years for the African countries to regain the per capita income level they reached in the mid-1970's.
This prediction sent a chill through the hearts of many African leaders. The answer to a shrinking belly is more belt-tightening, it seemed to be saying, and it's going to have to go on for generations.
 
The Pioneer
On Roller Coaster Since Freedom
 Ghana's role as star pupil seems fitting. For Ghana began black Africa's postwar adventure in independence under the fiery inspiration of Kwame Nkrumah in 1957 and since then has seen just about everything.
There have been five coups, some bloodless and some bloody. There have been three tries at civilian rule. There were those initial years of big-time spending, when the Nkrumah regime went through $481 million in foreign reserves to erect grand projects and grandiose monuments. And there were those long, dog days of the early 1980's when drought devastated the cocoa fields, Nigeria expelled 1 million Ghanaian workers, the Ambassador Hotel downtown had only a 25-watt bulb in each room, and even the local Star Beer was hard to come by.
In 1983, Ghana adopted a structural adjustment plan. Its terms were typically severe: devaluation of the hopelessly overvalued cedi, privatization of most of the 300 state-owned industries, a lifting of restrictions such as import licenses in order to lure foreign investors and open up trade, abolition of agricultural marketing boards so that farmers could get better prices for their produce, and large-scale layoffs of state employees, including 45,000 from the Civil Service lists alone.
Ghana has more or less stuck to the plan. From 1988 to 1992 its economy grew by between 4 and 5 percent annually, a credible showing. The exception was in 1992, when declining international cocoa prices and the temptation to spread Governmental largesse during elections threw the budget back into deficit. Aid flows from the World Bank were held up until the Government got its program back on track.
Now, signs of activity are perking up. There are traffic jams on the dusty streets, crowds around the ubiquitous red, green and yellow lottery shacks, vendors everywhere hawking magazines and carrying trays of bananas, cigarettes, watches and pirated tape cassettes on their heads.
Farmers are growing more cocoa. Supermarkets are stocked with goods. Electronic stores have appliances, video cameras and computers in the windows, though not many consumers can afford them. The G.N.P. per person -- about $450 -- is still among the continent's lowest.
There is a slight stirring of interest among foreign companies. Lonrho, the London-based conglomerate with extensive holdings in mining, agriculture and hotels throughout Africa, has bought a majority shareholding in the Ashanti Goldfields. Starkist Tuna, J.C. Penney, Coca-Cola and several South African companies are committed to or contemplating business ventures. And Morgan Stanley expects to invest in Ghana over the next few weeks.
But most of all, there's an optimism among Ghanaians. They feel that things are getting better, slowly but surely. This is true not just in the cities but in the countryside, where 80 percent of the country's 15 million people live and where poverty is the most grinding.
The ears of international financial experts would have been burning if they could have listened the other day to the chief of the tiny village of Doryum, about an hour northeast of the capital. After pouring a libation of schnapps onto the ground, the chief, Nene La Nimo Doryumu II, invited a visitor into a reception room at his house decorated with calendars. He wanted to chat.
"People's lives are definitely getting better," he said, seated in his robes with a sheepskin mat at his feet. "A lot of people go to school now, those who can afford the fees. We've been promised electricity by the end of the year. If there's electricity, maybe the young people won't all go off to Accra."
Western donors are so hungry for a success story in Africa that they suppress the nervousness they feel at President Rawlings's populist pronouncements and his tendency to swamp the opposition by sheer force of personality and swagger.
The donors have been pouring aid into Ghana at roughly the rate of $1 billion a year. That sum is such a pump to the economy that it is hardly fair to say that Ghana could serve as a role model to lead the rest of Africa out of the economic doldrums. It would be impossible to support other countries to the same extent, experts note.
 
The Debate
Help for Needy, Or for Wealthy?
 Critics of the World Bank argue that it really represents the interests of the creditor nations and that its dictates are delivered with neo-colonialist hauteur. The terms are so severe that in some cases they are tantamount to destabilizing a country or asking its leader to commit political suicide.
Cutting Civil Service payrolls means losing the leverage of patronage and creating unemployment. Charging for medical services that used to be free means the poorest will go without them. Reducing subsidies and relaxing price controls sows discontent in the congested cities.
When the cost of bread rose in 1990 in Zambia after an I.M.F.-imposed program, there were riots in the streets and the country backed away from the plan. January's drastic devaluation of the French-backed C.F.A. franc touched off labor disputes, demonstrations and violent clashes that are still shaking 14 French-speaking countries throughout West and Central Africa.
"Most of the criticism of the bank is deserved," said Jonathan Moyo, a professor of political science at the University of Zimbabwe. "But what are we looking for? These are two Bretton Woods institutions. They were created to manage international financial crises, not to manage individual countries.
"Of course they're insensitive," said. "Of course the structural adjustment programs can become a cause of social chaos. How can a country going through the throes of social change and under weak leadership sustain such a program?"
An even more frightening prospect, some African leaders admit privately, is that the pain that the reforms inflict may exacerbate ethnic tensions, which seem to be on the rise in many parts of the continent.
One Ghanaian official, speaking anonymously, said he could not rule out a connection between the social repercussions of the program and a series of ethnic clashes that began in northern Ghana in February. So far some 350 villages have been burned to the ground, with several thousand people killed and an estimated 150,000 displaced.
If a country abandons an austerity plan, it runs the risk of being cut off from all international aid. This is currently happening to Zaire.
In this, former President Julius Nyerere of Tanzania, who pursued economic policies that were disastrous for his country but who is sometimes called the "conscience of Africa" for his principled stands, sees a sort of blackmail.
"The I.M.F. has an ideology of political and social development which it is trying to impose on poor countries irrespective of their own clearly stated policies," he said in an interview with Stephen Riley, a British academic who specializes in African affairs. "And when we reject I.M.F. conditions we hear the threatening whisper: 'Without accepting our conditions you will not get any money, and you will get no other money.' "
On the other side, proponents argue that there is simply no alternative to the I.M.F.'s conditions if growth is to be achieved again.
"Adjustment can be a difficult and painful process and the benefits not immediately apparent, making it politically difficult for governments to stay the course of reforms," said Babacar Ndiaye, president of the African Development Bank. "But reforms are the only way forward."
Herman Cohen, who served four years as Assistant Secretary of State for Africa under George Bush, agrees. "The I.M.F. was created to tide industrial nations over when they had temporary balance of payment problems," he noted. "Now suddenly it's thrust into the developing world pit. Then the World Bank gets involved to push long-term projects.
"They've gone crazy. But no one else could impose the discipline and do what's got to be done. So I subscribe 100 percent to structural adjustment. There just is no other way to go."

Companies
 Donna Karan's fashion empire is now plagued by turmoil: partners want to sell out, retailers are complaining, bankers are worried. Her rapid success and the recent problems afflicting her company compose a familiar pattern in the American fashion industry, where family businesses frequently grow beyond the founders' ability to manage them. [Page A1.] 
 Philip Morris's chairman and chief executive unexpectedly resigned. The departure of Michael A. Miles comes less than a month after directors wrangled over and rejected a proposal to divide the company into separate food and tobacco units. [D1.]
The zealousness of Saturn owners has been skillfully cultivated by the auto company. And the "homecoming" in Spring Hill, Tenn., later this week -- a hoedown of some 25,000 Saturn owners -- may be the most audacious attempt yet by the G.M. subsidiary to cement the fevered loyalty of its customers. [D1.]
Lawyers for investors in Towers Financial contend that the lawyers, accountants, brokers and credit analysts who worked for the conglomerate were responsible for Towers' alleged fraud. The lawyers say their case has been helped by a recent Supreme Court decision. The Media Business
C-Span has been cut back on cable systems serving more than four million households as a result of the cable law passed by Congress two years ago. The new law forced many cable systems to add local broadcast channels, and a large number of the systems have chosen to drop C-Span and its sister channel, C-Span 2, to make room for more profitable channels. [A1.]
Comcast will acquire Maclean Hunter's U.S. cable TV systems for $1.27 billion in cash. Comcast won a bidding war for the cable systems, picking up 550,000 subscribers in New Jersey, Florida and Michigan. The deal would make Comcast the third-largest cable company in the United States. [D1.]
A double issue of The New Yorker devoted to fiction comes out this week. The issue -- which has been given a big promotional push, including planes trailing beach banners -- is a throwback to a time when fiction was a staple of mainstream magazines. [D5.]
The young publisher of El Diario-La Prensa has learned some tough lessons about the newspaper business running the New York Spanish-language daily the last five years. El Diario-La Prensa, which has survived sharp circulation declines and a stubborn recession that stalled advertising, is now recovering. [D5.]
World Cup '94 is a contest of 24 nations, each with its own pageantry, playing style and soccer tradition. So why are the commercials during World Cup matches so drearily similar, so lacking in imagination? Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
The Economy
 Mutual funds would have to include a new measure of risk alongside their tallies of past performance in advertisements, under a proposal being considered by the S.E.C. Condensing the myriad risks in an investment into a single measure is difficult. But the agency is considering whether some of the statistical tools that have been developed by pension funds and brokerage firms to measure risk can be simplified for use by individuals. [D1.]

 AT&T Bell Laboratories has patented a magnetic tape that wraps around optical fiber cable before it is buried so that construction workers can avoid digging into it. The tape would also make repairs easier and faster. Sabra Chartrand: Patents. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Preserving the History That Lies Underfoot;
Bluestone Sidewalks on Comeback Trail

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
John Buscarello of Brooklyn learned about bricks and stones and mortar from his father, Jack, following him into the family masonry business. As a matter of course, he learned how to install the massive slabs of bluestone, many the size of dining room tables, that a century ago were the city's dominant sidewalk material.
But the bluestone trade faded to almost nothing over his father's generation, and for years the only sidewalks Mr. Buscarello installed were concrete. The giant slabs of gray rock, which over time subtly show colors like red and green and azure, appeared to be going the way of gaslights, bowler hats and the 3-cent cigar. 
 The path toward extinction has been the same for other old-time paving materials -- the granite sidewalks of SoHo and TriBeCa; the red brick streets of Queens; the Belgian block, commonly called cobblestone, of lower Manhattan and dockside neighborhoods in Brooklyn, all inexorably fading away.
But bluestone, indigenous to neighborhoods like Brooklyn Heights and Park Slope, seems to be making a comeback. Prompted by pressure from the city to fix decrepit sidewalks of all types, and after years of campaigning by preservationists, many more property owners are making the historically correct choice and creating a bluestone boomlet.
More of the material is being repaired than ever before, contractors say. Mr. Buscarello, who says his bluestone installations have increased 80 percent since last year, has a waiting list of 25 jobs. Small bluestone quarries in New York State also report an increase in calls from the city.
Preservationists estimate that bluestone made up half the city's sidewalks at one time, chiefly areas near the harbor that were developed first, while today it accounts for just 5 percent. But they say hundreds of sidewalk strips have been renovated in the last two years, and that bluestone has been used in major new restoration projects like Bryant Park.
Lurching progress is also being made in setting up new city contracting procedures that would lower prices and make installation easier. Cost is still a stumbling block, and many home owners in historic districts, where sidewalks must be replaced with bluestone or concrete tinted to look like it, have complained about having to pay almost four times the cost of poured concrete.
In April, Park Slope won a promise from the City Department of Transportation that it would not rip out any more bluestone in areas adjacent to historic districts until the new procedures are established. "There's a new awareness of the value of the materials themselves, the streets, the sidewalks, the curbs -- both for appearance and longevity," said Franny Eberhart, executive director of the Historic Districts Council.
Bruce Mesh, vice president of the Park Slope Civic Council, said, "This is esthetics becoming economics, of using historic preservation as a means of building our community."
Bluestone, a sedimentary rock, has long been popular for patios and counter tops, but the renewed demand is for the enormous pieces, some as large as 5 by 5 feet, used in old-fashioned sidewalks. Some slabs weigh in at 2,000 pounds easily.
"It's more like there's been a revival of a particular breed of bluestone, the big slabs," said David Andersen, who owns Pascack Valley Stone and Slate Company in Closter, N.J.
Though the movement to save the material began in Brooklyn Heights, Park Slope and other neighborhoods in brownstone Brooklyn, proponents say interest has spread to areas with a bluestone heritage in Harlem; Long Island City, Queens; Yorkville on the Upper East Side, and Staten Island.
 
City Sends Contractors
 The revival is being catalyzed by stick and carrot. The stick is violations issued by the Department of Transportation to property owners whose walks have been heaved about by tree roots or erosion. Owners have 45 days to fix them or the city sends contractors in to do the job and sends owners the bill. Though the city offers bluestone replacement, the cost is four times the $4.81 per square foot it charges for pouring concrete.
The carrot has been leniency in enforcing violations until the transportation agency adjusts its bidding procedures.
"We're trying to accommodate the community on this," said Michael Weiss, the department's chief of staff.
The Historic Districts Council and the Park Slope Civic Council have also compiled a list of contractors who do bluestone work. City Council members from Brooklyn are working with the Department of Transportation to find a large lot for private contractors to store bluestone, as space for the rocks is a growing problem. A lot owned by the transportation agency in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn is being considered.
Though prices have fallen with demand and bluestone is considered more durable than concrete, the chief factor working against bluestone is still cost. People already angry with having to fix sidewalks at their own expense are not eager to multiply the cost by choosing a historic material. Accordingly, most people choose concrete, Mr. Mesh says.
Mr. Buscarello says he charges about $800 to pour a 10-by-20-foot patch of concrete, compared with $3,000 for a similar area of new bluestone. To lift and adjust existing bluestone and add a few new pieces costs about $1,200 for the same space.
"And stone is not a renewable resource," warns Richard Mirch, owner of the Tompkins Bluestone Company in Hancock, N.Y., a major supplier to local contractors. "As it is used up, it becomes less available. Therefore, the price goes up."
People say they are finding better deals by skirting the city government. Amy Kallman Epstein, who owns a brownstone in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, was quoted a price of $18,000 by the city to fix her bluestone, more than six times the charge for concrete. With the help of the Park Slope Civic Council, she got the job done for a price close to what the concrete would have cost.
"It's not the easiest thing to do, this re-creation of the 19th century," she said. "But it's important for chunks of New York to be the way they were as much as humanly possible."
Nicole Loveland, who publishes books about cats and and lives in Park Slope, was outraged when she was hit with notice of a sidewalk violation last fall. "Push came to shove, and we were going to get grief from the city, so we said, 'Well, fine.' "
She got together with two neighbors, and the three secured a contract to have the work done for less than $1,000 each, using new stone and patching existing material. "It looks quite fabulous," she said.
Michael Kaye, a lawyer, says he resented being forced to correct a violation at his Park Slope home. It cost him $700 to keep his slabs of history, but he says it was worth it. "The charm of a neighborhood like this is sort of incremental," he said. "Every little thing sort of adds up."
 
 
 
GLIMPSES OF STONES FROM THE PAST
 Concrete has been the preference for New York sidewalks and streets since the turn of the century. But glimpses of the stones of the past are still to be found.
BLUESTONE Often confused with slate, the dark stone is quarried in the Catskills and Poconos. It can still be seen in Brooklyn's brownstone neighborhoods, lower Manhattan, Harlem, Long Island City in Queens and the northern part of Staten Island.
GRANITE SLABS Blocks of granite, 6 by 8 feet, were quarried throughout New England and used for sidewalks in the downtown manufacturing neighborhoods of SoHo and TriBeCa. Many slabs, so thick that they also form the curbs, are still in place, as they are virtually indestructible.
BELGIAN BLOCK The material, commonly known as cobblestone, is granite, but in smaller blocks, generally 8 to 12 inches long and 5 inches in width and depth. It was used in most streets in lower Manhattan and on the West Side, as well as in older parts of Staten Island. Small patches peek through later paving, and some stretches have been restored.
RED BRICK Used in parts of Queens, patches are visible on some entrances to the Grand Central Parkway.

HEADLINE: Carter, His Own Emissary, Outpaces White House

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
Jimmy Carter was not exactly a submissive emissary.
Indeed, the former President said today that he would never have sought permission to go to North Korea if he had supported the Clinton Administration's plan to use economic sanctions against its Government in the dispute over its nuclear program. 
 He said he still found it "inconceivable" that President Clinton had not sent his own delegation to North Korea to try to resolve the standoff between the two countries.
And yet it was Mr. Carter who emerged from the White House this morning after briefing Administration aides to proclaim that the promises made to him by North Korea's reclusive leaders meant that the crisis was in effect over.
The White House expressed hope today that Mr. Carter might have opened the way to a breakthrough. But after a weeklong "private" visit that became a public spectacle, aides to Mr. Clinton spoke of their consternation that Mr. Carter's faith in conflict resolution made him too eager to accept assurances from a Government that has built no basis in trust.
And so a trip that was set in motion with a request nearly three weeks ago from Mr. Carter to Mr. Clinton ended, as aides to both men put it, with tense late-night phone calls between Washington and the former President, who had infuriated the White House with statements broadcast worldwide on CNN.
"I wouldn't want to call him naive or gullible," a senior Administration official said today. "But let's just say that we're a lot more skeptical than he is about whether the North Koreans mean what they say."
Mr. Carter said Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, had assured him that his nation was not building nuclear weapons, and had offered to freeze his nuclear program as long as high-level talks with Washington are begun and continued.
In his hotel suite here this morning, Mr. Carter was still buoyant even after a flight that took him from South Korea to Atlanta and then to Washington. And he offered no apology for carrying his own views to Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.
"Pressure on them is counterproductive," he said of the North Koreans, expressing hope that his mission might set the Administration on what he sees as a wiser course.
The former President spoke with a sense of achievement about his meetings with the 82-year-old Mr. Kim, in which he said his wife, Rosalynn, had acted as his note-taker.
"I don't know what would have happened today if no one had been willing to talk to anybody in North Korea," Mr. Carter told reporters whom he invited to his room.
For the one-time broker of the Camp David accords, the trip to North was merely the latest in a series of efforts to make good on his pledge to dedicate his life after the Presidency to promoting the peaceful resolution of conflicts.
Since leaving the White House in 1981, Mr. Carter, who is 69, made that goal the central mission of his presidential center in Atlanta. He has acted as an intermediary in conflicts in the Middle East, Africa, the former Yugoslavia and elsewhere.
 
Requests Refused Twice
 But the State Department had twice refused his requests to travel to North Korea in response to a 1991 invitation, and Mr. Clinton's unexpected decision to approve the journey at a time of mounting tensions gave it even more prominence.
Mr. Carter has always sought to play an independent role rather than serve as the emissary of his successors. But with a Democrat in the White House for the first time since he left it, his mission to North Korea was being subjected today to intense partisan scrutiny.
On the ABC News program "This Week," George Will, the conservative columnist, called Mr. Carter's performance "very injurious" and "a reminder of how important and good the 1980 election was."
Both the White House and the former President have emphasized that Mr. Carter was traveling as a "private citizen" during last week's visit. But accounts given today by both Mr. Carter and White House officials made clear that it was preceded by extensive discussions, including a three-hour session on June 5 in which Robert L. Gallucci, the Assistant Secretary of State for Politico-Military Affairs and the Administration's point man on Korea, flew to Atlanta after the former President expressed "extreme concern" about the danger of a confrontation.
Mr. Carter said today that he was still left "distressed" after that meeting and had telephoned Vice President Al Gore the next day to tell him that he was still "strongly inclined" to travel to Pyongyang. Two days later, he said, Mr. Gore relayed word that Mr. Clinton had given the go-ahead.
The former President left no doubt about his motivation for wanting to travel at a time when the White House was seeking agreement at the United Nations to impose sanctions against North Korea.
"If I had thought the sanctions were a good idea, I never would have gone over there," he said.
Today, senior White House officials said that because Mr. Carter was traveling as a private citizen they had believed it was more important to brief him on the Administration's position than to explore his personal views. But they acknowledged that Mr. Carter's expression of those views while traveling had provoked deep frictions, particularly when the former President told CNN from Pyongyang that the Administration was stepping back from its pursuit of sanctions.
Mr. Carter several times today described that statement as a "mistake," and said that he was not presuming to speak for the Administration.
Asked to respond to the criticism of his journey, Mr. Carter said: "I don't feel that I have been duped, but I have to say the proof is in the pudding."

HEADLINE: Liberal Is Elected President In a Tight Race in Colombia

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, COLOMBIA, June 19

 BODY:
Colombian voters elected Ernesto Samper Pizano today in the nation's tightest presidential race in 24 years.
Wth 97 percent of the ballots counted, Mr. Samper, candidate of the Liberal Party, had a slim lead over the Andres Pastrana Arango of the Conservative Party, the elections board announced. Mr. Samper had 50 percent, Mr. Pastrana had 48.4 percent, and 1.6 percent of the ballots were declared invalid. 
 Elected to lead South America's second-most populous nation through the rest of the 1990's, Mr. Samper intends to tap Colombia's pending oil boom to improve social conditions.
"We must improve social spending so that there is no Chiapas in Colombia," Mr. Samper, a rotund 43-year-old economist, said in a recent interview. While last January's guerrilla revolt in southern Mexico sounded alarm bells up and down Latin America, Colombia has long been plagued by guerrilla unrest fed by rural poverty.
Some Colombian business leaders had favored Mr. Pastrana, who had stressed fighting inflation and pushing for Colombia's rapid entry into the North American Free Trade Agreement. But with Colombia's Congress controlled by the Liberal Party, investors openly worried about a legislative deadlock with a Pastrana presidency.
 
A Trend in Latin America
 Mr. Samper's victory appeared to be part of a trend among Latin American voters. Last December, a Social Democrat, Rafael Caldera, was elected President of Venezuela. In Brazil, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, a socialist, enjoys a strong lead in polls in advance of next October's elections.
To increase living standards in Colombia, Mr. Samper promised voters that he would create 1.5 million new jobs and that he would dramatically raise social spending to 15 percent of the gross national product.
Mr. Samper's program includes investing $1 billion in improving rural infrastructure, investing in highway construction, encouraging the creation of 350,000 small businesses, and spending $1.5 billion for the construction of a subway system for this traffic-choked city.
However, Mr. Samper, a former Minister of Development, has said that he has no intention of rolling back the free market changes adopted by Colombia's outgoing President, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo. The Constitution bars Mr. Gaviria, a Liberal, from succeeding himself.
 
Trade Changes Unlikely
 "The opening has been done, we are not going to review the tariffs, we are not going to close to foreign investment," Mr. Samper said, referring to Colombia's radical opening to foreign trade. In recent years, Colombian import tariffs have dropped from 50 percent to 12 percent today, and the Government has negotiated free trade pacts with 22 nations.
Many of the planned public works are to be paid by revenues from Colombia's Cusiana oil field. The largest oil field discovered in America since the North Slope in Alaska, Cusiana is expected to start providing billions of dollars to Colombia's Government by 1996.
Mr. Samper said that he would tighten the current Government's policy of encouraging drug traffickers to surrender under plea bargains, but would raise minimum sentences.

HEADLINE: On Health, Congress Moves to Take Bold Action Subtly

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19

 BODY:
If Congress passes a comprehensive health care bill this year, it will require a grand compromise to finesse some tough decisions.
The latest idea for a political compromise on health care legislation calls for a device known as a trigger mechanism. Such a device would defer any requirement that employers provide coverage to their workers for at least several years. 
 During that time, voluntary efforts would be tried to expand coverage. If they failed under one proposal, the requirement, known as an employer mandate, would automatically take effect. Or, under another version of the proposal, Congress would have to reconsider the question and vote on whether to impose the employer mandate.
In the jargon of the health care debate, these proposals are called trigger mechanisms because they could set off the requirement for employers to insure their workers. If it was found that some proportion of Americans lacked health insurance at some future date, this finding would lead to an employer mandate or other action to achieve universal coverage, President Clinton's ultimate goal.
The proposals have attracted attention from senators, especially members of the Finance Committee, who say the panel will not vote to impose an employer mandate now.
In the last decade, Congress has often used mechanistic devices to avoid or finesse tough decisions. One of the best examples was a measure passed in 1985 to reduce the Federal budget deficit in large installments over five years. It set ceilings for the deficit and required automatic cuts in Federal spending if the limit in any year was exceeded. It also called for a balanced budget by 1991, but for various economic and political reasons, Congress never even came close to meeting that goal.
 
Base-Closing Analogy
 Another example is the procedure that Congress established in 1990 to close military bases. An independent commission makes recommendations to the President, who must approve or reject the list of bases to be closed in its entirety. Congress can block the closings only if both houses pass a resolution of disapproval. In two rounds, more than 100 bases have been marked for closing.
On health care, members of Congress have been getting mixed signals from the Administration, with various officials suggesting different degrees of flexibility.
After discussing health care with Mr. Clinton on Tuesday, senators said the President had appeared willing to consider some versions of a trigger mechanism, particularly those with the greatest likelihood of imposing an employer mandate.
But in a speech on the same day, Hillary Rodham Clinton seemed to reject the idea. "There are some who always in the face of controversy look for some way out," Mrs. Clinton said. "It would be as though when they were debating Social Security people started saying: 'Well, that's a good idea, but, you know, we really ought to phase it in. We really ought to try to make sure that the private sector first provides pensions for everybody, and only after we've waited to see whether every company does provide pensions should we do anything to make sure we provide Social Security.' That is not only a very short-term approach; it is one guaranteed to fail."
Some Administration officials say they want to negotiate with Congress on proposals for a trigger mechanism. They say they cannot publicly discuss such proposals before Mr. Clinton does. But they no longer insist that universal coverage must be achieved, as President Clinton originally proposed, by Jan. 1, 1998. The timetable, officials say, is now negotiable.
Still, Robert E. Rubin, assistant to the President for economic policy, said he disagreed with the perception of many people that the White House was showing more flexibility on this question. Roger C. Altman, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, refused to discuss the merits or details of a trigger mechanism.
"What we are seeking is a bill that's passed in 1994 and leads, by its terms, to universal coverage," Mr. Altman said. "I don't see much point in speculating whether this bell or that whistle reduces or enhances the chances of that outcome."
Senators John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, and Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, have expressed keen interest in a trigger mechanism. Such proposals assume that the Government can significantly increase coverage without imposing an employer mandate.
About 85 percent of Americans now have health insurance. Mr. Breaux said this figure could be raised to at least 91 percent if the Federal Government prohibited insurers from denying coverage to people with medical problems, subsidized premiums for poor people and took other steps to make insurance more affordable.
Other, less stringent proposals provide that if certain goals for health insurance coverage are not met, the President must submit recommendations to Congress, and Congress would have to consider them under special procedures limiting debate and guaranteeing an up-or-down vote.
White House officials say Mr. Clinton could not accept this approach because it would not guarantee universal coverage. Other people object for other reasons.
Jeffrey H. Joseph, vice president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said, "We are in dead opposition to mandates in any way, shape or form, or any triggers that would give politicians an opportunity to impose mandates."
Candice M. Johnson, a spokeswoman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said: "We are opposed to triggers. In order to have real health care reform, you need the employer mandate."
And Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, the acting chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said, "Triggers are for guns, not for legislation."

HEADLINE: Learning the Power of Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 17

 BODY:
Democratic Party leaders, alarmed by the growing popularity of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's income tax cuts, admit that, for the time being, they have lost their campaign to convince the public that the Governor's program will lead to dramatically higher local property taxes.
Assembly Minority Leader Joseph V. Doria said last week that Mrs. Whitman has done a remarkable job of hiding what Democrats call the downside of her tax program. 
 "The general public has never seen the connection between her income tax cuts and local property tax increases," Mr. Doria said, adding that Democrats will have to make voters aware of that if they hope to reverse their losses in the latest legislative and gubernatorial elections.
The Senate Minority Leader, John A. Lynch, concurred, and said: "This is the start of a long-term campaign. The Democratic Party's mission will be to identify for the property-tax payer the connection between actions taken in Trenton and the highest property taxes in the nation."
 
Sharp Increases Predicted
 Many local officials and the State League of Municipalities have predicted sharp increases in property taxes due to the elimination of some special state-aid programs in the Governor's budget. Mr. Lynch said he expects property taxes to rise about 8 percent this year, more than double the increase in the consumer price index, when the figures are released at the end of the year.
But in an interview, Mrs. Whitman said the public no longer accepts the argument that her tax cuts and local property tax hikes are linked "because they're not."
The Governor said the state affects local taxes only when it requires counties and municipalities to undertake new programs without providing the money to carry them out. And she said the Legislature, with her support, will vote to place a "state mandate, state pay" constitutional amendment before the voters in November that would end that practice.
 
Aid Levels to Stay Level
 She also said that in her proposed budget for the fiscal year starting July 1 most municipalities will receive the same level of state aid that they got in the current budget. "It's not how much local governments receive in state aid, but how they spend it," she said.
The Governor said towns are responding in one of three ways to her attempts to trim state government and her call for local governments and school districts to do the same. "Some are asking for help in auditing their operations, some are stabilizing their tax levies by pooling services and some are just complaining that the state government should provide vast amounts of aid," she said.
When Mrs. Whitman promised last September to roll back income tax rates by 30 percent, she gave her campaign for governor a needed boost, but only 20 percent of state residents believed she would follow through, according to opinion polls at the time.
 
'The Promised Land'
 In her inaugural address in January, however, she announced the first installment of her three-year program and quickly pushed the first 5 percent of the tax reduction through the Legislature. Last week she said, "We're halfway to the promised land" after the State Assembly approved cutting income tax rates an additional 10 percent starting in January. The Senate is expected to follow suit later this month.
And as the income tax rate drops, Mrs. Whitman's popularity increases. A recent survey by The Asbury Park Press placed the Governor's approval rating at 78 percent.
Before its passage, Mr. Doria tried to amend the latest tax cut bill to include a provision suspending the cut if the average increase in local property taxes exceeded the rate of inflation. That failed, and Mr. Doria joined 10 other Democrats in voting for Mrs. Whitman's tax cut, which passed 63 to 10.
The Democrats had not expected their proposal to be accepted, but they settled for what they hope will be an issue later.
Brendan Thomas Byrne, the State Democratic chairman, said he will try to focus attention each year in December and June on the state's reports of the average increase in local property taxes. That should remind people that the Democrats had a plan to generate more state aid by suspending the tax cut, he said. "The problem is that when the Governor talks about reducing the income tax, newspapers report it in banner headlines, but there are no front-page headlines about property taxes going up in this town or that," he said.
"I feel frustrated when I hear the Governor blaming the mayors for local property tax increases when she has it within her power to limit what municipalities can spend under our budget caps," Mr. Byrne said. "A member of her cabinet has to approve a town's request to spend more than 2.5 percent over the previous year's budget, and she recently raised the school spending cap that will allow school districts to spend $120 million more in the coming year, money that will have to come from local property taxes."
Mr. Byrne said the public does not realize that two-thirds of the state budget goes back to towns and school districts as state aid, and that when that aid is cut or fails to keep pace with inflation, local taxes must make up for the loss.
Mrs. Whitman said critics of her tax program are missing an important point. "You can't cut your way to a balanced budget," she said. "You must have a strengthening economy and job growth, and since January we've been creating about 6,000 new jobs a month, twice the rate of a year earlier." The Governor said cutting taxes and reducing government bureaucracy has helped convince businesses to move into or expand in New Jersey.
The Democrats and Mrs. Whitman each predicted that the 1995-96 budget will be the toughest to balance because of the continuing need to find economies to pay for the Governor's tax cuts. The Democrats said that by then the connection between lower state income taxes and higher property taxes will become apparent. Mrs. Whitman counters that she expects the state and local governments to have learned to live within their means.

HEADLINE: States Rush To Dispose Of Waste

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SNELLING, S.C.

 BODY:
Each day 20 trucks travel down the isolated blacktop road that leads to the nation's biggest dump for low-level radioactive waste. They are enough to create a traffic jam.
It can take a day or more before one of the tractor trailers loaded with steel boxes and 55-gallon metal drums or the flatbed trucks laden with tall carbon-steel boxes, lead-lined casks built to withstand 80-mile-an-hour crashes, gets its turn to drop off its radioactive cargo. 
 In normal times, only three trucks arrive in a day, but the states that send them are now rushing to beat a June 30 deadline, when the dump that has taken 25 million cubic feet of radioactive machine parts, ash, medical instruments, clothing and manufacturing waste will be closed to shipments from outside eight Southeastern states.
Since 1971, 37 states east of the Rockies have been shipping their dangerous refuse to be buried on the 240 acres of virtually impermeable clay soil here in Barnwell County, S.C., about 45 miles southeast of Augusta, Ga. If the waste were spread five feet deep, it would cover more than 100 football fields.
Once the deadline passes, there will be no permanent place to put the waste. It will have to be kept above ground at thousands of locations, often where it was produced, at utility companies, hospitals, research centers and manufacturers.
The waste at Barnwell County is not intensely radioactive high-level waste, which is mainly spent fuel rods from nuclear power plants and the byproducts of nuclear weapons production and research. This high-level waste remains radioactive for thousands, even hundreds of thousands of years before it decays.
The low-level waste is radioactive as little as 90 days to as long as 200 years. It tends to be a variety of irradiated, rather than intrinsically radioactive, materials. And most of it is not considered lethal even after long exposure but could cause illness or have uncertain long-term effects. About 1 percent of the waste now shipped to Barnwell County has enough radioactivity to kill a human being.
"The stuff is not very dangerous in the first place," said Michael Munger, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. "But it is the symbolism of a place being viewed as a low-level radioactive waste disposal site that overtakes all logic."
On the other hand, Professor Munger also said, "The probability of things going wrong are small for any one disposal site, but those chances increase tremendously when you have hundreds of storage sites and the ongoing need to move and transport the stuff."
The problem has been obvious for years. In 1980, Congress passed the Low Level Radioactive Waste Act to encourage states to organize themselves into compacts to develop new dumps. Ten compacts were set up, but states in eight of these have simply continued to ship waste to Barnwell County as have three unaffiliated states including New York.
Eighteen months ago, South Carolina, fed up with its reputation as the nation's dumping ground for radioactive wastes, decided to ban dumping to all but the Southeastern states. The state and the county are giving up $50 million a year by restricting access to the dump. Fees for material from outside the region are up to $220 a cubic foot compared with $40 a cubic foot for waste from the region.
The nation's one other dump of this kind is on the Hanford Reservation in Washington, which has been open only to 11 Rocky Mountain and Northwestern states since 1992, when a dump in Beatty, Nev., was closed.
The compacts established under the Federal law spawned studies and debates but only a dozen proposals for sites, none of which have any chance of being approved before 1996.
Local opposition is ubiquitous. No one is anxious to have a radioactive-waste dump next door, and the process is greatly complicated by the lack of a scientific consensus on the safety of various disposal methods.
In three regions, state legislatures have changed the rules for selecting sites, forcing officials to start their approval processes over. In California, which is to have the dump for the Southwestern Compact, the White House at the urging of environmental groups and other opponents has stalled progress by delaying the transfer of federally owned land.
Some people suggest that much of the planning by officials in many states has been faint-hearted at best. Everyone rationalized the lack of progress by noting that Barnwell County would be there as a backstop.
Its closing is sure to force the states to confront their old thinking. Holmes Brown, the executive director of the Low Level Radioactive Waste Forum, an organization of disposal planners, said the closing would accelerate planning for new dumps.
"No one wants to predict a date certain on any site," Mr. Brown said. "But everyone has been on notice that this day was coming. Legislatures have gotten serious about this."
But Mr. Munger, who has studied the planning process over the years, said most states were still not serious about being home to a nuclear-waste dump. He pointed out that more than $300 million had already been spent in the nation on planning, an amount that measures how far some states have gone to avoid having a disposal site.
"The closing of Barnwell will increase the pressure on other regions," Mr. Munger said, "but ultimately the compact system of regional disposal will fail because so many states are just going through the motions. Whether it wants to or not, the Congress and the Federal Government will have to re-enter the picture."
Caught in the middle are the utilities and other businesses and organizations that use radioactive material and create the waste.
Allan D. Pasternak, technical director of the California Radioactive Materials Management Forum, said the closing of the Barnwell dump amounted to the loss of the only safe port in uncertain and stormy seas.
"It's a double-edged sword because, if Barnwell stayed open, we would continue to have a disposal resource but it probably would have slowed down planning in other parts of the country," Mr. Pasternak said. "But, we all keep wondering how this closing now is going to create a sense of urgency about something that has been going on since 1980."
One piece of good news is an outgrowth of the escalating cost of dumping at Barnwell in recent years. The organizations that make the waste have been working to reduce the volume by limiting operations, incinerating wastes into ash or compacting it.
Their success has led some to question whether all of the disposal sites now being planned are necessary or economically viable.
