HEADLINE: Some Doctors Face Computer Age Warily

SERIES: Going on Line: A periodic look at a community hospital's place in the computer age.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J.

 BODY:
The computer age may have arrived at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center, but the bits and bytes have not changed a basic truth of hospital life: there are doctors, and there is everybody else.
Hospital administrators, in putting a new computerized hospital-records network on line here in April, decided early not to require physicians to type their orders into the computers. It would doom the effort, they said. That has put clerical workers like Alisa McClendon, a unit receptionist in the first-floor geriatric ward, in the vanguard of the hospital's march toward automation. An alternative point of view is that clerks and nurses have simply been saddled with the work. 
 "They, I think, will never change, no matter how much you give them," Ms. McClendon said, referring to the doctors who troop by her post every day, trying to extract information from the computer. "It seems like one little step they might not be familiar with, so instead of them just trying it on their own, they'll try to find the unit receptionist or the unit manager," she said. " 'Do you think it's possible to get this for me? Is there any chance you're not busy?' "
Old and new coexist everywhere in the special geriatrics unit known as Regan One West. The new computers are plunked down on tables in the crowded nursing station next to an ancient-looking Executone patient intercom. Nurses, aides and doctors whirl in and out through the corridors, checking computer screens one minute, dog-eared paper charts the next.
It is a hospital of time-honored traditions. Founded after the Civil War by the Roman Catholic Sisters of Charity to treat the immigrant poor, St. Joseph's has grown into one of the largest teaching hospitals in the region, with 792 beds and advanced treatment in areas like neonatal care and dialysis. Nurses, doctors and administrators say the old guard of physicians is still strong. Many do not deign to type.
And because administrators made the conscious decision not to force the issue, the anxieties that some doctors might have in dealing with computers have simply been avoided as an issue: no one has asked or required them to learn even the elementary step of signing on, not to mention requiring them to type in their own orders for hospital procedures, called physician order entries.
"I don't think it will ever come to a point where using the computer will be mandatory, because there will always be some physicians who do not want to do it," said Maureen Romoser, the administrative director for nursing services. "Maybe I should clarify that," she added. "Maybe in 50 years."
 
'It Takes Time to Learn'
 Other people said that the hospital, having leaped into the information age with a $25 million network that went completely on line in a single weekend this spring, should not expect miracles.
"To have 'physician order entry,' you have to have the physician staff capable of using the computer, and I'm not sure everyone is capable," said Dr. Gary Kosc, a gastroenterologist from West Paterson, who was checking on one of his geriatric patients on a recent afternoon. "It takes time to learn," he said, and time to embrace it as a useful tool.
Every hospital's culture is different. So too are the paths they take in adopting the tools of cost control, managed care and automated records systems, a transformation being forced on hospitals everywhere by insurance companies, big health care buyers like health maintenance organizations, and the prospect of a Federal health care overhaul from Washington.
At St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan, for example, the hospital is installing a new internal records network similar to St. Joseph's, but will leap directly to doctors' typing in their own orders in late 1995. At other hospitals, like New York University -- perhaps the most automated hospital in the region -- computer literacy for physicians has been a requirement for years.
Hospital experts say that places like St. Joseph's -- in an area with many hospitals -- have less leverage in compelling doctors, who can take their business elsewhere if they are unhappy. And the less a physician is tied to any one hospital, the less incentive to learn its computer system.
 
Challenging the Old Ways
 But there is no question, they add, that hospital records systems are threats to old bases of power.
"It challenges the old ways of doing things," said Dr. Patricia Flatley Brennan, an associate professor of nursing and systems engineering at Case Western Reserve University. "Once you change the way information flows, you change the way people work together -- you change who is in power and who has the right to make decisions."
But even here, some doctors are urging that they be required to participate fully.
Dr. John J. Farkas, a wiry, bearded gastroenterology and hepatology specialist, said he sees himself as a catalyst of sorts, prodding the administration to move faster on the road it has set for itself. While he understands the hospital's reluctance to compound confusion by forcing old ways to change too fast, he maintains that delaying a cultural adaptation by physicians will not make it easier. "Without physician order entry, the system is a big miss," he said.
But there is also fear, in various varieties.
The new network, essentially a nerve system for the hospital, now only allows coordination of medical supplies, lab results, admissions, transfers and dozens of other basic functions. Add-on components scheduled for introduction in coming months, however, will create a whole new push into matters of medical judgment, a function called "decision support."
Before the network came on line, orders for things like blood tests or radiology were handwritten and dispatched by messengers who roamed the hospital corridors; individual departments and labs had computers, but they were never coordinated. Under the new regime, the connections -- from the administrative offices to the warehouse -- are like nerves extending through every limb.
The computer will be able to assist doctors in diagnoses. It will schedule operating rooms by calculating how fast or slow a surgeon has performed a particular procedure in the past. It will allow administrators to know much more than they do now about who exactly does what.
Doing that also requires the assigning of numerical values to things that have always been done on human need and intuition. One software program scheduled to come on line early next year, for example, will calculate how many hours a day of hands-on nursing time should be required for a particular patient with a particular health problem.
For some, the computer symbolizes bureaucracy and intrusion.
"It's getting worse and worse," said Tammy Gundlah, a 28-year-old registered nurse, sitting in her office, a converted coat closet she shares with another nurse in geriatrics. "Everything is so legal, you need all this documentation all the time. It's disappointing, you're always afraid somebody's going to sue for this, you've got to make sure you write everything down, everything's got to be charted. And this computer thing; it's like you're more out at the desk dealing with the computers than with the patients."
In this unit, in particular, where the patients are older, sicker and likely to stay longer, health care providers worry that all the data will ultimately make it harder for the hospital to subsidize long-term and indigent patients.
As the computer system is able to collect very precise statistics on every cost, many doctors and nurses worry that administrators, armed with vast new amounts of information and under pressure to economize, could find it harder to justify providing treatment without regard to cost.
How, exactly, do you measure the treatment received by Stella Zober? Mrs. Zober, a wispy-haired 79-year-old Wallington resident, was admitted in late May, barely able to move after her arthritis suddenly worsened. Through therapy in the geriatrics unit, she has regained the ability to get about with a walker, but she is not ready to go back to her apartment, or to a nursing home. And no one is pushing to have her discharged.
"I think, always, that the quality of care, the quality of life, will prevail," said Dr. Belinda Vicioso, the chief of geriatric medicine. Then she paused for moment. "I'm hoping."
Dr. Vicioso also believes that physicians at the keyboard will ultimately be common at St. Joseph's, though she concedes it will not be painless.
"The old guard is dying off," she said. "It will happen; it has to happen. If we can cut down on the number of steps, the delivery of care will be more efficient, and cheaper, hopefully."
Hope is plentiful. Nurses who deplored the changes they see and fear, like Mrs. Gundlah, also said just as often that they couldn't envision working anywhere else. Some who seem to have inherited the burden of the work in the new electronic order have also observed that information is power, even if you have to work harder.
"Like they say, one hand washes the other. You be nice to me, I'll be nice to you; treat me with respect, I'll treat you with respect," said Ms. McClendon, the unit receptionist. Even the doctors figure that out eventually, she added, smiling, "So it's not that bad."
 
 
 
THE SERIES SO FAR
 The first article in this series about the introduction of a computer system at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Paterson, N.J., appeared on April 8. It described the hospital's preparations to computerize virtually all of its operations in a single weekend, and the fears and hopes of employees. The second article, which appeared on April 11, told of the big and small problems employees had encountered in the abrupt start-up of the system, and the solutions that were worked out.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Building New Roads for El Diario

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
Back when Peter W. Davidson was a young president of a newspaper company -- or, more precisely, when he was a younger one, since he is only 35 now -- he thought newspaper publishing was a relatively simple and lucrative business.
But listen to him now. 
 "I realize the newspaper business isn't as attractive as I, or any of us, thought," he said in his lower Manhattan office at El Diario-La Prensa, the 81-year-old Spanish-language daily in New York that he and a group of investors bought from the Gannett Company in 1989.
Call it the education of a yuppie in the real world of business. At the time of the purchase, Mr. Davidson, educated at Stanford and the Harvard Business School and the grandson of Jacob Merrill Kaplan, the philanthropist, was working as an investment banker at Morgan Stanley & Company under the media specialist Steven Rattner.
"Peter," Mr. Rattner said the other day, "is a classic yuppie in the positive sense: young, hungry, bright, well educated, thoughtful."
Five tough years later, after surviving sharp circulation declines and a stubborn recession that stalled advertising, the newspaper is recovering. And Mr. Davidson has clearly learned some lessons.
 
A New Patience
 One of them is shown in his manner. "He was less patient then; he is more patient now," said Carlos D. Ramirez, who has been publisher of El Diario both for Gannett and for Mr. Davidson. Mr. Ramirez is also part of Mr. Davidson's investor group.
Evidence of another lesson is in his strategic approach to the business, which has revenues of about $17 million, up from about $12 million five years ago. Mr. Davidson is now busily expanding into other businesses, many of which have little to do with traditional newspapering.
El Diario, with a circulation of 51,000, remains the center of the business. The tabloid newspaper makes extensive use of color printing in covering local, national and international news for Hispanic readers. Recently, Mr. Davidson said he was reaffirming a commitment to local news when he appointed two new co-editors: Juan Garcia, who had been managing editor, and Aileen Gelpi, who had been metropolitan editor. Ms. Gelpi is the first Puerto Rican-born woman to edit a major daily in New York. They replaced Fernando Moreno, who moved to other editing responsibilities.
Like many newspaper executives, Mr. Davidson has grown convinced that revenue growth at newspapers is likely to be much more limited than he used to think.
He has El Diario people working on Hispanic television programming. He is publishing a grocery-store promotional guide with coupons for Hispanic consumers. And he is particularly excited about a new El Diario-sponsored marketing and advertising agency that is helping big companies like Citibank get their message to a Hispanic audience.
Mr. Davidson also said his company was interested in possible acquisitions of magazines and broadcast outlets that are oriented toward Hispanic audiences. The company is also talking with potential new investors to increase its capital, he said.
 
 
A $20 Million Start
 At the beginning, non-newspaper ventures were not the goal. Fascinated by newspapers in high school and college, Mr. Davidson worked one summer while in business school for Donald E. Graham, the publisher of The Washington Post. "I liked the entire package of his life style," Mr. Davidson said.
So in 1989, Mr. Davidson did what many bright young investment bankers in the 1980's only talked about. He assembled investors to back his bid for a business. They won El Diario for slightly more than $20 million, it was reported at the time.
Part of the premise of the high-debt deal, Mr. Davidson acknowledges, is that the newspaper industry would remain robust, with revenues climbing each year.
"I think he came into this thinking it would continue like that forever," Mr. Ramirez said.
The first year was good. Mr. Davidson studied Spanish, learned about the Hispanic community in New York, and got to work on the paper. Revenue grew as expected.
And then, the lessons of the real world started.
Like a good investment banker, Mr. Davidson researched the possible decline in circulation if he raised El Diario's newsstand price, then 35 cents. He even got advice from his old marketing professor at Harvard.
The experts told him to expect a decline of 3 to 5 percent in circulation, which was then about 60,000.
Trying to build revenues, El Diario raised its price to 45 cents. The circulation plunged by 20,000, to 40,000, or more than 30 percent, Mr. Ramirez said. It has since climbed slowly.
With the economy in a slump in 1991, and with circulation, advertising and revenues down, El Diario was forced to lay off management employees and demand concessions from a union of editorial employees. The newspaper renegotiated loans and has been able to make payments, but it has not yet shown a net profit.
There were other lessons, too. A promoter persuaded Mr. Davidson to back a series of concerts of Mexican bands because of what sounded like the synergies possible through newspaper promotion. "We got killed," and withdrew from the deal after two concerts, Mr. Davidson said.
And then, there was every entrepreneur's vision of national expansion. Mr. Davidson formed a separate company and, with a partner, acquired Hispanic weekly newspapers in Chicago and San Francisco. On paper, Mr. Davidson said, the logic seemed clear: national advertisers would be drawn by a national network delivering Hispanic readers.
Only, he discovered, national advertisers were not really interested in the quality of printing available on newsprint. And, he said, it was frustrating to try to run publications so far from the home office. "Whenever the phone rang, it was a problem," he said.
Mr. Davidson gave up his stake in the weeklies about a year ago. "We don't want to be getting involved in far-flung operations, no matter how sexy it seems," he said.
 
Supplementing the Daily
 For now, Mr. Davidson is sticking to more manageable projects. Five months ago, he started El Diario Extra!, a free publication distributed in Hispanic neighborhoods in the metropolitan area. It has a circulation of 235,000. He said it was already moderately profitable, supplying advertisers with a way to reach Hispanic consumers who do not read El Diario.
He is imitating the efforts of many larger English-language newspaper companies that have tried to build revenues by adding editorial products to supplement their main dailies. El Diario imitates Parade magazine, for example, with a thin monthly magazine on special topics like soccer and business. It is distributed with seven Hispanic publications around the country.
And Mr. Davidson is especially enthusiastic about Paloma Promotions and Advertising, the agency he started as a way to take advantage of El Diario's status as an expert on the Hispanic community.
The creation of Paloma reflects Mr. Davidson's changing view of El Diario's franchise. It is not just a newspaper, he said, but a marketing "guide and a shepherd" for corporate clients who want to reach Hispanic readers. But he did not make any pretense that this was a carefully charted course.
Mr. Davidson described the product development plan he now uses at El Diario: "We rush out with a bunch of things, without -- I hate to say this -- without really studying it, and see what works."
It was as if he was trying to show how far he had come since the orderly days of the Harvard Business School and Morgan Stanley.

HEADLINE: Review/Dance;
Spirited, Wide-Ranging Tribute To Modern Choreographers

BYLINE: By JACK ANDERSON 

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.C., June 19

 BODY:
The American Dance Festival accomplished an extraordinary number of things in one single evening. The program on Saturday night at Page Auditorium of Duke University here emphasized the richness of American modern dance and called attention to the accomplishments of black choreographers.
The event featured two talented and versatile groups, one from Ohio, the other from Colorado. The Dayton Contemporary Dance Company dates from 1960. The Denver-based Cleo Parker Robinson Dance Ensemble was established in 1970. Their productions included two major revivals, a world premiere and pieces by three other choreographers. 
 The result was a historical and cultural survey that educated as well as entertained. Yet no pedantry was involved.
There was certainly nothing stuffily academic about the Denver company's revival of "Choros," which Katherine Dunham created in 1941. Miss Dunham, who turns 85 on Wednesday and was a guest at the festival, is one of the pioneers of black American choreography. In addition to studying dance, she studied anthropology at the University of Chicago, and her style combines elements of many folk forms with the theatricality of a Broadway revue.
Dance lovers had an opportunity to meet Miss Dunham in a special program on Friday night, during which she answered questions from the audience. Although she has used a wheelchair since knee surgery a few years ago, she promised, "I'll surprise everyone someday and go tripping down the road." She proceeded to recall economic and racial adversities in the Depression and urged everyone to study anthropology.
Her "Choros," based on a traditional Brazilian quadrille, abounds with deft little kicking steps. On Saturday, Karah Abiog, Gary Lewis, Angelica Edwards and Randy Brooks made all its bounces and leaps seem like chuckles.
The other revival, staged by the Dayton group, was "The Beloved," Lester Horton's grim 1948 dance drama. From the mid-1930's to his death in 1953, Horton, the only white choreographer represented on the program, directed a Los Angeles company that is believed to be America's first racially integrated modern-dance troupe. He was also a distinguished teacher, and one of his later pupils was Alvin Ailey.
"The Beloved," to a score by Judith Hamilton played on the piano by Kevin Ward, concerns a religious bigot who accuses his wife of infidelity and then murders her. The choreographic tone was established at the outset when the curtain rose upon Dawn Wood and Calvin Norris Young looking as rigid as the chairs in which they sat.
Mr. Young was a formidable presence, and when he was consumed with suspicion, he tugged at Miss Wood with brute force. One of the effective touches to her characterization was the way she let the wife give no hint of whether the accusations are true. For this woman, ambiguity was her one defense against her husband's overwhelming power.
Talley Beatty's "Ellingtonia," the evening's premiere, is a bright addition to the Denver company's repertory. Mr. Beatty, who is in his 70's and was also at the festival, danced with Miss Dunham in Chicago in the 1930's and has been creating his own works since the 40's. He is especially known for his patterns for groups. His new suite to four recorded compositions by Duke Ellington is both intricate and exhilarating.
Its opening sequence features running, jumping and whirling with many sudden changes of direction. Then a long line of twisting dancers breaks apart into small groups of swaggering, swiveling and sauntering people. A brief duet, in which Mr. Brooks and Marceline Freeman repeatedly run toward each other and separate, is followed by an energetic finale in which all 11 cast members leap on and off from all parts of the stage.
The Denver dancers also presented "Sombra y Sol," a fantasy to music by Aaron Copland, which Donald McKayle choreographed in 1991 as a tribute to the Mexican painter Frida Kahlo. Ms. Freeman, who portrayed the artist, encountered dancers costumed as monkeys and birds, and was haunted by a skeletal figure representing death. But the choreography was more effective as an evocation of atmosphere than as a symbolic drama.
The other productions came from the Dayton company. If the dancers were especially high-spirited this summer, that may have been because the director, Jeraldyne Blunden, has just received a grant from the MacArthur Foundation of Chicago of $320,000 over the next five years.
In 1991, Dwight Rhoden honored this crusader for modern dance with "Beyond a Cliff: A Tribute to Jeraldyne Blunden," to music by Michael Shrieve, Olfra Haza and Martin Birkenstock. His choreographic ode to indomitability was an appropriate addition to the program, and the way its leading dancer, Sheri Williams, conquered space symbolized a defiance of obstacles.
The Dayton dancers displayed their dramatic gifts in "Las Desenamoradas," the dance to music by John Coltrane that Eleo Pomare adapted from "The House of Bernarda Alba," Federico Garcia Lorca's play about a possessive mother. Ms. Wood, cast as this matriarch, moved implacably and convincingly and tyrannized her household.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Dayton Contemporary Dance Company performing "The Beloved," by Lester Horton, at Duke University in Durham, N.C. (Rebecca Lesher for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For a Festival, Rain or Shine?

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
This week at Waterloo, a restored colonial village near Stanhope, N.J., student musicians are getting their bearings, and groundskeepers are getting the 2,000-seat concert tent and the surrounding picnic area ready for the opening of the 19th Waterloo Festival on Saturday evening, when Catherine Comet will conduct a program of Russian music with Andre Watts as the soloist in the Rachmaninoff Second Piano Concerto.
But if the preparations seem to be business as usual for the hybrid music school and concert series, they come after an unusually tumultuous year. Administrative and artistic shakeups at the festival have yielded a shift toward more conservative programming. And in a way, the festival has been eclipsed by plans for the future of Waterloo itself. 
 Last October, Percival H. E. Leach, the president and founder of Waterloo, announced that he hoped to build a $50 million arts center in the village, and that he had been discussing summer seasons with the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and American Ballet Theater. The center would open in 1996.
At the time, Gov. Jim Florio said he supported a $21 million bond issue. But that was only weeks before Mr. Florio was defeated by Christine Todd Whitman, who had portrayed Mr. Florio's administration as profligate during her campaign. But if the state's $21 million can no longer be taken for granted, the project does have an ally in Gualberto Medina, the new Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development. Mr. Medina said that $5.5 million had been set aside from the Economic Recovery Fund, and that he was completing a study that he would present to Governor Whitman at the end of the month.
"All this is predicated on my feeling comfortable with the project from a financial standpoint," Mr. Medina said. "What we're doing in New Jersey is submitting any project that is proposed to a rigorous analysis. We have to look at the revenue we can expect the center to bring in, and we have to feel confident that it will repay the bond issue. Frankly, I feel that this project is doable, but I have to withold judgment until I have the figures in place."
 
Need for Persuasion
 The rest of the money for the Waterloo Center for the Performing Arts must be raised privately, and Mr. Leach said last week that he had commitments for virtually all of the remaining $30 million. That leaves, however, the chicken-and-egg business of persuading the Met, the Philharmonic and Ballet Theater to commit themselves fully.
After the October announcement, the Met backtracked slightly, pointing out that it gave annual performances at Waterloo already, and that it had not committed to extending its visits. A difference, though, is that the theatrical facilities of the new center would allow for fully staged opera instead of the concert presentations the Met currently offers during the summer. The Philharmonic, too, has been cautious. Deborah Borda, its executive director, is saying only that Waterloo "is one of several options we're considering."
For Mr. Medina, the participation of the New York companies is crucial. "The Met really is the major concern," he said. "If we can bring them, I think it will work, and if we can bring the Philharmonic and Ballet Theater, then we'll have an extremely attractive program to offer. We realize, though, that before we can sit down with those companies, we have to put together the financing so that we can give them firm dates for construction."
 
Conductor Resigns
 The festival, meanwhile, has weathered its own upheavals. Gerard Schwarz, who founded the festival in 1976, when he was a well-known trumpet soloist and a fledgling conductor, resigned as music director early this year, saying that his responsibilities as director of the Mostly Mozart Festival, the Seattle Symphony Orchestra and the New York Chamber Symphony were keeping him too busy for Waterloo. He has been replaced by Yoav Talmi, a 50-year-old Israeli conductor who directs the San Diego Symphony and conducted at Waterloo several times over the last five years.
"I was able to plan the festival's program and invite the other conductors and soloists," said Mr. Talmi, speaking by telephone from Wellington, New Zealand, where he is conducting. "But it is difficult, with only two or three months' notice, to reach musicians who are free. I think within the time we had, we have done miraculously well."
Besides Miss Comet and Mr. Watts, Mr. Talmi's roster for the festival's four concerts includes the conductor Joseph Silverstein, the soprano Helen Donath, the violinist Elmar Oliveira and the cellist Carter Brey. Mr. Talmi will conduct the last two concerts, on July 9 and 16. There is also a series of Friday evening chamber concerts (beginning this week) at Drew University, in Madison, N.J. And there are free rehearsals on Thursday evenings at the Seasons Resort and Conference Center in McAfee, N.J., where the school's master classes are held.
 
Director Dismissed
 In the other major administrative change, Samuel Lipman, the pianist and critic who, as artistic director since 1985, has guided the school and emphasized American music in the festival's programs, has been dismissed. The festival's literature now lists Carol Delaire as the director of the school, which has 90 students between the ages of 18 and 25 and a faculty that includes members of the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, the New York Chamber Symphony, the Seattle Symphony and other ensembles. Most of last year's faculty, Ms. Delaire said, is returning this year.
Mr. Leach's principal complaint about Mr. Lipman was that his programming, though admired by critics, was driving listeners away. Mr. Talmi, when asked whether he had been told to restrain his programming, said: "The only guideline was that the directors of the festival asked me to keep the programs very popular, since they are trying to attract more people. So keeping that in mind, I tried not to get too adventurous."
It may be, though, that programming alone has not been responsible for Waterloo's falling attendance in recent years. Pushed to present more mainstream fare, Mr. Lipman last year presented the popular violinist Pinchas Zukerman in the Beethoven Violin Concerto, and sold what Mr. Leach described as "fewer than 500" tickets.
"Our audiences have not been what they should be," Mr. Leach said. "Last year, on average, I would say we were half full. And the year before, when we had 12 weeks of rain, there was a tremendous impact on ticket sales. I do worry about this. It is increasingly difficult to sell good music."
Mr. Leach argues that his proposed arts center, which is to have 4,000 enclosed seats and 5,000 lawn seats, will deal with that problem more easily, since the high-profile ensembles he hopes to have in residence are likely to be a greater draw than Waterloo's combined student and faculty orchestra. (Waterloo also presents rock concerts during the summer, which Mr. Leach said do much better financially.) He added that plans to build a hotel and conference center nearby may make Waterloo a more attractive place to spend a weekend.
"People wend their way to Tanglewood," Mr. Leach said, "which is farther from New York than Waterloo is. We are only an hour out of town, and we have our own exit on a major artery, Interstate 80. We have a beautiful, entirely historical village in which a period from the Revolution to the Industrial Revolution is preserved. We're in a lovely area, surrounded by 11,000 acres of the Allamuchy Mountain State Park. There's no reason we can't become the Tanglewood of this area."

HEADLINE: Universal Coverage at Risk

 BODY:
The debate over health care reform has stalled over the issue of employer mandates -- the requirement, as proposed by President Clinton, that employers pay most of the cost of policies chosen by their employees. At stake is a primary purpose of health care reform -- universal coverage
The President is insisting on the mandate because he believes it is the only realistic way of moving to universal coverage. Small employers are fighting back hard because many fear a mandate will drive them out of business. And conservatives are fighting the mandate because, to them, it is the opening through which the Government will creep into every corner of health care. 
 Here, Mr. Clinton has it right. Universal coverage is not only a fair and noble objective, consistent with America's values; it is also essential if health care markets are to work well.
There are several variations of health care reform floating around Capitol Hill. Most of them would protect the chronically ill by requiring insurers to sell to any applicant at non-discriminatory rates. But once that guarantee is included, healthy people would be tempted to forgo insurance until they got sick; that would leave only the sick to buy coverage, at rates the insurers would be forced to set very high. The President would overcome the problem by requiring everyone to buy coverage. And because the vast majority of Americans already get coverage through employers, he proposes an employer mandate because it could achieve universal coverage without institutional upheaval.
That said, Mr. Clinton seems to be flexible about how to impose a mandate. It could be delayed or phased in slowly to give employers time to adjust. The President could also embrace a "hard trigger" whereby Congress would suspend the mandate for, say, five years; then if insurance reforms alone had not achieved universal coverage, a mandate would automatically kick in. But what the President ought not do is drop the mandate or accept a wishy-washy promise that someday, somehow it will be adopted if needed.
Small employers despise the mandate because, with profits already slim, they fear new costs will force them to lay off workers. But careful studies show the fear is exaggerated. For example, employers have offset state and Federal mandates requiring them to cover childbirth expenses by cutting back on wage increases for women of childbearing age and their husbands. The beneficiaries absorbed the cost of the mandate, employers were barely nicked and virtually no one had to be laid off.
Though the mandate is the best route to universal coverage, it need not be imposed immediately. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that insurance reform without mandates can achieve near-universal coverage. Reform would forbid insurers from discriminating against the chronically ill, "pool" small employers and individuals into large purchasing cooperatives, and provide subsidies to poor families.
Taken together, these reforms would lift the percentage of the population with insurance from 85 percent to over 91 percent. And since most of those who would refuse to buy coverage under such rules would be disproportionately young and healthy, insurance would cover perhaps 97 percent of the nation's total health care expenditures. At that point Congress could let a mandate automatically kick in to pick up the uninsured, or devise some other solution.
Small-business lobbyists and conservatives have done an excellent job of portraying an employer mandate as a huge economic risk. Now the President and his supporters must do an equally good job convincing a confused public that the mandate is the least-disruptive way to bring to every American family financial security from medical catastrophe.

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Towers Investors Try Aggressive New Legal Tack

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
Thanks to a precedent-smashing Supreme Court decision in April, the heat has been turned up in the fiery courthouse battle being waged by aggrieved investors in the Towers Financial Corporation of New York, a bankrupt conglomerate that Federal prosecutors have charged was the vehicle by which the financier Steven Hoffenberg defrauded investors of more than $450 million between 1988 and 1993.
 A sharply divided court reversed decades of practice by barring investors from filing "aiding and abetting" accusations against accountants, lawyers and other financial professionals whose clients had committed securities fraud. 
In response to the decision, lawyers for the investors have substantially raised the ante; they are now contending that the lawyers, accountants, brokers and credit analysts who worked for Towers when the disputed securities were sold were direct participants in the fraud -- and therefore bear direct responsibility for the investors' losses.
 
'Lame Explanations'
 The plaintiffs contend that Towers' lawyers -- the firm of Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Lehrer in New York -- permitted perjured testimony by company executives, accepted as fact the company's "lame explanations" and outright lies to market regulators, and ignored early warning signs in correspondence from brokers and from outside auditors.
 The plaintiffs also contend that accountants at Richard A. Eisner & Company who audited Towers' investment subsidiaries, ignored evidence of fraudulent behavior by the parent company; and that the credit agency that reviewed the firm's bonds, the Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company, knew or should have known that its prestige was being used as a selling point for the firm's notes, which were not rated.
 In each case, the plaintiffs argue, the alleged fraud by Towers could not have continued but for the participation of the professionals, whose reputation and standing lent credibility to the Towers operation.
 That argument is the core of a revised 175-page complaint filed last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan by lawyers representing investors. Those lawyers' firms include Milberg, Weiss, Bershad, Hynes & Lerach in New York and Lieff, Cabraser & Heimann in San Francisco. The amended complaint has provoked outrage among the defendants who provided professional services, several of whom are asking the court to dismiss the case and impose punitive sanctions on the lawyers who filed it.
 "The complaint is completely without merit," said Robert Jossen, the attorney for the Eisner firm. "Our client did the job they were supposed to do in their audit of the subsidiaries, and there is no basis to charge Eisner with any wrongdoing."
 Philip Kaufman, the attorney for the Squadron law firm, noted that his client had not been named in any of "at least a dozen separate class action complaints across the country" until the current complaint. Ira Sorkin, the principal lawyer who handled the Towers work, said the accusations were "totally baseless and would be proven to be so."
 The role of Duff & Phelps was limited to providing a credit rating for bonds sold by Towers, and not for the notes purchased by the plaintiffs in the current case, said Joseph Coughlin, the firm's lawyer in Chicago. "If the noteholders are told by the sellers that the notes are not rated, I don't see how you can say that we are lending our expertise to anything," he added.
 
A Reversal by Founder
 Lawyers for the professional firms named in the complaint argued that the harsh accusations were merely an effort by the plaintiffs to sidestep the limits imposed by the Supreme Court. But a plaintiffs' attorney familiar with the preparation of the complaint disagreed, saying that he and his colleagues "had always felt that these guys were primary wrongdoers." There was simply no reason to word the complaint in those terms until the Supreme Court decision, he said.
 There was no shortage of legal fireworks in the Towers Financial case even before the Supreme Court voted in April to restrict the rights of investors to sue in cases like the Towers operation, which securities regulators have described as one of the largest Ponzi schemes in history.
 Mr. Hoffenberg, who was the founder and chairman of Towers, is facing criminal charges of fraud and obstruction of justice in connection with his ownership and operation of the insolvent company, which is being dismantled under the protection of the Federal Bankruptcy Court. In addition, both Mr. Hoffenberg and Towers have been sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission, on civil charges of violating securities laws in the sale of the notes and bonds.
 In a bizarre twist, Mr. Hoffenberg has pleaded not guilty to the charges, but has also asked the Federal District Court to force prosecutors to reinstate a revoked plea agreement under which he agreed to confess to at least five criminal counts in exchange for leniency in sentencing. The plea bargain was nullified by the Government on the grounds that Mr. Hoffenberg had violated its terms by lying about ongoing violations of a court-ordered freeze of his assets.
 Lawyers for the S.E.C. are still preparing for trial in their case, said Richard Walker, regional securities administrator for the commission.
 Mr. Walker said he did not anticipate that the Supreme Court decision would affect that effort because that case does not contend "aiding and abetting" but rather direct violations of securities laws.
 "The private complaints have been more expansive in naming wrongdoers than we have," Mr. Walker said. "But we intend to be very aggressive in bringing cases, to test the parameters of the ruling."

An article in Business Day on June 20 about the legal battle between the Towers Financial Corporation and its investors used an outdated name for one of the law firms involved. The firm that represented Towers is Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent, Sheinfeld & Sorkin; it ceased to be known as Squadron, Ellenoff, Plesent & Lehrer about two years ago.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Russia to Back Bosnia Pact Jointly

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, June 20

 BODY:
The United States, Russia and the European Union aim to endorse a final territorial settlement for Bosnia at a three-day meeting of leaders of seven major industrial nations that begins July 8 in Naples, a senior United Nations official said today.
The settlement would assign 51 percent of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the federation of the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government and the Bosnian Croats, and the rest to the Bosnian Serbs. 
 The boundaries are to be approved at a meeting of foreign ministers from the United States, Russia, Britain, France and Germany that has been provisionally set for July 1 and 2 in Geneva, Western diplomats said.
The plan is to be endorsed by President Clinton and the other six leaders -- from Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan -- who make up the so-called Group of Seven; they are to be joined later by President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
The idea is to lend new weight to the long-muddled effort to end the 27-month-old war.
 
And if One Refuses . . .
 The proposal would then be submitted to the warring parties, take it or leave it, accompanied by a mixture of blandishments and potential punishments intended to insure acceptance.
"If the Muslims agree to the settlement and the Serbs don't, then the arms embargo on Bosnia could be lifted," said the United Nations official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If the Serbs agree and the Muslims don't, the idea is that trade sanctions on Serbia could be progressively lifted."
But after talks this weekend with Charles E. Redman, Washington's special envoy for the Balkans, the United Nations official said he was pessimistic that even a plan explicitly backed by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin would end the war.
"We are into a crucial few weeks that will decide if peace prevails or a wider conflict erupts, but the signs are not encouraging," the official said. "Low-level fighting continues despite a cease-fire signed by the warring parties, and there are indications of preparations for new offensives."
Mr. Redman and the Russian, British and French diplomats in the "contact group" working on the proposed settlement are thus racing the clock.
 
Both Sides Seem Dug In
 Indeed, Mr. Redman has already asked Yasushi Akashi, the top United Nations official in the region, to try to negotiate an extension of the tenuous month-long Bosnian cease-fire, which went into effect on June 10. Relative calm on the battlefield is widely regarded as essential to any political settlement.
The Bosnian Serbs, who hold about three-quarters of Bosnia, have said they might settle for half, but only if what they give up is mostly economically unattractive mountainous stretches, not towns. The Serbs say they will not give up Prijedor, Banja Luka, Brcko, Zvornik, Vlasenica or Visegrad, which they seized by force during the war, killing or evicting most of the non-Serbian residents.
But the Government says it will not give up the fight until those who were forced out can return to their homes.
For several weeks, members of the contact group considered establishing United Nations administrations in disputed towns. But this idea has been abandoned, a United States diplomat said, because "it just puts off the problem."
 
High Hurdles Remain
 Instead, the idea is to draw the border between the Muslim-Croatian federation and the Serbs so it runs through several of these towns. "Think of it as a series of little Nicosias," said one official, referring to the divided capital of Cyprus.
Several difficulties remain. The first is that the Serbs appear unprepared -- even under Russian pressure -- to give up control of what they regard as strategically vital towns.
The second is that the current Government offensive toward Vlasenica, undertaken despite the June 10 truce, suggests that the Government is still a long way from believing that diplomacy can secure its territorial demands.
The third is the danger that the unity between Washington and Moscow could fray if one of the warring parties rejects the proposal.
 
Carrots and Sticks
 If the Muslims balk, a lifting of trade sanctions on the Serbs would be a very hard decision for the Clinton Administration to make. The United States Government and Congress generally view the Muslims as the aggrieved party.
But if the Serbs, traditional allies of the Russians, say no, President Yeltsin would have great political difficulty in accepting a end to the arms embargo on the Bosnian Government, a decision his Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, recently described as a recipe for a third world war.
"Unity between Russia and the United States is essential if we are to bring real pressure to bear on the parties," the United Nations official said. "But I fear their cooperation may be severely tested."

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Hopeful Yet Cautious About Carter's North Korea Trip

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he welcomed "hopeful signs" that a clash over North Korea's nuclear weapons program could be averted. But he maintained an air of skepticism about the pledges former President Jimmy Carter won from the North.
Mr. Clinton's comments were his first on the matter since Mr. Carter returned from his visit to the Korean peninsula, and they reflected an insistence by the Administration that the Communist Government do more to demonstrate its willingness to halt its nuclear program. 
"The critical question is: are they willing to freeze this nuclear program?" Mr. Clinton said in an interview on the NBC News program "Today." He said the United States needed "to know what the facts are" before agreeing to the new round of high-level talks North Korea is seeking.
 
Sanctions Still Possible
 With the White House facing criticism from Republicans and even some Democrats for failing to hew to a hard line, the Administration sought to demonstrate today that it has not ruled out seeking economic sanctions against North Korea. American and Russian officials discussed those tougher measures in a meeting at the United Nations, and the subject is to be the primary focus of a meeting on Wednesday in Brussels between Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia.
But in the interview, Mr. Clinton also backed further away from the Administration's one-time insistence that the North insure that international monitors are allowed to determine how much plutonium North Korea might have diverted from its reactor at Yongbyon in the past.
"I think what we have to do is to look to the present and the future, and say we will evaluate words in terms of actions," Mr. Clinton said.
At the same time, Administration officials acknowledged that they were postponing considering a Pentagon recommendation for a buildup of American forces in South Korea. They said they had concluded that this could jeopardize whatever prospects exist for a settlement.
"I don't think anyone feels it's prudent to make those kinds of decisions while we're trying to determine the veracity of what the North Koreans apparently said," a senior Defense Department official said today.
Mr. Carter reported to Administration officials over the weekend that North Korea would be willing to freeze all activity that produces fuel for nuclear weapons if Washington begins high-level talks. Today, Mr. Clinton stopped short of embracing Mr. Carter's view that the offer represents an end to the crisis, but he made clear his belief that Mr. Carter's visit might have created a diplomatic opening.
"If North Korea wishes to talk and is willing to freeze their nuclear program, that is, not continue the reprocessing and refueling while they talk, then that would be a step forward," the President said.
In a hint that future steps will be delicate, Mr. Clinton and his top foreign policy advisers met this afternoon with nearly a dozen experts on North Korea from outside Government in a session intended in part to seek their guidance on how best to proceed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
A falling dollar put new pressure on the Federal Reserve to consider a fifth interest rate increase this year. Though Fed officials were unwilling to say so publicly, they have signaled a resolve to keep the dollar from slumping by raising short-term rates again -- even if the American economy suffers. [Page A1.] 
 The U.S. Supreme Court upheld California's method of taxing the state income of foreign-based multinational corporations, relieving the state of a $4 billion liability in tax refunds. The ruling ended years of uncertainty about the validity of the accounting method of worldwide combined reporting. [D1.]
 
Companies
Lotus Development stunned Wall Street analysts by announcing that its results for the quarter would not meet estimates. Lotus shares plunged $8.875 in after-hours trading. [D1.]
R. H. Macy's directors have agreed to hear a pitch by Federated Department Stores to combine the two department store operators, people familiar with the board's meeting said. [D3.]
Eli Lilly, which is slimming down to its core pharmaceutical business, said it would spin off five units that make medical devices to a new company, Guidant. [D3.]
Jenny Craig, the operator of weight-loss centers, suspended its quarterly dividend, sending its stock down sharply. [D3.]
Citicorp said it had sold I/B/E/S, a supplier of corporate earnings estimates, to an American subsidiary of VNU. [D4.]
GTE introduced a new business unit to develop interactive video games and multimedia computer programs. [D4.]
The board of a Manhattan cooperative filed a Federal class-action suit against Brown Harris Stevens, a management company, claiming systematic overcharging. [B3.]
 
International
The North American Free Trade Agreement is compiling a record that often belies its name. Interviews with dozens of exporters and importers on both sides of the U.S.-Mexican border indicate that many who expected to benefit from the pact are running into complications and costs, eroding its advantages. [D1.]
After years of being derided as overpriced, defect-prone gas guzzlers, American cars are starting to win some consumer acceptance in Japan. [D1.] New figures suggest that Japan's auto makers will have trouble meeting a goal of purchasing $19 billion of American parts this fiscal year. [D14.]
Europe's financial markets were racked by another spasm of anxiety as stocks and bonds tumbled in value in all the major financial centers and the dollar slid to ominously low levels. [D2.]
 
Markets
The stock market fell sharply for the second straight session, after a steep drop in the dollar and a selloff in European stocks. The Dow slumped 34.88 points, to 3,741.90. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed, with a steep drop in commodity prices easing fears about inflation helping to trim earlier losses attributed to the weak dollar. [D14.]
The dollar tumbled against most leading currencies as slumping global stock and bond prices encouraged investors to shift into cash deposits in countries with high interest rates. [D16.]
Scattered thunderstorms across the parched Midwest sent grain prices reeling. [D16.]
 
Today's Columns
Whatever happens to Michael A. Miles after his unexpected resignation as the chairman and chief executive of Philip Morris, one gamble he made will continue to reshape American consumer-product marketing. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D1.]
Louis V. Gerstner Jr. has won a fair measure of respect along Wall Street in his 14 months as I.B.M.'s chairman and chief executive, but he still has a long way to go. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Japan Faces a Difficult Goal on Auto Parts

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, June 21

 BODY:
Figures released today suggest that Japan's auto makers will have difficulty meeting their voluntary goal of buying $19 billion of American automobile parts in the current fiscal year, industry officials said.
The Japanese manufacturers bought $15.54 billion of American parts in the fiscal year that ended in March, a gain of 14.1 percent from a year earlier, an official at the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. The year before, purchases increased 30 percent. 
 To achieve the $19 billion goal in the year that ends next March, purchases will have to rise 22 percent -- growth that Japan's depressed auto industry may find hard to achieve, some officials say. It is "a very delicate situation right now," said Takumi Oue, a spokesman for the Japanese auto industry association.
Japanese manufacturers adopted what they called a voluntary plan in January 1992, when President George Bush visited Japan along with the heads of the Big Three auto makers.
In connection with the trade negotiations between Japan and the United States, the leading Japanese auto makers recently announced new voluntary plans for increasing foreign parts purchases beyond this year. Washington has called the plans insufficient.
Making the $19 billion goal is not out of the question, however, as the Japanese industry has been known to make extra efforts with a deadline approaching. In semiconductors, foreign manufacturers' market share in Japan shot up in a single quarter to surpass the 20 percent goal just at the deadline.
The $19 billion figure is the sum of a goal of importing $4 billion of American-made parts and buying $15 billion of parts for use in Japanese factories in the United States. Japanese auto executives have said it will be easier to reach the goal for parts used in their American plants. American parts have become more competitive in price as the yen has risen.
But executives have said it will be difficult to meet the goals for importing parts. Production of cars in Japan has been dropping because of the economic slump and because the yen's rise has cut Japan's exports.

HEADLINE: Laotians' Arrest in Killing Bares a Generation Gap

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BANNING, Calif.

 BODY:
Klaus and Gisela Pfleger, a retired German couple on vacation, were photographing spring flowers on a scenic hillside in May when three young men walked up to them, shot them in the head and drove away with Mrs. Pfleger's purse.
The attack, which killed Mrs. Pfleger and left her husband seriously injured, was the sort of gratuitous brutality that has become frighteningly common in Southern California among gangs, carjackers and thrill killers. But in this case, the police arrested three teen-agers whose backgrounds bewildered them. 
 They were Laotian refugees from America's "secret war" in Indochina during the Vietnam War, when the Central Intelligence Agency enlisted thousands of hill tribesmen to try to block the Ho Chi Minh supply trail into South Vietnam, an effort that proved to be futile.
Although the three teen-agers had grown up as Southern California boys who wore baggy hip-hop clothes and spoke the American slang of their generation, they were born in Laos, and two were members of the Hmong (pronounced "mung"), a clan-based people whose culture had no written language until recent times and centered on slash-and-burn farming.
 
Children Forsake Old WaysGeneration Gap
 The shootings, on May 16, bewildered members of the Hmong community here as well, including the families of the arrested teen-agers. Some 1,500 Hmong have followed their clan leaders to this city of 23,000 people in the smoggy Inland Empire, an area 50 miles east of Los Angeles.
Nu Yeng Yang, a toughened Hmong veteran of the war in Laos who came to the United States in 1980, maintained an awkward smile the other day as he talked of his alienation from his adopted country and his Americanized 19-year-old son, Xou Yang, who is being held pending his arraignment in the killing.
"Back in our country, you never saw things like this happen," Mr. Nu Yeng said. "There are no thieves, although our houses are not as nice as here. Nothing would come into your house except for the animals you own."
Like many Hmong parents -- and like many other immigrant parents through the decades -- he said there was little he could say to his son, Mr. Xou, to guide him in this strange new world, and that, in any case, his son had stopped listening to him.
 
'He Will Not Listen'
 "We have lost all control," Mr. Nu Yeng said. "Our children do not respect us. One of the hardest things for me is when I tell my children things and they say, 'I already know that.' When my wife and I try to tell my son about Hmong culture, he tells me people here are different, and he will not listen to me."
Mr. Nu Yeng's son is being held in the killing with a second 19-year-old, Khamchan Ketsouvannasane, and with a 17-year-old Hmong whose name has not been released because of his age.
Deputy District Attorney Richard Bentley, who is prosecuting the case, said the 17-year-old had fired the shots, accompanied by Mr. Khamchan, and that Mr. Xou had waited in their car. But he said he could not say whether they were members of a gang, as the police had initially suggested, or what might have led them to this sudden, brutal act.
Since the United States began accepting Hmong as refugees in 1980, more than 100,000 have come to the United States, clustering in places like Montana, Wisconsin, Virginia and central California. Some settled at the invitation of church or community groups, while some looked for small farm plots. Many followed a guerrilla leader, Vang Pao, to California.
In the first years after their arrival, the Hmong's culture brought them into conflict with American law because some engaged in the medicinal use of opium, the kidnapping of brides or the ritual slaughter of animals. A few have leaped the cultural divide, but most remain poor.
Most of the Hmong in Banning are from the Yang clan. By one account, they were drawn here when a contractor offered a few of them jobs building mobile homes. Others say it was simply cheap housing that attracted them.
 
Most Hmong on Welfare
 Some have found work in small factories or restaurants, but, because of cultural barriers and a lack of marketable skills, most Hmong, here and elsewhere, are on welfare. One of those on welfare is Mr. Xou's father, who has never held a civilian job. Mr. Nu Yeng, like many Hmong, is not sure how old he is. But he said that at about the age of 13, he had become a soldier and had fought on the American side until the fall of Laos to the communists in 1976. Before the fall, he rose to the rank of lieutenant and was in command of 100 men, he said.
Here in Banning, with his wife and his three school-aged children, he has little to do. He said he would like to return to Laos if the communist government changes.
For Mr. Nu Yeng, as for many other Hmong, the generation gap is one of the most disturbing signs of his alienation from his adopted country.
Pao Yang, who is earning a master's degree in sociology, noted that the very concept of teen-aged years is alien to the Hmong, who traditionally began working as farmers, or as soldiers during the war, when they were 13 or 14 years old.
"The Hmong go from childhood to adulthood; here, you have teen-agers or adolescents," he said. "We never had to raise our own children in that way, so it's very hard for people who have children who grow up here."
When Mr. Xou was a child, his father said, he was obedient, running errands and translating for his parents and helping his younger brother and sister with their schoolwork.
But as Mr. Xou grew older, things changed. "He would say to me, why are you still telling me all these things?" his father said. "I don't have to listen to you."
Mr. Xou dropped out of Banning High School after ninth grade. He held odd jobs, traveled out of state, was employed, and then unemployed. His parents lost track of what he was doing, until the police knocked on their door last month, saying he was wanted in connection with a shooting.

HEADLINE: Jose Fernandez, 70, Philippine Banker

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MANILA, June 20

 BODY:
Jose B. Fernandez, who headed the Philippine Central Bank under Presidents Ferdinand E. Marcos and Corazon C. Aquino, died Sunday. He was 70.
Mr. Fernandez was reported to have died of cancer. 
 He was named governor of the Central Bank in 1983 at the height of a financial crisis after the assassination of Mrs. Aquino's husband, Senator Benigno Aquino.
His predecessor had been accused by the International Monetary Fund of padding the nation's reserves. Mr. Fernandez was credited with restoring international trust in the Philippine banking system.
He was retained in the post after the popular uprising in 1986 that forced Mr. Marcos from office and led to Mrs. Aquino's becoming the President.
After Mr. Marcos went into exile in Hawaii, Mr. Fernandez investigated reports that the former President and his wife had taken millions of dollars with them in Philippine currency and gold bullion. Mr. Fernandez began the Government's lengthy legal proceedings against them.
Mr. Fernandez was born in Laguna Province and was educated at Ateneo de Manila University. He also earned degrees from Fordham University and Harvard Business School.
He is survived by his wife, four sons and a daughter.

HEADLINE: Poll Shows Support for Giuliani on Not Cutting Police Budget

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani negotiates a budget with the City Council, a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll shows that a solid majority of New Yorkers supports his stance that the Police Department should be spared from the spending cuts that he is demanding of other agencies.
Reflecting their belief that crime is by far the most pressing problem that the Mayor should concentrate on, two out of three of those polled said Mr. Giuliani should continue to insulate the Police Department from personnel cuts and other economies that critics in the Council and elsewhere have said would help close the city budget gap without gutting other agencies. Women were most adamant in their support for police spending. 
 More broadly, the poll found that after Mr. Giuliani's first six months in office, New Yorkers approve of his performance by a 5-to-3 edge -- a job rating that falls somewhat short of his predecessor, David N. Dinkins, but about the same as Edward I. Koch in their first few months in office.
The poll, which was taken June 12 to 15 amid last week's euphoria of a hometown hockey championship but well before the city begins feeling the impact of Mr. Giuliani's budget cuts, found that 49 percent of the 1,189 people questioned said they approved of Mr. Giuliani's job performance while 31 percent disapproved. The margin of sampling error for all respondents was plus or minus 3 percentage points.
 
Comparison With Dinkins
 Mr. Giuliani's immediate predecessor, Mr. Dinkins, had a more impressive job rating after six months -- 56 percent approved and 23 percent did not. But Mr. Dinkins lost ground as his four-year term progressed.
Mr. Giuliani has fared about the same as Mr. Koch, whose performance was viewed favorably by a split of 45 percent to 31 percent at a comparable point in his first term but who was re-elected overwhelmingly twice.
In addition to approving of Mr. Giuliani's protection of the Police Department from budget cuts, most people did not seem very worried that cuts in other agencies would have a harmful effect on city services.
Four in 10 people said reducing the number of city workers eventually would decrease the quality of city services -- a response that reflected deep racial and ethnic cleavages. About 3 in 10 whites, more than 4 in 10 blacks and more than half the Hispanic people polled said services would decline. "Generally speaking, the poll shows support for those policies Rudy has pushed," said David Garth, who was Mr. Giuliani's chief campaign strategist. Comparing the relatively close margin by which Mr. Giuliani defeated Mr. Dinkins with the poll's differential on Mr. Giuliani's job rating, Mr. Garth said, "It should happen to everyone who wins an election to pick up about 18 points during a difficult period when he's trying to get a budget balanced."
Cristyne F. Lategano, the press secretary for Mr. Giuliani, said that the poll indicated "a tremendous support for the Mayor's commitment to public safety, even in the black community."
Blacks were the only racial group in which a majority of those polled said they disapproved of the way the Republican Mayor was handling crime. But a solid majority of all New Yorkers -- and a plurality of blacks -- said Mr. Giuliani's focus on crime was not diverting attention from other problems facing the city.
Not surprisingly, the poll found that black, Hispanic and white New Yorkers diverged sharply in their perspective on public officials and policy issues, as they did in last year's mayoral election when Mr. Giuliani, who is white, was challenging the city's first black Mayor. Those disparities were reflected in responses to questions ranging from the impact of personnel cuts on city services to whether Mayor Giuliani was devoting too much attention to the needs of some other racial or ethnic group.
Still, despite fears that Mr. Giuliani's defeat of Mr. Dinkins might worsen race relations, about 2 in 3 of all those polled said race relations have stayed about the same under Mr. Giuliani. More Hispanic people and whites said relations had improved than deteriorated. But while most blacks agreed that relations were pretty much unchanged, 3 in 10 said they had worsened.
Over all, about the same proportion of New Yorkers -- a little more than 1 in 10 -- said relations had got worse as did the proportion who said things had got better.
Those perceptions varied sharply with predictions before last year's election when, in a Times/WCBS-TV News Poll of registered voters, 1 in 4 predicted that race relations would worsen. The latest poll represented a cross section of all New Yorkers, not just voters.
At the corresponding point in the Dinkins administration, more than half the blacks and whites polled said race relations were worse than they had been a year earlier -- before the mayoral campaign began in earnest and before the racially motivated slaying in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, of a black man, Yusuf K. Hawkins.
Mr. Guiliani also seemed to improve his standing among blacks. Fully 25 percent of the blacks polled said they approved of his performance -- about 20 percentage points more than the proportion who voted for him last November. After six months as Mayor, Mr. Dinkins's job rating among whites was also about 20 points higher than it was in the voting the year before.
In detailed interviews after the poll was completed, several people who participated in it voiced strong approval of the specific efforts Mayor Giuliani has undertaken. Frances Kelly, who lives in Kingsbridge in the Bronx, applauded several of the Mayor's initiatives, including his budget cuts, his proposal to fingerprint welfare recipients and the campaign against aggressive squeegee-men.
"The most important thing that he can do is make sure that every person on welfare is fingerprinted," she said. "If you can fingerprint the President and the Governor, right on down to police and firemen, why can't the homeless be fingerprinted? Why can't they be treated like everybody else?"
Edward N. Brown, who was home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan from college out of town, said he was impressed that Mr. Giuliani was not beholden to entrenched politicians.
"At first, his ideas may seem idealistic, but I think that in an earnest sort of way he is trying to stick to those ideals," Mr. Brown said. "You hear a lot of talk about the cuts in the budget, but Giuliani says that he's going to cut costs without cutting services.
"I take a wait and see attitude toward it," Mr. Brown said. "I'm not saying he's perfect, but he's on the right track."
Others were not so sure.
Rosa Mercado, a mother from the South Bronx who is H.I.V.-positive, expressed concern that the administration's policies were hurting the prospects for herself and for her 3-year-old daughter. Also, she said that while she sees more police officers, "they just don't do anything" to reduce drug dealing in her neighborhood.
"I see things Dinkins has done," she said. "I just don't see anything that Giuliani has done except cut the budgets."
Most people did not seem surprised by the new Mayor and his policies. More than 6 in 10 said that for better or for worse Mr. Giuliani was fulfilling their expectations about his performance.
The poll found that Hispanic New Yorkers were the most disappointed; nearly 1 in 4 said the Mayor was doing worse than they had anticipated. So did about 2 in 10 blacks and 1 in 10 whites. Conversely, nearly 3 in 10 whites and about 1 in 10 blacks and Hispanic people said Mr. Giuliani's performance so far had surpassed their expectations.
Given the city's disproportionate share of Democrats, the results may not bode well for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is seeking a fourth term this year.
The Democratic Governor managed a comparable approval rating (51 percent) to Mr. Giuliani but also a larger proportion of people who disapproved of Mr. Cuomo's performance (37 percent). Four years ago a Times/WCBS-TV News Poll found that 59 percent in the city approved of Mr. Cuomo's job performance and 24 percent did not.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Rebound From Day's Lows

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, rebounding from their lows of the day to trim earlier losses attributed to the weak dollar. A steep drop in commodity prices that eased investor fears about inflation brought the market back.
With no economic news yesterday, the market was also looking at a large supply of new Treasury issues this week, which added some anxiety. The supply is coming as traders adjust positions before the quarter ends. 
 Traders cited the dollar's weakness as setting the bearish tone, encouraging talk among bondholders of a possible raising of short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve coming sooner rather than later.
 
Long Bond Yield 7.46%
 The 30-year bond fell 6/32 , to 8522/32 , for a yield of 7.46 percent, up from 7.44 percent on Friday. Market traders said the yield was up as high as 7.50 percent before a falling commodity-price index gave the market some relief.
Prices also slipped in the note market, while the rates at yesterday's weekly bill auction came in mixed. The average rate for a three-month bill was 4.18 percent, down a couple of basis points from last week, and the six-month was unchanged at 4.55 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Joseph V. Battipaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisors, thought that the most revealing element of yesterday's trading was how the dollar declined on no discernible financial news. "The market is now questioning, will the Fed tighten in a dollar slump?" said Mr. Battipaglia, who added he did not think so. "It's not at that critical point yet where the Fed would have to act. But it is creating a great deal of uncertainty."
Mr. Battipaglia said he believed there were no compelling reasons why the Fed would raise rates now. "The economy has slowed because of previous interest rate hikes and the inflation numbers have not jumped out of the trend they've been in." he said.
 
Commodity Index Retreats
 The Commodity Research Bureau index retreated yesterday from levels not seen since mid-1990, levels that were regenerating inflation fears. As such, the pullback was a relief for the bond market, since many market participants use the index as a measure of future price pressure. The C.R.B. index, a basket of commodity futures contracts, fell 4.51 points, to 234.87. Rain in the Midwest and speculation that the heat wave is ending resulted in sharply lower call for the grains, with precious metals getting caught up in the decline, traders said.
"For the last three years at this time the market has had inflation fears that are food-commodity related," Mr. Battipaglia said. "Either a drought or talk of one would raise fears and cause commodity prices to surge. And each and every time that fear was ill founded."
As an example, he cited last year's flooding in the Midwest, which saw commodity prices surge but then fall back.
Today, the Treasury will auction $17 billion of new two-year notes and in late when-issued trading yesterday the issue was being offered at a price to yield 5.95 percent, up from Friday's 5.91 percent. The five-year note to be auctioned on Wednesday was offered at a price to yield 6.76 percent.
 
Some See Rate Rise
 Yesterday's rise in rates did find many analysts seeing the potential for a rate increase at the July meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee, which sets the central bank's monetary policy for months ahead, had increased.
"While the dollar is not the primary policy determinant," said James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International, "it is a factor that contributes to an already compelling list of reasons why the Fed will continue to raise rates. Even before the latest round of dollar declines, we viewed economic growth as sufficient to warrant a continuation of the tightening course."
The market, he added, is just barely acknowledging the risk of a July rate increase.
As Treasuries bounced from their lows, some bond investors took the opportunity to sell and limited any chance of gains on the day, traders said.
Tomorrow the Federal Reserve is scheduled to release its beige book economic survey for May and part of June. Analysts say the report should offer a clearer picture of the United States inflation scene and set the stage for a two-day meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee meeting on July 5 and 6.
The following are the results of yesterday's auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 34.88 After the Dollar Tumbles

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market fell sharply yesterday for the second consecutive session, after a steep drop in the dollar and a selloff in European stocks.
The dollar tumbled to an eight-month low against the German mark. A weak dollar typically depresses the price of stocks in this country because of expected cost and price increases. 
 In Europe, stocks were down sharply after traders saw inflation worsening and interest rates rising in the United States. Leading stock indexes plummeted more than 1.5 percent in Britain and France and about 4 percent in Germany and Italy.
"The downside performance over the last two days has muted thoughts about a summer rally," said Alan Ackerman, executive vice president of Reich & Company. "But with short positions due out after the market closes on Tuesday, we may have a knee-jerk reaction on the upside."
 
 
Fear of Higher Rates
 The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 34.88 points, to 3,741.90, its largest decline in five weeks. The Dow fell sharply at the opening bell amid concern that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates for the fifth time this year, perhaps at the next meeting of its policy-making group early next month.
Other key indicators also pointed downward. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 2.97 points, to 455.48, while the Nasdaq composite index declined 10.50 points, to 718.85, in keeping with the bigger declines taken by stocks of smaller companies.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange fell to a very light 229.5 million shares, from 387 million shares on Friday, when turnover was increased by triple-witching trading, which stems from the simultaneous expiration of three sets of options and futures contracts. Declining stocks outnumbered advancers on the Big Board, 1,748 to 495.
Stocks sensitive to changes in interest rates were among the day's biggest declines. Among banking companies, J. P. Morgan was down 3/8, to 63 7/8; Wells Fargo fell 7/8, to 154; Citicorp dropped 7/8, to 39 3/4, and Banc One slipped 1/2, to 36.
Cyclical shares that are sensitive to current economic activity also came under pressure, suggesting that the United States economy may face a slowdown. Caterpillar fell 2 3/8, to 106 3/8; Bethlehem Steel dropped 1 1/4, to 20 1/8, and Chrysler declined 7/8, to 47 7/8. .
Oil stocks were weak during the day as investors were rattled by higher crude oil prices that could affect profits from refining and marketing. Among them were Mobil, off 1/4, to 84 1/4; Royal Dutch/Shell Group, off 7/8, to 106 7/8; Exxon, off 1/8, to 58 5/8, and British Petroleum, off 7/8, to 74.
Semiconductor issues gave ground, following Micron Technology's announcement on Friday that third-quarter earnings would be lower than some analysts had estimated. Micron declined 7/8, to 32 3/4; Texas Instruments dropped 1 5/8, to 76 1/2, and Intel fell 1 1/8, to 58 7/8.
Some stocks, however, bucked the negative trend on Wall Street. Quaker Oats was up 3 3/8, to 81 7/8, on speculation that the company might be a takeover target. Kellogg, apparently moving in sympathy with Quaker Oats, advanced 1 3/8, to 56 3/8.
Philip Morris, the second-most-active stock on the New York exchange, gained 3/8, to 50 3/4, after two senior managers replaced Michael A. Miles, the chairman and chief executive.
