HEADLINE: Japan Gives U.S. Cars a 2d Look

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 20

 BODY:
After years of being derided as overpriced, defect-prone gas guzzlers, something unexpected is happening to American cars in Japan. They are starting to win some consumer acceptance.
Sales of passenger cars made in the United States by Ford, General Motors and Chrysler more than doubled here in the first five months of this year, compared with the period a year earlier, even as overall car sales declined amid an economic slump. The gains follow a 37 percent increase in Big Three imports to Japan in 1993 from 1992. 
 To be sure, sales of Detroit's cars here are still puny, and it will be many years before they grow enough to dent the roughly $20 billion annual trade deficit in vehicles that the United States runs with Japan.
 
 
Market Share: Less Than 1%
 The Big Three expect to sell about 35,000 American-made cars here this year, compared with 19,335 last year, giving them a market share of a little less than 1 percent. By contrast, Japanese companies export nearly 1.5 million passenger cars to the United States. Counting their North American production, they control 29 percent of the car market in the United States and 23 percent of combined sales of cars and light trucks.
Still, American auto executives are encouraged by the rapid growth in the Japanese market and by what they see as a gradual change in consumer attitudes since January 1992, when then-President George Bush was ridiculed on a visit here for trying to foist clunky American cars on the Japanese. The rising acceptance seems prompted more by the delivery of better-made cars suitable for the Japanese than by encouragement from the Tokyo Government.
"The consumers' mental barrier started to melt late last year," said Konen Suzuki, president of Ford Japan.
Jack K. Yamaguchi, an automobile writer here, agreed. "This year and next will be the turning point for American cars," he said.
 
 
Ford Packs Them In
 On a recent Sunday, in a scene that might have been unimaginable a few years ago, the showroom of Ford Seijo, a dealership in western Tokyo, was bustling with customers eyeing the Mustang, the newly introduced Mondeo and the Taurus station wagon. An American flag flew on the street outside. Just down the street, a huge Nissan showroom was devoid of customers and its salesmen sat forlornly at their desks.
"I have never even started an American car before," said Hajime Sakai, a 27-year-old hotel employee who was considering a Mustang. "The styling of American cars has really become quite good."
Spurring the gain has been the rise of the Japanese yen, which has made imports' prices more competitive with those of Japanese products. Overall passenger car imports, including European autos and cars made by Japanese companies overseas, are up 30 percent this year. In May alone, imports held a record 8.6 percent of the Japanese car market.
But Detroit has also helped itself by introducing new models better suited for Japan, by advertising more aggressively and by courting Japanese automobile magazine writers.
Chrysler's sales have more than quadrupled this year, following the introduction last year of a Jeep Cherokee with the steering wheel on the right side. The Japanese, like the British, drive on the left.
Ford's new Mustang, introduced last month with a highly competitive base price of less than $23,000, has exceeded all expectations. Ford expected to sell 2,500 Mustangs in Japan this year; it will reach that total in the first two months.
Product quality has also improved. "Nowadays people don't worry about the quality" of American cars, said Toru Hoki, a dentist who had just purchased a Taurus at Ford Seijo. His view is not shared by all Japanese. Hiroyuki Moriyama, a businessman who also looked at a Taurus, said some owners had told him that American cars still broke down.
The recent gains in American car sales seem to buttress Tokyo's arguments in its trade negotiations with Washington. Japanese officials say the nation's automobile market is not closed. American companies have done poorly here, they say, because they have not introduced cars with right-hand steering that are small enough and inexpensive enough for Japan's market. When they do introduce a suitable model, sales take off.
 
 
'Real Commitments'
 But United States Government and industry officials say they will not relax their demands, because sales of American cars here are still far below what they would be if the market were truly open. "The Big Three are making real commitments to this market, but we have still not seen any dramatic commitment on the part of the Japanese Government," Andrew H. Card Jr., president of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, said in Tokyo today.
Washington has asked that goals be set for increasing the number of Japanese dealers carrying foreign cars. American officials say the dealers who sell Toyotas, Nissans or other Japanese cars do not readily take on foreign models because of financial ties to Japanese manufacturers or because they fear disturbing relationships with their main suppliers.
Government and industry officials insist that dealers are free to carry other brands. "It never occurred to me to sell another car besides Nissan," said Hiroshi Iwai, a dealer from a suburb of Tokyo.
The number of Japanese dealers that offer foreign cars has risen to 530 this year from 85 in 1988, according to the Japan Automobile Importers' Association. There are about 2,000 car dealers in Japan, most of whom have more than one outlet.
In the 1980's, sales grew of foreign cars, mainly from Germany. BMW and Mercedes-Benz models were seen as offering high quality and snob appeal. But as Japan's economy soured, German imports, which peaked at 137,000 in 1990, began dropping. While German cars still vastly outsell vehicles from the United States, the Americans are gaining.
Some American cars sell because of their novelty or, like the Mustang, their fame. Even now, American companies are not in the mainstream of the market. About 80 percent of the cars sold in Japan have engine sizes of less than 2 liters and prices of less than 3 million yen, or about $30,000, according to the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association. But no American-made cars are sold in that category here, and right-hand-drive models are still scarce.
The American companies differ in their tactics. Ford has been the most aggressive, introducing its new Mustang and Mondeo at prices that match or undercut those of comparable Japanese models. Imports had previously been much more expensive than Japanese-built cars.
Ford also controls its own dealer network, through which it sells not only imports but also cars made for it by the Mazda Motor Corporation, of which Ford owns nearly 25 percent.
Ford, which began running television commercials this year, expects sales of its imports to triple this year to 15,000. It wants to sell 200,000 cars here in the year 2000, of which about half would be imported. To do that, it plans to expand its dealer network to 700 outlets, from 288 now.
So far this year it has recruited four Nissan outlets, and Mr. Suzuki, the president of Ford Japan, hopes to attract a total of 20 or 30 this year. Japanese dealers are becoming more receptive, he said, not only because of American pressure but also because many dealers are losing money and are desperate for new products.
This month, Ford began selling its first two imported cars with right-hand steering wheels: the Mondeo, made in Europe, and the Probe, made at a joint Mazda-Ford plant in Michigan.
Chrysler's spurt in sales has come exclusively from the Jeep Cherokee. Chrysler introduced a right-hand-drive version early last year and cut the base price 30 percent, to about $37,000. It subsequently introduced an even less expensive model.
Honda, which sells the Jeep through its dealers, minutely inspects each vehicle to make sure it will satisfy Japanese consumers. Customers here are known to reject a car because of a tiny scratch in the paint. But Hiroshi Saito, a Honda dealer, said Chrysler also risked alienating customers because of a shortage of the least expensive Jeep.
 
 
Chrysler May Be Vulnerable
 Without its own dealer network, some analysts say, Chrysler remains vulnerable should Honda develop its own competing product or should the Jeep's popularity wane.
Chrysler expects to sell 13,000 vehicles here this year, more than double last year's total. It recently tripled the size of its office in Tokyo and is recruiting new dealers. In the next few years, it also plans to import right-hand-drive versions of its low-priced Neon and of a new mini-van.
General Motors has largely missed out on the recent gains. After long being the largest seller of American cars in Japan, G.M. will be surpassed this year by both Ford and Chrysler. Its German subsidiary, Opel, sells cars here separately.
Still, G.M., which expects to sell 9,000 cars in Japan this year, has seen its sales rise 11 percent so far. And its truck sales, while still small, have more than doubled.
But analysts say that General Motors and its single Japanese dealer have not priced G.M. cars aggressively, compared with Japanese cars or even with other imports. The company's Camaro sporty car, for instance, sells for almost $10,000 more than the new Ford Mustang.

HEADLINE: Dollar's Slump May Push Fed To Raise Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20

 BODY:
The continued fall of the dollar in international currency markets today put new pressure on the Federal Reserve to consider a fifth interest rate increase this year, as stock markets dropped sharply around the world.
Even though Federal Reserve officials were unwilling to say so publicly today, they have privately signaled this spring their willingness to stop any steep slumps in the dollar's value by raising short-term interest rates again -- even if that further slows the pace of American economic growth. 
 Their recent comments that inflation was under control always carried the caveat that all bets were off if a new threat appeared, notably a drop in the value of the dollar or a big jump in commodity prices.
The choice between the domestic economy's short-term health and helping the dollar with higher interest rates is a staple of economic textbooks. For the Federal Reserve, such a choice is particularly painful now. After its fourth increase in short-term interest rates in as many months, the Federal Reserve said in May that it had "substantially" completed its current round of interest rate increases.
"It's a bad dream," said John H. Makin, a resident economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington research organization. "No central banker wants to be in the position of thinking they've raised interest rates enough and then global capital markets don't think so."
Responding to the weak dollar, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped almost 35 points, the London and Paris stock markets fell and the German market in Frankfurt suffered its worst one-day loss since 1991. [Page D2.]
The dollar fell to 1.5995 German marks and an anemic 101.95 Japanese yen today on fears of growing imports and shrinking American exports, higher oil prices and what traders said was a lack of confidence in the Clinton Administration's foreign policy. All three factors unnerve investors who fear slower economic growth, faster inflation and political uncertainty.
While the dollar has been weaker against the mark, including a postwar low of 1.386 marks to the dollar during a European currency crisis in September 1992, the level is low enough now that German brewers and Japanese car makers will be under pressure to raise prices in the United States to collect their anticipated revenues and profits. Today's closing level was the lowest for the dollar against the mark since October and the lowest against the yen since early May.
 
A Difficult Position
 The dollar's fall puts top Federal Reserve officials in a quandary. Raising interest rates would tend to halt the dollar's fall by making American bonds more attractive to international investors who must buy dollars to acquire Treasury bonds. But higher rates would hurt American economic growth.
Leaving interest rates untouched might help the economy now but would risk further drops in the dollar, perhaps feeding inflation as prices for imported goods would tend to rise.
Oil prices have also risen rapidly in the last week, climbing another 4 cents a barrel today, to $20.75. But prices for other commodities, notably corn and soybeans, dropped today.
Top Federal Reserve officials had believed that by raising short-term interest rates four times this spring -- the last time as recently as May 17 -- they had successfully prevented a burst of runaway economic growth. Such a rapid expansion could have fed inflation by forcing companies to pay more for scarce materials and highly trained workers. But just as the economy had seemed to be settling into a steady rhythm of growth, the dollar began falling again.
If interest rates on long-term bonds rise to 8 percent or higher, as some economists now predict, then fewer Americans will be able to afford car loans and home mortgages, fewer cars and houses will probably be built and the economy will slow. Higher interest rates would also tend to push down stock prices, as corporations are forced to pay more to borrow money and as demand for their products slows.
Complicating the Federal Reserve's difficulty is the scheduled release on Tuesday of the nation's trade balance in April, which is expected to show deterioration from March and may put further downward pressure on the dollar. And on Wednesday, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, whose words can roil even relatively quiet markets, is scheduled to testify before a House panel.
Still, the biggest problem now for the Federal Reserve is that the economy is already showing some signs of weakening.
"I think that in the nation as a whole, we've seen some slight slowing of activity," Robert P. Forrestal, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, said in an interview on June 6. Three of the five sitting governors of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington expressed similar sentiments two weeks ago.
 
A View From the South
 Some of the Federal Reserve's regional governors are more guarded.
For instance, J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, which keeps track of economic conditions in Maryland, Virginia, the Carolinas and part of West Virginia, said last week in referrence to housing and car sales, "On balance, the information we have on our district suggests the possibility -- not the certainty but the possibility -- of some deceleration in some segments of the economy."
Lawrence Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said today that the American economy was still in good shape. "Economic fundamentals are very strong, this is the first investment-led recovery from a low inflation base that the United States has had since the Kennedy Administration," he said.
Although currency traders seldom mention it, one possible reason for the fall in the dollar lies not in the United States but in Europe. Interest rates have been rising there as central banks, led by the Bundesbank in Germany, have proved less willing to reduce interest rates than many investors had expected. This has made the German mark more attractive to investors seeking higher interest rates and the dollar, by default, less attractive.
Even if the dollar continues to fall, economists at the Federal Reserve and elsewhere disagree about the precise effects on inflation. Only a third to two-fifths of the American economy consists of goods subject to international competition.
Many industries, from residential construction to medical care and other services, are virtually immune to international competition. Their prices presumably would be little affected by how much it costs to build a house in Hamburg or to have a sprained ankle treated in Osaka.
New figures from the Commerce Department last week showed that prices in service industries are rising at the slowest pace in a decade, a phenomenon that might offset part or all of any rise in prices for tradable goods.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Tumbles as Investors Seek Higher Yields Abroad

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar continued to slide against the German mark and other currencies yesterday as slumping global stock and bond prices encouraged many investors to shift their money into cash deposits in countries like Germany that have high interest rates.
"As people move out of bonds and into cash, they're going for the highest yields," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics. "Dollar yields are the lowest of any market in the world except Japan." 
 The dollar traded as low as 1.5965 German marks yesterday, its weakest level since last October. In late New York trading, it was at 1.5995 marks, down more than one pfennig from 1.6105 marks on Friday.
The dollar also fell to 101.95 Japanese yen, from 102.70 on Friday.
The dollar weakened against the mark as a selloff in the German bond market pushed up German interest rates. Most German interest rates were already higher than those for United States Government securities with comparable maturities, making mark-denominated securities more attractive. The yield on three-month German Government securities is 4.953 percent, for instance, compared with 4.18 percent for three-month Treasury bills.
But the dollar steadied just above the day's lows amid speculation that the Federal Reserve and other central banks were poised to support the dollar again as they did on May 4.
"The markets are jittery," Lynn Tierney, a trader at Shawmut Bank in Boston, said. "Everyone is wary of central bank intervention at these levels."
Yesterday's drop in the dollar continues a decline that has been under way for much of the year. The dollar has dropped 8 percent against the mark and 9 percent against the yen so far this year, hurt by slumping American stock and bond prices and concerns about the Clinton Administration's trade policies.
The Swiss franc also gained yesterday, rising to a 20-month high of 1.3428 francs to the dollar, from 1.3557 francs on Friday.
"Sentiment toward the dollar is very poor," said Paul Farrell, manager of strategic currency trading at Chase Manhattan Bank. "There's an air of nervousness in the market."
The dollar tumbled 1.5 percent against the mark on Friday. Some of the selling was attributed to a statement by Gail Fosler, the chief economist at the Conference Board, who said that the dollar would probably fall to 1.50 marks by the end of 1995. But a number of traders said Ms. Fosler's statement was more of an excuse to sell dollars in a market that has become increasingly bearish about the dollar.
Indeed, the fact that the dollar fell so far on comments from a non-Government economist showed that the currency was weaker than they had thought, analysts said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Former Philip Morris Chief Leaves Name-Brand Legacy

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
Whatever happens to Michael A. Miles after his unexpected resignation as the chairman and chief executive of the Philip Morris Companies, one huge gamble he made will continue to fundamentally reshape American consumer-product marketing.
Mr. Miles may be no Julius Caesar, but there was widespread agreement yesterday that his most surprising decision will live on after him rather than be interred with his Philip Morris career. That was, of course, his move on Friday, April 2, 1993, to sharply cut the price of the company's flagship cigarette brand, Marlboro, to stem the loss of sales to cheaper competitors. 
 Mr. Miles later tried to split off the cigarette business, a failed move that helped lead to his departure over the weekend and upset some big shareholders. [Page D4.]
But the impact of his cigarette price cuts, felt initially by the tobacco industry, has widened to include virtually every name brand under siege from lower-priced rivals.
"It was a seminal moment," said Watts Wacker, a managing partner of Yankelovich Partners Inc., a consumer marketing research company in Norwalk, Conn.
"The 1980's ended on that day," he added, referring to that decade's prizing of image and status over price and value. "Now people tell us that rather than buy brands because 'they tell people I've made it,' they say they buy brands because 'they minimize exposure to risk.' "
The effect has been startling. Now, even when commodity prices rise rapidly, as is happening with coffee, marketers are raising selling prices slowly, if at all, for fear that consumers will abandon brand names for less expensive private-label products.
Mr. Miles's own risky move suddenly reversed a skein of hefty price increases, running 8 to 10 percent a year, that threatened the hegemony of Marlboro, the world's best-selling cigarette. Since the late 1980's, as smokers switched in droves to discount and private-label products, which often cost half as much as Marlboro, the brand remained No. 1, but its market share fell from 25 percent to low as 22 percent in the United States. Each percentage point of market share in the $48 billion American cigarette industry is worth $480 million.
Mr. Miles's abrupt strategic shift, announced without warning, was deemed so significant that it has entered the marketing and advertising lexicon under the nickname Marlboro Friday.
"It certainly was a day of reckoning in the consumer packaged-goods industry," John McMillin, food industry analyst for Prudential Securities in New York, said, "Not because he was the first but because it was so dramatic a move."
Before Marlboro Friday, he added, the rule of thumb seemed to be "to raise your price every year by a figure equal to the rate of inflation, even if your costs didn't go up."
"But when the spread between private label and your brand gets to 50 percent," he continued, "it can bring down even the strongest of brands."
Frank Assumma, president and chief executive of Bates U.S.A., formerly Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., in New York, asserted that "Marlboro Friday said, 'Stop, everybody!'
"It was about getting the price/ value equation into perspective," he added. "Until then, there was no point where someone said, 'Whoa, we've got to slow down our price increases because consumers are telling us the value isn't there.' Now we know that people are willing to pay a premium for brand names -- but there's a limit."
"It was a very courageous decision, a watershed," Mr. Assumma said of Mr. Miles's drastic step.
Indeed, for those marketers who have scrambled to learn the lessons of Marlboro Friday in altering how to sell name-brand products to consumers, it was a D-Day that for several has proved to be a V-E Day. Others who refused to absorb the implications of Mr. Miles's about-face are finding Marlboro Friday the equivalent of a Pearl Harbor Day for their own brands.
The most significant discovery "is a correlation between brand loyalty and price sensitivity," said Larry Light, chairman of the Arcature Corporation, a marketing consulting company in Stamford, Conn., and of the Coalition for Brand Equity, a group formed by the marketing and advertising industries in the wake of Marlboro Friday.
"Many marketers fell into the trap of overcharging their most loyal consumers on the assumption they'd pay anything," he added. "But brand loyalty, it turns out, is not a license to overcharge the consumer.
"They ripped off their best customers, while at the same time, they rewarded disloyal customers."
Mr. Miles, according to Mr. Light, was among the first consumer marketers to realize the paradoxical truth that "you can increase sales, and even profits, in the short term by increasing prices and emphasizing promotions -- while hurting loyalty."
Emanuel Goldman, who follows the tobacco industry for Paine Webber Inc. in San Francisco, said that before Mr. Miles, the constant price rises by Philip Morris (and other cigarette marketers following the leader) touched off "a mix downgrade" among smokers -- that is, they abandoned premium, higher-priced, higher-profit brands like Marlboro, Winston and Newport for cheaper, lower-profit smokes like Basic, Doral and GPC Approved.
As a result, at Philip Morris the percentage of premium brands sold fell from "the mid- to high-80's five or six years ago," he added, to 71 percent last year.
"In the first quarter of 1994, that percentage has risen to 79 percent," Mr. Goldman said, after Mr. Miles cut Marlboro prices about 40 cents a pack.
And Philip Morris said yesterday that Marlboro's market share, as of May 31, has rebounded from 22 percent to more than 28 percent -- a record level.
There has, of course, been a price paid for this. At Philip Morris, Mr. Goldman and Mr. McMillin estimated, lost profits totaled more than $2 billion since Marlboro Friday.
And there was speculation that Mr. Miles might have paid the price of his job, Mr. McMillin said. Marlboro Friday represented a direct contradiction of his predecessors' belief that "he should have milked the cow as long as the cow could give milk" -- in other words, keep raising prices until the name brands went dry.
"Mike Miles, above anything, is a marketing man," he added. "He might be second-guessed for the move, but I've sensed he had no queasiness about it.
"He felt he did what he had to do."

HEADLINE: 2,000 Go on Strike at General Dynamics

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WARREN, Mich., June 20

 BODY:
About 2,000 workers went on strike at General Dynamics plants in Michigan, Ohio and Pennsylvania this morning, but the company, a military contractor, said it could not remain competitive if it gave in to the union's demands.
A United Auto Workers spokesman, Bob Barbee, said the strikers included white-collar, production and maintenance workers at factories making tanks and other land-based equipment in Warren and Sterling Heights, Mich.; Lima, Ohio, and Scranton, Pa. 
 Talks on a new three-year contract began in April. The old pact expired on Saturday, Mr. Barbee said. No new negotiations were scheduled.
The sticking points include the cost of employees' health insurance and vacations and the question of how long salaried workers at a plant would continue to get paid if the company shut it down, Mr. Barbee said.
A spokesman for General Dynamics, Pete Keating, would not discuss the cause of the breakdown in negotiations, except to say: "The major issue that needs to be resolved is economic.

HEADLINE: Co-op Board Files Suit Against Management Company

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR 

 BODY:
In the latest fallout from a wide-ranging real-estate corruption scandal, the board of an East Side cooperative has filed a civil lawsuit in Federal District Court in Manhattan claiming that "hundreds" of residents were cheated out of "tens of millions of dollars" by one of the city's most prominent management companies.
The class action suit, filed on Thursday against Brown Harris Stevens, came one day after more than 80 New York real-estate managers and management companies were charged or pleaded guilty in connection with bribery in the maintenance of some of New York City's most prestigious cooperative and condominium apartment buildings. 
 The suit, filed by the Park Avenue and 84th Street Corporation on behalf of other co-ops managed by Brown Harris, contends that the company's employees, by demanding kickbacks from contractors doing work at the buildings, caused residents to be overcharged by as much as 10 percent. Law-enforcement officials said yesterday that the civil action is the first of what they expect to be many related suits by building owners and residents.
 
Manager Indicted
 The Park Avenue and 84th Street Corporation, made up of the owners of about 30 apartments at 103 East 84th Street, was managed by Brown Harris from at least the 1970's until 1993, said Fred Taylor Isquith, a lawyer for the plaintiffs. Its managing agent, Noel Intner, who worked first for Brown Harris, then Century Operating, was named in the indictment last week.
Daniel J. Castleman, chief of the investigations division for District Attorney Robert Morgenthau, declined to say yesterday whether the 84th Street building was involved in the investigation.
But Mr. Isquith insisted the 84th Street building, one of about 80 apartment buildings managed by Brown Harris, had been systematically overcharged by about 10 percent for maintenance and services, including elevator repairs, a new boiler, brickwork, a new roof and plumbing.
The bills for those services, which totaled between $200,000 and $300,000 over the last five years or so, were paid for out of the apartment owners' monthly maintenance fees, which range from $1,600 to $2,600, he said.
 
'Shocking Situation'
 "This is a really shocking situation," Mr. Isquith said. "The thought that people have to pay bribes or kickbacks or the like to get a telephone installed or plumbing fixed or roof repaired is part of the reason, I think, that New York's economy isn't as strong as it should be."
Last week, Brown Harris, which saw 17 of its past and present managing agents charged in the scandal, acknowledged that it had failed to supervise its employees properly and agreed to pay $1 million in restitution into a fund for aggrieved residents. The company also agreed to engage an inspector general to monitor its practices. Calls to the company were not returned yesterday.
Investigators disclosed in March that they had found managers routinely extorting millions of dollars annually from painters, plumbers and other contractors for the right to work in the managers' buildings.
But the indictments last week indicated for the first time that the corruption extended to the top levels of some management companies, where, prosecutors said, some executives shared the graft.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Rain Sends Grains Down And Price Index Plummets

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Scattered thunderstorms across the parched Midwest sent grain prices reeling yesterday, causing selling that caused a key commodity price index to fall sharply.
Limit-down price moves in the Chicago corn and soybean markets were largely responsible for the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities to tumble 4.51 points, to 234.87. On Friday, the index had reached a three-and-a-half-year high of 239.38 points. 
 Among other commodities that declined were cotton, lumber, coffee, cocoa, sugar, gasoline and metals.
"Certainly more rain fell than was expected," said Mark Cermak of Prudential Securities, explaining the steep fall in grain prices. "The distortion in the maps on Friday that got everyone very friendly for this week didn't pan out this morning," he added.
 
Grains Are Volatile
 The grain market has been volatile of late, as successive high-pressure systems settled over the Midwest and left some growing areas thirsty for rain. But scattered thunderstorms through the region, especially indrought-stricken northeastern Illinois, including Chicago, broke the bullish psychology.
July soybeans plummeted 30 cents, to $6.81 a bushel. July corn sank its 12-cent limit to $2.71 1/4. July oats lost 3.25 cents, to $1.34, and July wheat declined 13.25 cents, to $3.22 a bushel.
After the close of trading, a state-by-state crop report summary showed that 77 percent of the corn crop was in good or better condition, belying worries that a lack of rain this spring had hurt most crops. The soybean crop was described as in good to excellent condition in 68 percent of fields.
The steep fall in grain prices in turn caused a drop in the Commodity Research Bureau's index, and speculators chose to get out of positions in a variety of commodities.
Prices for inflation-sensitive metals also sagged, with August gold down $2.80, to $390.90 an ounce, and July silver off 11.8 cents, to $5.475 an ounce. High-flying July copper fell 1.4 cents, to 112.15 cents a pound.
Included among the declining commodities was cotton, which dropped its 2-cent limit to close at 77.66 cents a pound in the July contract.
A soft cash market caused July lumber prices to fall $8, to $365.30 for 1,000 board feet.
Oil prices ended nearly unchanged in a volatile session at the New York Mercantile Exchange after prices staged wild swings.
The July crude oil contract, which expires today, ended 4 cents higher at $20.75 a barrel after trading in a range of $19.35 to $20.89.
July gasoline and heating oil both lost 0.55 cent a gallon, with gasoline down to 54.65 cents a gallon and heating oil to 51.47 cents.

HEADLINE: Europe's Case of Jitters Worsens

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 20

 BODY:
Europe's financial markets were racked by another spasm of anxiety today as stocks and bonds tumbled in value in all the major financial centers and the dollar, the linchpin of the international financial system, slid to ominously low levels.
Although Europe has seen steady signs in recent weeks that its long recession is ending, today's financial carnage left investors shaken and worried that the broad-based selloff would continue. The turmoil also added to uncertainty in the United States, where worries at the end of last week about inflation and predictions of a weakening dollar had set off a round-the-world wave of selling that failed to subside over the weekend. 
 The main stock exchange index in Frankfurt fell nearly 4 percent, its steepest one-day drop since 1991, and long-term interest rates were forced sharply upward as investors fled bonds. Stock markets in London, Paris and Milan also had big drops.
 
Volatility in Germany
 Frankfurt's DAX index lost 81.90 points today to close at 1,968.82, its low for the year. The index hit a record high of 2,271.11 just over a month ago.
In London, the largest of the European markets, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares closed down 51.8 points at 2,971.1. In Paris, the CAC-40 index closed at 1,903.4, down 32.91.
The dollar also weakened through much of the trading day in Europe, and breached the psychologically important level of 1.60 German marks, before stabilizing slightly below that level. A week ago the dollar stood at 1.6685 marks.
The day was bad enough for investors and traders. But it also highlighted a problem for those who make economic and monetary policy: the growing mismatch between the globalized financial markets, where money and investment decisions zip around the world at warp speed, and the needs of national economies, which still look to markets to reflect their individual situations.
 
Not the Usual Pattern
 By traditional measures, Germany, France and other big European nations should be enjoying relatively low long-term interest rates. Inflation is low and should remain in check for some time because factories have plenty of idle capacity, lots of workers are still looking for jobs and consumers are in no mood to spend.
But the markets have largely ignored those factors and have focused on the outlook for inflation and interest rates in the United States, where the economic recovery is two years ahead of that in Europe.
With rates rising in the United States, the result has been to spread the inflationary psychology of the American markets to the European markets. Concern that the Federal Reserve might defend the dollar by raising rates only served to increase concerns about the direction of American rates and put more upward pressure on European bond yields.
"The globalization of capital markets appears to be playing a major role in the current behavior of long-term interest rates," said Stephen R. Waite, senior European economist at Merrill Lynch in London. "Our work has shown that in the 1990's there's been a very close correlation between movements in interest rates in the United States, Japan and Europe, despite the differences in the respective economic cycles."
In Germany, long-term interest rates, which are determined by the prices investors are willing to pay for bonds, are rising sharply, even as short-term rates, which are set by the Bundesbank, continue to decline. The yield on the benchmark 10-year government bond rose today to 7.33 percent from 7.17 percent on Friday. It has been rising most of the year.
Higher long-term rates, among other things, make it more expensive for companies to raise debt and for home buyers to get a mortgage.
"It's going to slow down this recovery quite appreciably," said Stephen Lewis, the research director at the London Bond Broking Company.
"The businessman in Munich and the prospective home buyer in Paris expected at the beginning of the year that interest rates would fall further from a level where they were already very low," Mr. Lewis said. "Instead, what has happened is that yields have reared up in a most alarming way with as yet no indication that the top has been reached."
Other economists said the recovery in Europe was not yet in any real danger. "All the surveys we've seen since the start of the turmoil indicate that business intentions to invest haven't been dampened and that consumer confidence has not turned down," Ian McCaffrey, an economist at NatWest Markets in London, said.
But most analysts agreed that unless there was a clear shift in market psychology, the economic consequences for Germany and its European neighbors could be substantial. The situation could be complicated if the dollar weakens further. Europe's recovery has been led by exports, and to the extent that a weak dollar makes goods sold in other currencies relatively more expensive, it could put a crimp in Europe's recovery.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Orchestra League Peers Into Its Future

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 17

 BODY:
"Celebrate Excellence," was the declaration on the banners and program books at the four-day national conference of the American Symphony Orchestra League here. And 1,700 representatives of 299 orchestras gathered to mourn its absence, chart its costs, debate its relevance and catalogue its virtues. These annual meetings have, in recent years, become a chronicle of a field in crisis, and this one was no exception.
Two years ago, the league -- the national organization serving orchestras -- presented a report documenting the causes of failing orchestras, offering explanations for dwindling audiences and drawing attention to increasing racial pressures against all-white orchestras in largely black cities. The statistics were sobering (though there are some who still disagree with the report's analyses and apocalyptic tone). Last year, a sweeping series of proposals were made in a study called "Americanizing the American Orchestra." That report became the most controversial document in the history of the orchestra. 
 It recommended a radical policy of affirmative action and urged the courting of younger audiences with pop, jazz, decorative lighting and interior design. The managers of the country's most important orchestras raised a formal objection to the ways the report was prepared and released, calling it "seriously flawed." Instead of finding ways for the orchestra to lead a changing population into the orchestral tradition, the managers thought the report was urging the orchestra to abandon that tradition to satisfy audience tastes. For many outside readers, including this critic, the report betrayed the league's mandate to preserve and serve the American orchestra.
So this year, in panels on labor negotiations and fund raising, on programming and marketing, the report and the issues it raised were on nearly everybody's mind. In one panel, "The Pursuit of Excellence," much energy was expended in an effort to define just what excellence is; Ernest Fleischman, the managing director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, urged that the panelists send their conclusions directly to the league officers who were leading the national service organization. The league, he implied, did not even know what was meant by the word; it was being invoked, he said, in order to "correct the impressions" left by last year's report.
Opening the conference on Thursday morning, Catherine French, the president of the league, also gave that impression, suggesting that while the report had "deeply disturbed" many of its readers, it had led to much debate and a renewed "commitment to excellence." Jane Alexander, the chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts, picked up the theme in her keynote address, adding lots of qualifications. "Orchestras should never compromise their artistic ambition," she suggested forthrightly, but excellence, she noted, is a "slippery concept." Orchestras must "challenge the audience to excellence," but should also have other goals in mind, supporting the "broader cultural agenda of this Administration."
A similar tension between excellence and other agendas was present throughout the conference. "Excellence" was often invoked while much more attention was on audience size and audience composition. Even music critics got into the act in a rather somber panel (in which I participated) led by Scott Cantrell, the president of the Music Critics Association of North America, which was meeting at the same time as the league. Each speaker compared the lot of music critics with the crises facing orchestras. My colleagues brought up incident after incident in which newspaper editors questioned the need to devote serious attention to classical music, citing decreased interest among readers.
For orchestras, this cultural shift and overly ambitious plans for large audiences have had profound effects, beginning with the failures of smaller American orchestras in the late 1980's -- including those in Oakland, New Orleans and Denver -- and continuing with a variety of crises today. Ms. French noted that orchestras in Tulsa and Louisville had asked for significant economic concessions from their players; the Florida Orchestra in Tampa has even missed its payroll. Many orchestras were still groping for a way to reshape themselves into leaner organizations serving smaller audiences.
In cities where the population is largely composed of minorities, political issues compound the economic problems and loom far larger than definitions of excellence. One orchestra manager complained about the director of a major foundation who boasted that his goal was "remaking cultural organizations," including orchestras. The president of the Dallas Symphony, Eugene Bonelli, said that the city of Dallas was attempting to cut back on its agreed-upon support for a new concert hall in order to direct more money toward social programs for minority groups.
Even Henry Fogel, the executive director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, who has characterized himself as a "supporter" of the league's report, pointed out, with some regret, that "There is no orchestra, from Omaha to our own, that is not finding that funding from government, foundations and corporate sources is restricted because we are seen as serving an upper-class and mostly white audience."
The result is widespread preoccupation with the issue. Stacy A. Cullison, the development director of the Des Moines Symphony, noted in one session that many of the orchestra's outreach programs into the minority community had been failures. One of her colleagues pointed out that since Des Moines had just a 10 percent minority population, perhaps the orchestra would be better off putting its energy into other areas.
But some orchestras were finding unusual ways to be true to their tradition and involve local communities. The St. Louis Symphony, for example, has established a "partnership progam" with black churches and has absorbed a local conservatory to become involved in arts education.
Christopher Wilkins, the music director of the San Antonio Symphony, which nearly folded in the 1980's, has an impressive long-term plan for involving the city's Hispanic population, which makes up 60 percent of the total. He programs orchestral music written by Latin American composers, has staged works by Falla and Mendelssohn using Spanish actors, and has recently begun commissioning orchestral works from Hispanic composers. Two Hispanic composers are in residence as part of a program the orchestra runs with the Meet the Composer organizationand a local arts center. They are writing symphonic music influenced by conjunto and tejano, varieties of Tex-Mex folk and pop styles.
Mr. Wilkins said the program has led to "massive increases in support from the city and business communities." Over time, it may also lead to unusual musical hybrids, and perhaps to new audiences. Or, it may not.
Given what Ms. Alexander called the "lack of a shared value system," it is impossible to see clearly where political and populist pressures will lead. A lot depends on the spin given to that catchword "excellence." During one session on "New Approaches to Concert Presentation," which was a demonstration of attempts to attract younger, more involved audiences, Ty Johnson, a producing associate of the Indianapolis Symphony, spoke of the need to constantly demand that "standards be kept very high." He provided an example on videotape: the orchestra's Christmas show, in which the orchestra played in the background as two actors in white bear suits led a row of tap-dancing, high-kicking Santas.
To each his own excellence.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Of Princes, Paupers And Balance Afield

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
Among other reasons, the owners want to impose a salary cap on their players in the name of competitive balance. Eighteen years ago Bowie Kuhn, then the commissioner, loudly issued management's dire warning that free agency would doom competitive balance.
What exactly is competitive balance? Does it mean parity, where every team is a .500 team and everyone suffers a severe case of boredom? Does it mean that one team doesn't dominate year after year the way the Yankees did from 1936 through 1964, when they won 22 pennants in 29 seasons? Or does it mean a circumstance where any team has a chance to win in any given season, as in the past 14 seasons, in which 23 of the 26 pre-expansion teams won division titles. 
 When he unveiled the clubs' salary cap proposal last week, Richard Ravitch noted that last year eight clubs had smaller gross revenues than the Toronto Blue Jays' payroll.
"If the system continues as it is today," the clubs' chief labor executive said, "you're going to see more and more clubs fall into that category and you'll see competitive balance worsen."
But one of those eight clubs Ravitch discussed was the Minnesota Twins, and they're always the one that undermines the argument the owners are making this year. Despite the size of their market and the size of their payroll, the Twins always create their own competitive balance.
They're doing it again this season, and don't the Yankees know it. The Twins came to Yankee Stadium last night for their first game with the Yankees since they ended a 10-game winning streak for the American League East leaders, beat them twice in a two-game series and started them on the slide in which they have lost 17 of 31 games.
These Twins were not supposed to upset the competitive-balance argument this season. They started with an 8-16 record, and that was supposed to be the course their season would take. But they got as close to one game from first in the A.L. Central last week, and they have indicated they could be a legitimate contender until the end of the season or the start of the strike, whichever comes first.
These Twins are 21st in the payroll standing, according to information provided by the Player Relations Committee. That position, though, has not stopped them from standing near the top of the won-lost standing.
The Yankees are third on the payroll list. They are generally near the top. Just as the Twins undermine the competitive-balance argument in their way, the Yankees do it, too. They are Exhibit A of the argument that no correlation necessarily exists between a high payroll and a high spot in the won-lost standing.
From 1982 through last season, a 12-year span, the Yankees had the major leagues' highest average salary four times and were in the top four five other times. They did not win a division championship in that period.
The Twins, on the other hand, cracked the top 10 only once and were in the bottom 10 six times, and they won the World Series twice in a five-year stretch during that period.
The Twins represent one-half of a two-part axiom that holds true in baseball, as well as any other business: Good management overcomes all sorts of problems; poor management undermines all sorts of positives.
In General Manager Andy MacPhail, the Twins have good management. But they also have an owner who allows MacPhail to make baseball decisions, tempered only by their impact on the club's economics. Working under the constraints of their revenue, which is considerably less than the Yankees', MacPhail manages to build a winner not every year but often enough to make the Twins a successful franchise.
One of MacPhail's strengths is his belief in stability in the dugout. Tom Kelly has been the only manager MacPhail has had in his eight years as general manager. But while the Twins have had one general manager and one manager for eight years, the Yankees, the other half of that axiom, have had six or seven general managers, depending on certain technicalities, and seven managers.
MacPhail refused yesterday to take any credit for the Twins' development into a contender this season. He gives all of the credit to Kelly and the players. The development, he said, was so unexpected that the fans haven't caught on.
"As good as we've played, our attendance is down," MacPhail said. "We're suffering a hangover from the people who didn't think we had a flying chance, and they have their interest elsewhere."
The team's plight reinforces the fear MacPhail said he has for teams in the Twins' circumstances. "In my own mind, I don't think it can go on," he said. "I am a big proponent that you have to have some sort of different economic scheme."
But if the Twins were to win their division championship, wouldn't they at least set back the competitive-balance argument as they have in recent years?
"Sure," said MacPhail, honest and candid as always.

LENGTH: 536 words

HEADLINE: The Carter Opening

 BODY:
Granted, it was not a masterpiece of clarity and coordination. But former President Jimmy Carter and the Clinton Administration, which approved his trip, appear to have moved the crisis over the North Korean nuclear program back toward the negotiating table. Mr. Carter's personal diplomacy, conducted with North Korea's President, Kim Il Sung, may well provide a face-saving way for both sides to pull back from confrontation.
Mr. Carter says he won Mr. Kim's consent to freeze his nuclear program in a verifiable way while high-level talks are resumed between the United States and North Korea to resolve the nuclear issue. If the specifics of the Korean offer are confirmed, it offers a promising route toward a deal. 
 The former President also won Mr. Kim's assent to a meeting with South Korea's President, an offer that the South has welcomed. If the talks take place, they could further defuse the crisis on the Korean Peninsula.
True, Mr. Carter erred in saying that the U.S. would suspend efforts to seek United Nations endorsement of sanctions; President Clinton had conditioned that suspension on confirmation by North Korea of its nuclear freeze.
But sanctions would be difficult to mount effectively at this point anyway. Japan and South Korea, never mind China and Russia, are unlikely to move to sanctions while there is a chance for diplomacy. Tough sanctions could bring down Japan's coalition Government and raise risks of war that South Korea does not care to run.
The promises Mr. Carter says he has won from North Korea would go a long way toward meeting conditions set by the Administration for holding high-level talks with the North.
One condition has necessarily been abandoned. North Korea's abrupt removal of fuel rods from its reactor at Yongbyon barred international inspectors from their preferred way of determining whether the North diverted enough spent nuclear fuel in 1989 to yield a bomb's worth or more of plutonium. So other ways must now be found, a major issue for the high-level talks.
But an even more important condition was met when President Kim gave Mr. Carter his personal pledge that the inspectors could remain at Yongbyon, thus preventing diversion of an additional five bombs' worth of plutonium. In the meantime, North Korea needs to defer loading the reactor with new fuel rods that could be available for future diversion, an issue that Mr. Carter did not raise with the North.
Once Washington confirms that a freeze is in effect, high-level talks can resume and preparations for economic sanctions can halt. The U.S. will then seek a verifiable end to the North's nuclear program, especially its capacity for reprocessing spent fuel, and an end to the North's missile exports.
Pyongyang, in turn, is seeking a peace treaty formally ending the Korean War and establishing diplomatic ties with Washington. It also wants the world to give it a less proliferation-prone reactor to replace its current reactor, a potentially promising investment from a security standpoint.
Mr. Carter was probably premature in declaring the Korean nuclear crisis over, but his intervention may have usefully pointed the way toward its eventual resolution.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Fresh Air for America

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
In Washington, some members of Congress have decided to remain faithful to themselves, their concept of what America means and their special constituency. They bring fresh air to America.
For no political gain and at some risk, they have chosen to be constant to the hounded and battered constituency they selected for themselves -- the prisoners in the torture cells of China and Tibet and all the other political and religious victims of Beijing. 
 At first there were four Democratic members of Congress. They introduced legislation to override President Clinton's own personal decision. That, of course, was to renege on his promise to use tariff pressure on Beijing to ease repression of dissidents, priests and workers.
Then, within hours, 40 more members, both parties, signed up and the list grows. They know they are taking on the power of the Presidency, party politics and the rich and very tough China lobby.
Under the legislation the U.S. would remove the low tariff privileges for all products of China's most varied and strongest economic conglomerate -- the army. Through scores of dummy corporations, the Chinese Army uses soldiers, "volunteers" and particularly low-cost labor to make and export products ranging from toys to assault rifles.
The legislation would also remove low-tariff privileges from specified products of state-owned enterprises -- among them plastics, wood articles, footwear, apparel. All told, the tariff hikes would affect the costs of only $5 billion of China's $40 billion exports to the U.S.
Still, and whether they succeed or not, these politicians are opening windows to some refreshing reminders of American idealism.
We need it. Not only has Mr. Clinton broken his human rights promises on China but Jimmy Carter, strong for human rights during his Presidency, astonishingly soils his mission to North Korea by some of the warmest praise of a dictator since the American adoration of Uncle Joe Stalin. Has Mr. Carter changed?
Beijing has not, not at all. So Mr. Clinton's surrender to the Chinese Government was notice that the Administration was canceling human rights as an effective part of American policy.
Now members of Congress are crying stop -- the U.S. must return to human rights as one instrument and goal of policy.
The human rights concept simply is that liberty is not just the struggle of those who do not have it but also of those who live within its grace. It was a reason America's name was blessed around the world.
On his human rights record, President Clinton encourages what the country needs least: cynicism. He was elected because enough Americans saw him as an open-hearted democratic idealist, the antithesis of life as a bottom line.
So one message of the legislation is particularly important. The politicians are saying that cynicism need not be the country's soul-destroying destiny. Fresh air; lovely.
On economics, the sponsors of the legislation open other windows by dissecting the fraudulent argument that the U.S. cannot afford a human rights policy in China.
China, they point out, racks up a $31 billion sales advantage over the U.S. The Communists did not accomplish that through brilliant new managerial methods but through imposed low wages and banning of unions. Working conditions are so bad that police are busy putting down strikes. How many workers have been killed?
Low wages in China may improve the balance sheet of some U.S. companies, relatively few. But tens of thousands of American workers stand to lose their jobs. They are unable to compete with Chinese wages and hours -- thank God.
Written with respect, the names of the original sponsors of the legislation are: in the Senate, George Mitchell, the majority leader; and in the House, the majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt; David E. Bonior, the majority whip, and Nancy Pelosi of San Francisco, a strong, steady leader for human rights.
In Congress or out, the human rights movement does not ask the U.S. to dispatch arms or armies but to use economics and diplomacy to pressure dictatorships into allowing some elemental civil decencies.
The sponsors of the legislation are putting a question to Americans: If America cannot do that much for the rights of humans, then what are we, to the world and ourselves?

LENGTH: 1606 words

HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY'S BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
GIULIANI'S BUDGET WINS THE SUPPORT OF COUNCIL CHIEFS

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the leaders of the City Council agreed yesterday on a $31.6 billion budget that would sharply curtail the growth in spending for the first time since the city fiscal crisis of the 1970's and begin to wrench down the size of New York City's government.
The Mayor and the Council leaders struck a tentative deal at 3:30 yesterday morning -- toasting it with champagne -- after two weeks of talks and a final day and night of haggling about what spending to cut and whether to merge the city's three police forces, which in the end was given the green light by the Council. 
 It then took 17 hours for Mr. Giuliani and the Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, to announce a formal agreement on the budget as the leaders presented the details to restive Democrats on the Council, many of whom were angered by parts of the deal and the public announcement of the accord by the Mayor's office before they learned of it themselves.
Appearing with Council members in the rotunda of City Hall late last night, Mr. Giuliani said the budget sent a "strong signal" that the city could straighten out its financial affairs and start to turn around its economy.
"This is a budget that will very, very much help the economy of New York City continue the recovery that is under way," the Mayor said.
For his part, Mr. Vallone said that the Council had preserved at least some vital services from the Mayor's budgetary ax, but he acknowledged that it had little room to maneuver due to the city's feeble fiscal state.
The Council's 51 members must still vote on whether to adopt the agreement, but the Speaker and his aides said they had enough votes to pass it as soon as today, despite discontent from liberals and some black and Hispanic members.
"Not everything that we wanted was in this budget," Mr. Vallone said. "It couldn't be in this budget."
In broad strokes, the agreement preserved Mr. Giuliani's priorities: closing a budget gap of $2.3 billion for the fiscal year that begins on July 1, protecting the Police Department, slashing more than $1 billion in services, cutting the work force and modestly cutting taxes on hotel rooms and commercial rents.
Under the agreement, the Council members succeeded in restoring about $75 million in services cut by Mr. Giuliani -- only two-tenths of 1 percent of the whole budget. The restorations ranged from programs for young people to weekly recycling pickups in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.
And for every dollar put back, Council leaders agreed to cut spending elsewhere, including a token $12 million cut in administrative costs for the Police Department, which Mr. Giuliani had declared all but untouchable.
"We had to take our cuts and take it in stride," Councilwoman Priscilla Wooten of Brooklyn said.
The Council also reallocated $111 million in capital projects that the Mayor's senior aide had decried as "pork" only four days ago but again matched restorations with alternative cuts. The largest restoration was a new police academy in the Bronx, with the Council allotting $11 million in design costs after Mr. Giuliani had abandoned the proposal altogether.
 
Test of Strength
 The budget represented the first real test of strength between the city's first Republican mayor since the early 1970's and the Council, which still has a majority of 44 Democrats.
But with a projected budget gap of $2.3 billion and most of the Council's Democrats unwilling to raise taxes, Mr. Giuliani succeeded in pushing the major parts of his budget.
The budget agreement included modest cuts in taxes for businesses this year and deeper reductions down the road. It cut the size of the work force paid with city tax dollars by 15,000 jobs, to 201,000, the fewest since 1985. And it held spending by the Mayor's count at $31.6 billion, $100 million less than the current fiscal year, which Mr. Giuliani has said would mark the first time a city budget has shrunk in 16 years.
Other city officials said that the figure was largely symbolic, but even their count produced only a fractional increase in spending, far smaller than the growth from year to year between any recent budgets. They said the Mayor's office had undercounted at least $140 million in Federal aid that would push spending slightly higher than this year. The city's spending, which the Mayor's office directly controls as opposed to Federal and state funds, actually increases by $254 million, to $22 billion.
 
Measured Praise
 Fiscal monitors offered measured praise for the tentative agreement. Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the state's Financial Control Board, said the agreement made "very, very important progress" toward restoring stability to the city's finances, although about $700 million of the budget remained at risk.
"There's a lot of ifs, ands and buts," he said, "but it's a major change."
Even with an agreement, the Speaker still has to push the budget through the full Council, which is expected to be done sometime in the next day or so. An aide to one member complained that the Council's negotiators had won little from the Mayor, saying, "There's nothing bold here."
Councilwoman Annette M. Robinson of Brooklyn, one of 21 members of the Council's black and Hispanic caucus, said the Mayor's austerity hurt neighborhoods like hers in Bedford-Stuyvesant. "This is a bad-news budget," she said. "It reflects the priorities of this administration, and I am deeply dissatisfied."
 
Priorities Accepted
 In fact, despite the differences in political party, the Council's leadership essentially accepted the priorities laid out in the Mayor's financial plan in February and in the executive budget in May -- a smaller government with less spending, leaner services, fewer municipal workers and no new taxes.
To close the projected gap between revenues and spending, the Mayor's budget cut spending by a total of $1.2 billion in virtually every city agency except the Police and Fire Departments.
The rest of the gap would be closed through a variety of steps, including saving $200 million in contributions to workers' health benefits and at least $560 million in state and Federal aid, including $75 million the Council won in a commitment from the state's ranking members of Congress, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Representative Charles B. Rangel.
Over the last two weeks of budget talks, the most vehement confrontations have swirled around the Council's attempts to restore less than $100 million worth of spending in agencies or programs, as well as more in capital projects, that are dear to members' constituencies.
One area that proved particularly contentious was spending for the Board of Education. The city's share of the board's $7.5 billion budget grew slightly from the current fiscal year, but was $358 million less than Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines had asked for.
In the end, though, the Council restored no new funds for the public schools. The budget did include $115 million in new aid, earmarked for specific programs, included in the state budget approved early this month, and a $36 million surplus from the board's current budget.
The Council's leaders left the fate of more of the school board's financing to Albany, where the Assembly and the Senate have passed a measure that would require the Mayor's office to spend an estimated $75 million more on schools. That bill appears to have stalled, however, with the Republicans who control the Senate not moving it on to the Governor for a signature.
 
A Critical Statement
 Mr. Cortines released a critical statement yesterday, saying the budget was "ultimately harmful" for the city's public schools. "It will continue the pattern of neglect that has come to be a hallmark of this system," he said.
At more than one point, the talks between the Mayor and the Council's negotiators broke down over the total amount of spending the Council wanted to restore. When the Council proposed adding new spending on capital projects under the members' discretion, the Mayor's chief aide, Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers, lambasted the spending as "pork" and said the Council lacked "the vision you have to achieve" to control spending.
Although some Council members, joined by elected officials and fiscal monitors, pressed the Mayor to extract significant savings from the Police Department, the Council finally bowed to Mr. Giuliani's steadfast refusal to cut the department more than symbolically. The Council's leaders settled for the modest cut in administrative spending in the Police Department, as well as $1.2 million in spending in the Fire Department.
The Council mounted a stiffer challenge to the Mayor's proposal to merge the Police Department with the housing and transit police forces. Some members complained that the merger would jeopardize the number of officers on patrol in the city's housing projects and the subways.
The Council cleared the way for the merger to move ahead, but attached to the budget agreement a "condition" that would give the Council some say as the proposal moves forward and would require the Mayor to maintain "policing," though not specific levels of officers.
The merger would allow the Mayor's office to consolidate about 400 jobs financed by the city. The Council used those 400 positions, together with others, to restore a total of 720 jobs in the Department of Social Services.
The budget agreement also dropped the Mayor's proposal to consolidate the Taxi and Limousine Commission into the Police Department and to sell the commercial license of WNYC-FM, a city radio station.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY'S BUDGET: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Surprisingly, No Gridlock

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Rudolph W. Giuliani edged into office last November to become a Republican Mayor surrounded by Democrats, a political alignment in City Hall that seemed like a formula for municipal gridlock.
But the first major test between the parties -- the battle over Mr. Giuliani's austere budget -- barely rose to the level of a confrontation, as the leaders of the Democratic-controlled City Council agreed to a $31.6 billion plan so similar to Mr. Giuliani's original proposal that the Mayor could fairly say it represented the break he had promised with New York's tradition of expansive government. 
 Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone spent all day yesterday selling the deal to Democrats, who expressed anger and resignation at the results. But shortly after 10 P.M., with enough votes in hand, Mr. Vallone stood with a dozen Council members at the Mayor's side and spoke of achieving a "good government budget, a budget within our financial resources."
Why a Council that had once fought so bitterly with Mr. Giuliani's Democratic predecessor bowed so easily to the new Mayor is a complex tale of politics and fiscal policy. It begins with the climate created by the elections of the Republican Mayor and a Republican Governor in New Jersey. It ends with the fiscal constraints imposed by a $2.3 billion deficit, an overwhelming problem that left only hard, unpalatable choices.
But it is also the story of a Mayor who had a clear, well-articulated Republican vision of smaller government, and a Council that made no attempt to forge a broad Democratic alternative, its members ranging across an ideological spectrum and more concerned with parochial, neighborhood interests.
Above all, the city's dire financial straits dominated the budget negotiations, making them an exercise in apportioning pain. "Giuliani isn't the enemy," said one of the Council's negotiators. "The enemy is the $2.3 billion hole."
But Mr. Giuliani governed as if he had won election by a landslide rather than by 3 percentage points, and he skillfully seized on the deficit to further his own agenda to scale back the mission of government and the tax burden.
He made his first move a month before entering office, when a panel that had been appointed by his predecessor, David N. Dinkins, reported that the city was nearing a "fiscal collision" and outlined a menu of drastic measures that officials could use to balance the budget, including several new fees, tolls and increases in sales and property taxes.
 
'Old Thinking'
 Surprising the city's fiscal establishment, Mr. Giuliani, however, promptly dismissed the report as "old thinking" because of its inclusion of taxes and fees. In February he released a fiscal plan that did what the experts had said would be too drastic and jarring -- closing part of the deficit through $1 billion in reductions in services and the departure of city workers.
Once Mr. Giuliani ruled out additional taxes and fees, which would have allowed more services to be maintained, only several municipal unions and advocacy groups broached the subject again.
The fiscal monitors were clearly on Mr. Giuliani's side. If Council members doubted the anti-tax mood, they could look not so much to the election of Mr. Giuliani, whose main campaign issue was crime, but to the defeat of Jim Florio, the Democratic Governor of New Jersey, with voters citing taxes as their primary reason for electing a Republican, Christine Todd Whitman.
 
Severance Packages
 Mr. Giuliani took a second step that boxed in the Council when he won both the support of the municipal unions and the Municipal Assistance Corporation to use severance packages to lure 7,000 workers off the payroll immediately.
To get permission to use a $200 million city surplus that the assistance corporation controlled to pay the workers, he made a binding pledge to cut 15,000 employees from the city work force by the end of next year, a pledge that confounded Council negotiators when they tried to restore money for city services important to their members but without increasing the size of the work force.
But if the Council had few options, it made no attempt to become the voice of opposition, to create a broad message to counter Mr. Giuliani's crusade against bureaucratic bloat.
Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger and Public Advocate Mark Green accused Mr. Giuliani of Reaganomics, and spoke of core services needed for a functioning city. But the Council splintered, with conservative Democrats like Speaker Vallone largely supporting Mr. Giuliani's priorities, and liberals and members of the black and Hispanic caucus denouncing the Mayor for failing minorities and the poor.
The result was a cacophony instead of a message that could seize and mobilize the public. "You have a Republican mayor who -- you can quarrel about whether they make sense or not -- has some bedrock principles," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission. "I'm not sure what the principles are that hold the New York Democratic party together anymore."
So the negotiations focused mostly on the margins, much as they had when Mr. Dinkins was Mayor and the Council was just learning how to use the powers granted to it by the City Charter. The Council ultimately won a small number of restorations, $75 million in areas like youth services, parks, libraries and recycling -- two-tenths of one percent of the total budget. And Democrats won only a $12 million cut from the police budget.
It was not much, but most Democratic opposition dissolved -- most notably from members of the black and Hispanic caucus, who had been vocal in their objections to the Mayor's priorities, some of them assuring union leaders in public as late as Monday night that they were going to fight. Councilwoman Priscilla A. Wooten, the caucus head, even joined Mr. Vallone and Mr. Giuliani at their press conference. "We've come a long way," she told reporters. "Yes, I will vote for the budget."
It now remains to be seen how New Yorkers respond to the service cuts that the budget will put in place, and whether the year ahead will bring a groundswell of opposition to Mr. Giuliani's vision of a leaner government. How long will the lines be in welfare offices or in the Parking Violations Bureau, which has already shortened its hours? Will child welfare workers fail to detect cases of child abuse? How will New Yorkers respond to dirtier parks and slowdowns in subway station repairs?
"I'm interested in the next 12 months and how bad this budget may end up in terms of services," said Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, a Brooklyn Democrat. "That's where you'll see reality hitting."
