HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Study gives name-brand marketers a plan to mount a counterattack on private labels and store brands.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
JUST as a sign admonished Clinton campaign workers to remember "It's the economy, stupid," marketers are being advised to behave as if signs in every corporate board room are reminding them "It's the best value, stupid."
By now it is a truism that marketing has been profoundly affected by the sea change in attitudes since the 1990's began, as value for money spent becomes the crucial attribute sought by consumers choosing among goods and services. Marketers have slashed prices, increased package sizes and eschewed glitz for substance for products like cereal, cigarettes, drugs, fast food and paper goods. 
 Still, the war between name-brand products and their lower-priced counterparts like private labels and store brands rages on. According to a study by Bates U.S.A., formerly Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., many national marketers continue to be "out-marketed and out-sold" as the fighting shifts from attributes like quality, which offer them opportunities to persuasively argue the benefits of brands, to price, which purveyors of cheaper products can almost always undercut.
"The increasing level of price-based competition in the marketplace means brand marketing has diminished, causing brand depreciation," said Frank Assumma, the president and chief executive of Bates U.S.A. in New York, offering a preview of his agency's study, which is called "These Prices Are Killing Us: What Brand-Driven Marketers Must Do to Combat Price-Based Competition."
"There has been price-oriented competition since the dawn of time, but it was not a crisis," Mr. Assumma said. He said the problem had intensified because "the disparity in pricing had gotten too great" during the period from the 1987 stock market crash through the 1990 recession and because short-term promotional price cuts had "trained the consumer to think if the price is a little too high, don't worry; something else is on deal this week."
And while advertisers and agencies continued to perceive distinctions among brands, whether nationally marketed or supermarket copycat versions, Mr. Assumma said, consumers came to believe that "all brands are equal."
"When we say private label or store brand, a consumer sees a brand, not a cheap brand," he added. "That means all brands have to satisfy an equation," balancing price and quality to form a perceived value, he said.
"This being the death knell for brands is silly," he continued. "What it actually means is that consumers will pay more -- but not that much more."
The study concludes that marketers of name-brand products must take immediate measures to mount a counterattack on the inroads of private-label and store brands. It suggests that marketers take several steps:
*Insure that a brand "more than delivers on its promises" and will "perform better than anything else in meeting a specific consumer need."
*Direct a brand's marketing communications to messages that "convey those benefits to the consumer."
*Ration resources by weeding out poorer-performing marginal brands because "they can't all survive profitably over time."
*Choose between selling name-brand products and the often lucrative sideline of manufacturing and supplying private-label products to retailers, which does nothing but "undermine the health" of branded trademarks.
*Close "the price gap" between name brands and their rivals "to the point where a consumer can afford to remain loyal to the national brand."
*End "unproductive product proliferation" by devoting corporate funds to research and development projects that will yield truly distinctive, innovative name-brand products that consumers see as better or different.
*Become the high value marketer, for example, providing the highest quality for the most reasonable price.
*Build relationships with customers to effectively counter "the bond between consumer and retailer," which stores often exploit by favoring their own products that cost less but produce higher profits than selling name brands.
Finally, it calls on marketers to increase the effectiveness of, and reduce the waste associated with, a brand's advertising campaigns.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Dollar's Plunge Lifts Gold And Other Precious Metals

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar's plunge touched off a rally in gold and other precious metals yesterday, as investors sought a safe haven from financial assets that lose value as the currency tumbles.
Gold prices approached $400 an ounce, ending at their highest levels in more than 10 months. The active August gold contract jumped $5.40, to $396.30 an ounce. 
 Analysts said gold prices would probably continue moving higher as long as the dollar remained under pressure. "In this turbulent atmosphere, being long gold is prudent," said James Steel of Refco.
The surge in gold extended to other metals, with July silver gaining 12 cents, to $5.595 an ounce on the Comex, and July platinum rising $4.60, to $411.10 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
But several analysts warned that the rally in precious metals could run out of steam, pointing to a lack of physical demand for the metals and the possibility that the Federal Reserve might push up short-term interest rates for the fifth time this year to support the dollar.
"At this point, they are playing Russian roulette with the Fed and Treasury," Bernard Savaiko, an analyst for Paine Webber, said of the precious metals speculators. He noted that higher metals prices were "rather amazing if you consider inflation is not a threat."
On the inflation front, recent advances in grain prices and various other agricultural commodities had lifted the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities to a three-and-a-half-year high on Friday. But changing forecasts that called for more rain sent corn and soybean prices falling for the second trading session yesterday, and the C.R.B. index fell 0.58 point, to 234.29, despite gold's gain.
Still, analysts said the same hot, dry weather that caused the market to rally this month could return.
On other commodity markets, oil prices declined steeply as investors unloaded expiring July crude oil futures contracts. July oil set a new high of $20.95 a barrel, but the failure to breach the $21 level sparked selling and it expired 71 cents lower, at $20.04 a barrel. August crude oil dropped 33 cents, to $19.38 a barrel.
And the premium of the July over the August oil contract, which had reached roughly $1 a barrel based on immediate demand in the Midwest, which is short of oil, closed at 66 cents.

HEADLINE: Canadian Trade Surplus

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: OTTAWA, June 21

 BODY:
Canada's merchandise trade surplus widened in April to a record 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($864 million) thanks to strong sales of cars and trucks to the United States, Statistics Canada reported today. The surplus was 866 million Canadian dollars in March and 796 million in April last year. The surplus with the United States rose to 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($1.7 billion) in April from 2.1 billion in March. After a lull late last year, exports have regained momentum as the driving force behind Canada's economic growth.

HEADLINE: George Michael Loses Lawsuit Against Sony

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 21

 BODY:
In a case that mixed questions about artistic freedom, money and ego, a British judge today rejected a bid by the pop singer George Michael to be freed from his long-term recording contract with the Sony Corporation.
The ruling was welcomed by industry executives, who saw in Mr. Michael's case a challenge to the traditional practice of signing artists to multi-album deals as a way to offset their heavy investments in discovering and promoting new acts. 
 But it prompted Mr. Michael, one of the biggest stars of the late 1980's, to call his situation "professional slavery" that left him little control over his own work and career.
 
A 15-Year Contract
 Mr. Michael had filed suit against Sony a year and a half ago, contending that the eight-album contract he signed in 1988 was unfair under British and European Union law because it bound him to the company for up to 15 years and gave him no control over how his music would be marketed.
Mr. Michael testified that his discontent followed Sony's reaction to his 1990 album "Listen Without Prejudice, Volume I." With that album, Mr. Michael said, he made a deliberate decision to play down the sultry, sex-symbol image he had cultivated starting with his days with the pop duo Wham, a decision he said did not sit well with Sony executives interested only in sales and not in his development as an artist.
He also testified that Sony had sought to punish him by not promoting "Listen Without Prejudice" as aggressively as it should have, particularly in the United States. The album sold five million copies, a relative disappointment after his 1988 album "Faith" sold 14 million copies worldwide.
Sony executives testified that they had marketed the album to the best of their abilities. And Sony's lawyers tried throughout the trial to establish that Mr. Michael was well aware of the terms of the contract he signed in 1988, and that the deal was a considerable improvement over his earlier contracts with CBS Records, which Sony acquired seven years ago.
 
Ruling: A Fair Deal
 In issuing his ruling today in the High Court in London, Justice Jonathan Parker largely accepted Sony's view of the matter, saying that the contract was "reasonable and fair" and that Mr. Michael understood the deal.
"I am satisfied on the evidence that there is no substance in George Michael's claim of unfair conduct by Sony or in any of the detailed complaints which he makes," Justice Parker's ruling said. "In particular I am satisfied that there was no such deliberate policy decision by Sony as George Michael alleges."
At a brief news conference, Mr. Michael said that he thought there were strong grounds for an appeal and that he would probably file one.
But the singer, who turns 31 on Saturday, declined to answer questions about whether he would make good on his earlier threat never to record again for Sony.
Sony, clearly trying to avoid further damage to its relationship with Mr. Michael, restricted its official reaction to a one-sentence statement: "We have great respect for George Michael and his artistry, and look forward to continuing our relationship with him."
 
A Way to Recoup
 The case had been followed intently in the recording industry, not just because it was a rare instance of a spat between between artist and label being aired publicly and in great detail, but because of the precedent it could have set regarding long-term contracts.
Recording companies have always argued that because they spend so much to find and develop new artists, they can recoup their investments only through long-term relationships with those relatively few acts who go on to major success. If artists were given freedom to break their contracts and walk away after an album or two, the companies would no longer be able to afford to spend so much on new talent, executives said.
"The concern we had was that the judge might have found against long-term contracts between artists and record companies," said David Hughes, a spokesman for EMI Records in London. "Had the judge found that, it would have had quite severe implications for us in our confident ability to invest in artists."
At the news conference, Mr. Michael said he had signed the 1988 contract "to make the best of a bad job" and sued only when left with no other option.
"In fact, there is no such thing as resignation for an artist in the music industry," Mr. Michael said. "Effectively, you sign a piece of paper at the beginning of your career and you are expected to live with that decision, good or bad, for the rest of your professional life."

GRAPHIC: Photo: George Michael arriving at the High Court in London yesterday to hear the ruling in his bid to break his 1988 contract with Sony. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: The G.I. Bill, 50 Years On

 BODY:
Not all the great victories in World War II took place on the battlefield. What proved a landmark triumph for America and its fighting forces had its start in the White House 50 years ago today when President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the G.I. Bill of Rights. Few laws have done so much for so many, yet the anniversary of this political and social counterpart of D-Day has been all but forgotten.
Formally known as the Servicemen's Readjustment Act of 1944, this innovative bill was ambitious in design and laudable in purpose: to help 10 million veterans, and their country, adapt to peacetime. The measure offered guaranteed loans to buy a home, farm or business; 52 weeks of unemployment insurance at $20 per week, plus job placement services; and most enduringly important, up to four years of Federal aid for learning or training at any level, from grade to graduate school. 
 And so Americans who never dared dream of attending college joined a flood that crested in 1946-1947, when 2.5 million veterans qualified for $500 or more in annual tuition, plus monthly allowances of $65 for single students, $90 for married. Almost overnight on U.S. campuses, Quonset huts and prefab houses bloomed to accommodate this influx. In a stroke, the legislation kept a demobilizing army from engulfing the labor force, threw open cloistered academic doors and offered energizing plasma to schools of every kind, public or private.
The special genius of the law was that it bypassed old arguments over states' rights and tax aid to religious institutions by extending its benefits to individual citizens, who had wide freedom of choice. This notable home-front victory was chiefly the work of President Roosevelt. As early as November 1942, he had asked a panel of educators to design a comprehensive program for ex-servicemen and -women. In summer 1943, in a message to Congress and in a radio fireside chat he urged approval of the panel's core recommendations, and got vital support from the otherwise staunchly conservative American Legion.
Even so, the school provisions were assailed by John Rankin, the race-baiting Mississippi Democrat who headed the House Veterans Committee; he protested that blacks were incapable of benefiting from college. Less predictably, President Robert Maynard Hutchins of the University of Chicago gloomily warned that "colleges and universities will find themselves converted into intellectual hobo jungles. And veterans unable to get work and equally unable to resist putting pressures on colleges and universities will find themselves educational hoboes."
Such prophecies were wildly off the mark. So popular and successful was the law that many of its benefits were extended to Korea and Vietnam veterans, and are now available to those who serve in peacetime. As a Federal stimulus to learning and opportunity, the G.I. Bill ranks with the Land Grant College Act of 1862, which promoted the growth of the state universities.
It is useful to be reminded periodically that Federal spending is not always wasteful, and that taxes, to paraphrase Mr. Justice Holmes, can be the agent of civilization.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: In Performance: Theater

BYLINE: By D. J. R. BRUCKNER 

 BODY:

A Neighborhood's Population
In a One-Man Show
Irish Arts Center
Under all the laughter in Colin Quinn's "Sanctifying Grace" is a rueful meditation on loss that gives this 80-minute play a real bite. The characters Mr. Quinn creates in the one-man show, residents of an Irish neighborhood in Brooklyn in the 1970's, are very funny people. But they hurt without saying so, except for one remark by a woman named Margaret: "We didn't go after what we wanted. We went after what was left." 
 Three former New Yorkers in Hollywood collaborated on the work. Mr. Quinn, a comic television and movie actor, and another actor, Lou DiMaggio, wrote it as stand-up comedy, and the director, Robert Moresco, cut and clipped it into shape, keeping the jokes but making the characters stand out in dramatic clarity.
That they do: Jimmy, the know-it-all neighborhood watchdog; J. T., the dope-dealer so lost in paranoia he cannot recall the drug combination that gave him one hilarious night of perfect sex; Joe, a gaseous bully with an amazing gift for covering his own lies even before they're challenged; Eddie, "the only liberal who ever grew up in the neighborhood"; Aidan, as charming as a viper, and more. It is a pity it is such a man's world; the unforgettable Margaret is a triumph, and Mr. Quinn ought to conjure up more such women.
He is an economical actor, relying on slight tics and habits rather than broader mimicry to embody his characters, but making them most memorable in their words. And his eyes and mouth constantly reveal subtle silences and evasions in these fragile people moving through a story that is a fast sequence of surprise outcomes leading to other surprise outcomes.
"Sanctifying Grace" continues at the Irish Arts Center, 553 West 51st Street, Clinton, through July 16. D. J. R. BRUCKNER

HEADLINE: Price, Not Safety, Drives Yankee Fans Away;
Resist His Blackmail

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We must keep the Yankees in New York City. But it makes little economic sense to spend hundreds of millions on a business that was recently valued at $160 million. The Yankees represent social and political values that ought to be protected if reasonable compromise can be reached, including public expenditures. The amount must be related to value, especially when schools, police and infrastructure are under attack. We ought to keep the Yankees, we ought to pay a rational price, and we ought not let George Steinbrenner blackmail us. 
 If, at the end, he continues to do so, the government should stop him. New York State ought to exercise its powers of eminent domain to condemn the Yankee partnership and keep it in New York. The state could do so by owning the team directly, or for those who find public ownership distasteful, the state could sell shares in the Yankees to the public, similar to what the Green Bay Packers and the Boston Celtics have done.
Or the state could simply spin the Yankees off to another private owner. However, the necessary condition of ownership and operation would be to keep the franchise in New York City.
I personally would find a change of ownership in the best interests of baseball, the public and the community. Mr. Steinbrenner owns the Yankees, however, and is entitled to the protection of the free enterprise system. He is not entitled to enormous tax subsidies, however, at the same time the Yankees are enormously profitable.
If that is the choice that he forces, then the free enterprise system also permits us to use the powers of condemnation to keep the Yankees in New York.
 
RICHARD L. BRODSKY
Member of Assembly, 86th Dist.
Albany, June 13, 1994

HEADLINE: Big Board Uncovered Short Sales Up; Amex Off

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
For the first time since January, the number of borrowed shares sold short and not yet covered by repurchases fell on the American Stock Exchange in the month that ended on June 8, even as the uncovered short sales rose to a record on the New York Stock Exchange.
In separate reports released yesterday, the New York exchange said that the number of these uncovered shares rose 5.4 percent, to 1.56 billion shares, surpassing the previous record of 1.48 billion shares set for the month that ended on May 6. 
 But the American exchange reported that short interest fell by 2.7 percent in the period, to 110.75 million shares, from 113.78 million for the month that ended on May 6.
Laszlo Birinyi, who runs Birinyi Associates, a research firm in Greenwich, Conn., said improving commodity prices probably played a role in the decline of short interest on the American exchange. Historically, the Amex has listed a lot of Canadian natural resource stocks, including the shares of numerous oil companies.
Mr. Birinyi added that after months of volatility, stock prices consolidated during the month. That sort of bottoming out might tend to dampen short-selling.
"The market is still groping for its footing, but the downward trend has been arrested," he said.
Someone might sell a stock short for several reasons; the most common is an expectation that the price will fall. Until recently, when stock prices stabilized and then rallied, those expectations were realized as prices weakened in the face of rising interest rates.
Shorting a stock is the flip side of buying a security in the hope that it will go up; a short-seller borrows shares, sells them and later buys them back to return to the original owner. If the price has dropped, the short-seller makes a profit.
Traditionally, a high short-interest level indicates that many investors are bearish. But some analysts say big short-interest positions are a positive sign, because the short-sellers eventually have to buy shares.
And others argue that over a relatively limited period of time, changes in short interest may say nothing about market sentiment at all. Proponents of this view note that over the last few years strategies involving short-selling of stocks have become much more complex.
"As investors become more sophisticated in combination investment strategies involving stocks, options and futures contracts, one can no longer look at short interest as an indication of what is going to happen," said Steven Bloom, chief economist at the American exchange.
Last month, two large companies saw huge increases in short interest positions. Short interest in AT&T rose by more than 7 million shares. And short interest in General Electric more than doubled to 8.8 million shares. During the month there were numerous reports about problems at the company's Kidder, Peabody unit.

HEADLINE: THE SIMPSON CASE: THE VICTIM;
Nicole Brown Simpson: Slain At the Dawn of a Better Life

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 22

 BODY:
For nearly half her life, Nicole Brown Simpson was known as O. J. Simpson's girlfriend, his wife, then his ex-wife. But in her last days, after she had broken off their efforts to get back together, she had been struggling to be Nicole Brown.
Hours before Mrs. Simpson was killed, she and her family -- her two children, her parents, two of her sisters -- were celebrating her freedom at Mezzaluna, one of her favorite neighborhood restaurants. 
 "She was just so vivacious, so full of life," her older sister, Denise Brown, said in a telephone interview today. "She had just gotten it all together, and it was so exciting. I was so happy for her. For the first time in her life, she was able to have her own friends. We were talking about going to Yosemite, camping, taking the kids to Club Med. Everything was going to revolve around the kids.
"She was so happy," Ms. Brown said. "She had broken up with O. J. a week and a half before. She was going to start her life over. It was going to be without O. J., with her children. Funny thing, she still loved O. J. She just couldn't live with him."
Mrs. Simpson had called the police on the 911 emergency line as recently as Oct. 25, police tapes indicate. [Excerpts, page A20.]
And sometime after she left the restaurant on June 12, Mrs. Simpson was slashed to death on the steps of the town house where she had hoped to forge a new identity. She had just turned 35. She left two children, Sydney, 9, and Justin, 6.
Even now, it is her former husband, charged with the murder of Mrs. Simpson and a friend, Ronald Goldman, who is drawing most of the attention. There is an extensive record of his public life -- as a football star, a television pitchman, Hollywood actor, the man about town with the beautiful, blonde wife on his arm. Far less is known about Nicole Brown, and her life with O. J. Simpson.
"She was totally, totally devoted to this man," Denise Brown said. Then, referring to Mr. Simpson's best friend, Al Cowlings, who helped Mr. Simpson flee the police last Friday, she added, "Even A. C., he says to me, 'Denise, I could not believe a woman could love a man as much as she did, bringing him coffee every morning, in bed.' Every morning for how many years -- 18 years -- she was so in love with him."
They fell in love when she was still a teen-ager, and until their divorce in 1992 they seemed to define the California dream.
His life was her life. The $5 million mansion in Brentwood, on the same street as Meryl Streep, the actress, and Michael Ovitz, chairman of Creative Artists Agency. The $2 million oceanfront house in Laguna Beach. His and her Ferraris. Vacations in Vail, Colo., and Mexico.
But there was a price. Friends of the couple said that he had tried to control the relationship and that even after their divorce he had been possessive about her. The Los Angeles police reported today that last October Mr. Simpson kicked in the backdoor of her house. The police said Mrs. Simpson, who summoned help by dialing 911, told them that Mr. Simpson had visited her earlier in the evening and had become upset over a picture of a former boyfriend in her photo album.
Several times in the last years of their marriage and after the divorce, she called the police. Friends noticed bruises on her arms and neck. In 1989, after a New Year's Eve party, a frantic Nicole Simpson telephoned the police again. As officers arrived, according to police records, she ran out of the bushes, yelling: "He's going to kill me! He's going to kill me!" She had a cut lip, a swollen black eye, a bruised cheek and a handprint on her neck, they said.
Several months later, Mr. Simpson pleaded no contest to spousal battery. A judge fined him $700 and ordered counseling. The couple released a statement saying their marriage had never been stronger.
Around the same time, a smiling, relaxed Mr. Simpson dismissed the incident in a 1989 television interview with ESPN, saying: "We had a fight. We were both guilty. No one was hurt. It was no big deal, and we got on with our life."
 
A Victim Perhaps, But Far More
 Now, Mrs. Simpson's death has touched off a national debate about spousal abuse as a hidden crime. But Denise Brown, 37, says she doesn't want her sister, whom she was closer to than almost anyone, to be remembered only as a victim.
"She was not a battered woman," Ms. Brown said. "My definition of a battered woman is somebody who gets beat up all the time. I don't want people to think it was like that. I know Nicole. She was a very strong-willed person. If she was beaten up, she wouldn't have stayed with him. That wasn't her. Everybody knows about 1989. Does anybody know about any other time?"
Ms. Brown stressed throughout a lengthy interview that she did not want to criticize Mr. Simpson in any way, for the sake of her sister's children and the two children from Mr. Simpson's first marriage. "He's their Dad," she explained. "I love Arnelle and Jason. I love Sydney and Justin. I'm not going to do anything to hurt them."
No one who knew Mrs. Simpson, who was 5 feet 8 inches and about 125 pounds, thought she was weak. Jean Vallely, a writer and mother of four who lives in Brentwood, saw Mrs. Simpson regularly at youth basketball games at the recreation center in Pacific Palisades. Mrs. Simpson would cheer on her daughter, Sydney, who played for the Tar Heels.
Ms. Vallely said she saw Mrs. Simpson and her children at a game the week before she was killed. "You couldn't stop looking at her because she was so striking," Ms. Vallely said. "She was not this frail, skinny little blonde. She had this great body. She was strong, and she worked out."
Back at Dana Hills High School in Orange County, Denise and Nicole Brown had been homecoming princesses. Nicole's home economics teacher, Jo Hanson, said: "Everybody was in awe of her. We get a lot of beautiful students. But she was the ultimate beauty. The girls liked and admired her. The guys were in love with her."
But it was Nicole's father, Lou Brown, who escorted his daughter to the homecoming dance, Mrs. Hanson said.
"I thought she was going to be a model, or a movie star," Mrs. Hanson said. "I used to tease her, 'I should get your autograph now.' "
Nicole was one of five children, four sisters and one brother, who grew up steps from the beach in Monarch Bay, an upper-middle-class beach community in Orange County west of Dana Point. Her father was a small-business investor, who now runs a Hertz rental-car franchise. Her mother, Judy, had dabbled briefly in modeling.
Nicole Brown seemed destined for big things, said Valerie Rigg, who attended high school with her. "People said somebody wealthy and famous would nab her," Ms. Rigg said. "She just seemed bound for that." She added, "Nicole was famous to us."
Though Nicole was not the oldest of the Brown sisters, she was viewed as the most mature. "I remember her presence, her bearing," said Bill Prestridge, recalling her from his journalism class. "She didn't have that girlish laughter."
After high school, she went to work as a waitress in a Beverly Hills nightclub, the Daisy. She tried modeling but apparently didn't like it.
 
A Restless Beauty, A Vulnerable Athlete
 Then she met O. J. at the Daisy. She was barely 18. He was 30, and at a turning point. His first marriage was breaking up; his fabled knees were failing. The attraction was immediate and intense.
"I was living in New York and modeling when she told me about him," Denise Brown said. "I said, 'Oh, who's that?' She said, 'Oh, he's a football player.' She just loved O. J. She didn't care if he was a football player or a dirt digger. They were really great for each other."
They lived together for six years and married on Feb. 2, 1985. That summer he was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio. In an emotional acceptance speech, he thanked "my wife, Nicole, who came into my life at what is probably the most difficult time for an athlete, at the end of my career."
And, he added, "she turned those years into some of the best years I have had in my life, babes." She smiled proudly back at him.
Mr. Simpson began a new career. He became a spokesman for Hertz, a football commentator for ABC, then NBC, and an actor. He was earning an estimated $1 million a year. He was on the road several months a year. The daily care of their two young children fell to her.
Wherever Mr. Simpson went, he talked about his wife. "He was very possessive," said Corey La Russo, a professional golfer who caddied for Mr. Simpson at the Riviera Country Club in Brentwood from 1991 to 1993. "He'd say, 'If I ever caught her with another man, I'd kick his ass.' He didn't want to catch anyone with his wife, and he was adamant about it. He put her on a pedestal. He'd say: 'Hey, she's all I need. She's the most beautiful thing in the world.' "
Cory Waldman, a tennis pro in Miami and a friend of Mr. Simpson, said of Mr. Simpson: "He always used to talk about Nicole. He was always in love with her. Nicole was always there -- in the picture."
 
Dream Dissolves But Intensity Lingers
 Mrs. Simpson filed for divorce on Feb. 25, 1992; the divorce became final Oct. 15 that year. The court documents offer a window into their relationship. "By the time I was 19 years of age, we were living together most of the time," Mrs. Simpson said in her filing. "I traveled back and forth between Los Angeles and San Francisco to be with him. I only attended junior college a very short time because respondent required me to be available to travel with him whenever his career required him to go to a new location, even if it was for a short period of time."
She continued: "I have had no other college education, and I hold no college degrees. I worked as a waitress for two months. Prior to that, I was a sales clerk in a boutique. These two jobs are the sum total of my employment experience. I worked on my own as an interior decorator, mostly for respondent and his friends. I no longer have that opportunity."
She described their lavish life style. "We had a full staff to assist us," she said in her filing. "The house was extensively remodeled a few years ago, and no expense was spared to update and modernize the kitchen, pool and other amenities." Every year they traveled to Hawaii, she said. They had an apartment in New York. Back in Brentwood, she had a nutritionist and a personal trainer.
Mrs. Simpson won a $433,000 settlement, as well as $10,000 a month child support. He said he couldn't pay more because he was saddled with the costs of supporting his mother and his two adult children, among others. The settlement was consistent with a prenuptial agreement Mr. Simpson had signed after a seven-month negotiation over the terms.
In addition, NBC that year cut his salary by $100,000. Two fast-food chicken franchises closed in the aftermath of the 1992 Los Angeles riot. And, he said in his filing, he had lost money on some bad investments.
According to his filing, Mrs. Simpson was not using her full abilities to make money on her own. "Petitioner has done nothing but play," Mr. Simpson's filing said, "taking nice vacations, spending time exercising and entertaining and being entertained."
Mrs. Simpson and the children moved out of the mansion, but they didn't go far. They rented a house about a half-mile from Mr. Simpson. A few months ago, after the incident when Mr. Simpson kicked in the door, they moved to a $650,000 town house on Bundy Drive.
David Bursin, a friend of Mrs. Simpson and a bartender at a Beverly Hills restaurant, said Mr. Simpson kept a close eye on Mrs. Simpson after the divorce. "It was common knowledge that he followed her," Mr. Bursin said. "He would show up at places. She would have to calm him down. It wasn't like he was in a tirade. She just didn't want it to escalate. She would go off for a few minutes and then come back." Other friends recalled an occasion when they were drinking coffee at a cafe when Mr. Simpson drove up and glared at their party for a long minute.
In her last months, Mrs. Simpson was reaching for a new freedom, said Dee Dee Burnett, a 24-year-old who said she befriended Mrs. Simpson five years ago when Ms. Burnett was dating Jason Simpson. "O. J. had possessed her, and she was finally able to have her own life," Ms. Burnett said.
Ron Hardy was one of the friends who accompanied Mrs. Simpson on evenings out. "We would go out and have dinner and then dance all night," he said. "Wherever there was dancing, there was Nicole. Five, six, seven songs at a time. She had more stamina than all of us."
All along, behind the walls and high security gates of Brentwood, there was a lot of talk about Nicole and O. J.: They were together, they were apart, they were together again.
"I ran into her six weeks ago at San Vicente Foods," said a woman who lives on the same street as the Simpson mansion. "I hadn't seen her in three years. She told me: 'Did you hear? O. J. and I are getting back together.' I said, 'Oh, that's wonderful.' I took that to mean he had some rehabilitation after what had happened in 1989. She was very happy."
But the reconciliation did not last. "She tried her hardest, and it didn't work," Denise Brown said.
Denise Brown said her sister told her she would never marry again, adding, "She loved him to death."

HEADLINE: Panel's Moderates Say a Compromise Is Near on Health

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
Moderate Democrats and Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee approached agreement today on a national health insurance plan that would require people to buy health insurance for themselves and not make employers buy it.
If the three Republicans and five Democrats can agree among themselves, they said, they will present their plan to the 12 other members of the committee on Friday. They said they thought they could get enough votes to have the committee then send the measure to the full Senate. 
 Deadlock in the Finance Committee has presented the most severe Congressional threat to hopes of passing legislation that would insure all Americans. Many supporters of that goal, even those who quarreled with the emerging details of the compromise plan, said today's development was a major step toward the overhaul of the nation's health care system.
Some members of the committee said they had reservations about the proposal but would vote for it anyway to keep the process going.
The Clinton Administration was tentatively friendly to the moderates' efforts. Hillary Rodham Clinton, after meeting with Democratic senators at lunch, told reporters that she would not comment on the proposal because she did not know its details. But she added, "I am encouraged by what I hear is very substantive discussion."
Some Republicans were dubious about reports of progress. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said he was preparing an alternative plan. "I think we are still a long way from any consensus either in the committee or in the full Senate," he said.
 
Details of Proposal
 While the compromise plan, backed by two leading figures in the health debate, Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, was not available in writing, senators and aides described some major features.
The plan would provide subsidies for people who cannot afford to buy their insurance, they said.
In addition, the requirement that people buy their own insurance, an "individual mandate" in the political jargon of health care, would not come into effect until 2002. And it would take effect only if other methods to spread health insurance had not led to either 95 percent or 96 percent of the American people's being insured. One participant in the talks said 95 percent; another said 96 percent. Such methods might include laws to make it easier for small businesses to join together and bargain for good rates, or a ban on excluding people with pre-existing medical problems.
Politically, the moderates' approach tries to meet President Clinton's insistence on universal coverage, while skirting the intense opposition to the means he chose to achieve it: requiring employers to pay most of the cost of their workers' health insurance. Opposition by small businesses has made that approach dangerous to many Congress members.
Senator Breaux said he believed that the individual mandate might never come into effect, because a commission to administer the plan would make regular recommendations on how to increase the number of Americans with health insurance. As a result, he said, it would not be necessary to rely on a mandate.
 
Tax on Some Policies
 Another major element of the plan, first sketched to reporters on Monday by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, would be a tax of 35 percent or 40 percent on expensive health insurance policies. The tax would raise money for insuring those whose annual income was up to 240 percent of the Federal poverty level, or about $34,000 for a family of four.
Since insurance companies would probably pass the tax on to consumers in the form of still-higher premiums, this tax could induce customers to choose cheaper health insurance plans, which supporters of the plan think would lead to a reduction in the soaring inflation in health care costs.
One element that Mr. Bradley discussed has apparently been dropped. On Monday the Senator said that if 96 percent of Americans were not insured in five years, not only would individuals be required to buy insurance, but employers who did not insure their workers would also be taxed.
That section, a pale imitation of the employer payments required under the President's proposal and the variations on it offered by Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, apparently proved too much for the Republicans in the group. Besides Mr. Chafee, they were Senators Dave Durenberger of Minnesota and John C. Danforth of Missouri.
 
Republican Criticism
 While those three Republicans tried to avoid the partisan shoals that have threatened the bill, some of their colleagues still rejected the notion of government guaranteeing health insurance coverage.
After the Republicans caucused this afternoon, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas said that any plan that got his support and that of most Republicans could not "guarantee anything."
The moderates' effort was discussed at the Republican caucus, and there was no evidence that it picked up allies. But, Mr. Chafee said with a shrug, "they didn't say I was off on the wrong track."
At the same time, the idea of requiring people to buy their own health insurance drew criticism from liberal Democrats. Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota said it did little to help people who lacked the money for insurance.
In the House, Representative Vic Fazio, the Californian who heads the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, sent a memorandum to other House Democrats today criticizing what he called the Republican idea of the individual mandate.
Mr. Fazio urged Democrats to work against the individual mandate and in favor of a bill requiring employers to insure their workers. He said they would be rewarded in the November elections once voters saw that Republicans were more interested in helping business and the wealthy and were "selling out the middle class."
Still, there seemed to be a rickety bandwagon moving forward for the moderates' proposal. Mr. Kennedy said things "look increasingly hopeful." And Mr. Moynihan, who only Tuesday had said that his committee would not start voting on a health insurance bill until mid-July, changed his mind today and said voting would begin on Monday.
In addition to Mr. Breaux and Mr. Bradley, the Finance Committee's moderate Democrats behind the compromise are Senators David L. Boren of Oklahoma, Max Baucus of Montana and Kent Conrad of North Dakota.
 
Action in the House
 Two other Congressional committees were also at work today on health legislation. The House Ways and Means Committee rejected, 23 to 15, an amendment to eliminate abortion services from its version of the bill. Three Republicans joined 20 Democrats to defeat the amendment.
Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut and a critic of many elements of the Ways and Means Committee bill, voted with the majority, saying, "It would be a grave mistake to set a precedent of stripping out services from the package because they weren't politically correct. After abortion comes AIDS care; after AIDS care comes sexually transmitted disease care."
The House Education and Labor Committee nearly finished its work on its more generous version of health care legislation and hopes to complete action on Wednesday.

Danforth of Missouri meeting yesterday in Washington to discuss the health care overhaul. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: THE SHAKEN DOLLAR: THE POSSIBLE ACTIONS;
Dollar Steadies Although U.S. Does Not Intervene

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
As the dollar rebounded slightly today from Tuesday's record low against the Japanese yen, the United States held back from intervening to shore up the American currency. Instead, the Federal Reserve chairman assured investors that the American economy was as healthy as ever, while the Treasury Secretary warned speculators that Washington would act if they tried to push the dollar down further.
Many market analysts were surprised by the Administration's relatively laid-back behavior today. Some viewed it as a gutsy high-risk strategy to convince the market that the dollar's fall was not justified by economic fundamentals, much like a doctor allowing a patient to heal naturally before trying more drastic intervention. 
 Others viewed the Administration's tactics as the quiet before the storm. There is widespread speculation in the currency markets that behind its poker face and low-key actions, the Clinton Administration was organizing a global rescue plan to prop up the currency by coordinated buying, and maybe even coordinated interest rate adjustments, by all the major industrial powers. Many traders believe the Administration is letting the market settle a bit before it intervenes in order to have the maximum impact.
Still others said they were completely baffled as to what the Administration was doing, but hoped that there was a strategy in place.
Government officials, however, refrained from explaining their thinking. They declined in any way to suggest what might come next if the dollar weakens.
It was a strange day. The Japanese central bank intervened heavily during trading in Tokyo early today to stabilize the dollar-yen exchange rate at just over 100 yen to the dollar, after its brief descent below the 100-yen level for the first time ever on Tuesday. The Japanese do not want the yen to strengthen against the dollar because it makes all Japanese exports more expensive and harder to sell. The dollar has fallen more than 10 percent against the yen this year.
Many investors had expected the United States to at least signal some intervention when markets opened here as well. Instead, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who was the first senior official to speak publicly, told a previously scheduled meeting with a Congressional committee that while the central bank could not be indifferent to currency movements, the American economy was very healthy. He did not indicate in any way how the Fed might respond to further dollar weakness.
In particular, he gave no hint as to whether the Fed would raise interest rates for the fifth time this year -- a move that might help stabilize the dollar by making dollar-denominated bonds and bank accounts more attractive. The Fed's policy-making committee is scheduled to meet next on July 5 and 6, though it could act before then if it wanted. Historically, though, the Fed has viewed its mandate as controlling inflation, not controlling the dollar.
"The outlook for the U.S. economy is as bright as it has been in decades," Mr. Greenspan said. "Economic activity has strengthened, unemployment is down and price trends have remained subdued."
Just as the financial wires started quoting currency traders as saying how disappointing Mr. Greenspan's remarks were, President Clinton spoke. Asked about the falling dollar during a White House picture-taking session, Mr. Clinton said: "I talked to Secretary Bentsen again today about it and I think that I would let him speak for us today on it. We agreed on what he will say and what our course will be."
 
Raised Expectations
 That comment raised expectations in the market that a big announcement was coming. Reporters besieged the Treasury Department with phone calls about when Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen would hold his news conference. But several hours passed before the Treasury faxed to financial reporters a rather bland two-paragraph statement in Mr. Bentsen's name.
It read: "I'm concerned by recent movements in the exchange markets. We are carefully monitoring developments. We continue to be in close communication with our G-7 partners, and we continue to be prepared to act as appropriate.
"Ultimately, what is important is the fundamental strength of our economy, and I am very confident in the outlook. We are now in the midst of the first investment-led recovery from a low inflation base in 30 years. And there is increased evidence of recovery abroad. We share with the Fed and with our G-7 partners the common goal of sustaining recovery with low inflation."
The Group of Seven industrial democracies -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, the United States and Japan -- teamed with nine other central banks to prop up the dollar on May 4, when it also plunged against the German mark and the yen. But while the dollar on Tuesday hit a post-World War II low, the United States and its partners have thus far refrained from engaging in another coordinated round of heavy dollar purchases to prop up the currency.
 
Reaction to Statement
 Reacting to the Bentsen statement, Neal Soss, chief economist at the First Boston investment firm, said: "There must be more to it than this. That is the only way I can explain why they would make such a fuss about a statement coming and then say so little. There must be something they know that is lurking in the background: either another round of interventions or that the Fed will be taking some actions. If not, you really have to worry that this will add to the unconvincing posture in which the United States has found itself in the currency markets in recent weeks."
By the end of the day in late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 101.10 yen, up from 100.30 yen late on Tuesday. Currency traders either were afraid to take another run at the dollar, for fear that Washington would carry out its threat to intervene, or stopped for a moment to take some profits, or were concluding that maybe the currency had been oversold beyond what the economic fundamentals would justify and were pulling back on their own.
Either way, the dollar seemed to stabilize -- for the moment -- without any intervention. But traders noted that all the dollar basically did was stop falling today. Its rebound was so slight that it could hardly be construed as any long-term fundamental reversal in its downward trend. That means another drop could come at any time.
Does it really matter if the dollar goes down further? The dollar is one of the most tangible symbols of the United States, and a precipitous fall sends a certain political signal of weakness about the United States and the current Administration. But the real economic impact of such a drop is ambiguous.
 
Makes Exports Cheaper
 On the one hand, a weaker dollar makes all American exports cheaper, and easier to sell abroad, and therefore helps to reduce the country's huge trade deficit. Many economists attribute the dollar's long-standing weakness to the continuing deficit, and see the lower dollar as a natural response to the trade imbalance.
A cheaper dollar, though, makes things the United States imports from Japan and Germany more expensive, which can increase inflation. But imports are a smaller share of the economy for the United States than they are for many other nations, which has made Washington policy makers somewhat less concerned about the fortunes of its currency than leaders of other countries are about theirs. Furthermore, although the dollar has been falling against the mark and yen, it has actually been stable or rising against most other currencies, mitigating the inflationary impact.
But on the negative side, a weaker dollar can also drive up long-term interest rates. To finance America's trade deficit -- and domestic budget deficit -- the Federal Government has to sell Treasury notes to foreigners, since there are not enough American buyers. But foreigners will not buy Treasury securities if the dollar is falling in value unless they are paid a higher interest rate to compensate for any devaluations. Those higher interest rates that the Treasury must charge then get passed through to the American economy at large, putting a crimp on growth.

HEADLINE: Clinton Says the North Koreans Really May Be Ready for Talks

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he was now satisfied that North Korea is willing to freeze its nuclear program temporarily, and he agreed to open comprehensive talks next month in Geneva.
The announcement may ease the tension that has built up in recent months. But it does little more than move the standoff to an unpredictable new stage; it remains unclear whether any progress has been made toward resolving the basic differences. 
 After 15 months in which optimism has several times given way to despair, the President injected a note of caution even as he expressed satisfaction that the two countries could take their dispute over nuclear weapons back to the bargaining table.
"This does not solve the problem, but it certainly gives us the basis for seeking a solution," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference at the White House. He described the agreement as "a very positive development."
After six days of wariness and skepticism, the late-afternoon announcement amounted to a willingness to accept that North Korea's leaders really meant what they said when they told former President Jimmy Carter of their willingness to halt nuclear operations while the talks went forward.
Some of Mr. Clinton's aides had spoken disparagingly of Mr. Carter's performance in North Korea and his assertion upon returning that he believed the crisis to be over. But the President went out of his way today to offer thanks and praise to his Democratic predecessor and what he called Mr. Carter's "important role."
"It is the beginning of a new stage in our efforts to pursue a non-nuclear Korean peninsula," Mr. Clinton said.
In accepting North Korea's commitment as a basis for the new talks, the White House has dropped its demand that the North preserve evidence of its past nuclear operations, which could show whether it has extracted the plutonium necessary to make nuclear weapons. But Administration officials say they still hope North Korea will allow them to learn in detail about the past.
As the basis for their confidence, Administration officials pointed to a letter received in Washington today in which Deputy Foreign Minister Kang Sok Ju of North Korea described his country's willingness to suspend the nuclear activities that most worry the United States.
In return, Mr. Clinton made it plain that Washington would make good on its offer to suspend its push for economic sanctions once bilateral talks are under way. The talks would bring together American and North Korean representatives for the first time since last summer, and would expand and thus complicate a dialogue that has focused almost exclusively on the dispute over nuclear weapons.
Since his return from North Korea, Mr. Carter has been an outspoken advocate of bilateral talks as a likely route to a permanent solution. In interviews, he has pointed to North Korea's interest in obtaining more modern nuclear reactors and in winning Western assurances that it will be spared from nuclear attack as reasons that the North might accede once and for all to Western demands that it open its nuclear plants to international inspectors.
But skeptics inside and outside the Administration have warned that the North may simply be seeking once again to buy time, and Mr. Clinton's announcement was received with particular disdain today by Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader.
Accusing the Administration of an "apparent readiness to throw in the towel," Senator Dole issued a statement warning, "There is no basis in history or experience to believe more talk and more delays will limit North Korea's nuclear ambitions."
But Representative Gary L. Ackerman, a New York Democrat and a leading member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, praised the step as a "very, very welcome breakthrough."
 
Two Key Assurances
 The letter today from Mr. Kang, the Deputy Foreign Minister, was a response to one sent to him on Monday by Robert L. Gallucci, Assistant Secretary of State for Politico-Military Affairs. Mr. Gallucci wrote that Washington would resume talks soon if North Korea confirmed that it was willing to suspend its nuclear weapons program.
Mr. Kang's letter was not made public, but Mr. Clinton said it contained assurances that North Korea would neither reprocess the spent nuclear fuel rods it recently removed from a nuclear reactor, nor reload that reactor with new rods, the main steps Washington had demanded.
In order for the West to verify these assurances, Mr. Clinton said, North Korea also promised to allow international inspectors and their monitoring equipment to remain at the Yongbyon nuclear complex.
 
Looking Toward July 8
 Tonight, Mr. Clinton described the commitment to inspections as the central feature. "If we didn't have some way of verifying it, you and I wouldn't be having this conversation at this moment," he told reporters in the White House briefing room.
United States officials said the talks were likely to begin in Geneva on July 8, the date proposed by North Korea. Mr. Gallucci is expected to be the American representative, Mr. Kang the North Korean.
While nuclear issues will be at the fore, a senior Administration official told reporters in a briefing at the White House, North Korea's rapidly developing missile program may also be discussed.
Securing permission for international inspectors to visit several sites where North Korea is suspected of storing plutonium or conducting secret nuclear programs will be high on Washington's agenda, the official said. Only by inspecting such sites will investigators have any hope of reconstructing North Korea's nuclear program and determining how far they have progressed toward building a nuclear weapon, if at all.
 
Conferring With Allies
 The official said the North Koreans had stated that they would discuss fulfilling their obligations as a signer of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, including allowing inspections of suspected nuclear sites, in the context of an "overall solution."
Mr. Clinton and his top aides began even tonight to consult with allies about how to capitalize on the new step.
While the President called President Kim Young Sam of South Korea from the White House, Secretary of State Warren Christopher was placing calls from his Air Force jet on a flight home from Brussels to his counterparts in Russia, Japan and South Korea.

FROM NIGHT OF RAGE, SEEDS OF LIBERATION
The Stonewall uprising is widely regarded as the turning point in the gay-rights movement, ushering in an era of pride, openness and activism. But through the eyes of five people who were there that night, the uprising itself was not glamorous. The fact that it has become an icon amazes them still. A1.

HEADLINE: Indonesia Shuts Three Outspoken Magazines

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, June 22

 BODY:
An era of relative political openness and press freedom in Indonesia appeared to end this week as the Government of President Suharto shut down three influential magazines, including the country's most prominent newsweekly, and warned other publications that they could soon share a similar fate.
Diplomats and human rights advocates said the closing of the magazines was the most serious blow to freedom of the press in Indonesia in decades and would harm the international standing of the Suharto Government at a time when it seemed to be otherwise improving. 
 The publications are Tempo, which began publication in 1971 and was considered the nation's pre-eminent newsmagazine; DeTik, a year-old magazine praised by readers for its daring investigative reporting, and Editor, another newsweekly. They were notified late Tuesday that their publication licenses had been revoked by the Government.
The United States Embassy in Jakarta, the Indonesian capital, issued a statement expressing "regret over the Indonesian Government's decision to cancel the publishing licenses." President Clinton is expected to travel to Indonesia in November for a meeting of the leaders of Asian and Pacific countries.
Fikri Jufri, editor in chief of Tempo, said in a telephone interview from Jakarta that there was no hope of resurrecting the publication -- "at least not in this regime."
"Tempo becomes history, and I'm surprised and I'm saddened," he said, adding that the move would chill the reporting of other Indonesian publications, a view shared by diplomats and human rights groups.
In their willingness to challenge the Government of President Suharto, who has held power in Indonesia for a quarter of a century, the three publications had no rival among Indonesia's daily newspapers, which are far more timid in their coverage of the Government. News broadcasts on Indonesian television and radio have traditionally been subjected to tight Government control.
The Information Ministry said Tuesday in Jakarta that it closed Tempo after the magazine, which had a circulation of about 190,000, failed to heed several warnings about its news coverage. The director of the ministry's press department was quoted in news reports from Jakarta as saying that recent articles in Tempo "haven't reflected the life of a sound press, a free and responsible press."
The ministry said the other two publications were being shut down for "administrative" reasons involving their supposed failure to operate according to terms of their licenses.
The shutdown of the three magazines appeared to offer new evidence of the growing influence of the Indonesian Technology Minister, B. J. Habibie, a close friend of Mr. Suharto and a possible successor, who was the subject of unflattering scrutiny in Tempo and elsewhere after he arranged the purchase of 39 ships from the former East Germany Navy. The purchase had been opposed by senior officers of the Indonesian Navy.
DeTik, which means a second of time, began publishing in February 1993 and aroused the anger of the Government because of a series of recent articles implicating senior officials and friends of President Suharto in the country's worst banking scandal, a $436 million swindle of Government funds.

HEADLINE: 3 Governors Take Pleas On Aliens to the Senate

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
Armed with metaphors equating illegal immigration with natural disasters, the Governors of California, Florida and Arizona beseeched the Senate Appropriations Committee today for reimbursement for services that their states provide illegal aliens.
The Governors, who have already sued the Federal Government in an effort to recover some of those costs, used a hearing of the committee to restate their alarm at the havoc they see being wreaked by Washington's failure to police the nation's borders sufficiently to stem the flow of illegal immigration. They spoke of storms, floods and tidal waves of illegal aliens. 
 Gov. Pete Wilson of California testified that every fifth grader in his state could have a computer if it were not for the cost of educating illegal aliens. Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida called for a Federal charge card so illegal aliens could bill their health care and education directly to the Government. And, referring to "the immigrant invasion," Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona noted that the Constitution guaranteed the states protection against invasion.
 
Storm 'Battering Our Shores'
 Mr. Chiles, a Democrat, described illegal immigration as a "living nightmare" akin to Hurricane Andrew. "As surely as the winds and rains of Hurricane Andrew assaulted South Florida in a crisis that forever changed it," he said, "there is another storm, illegal immigration, that is battering our shores today."
The witnesses' rhetoric fell on mostly sympathetic ears. None of the senators on the committee chastised the Governors for antagonizing the Clinton Administration by filing suit. (Indeed, Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, went so far as to wish them victory.) And no one challenged the Governors' immigration-cost estimates, which do not take into account that illegal aliens contribute to the states' economies as consumers, laborers and even entrepreneurs.
But the senators, who themselves did some tough talking on immigration, offered little encouragement about reimbursing the states with Federal money. "Old Mother Hubbard's cupboard is pretty bare," said the committee chairman, Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia.
Mr. Byrd also urged Governor Wilson, a Republican, to stop blaming Washington for so many of California's woes. Singling out a California agency brochure that describes prenatal services offered to immigrant women, the Senator termed it "an open invitation to illegal aliens."
 
Distrust of the Governors
 Advocates for immigrants distrust the Governors' very public campaign to try to recover money spent on illegal aliens.
"They are simply grandstanding," Jeanne Butterfield, the chief policy analyst for the American Immigration Lawyers Association, said in an interview. "They are pushing the hot button of immigration at a time when they are facing tough re-elections. Everyone's playing to an audience on this issue."
The Immigration and Naturalization Service estimates that there are 3.85 million illegal aliens in the country. The leading states in this category are California, with 1.6 million, New York (510,000), Texas (405,000) and Florida (333,000).
In calculating the costs of educating and providing health care to illegal aliens, as well as incarcerating those criminally charged or convicted, the states use higher population estimates than does the immigration service. Mr. Wilson said California spent $3 billion a year on illegal aliens, Mr. Chiles said Florida spent $884 million and Mr. Symington, a Republican, said Arizona spent $204 million.
In his budget request for the 1995 fiscal year, President Clinton asked Congress for $350 million to help states defray the costs of imprisoning illegal aliens. But that money has already been swallowed up in the House Appropriations Committee's budget bill by a program of grants to fight drugs. States could elect to use the grant money for prison costs, but, because the money would be spread among so many more states, those grappling with the heaviest immigration burden would receive far less than under the Clinton proposal.

HEADLINE: Drug Cartel Tied to Vote In Colombia

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 22

 BODY:
Hoping to buy leniency from the future Colombian President, a Cali cocaine cartel leader agreed to donate $3.75 million to the presidential campaign of Ernesto Samper Pizano, according to wiretap tape recordings made public here today.
Mr. Samper, who won the presidential election Sunday by the narrowest margin in memory here, denied the charges and demanded a police investigation. His campaign treasurer, Santiago Medina, said, "This campaign did not receive one peso from drug trafficking." 
 The No. 2 finisher, Andres Pastrana, played the telephone recordings at a news conference and asserted on national television, "If it is proved that the President-elect's campaign received drug trafficking money, he should resign because his mandate would be invalid."
While some journalists here called the donation offer Colombia's most serious political scandal of recent years, others predicted that it would eventually fizzle out, as have past denunciations of traffickers' influence in politics.
Past incidents that never went beyond newspaper headlines include a 1991 videotape that showed delegates to Colombia's Constitutional Assembly accepting envelopes stuffed with cash from cartel emissaries. The Assembly voted overwhelmingly to bar the extradition of Colombian trafficking suspects to the United States for trial.
 
President Flies to U.S.
 Today, belying a crisis climate, President Cesar Gaviria flew to Los Angeles for the World Cup soccer match between Colombia and the United States.
Seeking to appear presidential, Mr. Samper visited a remote Andean region where an avalanche killed about 1,000 Indian peasants two weeks ago. Both Mr. Samper and Mr. Pastrana plan to travel to the United States on Thursday to follow Colombia's team in the World Cup championship.
Police technicians verified today that the voices on the tapes belong to Alberto Giraldo Lopez, a newspaper columnist, and Gilberto and Miguel Rodriguez Orejuela, two brothers who manage the Cali cartel, the world's largest cocaine trafficking organization.
"What a funny thing, the presidency is in your hands," remarked Mr. Giraldo, who appeared on the tape as an obsequious messenger boy for the Rodriguez Orejuela gang.
When Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela grudgingly agreed to donate five billion pesos to the Samper campaign, Mr. Giraldo whined, "In turn, you wouldn't even give me five pesos."
The trafficker replied on the tape: "Yeah, well you can't help us go straight. That fine day when you are a presidential candidate, and you have 47 percent in the opinion polls, you won't get just money, you'll have our lives in your hands."
"We've already talked to Medina," Mr. Rodriguez Orejuela said, apparently referring to Mr. Samper's campaign treasurer. "We'll send around some money on Wednesday, and then the rest around Monday of next week."
Although the dates of the tapes are unclear, the proposed multimillion dollar donation was apparently timed to flow last week, when pollsters were predicting a dead heat for the two candidates.
Playing the role of the intermediary, Mr. Giraldo said, "The important thing is that the five points be reassured, set, taken care of."
Today's issue of La Prensa newspaper, owned by Mr. Pastrana's family, speculated that "points" referred to five nominees in a future Samper Cabinet.
"What's that?" rasped Mr. Rodriguez Orejuela, apparently confused.
To explain, Mr. Giraldo said, "Those are the fundamental nominations."
At the end of the conversation, the trafficker said: "Please don't tell anyone. We aren't dopes. We know how to run our business."
As soon as copies of the tapes started circulating here Monday night, Mr. Giraldo went underground. Today, he openly admitted his role as an emissary for the Rodriguez Orejuela brothers, two men who, in theory, are targets of nationwide manhunts.
 
'My Efforts Were Useless'
 "I suggested to the Rodriguez Orejuela gentlemen that I could intermediate with the candidates' advisers to see if it were possible, without any commitment, deliver economic donations to the campaigns," Mr. Giraldo said in a written statement. Advisers for the two candidates rejected the offer, Mr. Giraldo said, adding, "My efforts were useless."
"Curiously, this part of the dialogue was not published," he continued, implying that Mr. Pastrana edited the tapes.
Denying that the tapes were edited, Mr. Pastrana today gave his account.
On June 15, he said, an unidentified man pressed the tapes into his hands as he was leaving a campaign rally at the Inter-Continental Hotel in Cali. The next day, after listening to the tapes, he delivered them to President Gaviria in Bogota.
On June 17, President Gaviria sent the tapes to Colombia's Prosecutor General, Gustavo de Greiff, and ordered him to investigate their authenticity. The tapes were not made public before polls closed Sunday night.

HEADLINE: THE SHAKEN DOLLAR: THE REASONS;
A Currency Dragged Down by Twin Deficits

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
With all the talk about the United States economy doing well -- so well that the worry is that it may overheat, why is the dollar hitting record lows against the Japanese yen?
To some, the economy may seem like a child who has been diligently doing his homework but still getting a bad report card. The Clinton Administration appears to taking the dollar's plunge that way. 
 But experts, from currency traders to economists, suggest that currency markets are not quite so simple. While the economy is growing -- and the dollar is undervalued by some measures, they say -- America's trade and budget deficits have combined into a considerable force pushing the dollar down.
Another complicating fact is that investors, who have an increasingly global view, have been licking their wounds from market declines earlier this year and have been moving some money in recent months from American to German markets, which are seen as more stable, and to Japanese markets, which may be more lucrative.
 
Conflicting Forces
 Economists note that the value of one currency versus another results from both short- and long-term forces that often push in different directions.
Over the long run, the price of goods, like cars and machinery and corn, that are traded in world markets should equalize across borders. And as countries become more efficient at producing these goods, that improvement will be more or less reflected in the values of their currencies. Such changes go a long way toward explaining why the dollar has dropped so sharply against the yen since World War II, as Japan built its economy and became much more competitive with the United States and other nations. The cost of production in Japan has risen far less rapidly than in the United States.
"The relative price of a basket of American goods compared to a basket of Japanese goods has been going down in real terms since 1950," said Maurice Obstfeld, an international economist at the University of California at Berkeley. "Most people feel that is related to relative gains in Japanese productivity."
Still, some economists said that based simply on the cost of goods, the yen is extremely overvalued. A quick check of prices in a Japanese department store, they say, where an American tourist would pay far more for goods than in the United States, argues that the yen should fall.
 
Supply and Demand
 But at any given moment, currency rates, like any price, are also determined by supply and demand. And in recent weeks, more people have wanted to sell dollars than to buy them, pushing the dollar down against both the yen and the German mark.
The recent decline in the dollar has occurred even though interest rates in the United States have climbed sharply in recent months. This seems to run counter to financial theory that suggests that when interest rates rise in a country, its currency should also gain because investors are paid more to invest in that currency. But this phenomenon is actually a lagging indicator. While rates are rising, the value of bonds falls and stock markets often decline as well.
So, in a global economy, investors shun bonds in countries with rates that are heading up, but they prepare to pounce on those bonds when the rates appear to be at their top. With American bond rates still at historic lows, there is little such sentiment drawing investors to the dollar.
"Rising interest rates are bad for the dollar, but high interest rates are good for the dollar," said John Taylor, president of FX Concepts, a money management firm specializing in currencies.
Ironically, a significant source of the recent selling has been speculative investors, closing out money-losing positions that meant to gain from a rise in the dollar.
"Since the U.S. economy is doing well and the Japanese economy is doing poorly, it looked like the dollar had to appreciate against the yen after its long, long slide," said Klaus T. Said, head of foreign exchange for J. P. Morgan & Company. "Making the dollar-yen bet for speculators and interbank traders was the one sure bet for 1994."
The investors lost money on their positions in February after trade talks with Japan broke down. Somewhat chastened, many speculators kept their dollar investments. But as the dollar fell, they reached their limits for losses and closed out their positions. Mr. Said said that the sentiment among traders may be reversing, though betting that the yen will rise from its current levels is seen as a big risk.
"This year has not been very kind to participants in the forex markets," he said. "The big, seemingly clear trends didn't work out. We're here to make money, and if there is weakness in the dollar, we'll try to capitalize on it."
This said, the speculative investors, like hedge funds and bank proprietary trading desks that had been so influential in currency trading over the last few years in Europe, have maintained a much lower profile. They are using much less leverage and generally looking for conservative, short-term trading opportunities.
And more broadly, most investors are uncertain. The world economy is midway through a lengthy transition from recession and falling interest rates to growth with inflationary fears and rising interest rates. Amid that shift, short-term trends are harder to determine. Traders are less willing to commit themselves. And markets become more volatile.
Historically, the dollar has been a haven for uncertain times, but now the German mark, along with the Swiss franc, appear to some to be a safer choice. The crisis in North Korea has scared some investors. Moreover, there are questions about Washington's resolve to fight inflation.
"There has to be a lot of concern that the disinflationary trend that started with Paul Volcker, will be repudiated over the course of the 90's," said Mr. Obstfeld, the economist.
The German mark, meanwhile, is seen as at least as stable as the dollar. Investors do not have to pay a penalty for that view because short-term German rates are somewhat higher than those in the United States while rates in other European countries are even higher.
The mark has gained after the German central bank indicated that interest rates would probably not be cut further. And support for Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government in the European parliamentary election reduced worries about political change in the elections in the fall.
"Most people would rather be in Germany because the central bank is more predictable," said Adam M. Greshin, the manager of international bond funds at Scudder Stevens & Clark. "The Fed is an unknown at best."
But at 1.60 to the dollar, the German mark is not seen as abnormally high. It has been as strong as 1.40 to the dollar as recently as September 1992, but it had fallen to 1.76 this February. Moreover, from a purchasing-power point of view, the mark's value is not out of line, many currency experts say.
"If you go to Germany the prices seem normal, but in Japan they are a joke," said Mr. Said, of Morgan.
While the dominant trend among investors has been to become more conservative, some who are looking for higher returns have been drawn to Japan. The Tokyo stock market is up sharply this year, and investors in the United States and Europe have rushed to buy Japanese stocks, for which they must pay yen, thus pushing up the Japanese currency.
And as the American economy has rebounded, the United States has imported more goods from Japan than Japan has taken from the United States, increasing the trade deficit. This has increased the demand for yen, to pay for the Japanese goods.
In the 1980's, Japan invested the dollars it earned from trade in the United States, buying Treasury bonds, real estate and entire corporations. Amid the turmoil in the Japanese economy, the foreign investment flow to the United States largely stopped. Now Japanese companies quickly sell the dollars they earn, converting them back to yen.
Only when Japan chooses again to invest its dollars in the United States or to buy American goods will the dollar rise significantly against the yen, experts say. Japan's central bank appears to be signaling to other Japanese investors that the time is right to move the money overseas by its continued purchase of dollars. Yet it is unclear that the message has taken hold.
