HEADLINE: THE SHAKEN DOLLAR: THE GROWING FEARS;
Japan Sees Rise of Yen As Threat to Recovery

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 22

 BODY:
The rise of the yen to its strongest postwar level against the dollar has renewed fears that Japan's export-oriented automobile, electronics and steel companies will suffer another blow to their competitiveness, nipping in the bud Japan's fledgling economic recovery.
The decline of the dollar on Tuesday to below the crucial level of 100 yen brought back nightmares of what happened last year, when a sharp appreciation of the yen extinguished an economic resurgence after the Government declared, prematurely, that the economy had hit bottom. 
 Some economists and businessmen said the dollar had overshot the level at which it should be and would rise again soon. Even if it does not, some said, a slow economic recovery would still be possible for Japan this year unless the dollar dropped as low as 95 yen. Because of the improved economic conditions in the United States and Europe and cost-cutting by companies here, Japan is more resistant to the yen's rise than it was a year ago.
Still, with the dollar having fallen briefly to 99.90 yen in New York trading on Tuesday, piercing the 100-yen barrier, the Japanese appeared in no mood to take chances.
 
'Firm Actions' Promised
 Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata held an emergency Cabinet meeting today on the currency situation. After the meeting, Finance Minister Hirohisa Fujii promised to take "firm actions" to stem the yen's rise, which he called "bad not only for the nation but also for the world economy."
Japanese auto makers, meeting with Trade Minister Eijiro Hata, called for immediate action to stabilize currency rates.
The Bank of Japan intervened heavily in the market to stabilize the dollar somewhat. In trading here today, the dollar closed at 100.65 yen, its lowest close ever in Tokyo, but still above the opening rate of 100.35 yen.
But economists here said they doubted that the Bank of Japan alone would be able to stem the tide for long unless it was joined by the central banks of other countries. They said Japan had little power to act because what had happened was not so much a strengthening of the yen as a weakening of the dollar against many leading currencies, fueled by fears of inflation in the United States. The solution, they said, might entail raising interest rates in the United States.
"The problem is not the yen; the problem is the dollar," said Ron Bevacqua, an economist for Merrill Lynch in Tokyo.
 
Stabilization Efforts
 Mr. Fujii, the Finance Minister, said after today's Cabinet meeting that Japan was seeking the help of the other industrialized economies to stabilize currencies. He also said the Government would push ahead with efforts already under way to stimulate the economy, such as extending this year's income tax cuts to future years and deregulation.
Other officials said the rise of the yen added to the urgency of Japan's need to reach trade agreements with the United States, because the yen tended to rise when trade relations between the two nations soured.
Makoto Utsumi, a professor at Keio University who was a high-ranking official in the Finance Ministry, said the recent currency movements were the results of speculation, not economic fundamentals, and might soon be corrected. "It is rather counterproductive for Japan to respond to the speculative movement by fundamental policies," he said.
A big concern is what will happen to Japan's export-oriented companies, which have been restructuring to cut costs and moving manufacturing operations abroad to offset the rise of the yen. Many of these companies have trimmed enough that they could live with an exchange rate of 105 yen or 110 yen to the dollar.
 
More Trims Possible
 But if the dollar stays at 100 yen or drops to 95, the companies would return to losing money on exports and would have to trim even more. That would mean a continued decline in capital spending.
The Sony Corporation, for instance, has forecast that its operating earnings will grow by 71 percent in the current fiscal year because of the economic recovery and its cost-cutting efforts. But that forecast was based on an exchange rate of 105 yen to the dollar.
A Sony official said the company was not worried about a short-term dip in the dollar, because it had hedged to cover much of the risk of currency fluctuations. But, the official added, "if the yen stays at 100 or 99 yen per dollar for the second quarter, it will be difficult."
Still, some economists say, Japan's economy is better able to withstand the shock of the yen than it was a year ago. The United States economy is stronger than it was a year ago and Europe is showing some recovery, providing larger markets for Japanese products.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Post Sharp Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday as a result of a rebounding dollar against the yen and three consecutive days of decline in commodity futures prices.
A stronger dollar and weaker commodity prices helped to ease concerns that the Federal Reserve would need to raise short-term interest rates soon to combat inflation or support the dollar. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities dropped 3.42 points yesterday, to 230.87. 
 Earlier in the day, President Clinton announced that Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen would issue a statement on the dollar, and that it would represent the position of the Administration. The bond market took it to mean that Mr. Bentsen would announce a broad package to defend the dollar's value and that seemed to give the bond market a lift.
But Mr. Bentsen, while saying that the Government was prepared to support the dollar, announced no plans to intervene. Mr. Bentsen also said the Government was in touch with the Group of Seven industrial nations about the dollar, and that the Administration continued to share the Federal Reserve's goal of low inflation.
The price of the 30-year bond surged 13/32 , to 8614/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from prices, fell to 7.39 percent, from 7.49 percent on Tuesday. The strong move still leaves the bond in its current trading range.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, in an appearance before the House Budget Committee, avoided any mention of the dollar's plunge in his prepared text and refused to answer questions about the dollar, saying the situation in foreign exchange markets was such that he "did not want to get involved" in such a discussion.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, who says the dollar is not high on the Fed's priority list, said he believed that "when the Fed moves, it will be strictly for reasons relating to inflation and economic growth rather than to merely stabilize the dollar."
"Interest rates and exchange rates, along with the levels of prices, income and employment, are mechanisms that facilitate economic adjustments," he said. "It may not be wise in a longer-term context to use monetary policy to influence exchange rates, because it would than tend to limit the impact of these tools on economic policy, and as a result put under stress the levels of income and employment as adjustment mechanisms."
The Fed released its so-called beige book summary of business conditions and it had something for everyone. The report showed economic growth had moderated in some areas but that manufacturing was still showing strength and that loan demand was picking up. "It was only interesting if you happen to be coming back from another planet, since most of the data is months old," Mr. Fine said.
 
Treasury Auctions Notes
 In the government market, the Treasury sold $11 billion of new five-year notes through auction and traders said they were relieved that the auction went well.
The note was awarded at a high yield of 6.77 percent, down from 6.78 percent last month, an indication of good demand.
In the tax-exempt municipal market, New York City's Industrial Development Agency is selling $430.6 million of special facility revenue bonds through Smith Barney with a maximum yield of 6.50 percent for an issue due 2024. Yields are 6.45 percent for a bond due in 2019 and 6.40 percent for another due in 2015. Shorter-maturity serial bonds yield from 5.25 percent in 1999 to 6.20 percent in 2009.
The bonds, which are being sold for a Terminal One Group Association limited partnership project, are, for some investors, subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax and are rated A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's and A- by Fitch Investors Service.
Yesterday, the Federal National Mortgage Association, better known as Fannie Mae, priced its first global debenture issue ever through an underwriting group led jointly by Merrill Lynch and J. P. Morgan Securities.
The $1.5 billion 10-year global issue was given a 7.40 percent coupon and offered at a price of 99.75 to yield 7.436 percent, or about 25 basis points more than a 10-year Treasury. A basis point is one hundredth of 1 percent.
Both S.& P.and Moody's rate the issue triple-A.
Fannie Mae officials expect more than half of yesterday's issue will be sold to overseas investors. And those investors in 1993 bought about 10 percent of the $46 billion in long-term debt that Fannie Mae issued.

HEADLINE: Anticipating Influx of Refugees, Miami Plans Schools for Aliens

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 22

 BODY:
Concerned that political troubles in the Caribbean might cause a major influx of refugees, Miami's school board today approved a contingency plan that would put the children of aliens into makeshift special schools rather than integrate them immediately into the district's already overcrowded schools.
The plan, which would involve students attending classes in places like shopping centers and movie theaters, has met with resistance from advocates for children who worry that segregation would provide unequal educational opportunities. Others worry that any plan aiding immigrants will lure more to Florida. 
 Dade County school board officials said that they based the plan partly on an assimilation program in San Francisco and that they planned to have the program evaluated by the United States Education Department's office of civil rights to insure that it did not violate the rights of students to have equal public educations. The plan allows for students in the orientation program to apply for waivers that would transfer them to regular schools.
The board vote was not unanimous. One member, Rosa Castro Feinberg, said schools did more than just educate. "They don't just produce school learning and smart kids; they produce Americans," she said. "It is precisely that experience we will be denying under this plan."
The plan was presented by the superintendent of schools, Octavio J. Visiedo, who came to Miami from Cuba in 1961 when he was 9 years old and entered the public school system. "Sometimes they get lost in the regular setting," Mr. Visiedo said of students from abroad.
The plan would be triggered when the daily new enrollment of students becomes 100 more than normal.
During the 1980 Mariel boatlift, when about 125,000 Cubans came to the United States, the Dade schools opened two centers for a short time to absorb about 15,000 new students. School officials, with their eyes on trouble in Haiti and a worsening economic crisis in Cuba, fear that a new influx could be much larger.

HEADLINE: Pledge Made To Give ABC Tax Breaks

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In the latest pledge of city and state resources to keep a large company in New York City, the ABC Television Network and its corporate parent, Capital Cities Communications, will receive $26 million in sales-tax abatements and subsidized electricity.
Capital Cities/ABC said yesterday that it would use the incentives to invest more than $150 million in new high-technology production equipment for its New York City studios. 
 The ABC network said it would also create 185 jobs in Manhattan over the next two years. It now employs 3,700 in New York City.
The deal, announced at a news conference by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, comes after more than a decade of corporate brinksmanship in which dozens of large employers, ranging from department stores to Chase Manhattan, have received financial incentives to remain and expand in the city.
 
Headquarters Building
 Capital Cities/ABC executives said yesterday that they had never considered moving the company's headquarters or a large part of its production operations out of Manhattan. The company spent $90 million for a new 22-story headquarters building on West 66th Street in the late 1980's.
But considering incentive packages already granted other companies, including NBC and CBS, some form of financial help for Capital Cities/ABC may have been inevitable.
NBC, which had threatened to move its studios to New Jersey, got $100 million in tax breaks and other incentives in 1989. CBS, which had also said it would leave the city, received a $49.5 million package of incentives last year.
"The communications field is one in which we cannot afford to lose our edge," Mr. Giuliani said at the news conference, which was held on the set of ABC's "Good Morning America" in a studio on West 67th Street.
 
Acquired in 1986
 The ABC network was acquired in 1986 by Capital Cities, a New York company with large holdings in local television and radio stations, newspapers and other publications across the nation. ABC has eight studios on the Upper West Side, from which it produces several soap operas, network news and other programs.
In the deal announced yesterday, Capital Cities/ABC promised to keep its headquarters in the city for at least 15 years. Its $26 million incentive package is to include $14 million in savings on power bills from the New York State Power Authority and $12 million in sales-tax abatements on the purchase of equipment.
Network executives said yesterday that the sales-tax abatements were particularly important because they would help defray the $150 million they plan to spend for new high-technology studio equipment.
The equipment, including a new generation of cameras, studio wiring and computers, will be necessary to broadcast the digital signals to enable viewers to receive high-definition television, known as HDTV.
 
Investments in Technology
 Although HDTV is expected to be years away for most Americans since it will require more advanced television sets in home and more detailed regulations, all the major networks are beginning to make large investments in the technology.
ABC executives said yesterday that last fall they approached economic advisers to Mayor David N. Dinkins to request financial incentives. Though those negotiations were incomplete when Mr. Dinkins left office, ABC's request was first considered by aides to Mayor Giuliani in January, officials said yesterday.
In an interview, John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, who led the city's negotiating team, maintained that the public incentives granted to Capital Cities/ABC were small when compared to the long-term benefits the company would provide in creating new jobs.
By committing itself to a new generation of studios in Manhattan, he said, "ABC is investing in the high-tech future of the city."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in Rebound vs. Yen; U.S. Support is Anticipated

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rebounded yesterday from its record low against the Japanese yen, as traders speculated that the Clinton Administration would ultimately act to keep the dollar from falling further.
The United States did not intervene in the market yesterday, surprising many traders. But there was speculation that the Administration was organizing a global rescue plan to prop up the dollar, which had fallen below 100 yen on Monday for the first time since World War II. 
 "It's obvious that the Administration isn't going to sit on the sidelines if the dollar starts sliding again," said Hunt Taylor, managing director of the Reynwood Trading Corporation, a currency trading firm in Short Hills, N.J. "A lot of people expect central bank intervention, and maybe an interest rate increase as well."
A bout of dollar buying by the Bank of Japan during trading in Tokyo also helped the dollar gain, traders said. It rose as high as 101.35 yen in Asian trading, and was quoted at 101.10 yen in late New York trading. The dollar hit a postwar low of 99.90 yen during the day on Tuesday.
The dollar also gained against the German mark, rising to 1.6055 marks from 1.5960 marks.
Words of caution from the Federal Reserve also helped the dollar rebound, traders said. It rose after the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, told the House Budget Committee that the United States "cannot be indifferent" to the dollar's plunge.
Traders drove the dollar to a postwar low against the yen on Tuesday in part because the Fed was not buying dollars to stem the slide. So far this week only the Bank of Japan has stepped in to rescue the dollar, traders said.
The Administration showed its concern about the dollar yesterday as Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said in a statement that he was "carefully monitoring developments" in the market.
The Treasury orchestrated a huge dollar buying campaign by the Fed and other central banks on May 4 to prop up the dollar.
The dollar tumbled 2 percent against the yen on Tuesday after the Government reported that the United States trade deficit widened 22 percent in April. The swelling trade and current account deficits are among the reasons traders noted to explain the dollar's slide of 10 percent against the yen and 8 percent against the mark so far this year.

HEADLINE: Fed Report Sees a Moderating Economy

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
Rising interest rates are beginning to moderate the economy's rapid pace of expansion while wage and price pressures appear to be in check, the Federal Reserve said today.
"Districts report continued economic expansion, although in some areas growth has moderated recently," said the Fed's latest so-called beige book summary. The book is a summary of economic activity in the 12 Fed bank districts culled from interviews with business people, prepared this time by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. 
 The Fed survey, based on interviews before June 14, indicates an expected moderation in activity was setting in since its last survey was issued May 4. At that time, the Fed found "solid economic growth" in most parts of the country.
 
Manufacturing Still Strong
This time, it said manufacturing continued to strengthen in most parts of the country, with orders and shipments rising for most companies except for industries that supply the military.
But it found some slowdown in response to rising mortgage rates amid a generally brisk pace of new-home sales and construction. The survey also found that rising interest rates were causing declines in loan demand in some areas.
As for inflation, the Fed survey said prices for many industrial materials used in manufacturing processes were rising but said competition was curbing price rises for finished goods.
In a similar vein, it found the number of skilled employees needed by factories in some parts of the country was tight but said that wage pressures were moderate "at this point."
Fed banks in Boston, Philadelphia and Dallas said chemicals and metals prices were rising, while Atlanta, Kansas City, Mo., and Richmond reported construction materials prices were increasing.
The bite of more costly credit showed up at several points.
For example, the New York Fed said demand for loans was falling because of higher short-term rates; demand was reported flat in the Atlanta and Philadelphia Fed districts. Loan demand remained weak in California and banks were easing their terms to try to attract business.

HEADLINE: Vast Changes Sought in Electric System

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
The two top officers of the New York Power Authority yesterday presented a proposal for a vast restructuring of the state's electric power system. They would form a single company to operate the thousands of miles of transmission lines now owned by the Authority or by the seven investor-owned utilities around the state and another entity to run the six nuclear reactors in the state.
The proposal also called for the Power Authority to gradually reduce the amount of inexpensive hydroelectric power that it supplies to utilities upstate, and instead to use the electricity to lure job-producing industries there. 
 It recommended using 2 percent of the revenues from hydroelectric projects to support "renewable resources," like solar power, and for electric cars. It also called for severe budget cuts, especially at the authority's two nuclear reactors, which it said must be run more economically or shut down.
The proposals, the result of a three-month study, were contained in a report to the Authority's trustees. The report was offered S. David Freeman, the authority's president and chief executive officer, who earned a reputation for dramatic solutions when he served as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, and by Robert G. Schoenberger, the first executive vice president and chief operating officer.
 
Harsh Words on Nuclear
 Some recommendations, like cutting budgets, could be carried out unilaterally by the Power Authority. Others, like cutting costs statewide by joint management of assets owned by for-profit utilities, would require the assent of those companies, which have always been limited in their cooperation. Still other recommendations would require new law.
One area solely within the Authority's power is its two nuclear plants, which the report assessed in stark terms.
"The harsh truth is that at the moment, our rates don't cover our costs of producing nuclear power," Mr. Freeman and Mr. Schoenberger said.
"The Power Authority must either reduce costs and increase production at its nuclear power plants or shut them down," the report said.
The Indian Point 3 plant, in Buchanan, N.Y., in Westchester Country, has been shut since early 1993 because of operating and management problems. Together with the adjacent Indian Point 2, owned by Consolidated Edison, the plant is at the center of a region more densely populated than any other reactor site in the United States. Its operation has been controversial for years.
 
A 15-Percent Budget Cut
 The Authority's other reactor is the James A. FitzPatrick plant, in Scriba, near Oswego. It is adjacent to the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation's Nine Mile Point 1 and 2 reactors. The only other power reactor in the state, Rochester Gas and Electric's Robert E. Ginna plant, is near Rochester.
The Authority's trustees received the report but took no action. They are scheduled to take it up at a meeting next Tuesday in Massena, at the St. Lawrence hydroelectric plant.
The two executives called for cutting the authority's budget, now $487 million a year, by nearly 15 percent over the next 18 months. They would reduce reliance on contractors, reduce staff, cut the travel, legal and public affairs budgets, and take a variety of one-time steps, including selling the Thomas Hart Benton murals at the Niagara and St. Lawrence-F.D.R. visitors' centers. (The murals would fetch about $3 million in a gallery, the report estimated.)
A major problem for the authority, according to Mr. Freeman, is that New York State has more electrical power than it needs, and the glut has cut prices. Unlike traditional utilities, the Authority does not have a service territory. It sells its power on the open market, and in some cases is having trouble competing.
The report said that the Authority should do more than compete; it should promote clean-energy sources and energy conservation and stimulate the state's economy.

HEADLINE: U.S. Investments Overseas Benefit From Dollar's Drop

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The dollar has dropped substantially this year against both the yen and the mark, but for an increasing number of Americans who invest overseas, it has been a real boon. That is because as the dollar has declined against other currencies, investments in overseas assets have become more valuable.
"This is probably a bad time to go to London and pay for a hotel and meal, but if you had some money there, you got a boost," said Mark Headley, director of international investments for Litman/Gregory & Company, an investment adviser in Orinda, Calif. 
 While stock and bond markets around the world have tumbled, currency gains have cushioned the losses for American investors. For example, Germans who invested in their stock market this year lost 12 percent. For Americans, that loss was cut to less than 5 percent because German stocks are worth more in dollars. In German marks, short-term German bonds inched up just 1 percent this year. But translated into dollars, they returned more than 9 percent.
In the few countries with bull markets, currency gains have worked as a turbocharger. The Japanese stock market, for instance, has risen about 18 percent when measured in yen. When that gain is converted into dollars, investors have gained more than 30 percent this year.
"That's really having the wind at your back," said William McBride, international editor at Lipper Analytical Services. "Currency can have a particularly powerful effect in fixed-income, when the currency is rising and interest rates are going down. You don't find it very often, but when you do, you get big gains."
This year the dollar has fallen more than 9 percent against the yen, and almost 8 percent against the mark. But the dollar has risen almost 9 percent against the Mexican peso.
So, currency has hindered as well as helped. Mexico's stock market has sunk 13 percent this year, but because the peso has fallen even further than the dollar, Americans' stock investments south of the border have sunk more than 20 percent. The Canadian dollar has also been a disaster, causing steep losses for bond funds that specialize in North American securities.
Of course, most Americans do not invest directly overseas. Instead, they use mutual funds. While some of these funds specialize in single countries, like Japan, most invest in many markets and as a result feel the effects of different currencies. This muddies the picture a bit, as does the fact that some funds try to dampen the effects of currencies by hedging their holdings, a strategy that can backfire when the dollar drops.
Even so, currencies clearly count. The Vanguard Group's fund that mimics an index of European securities would be down close to 6 percent in Continental currencies, but in dollars it has declined only 1.5 percent. The firm's index fund that invests in Pacific Rim markets has risen about 9 percent in yen, but 15.8 percent in dollars.
Americans' interest in investing overseas has been growing at a torrid pace. Five years ago, there were 59 funds specializing in foreign stocks valued at $7.2 billion; today, 217 such funds hold $83.3 billion of overseas equities, according to the Investment Company Institute, the fund industry's trade association.
The assets of global funds, which can invest at home and abroad, have increased to $53 billion, from $12 billion. And funds that invest in international bonds have risen to $37.3 billion, from $2.8 billion.
 
A New Cascade
 During the second half of last year, investors put as much into international stock funds as they put into funds that kept their money at home, according to figures from AMG Data Services. Americans' appetite for these funds seemed to slow earlier this year, as the markets began to perform badly.
But recently, money has been cascading back into international stock funds, which are getting about a third of all the money moving into stock funds. T. Rowe Price & Company reported a rebound in international stock fund sales, with its Japan fund attracting particular attention.
Renewed interest in international funds is not surprising, given that foreign funds have been doing much better than many of their domestic counterparts. The Lipper Analytical Services index of international funds has edged down 1.7 percent this year through Tuesday, while its index of funds that invest in United States growth stocks has slipped 4.4 percent.
The picture for bond funds is murkier because many worldwide fixed-income funds own a lot of Brady bonds, most of which are issued by emerging nations, Mr. McBride of Lipper said. These bonds have been highly volatile, and because they are denominated in dollars, have not felt any benefit from the recent decline. If they had been in currencies like the peso, the damage could have been worse.
 
Caution Urged
 In any event, world income funds have fallen more than 8 percent this year, while United States Government bond funds have dropped about 4.5 percent.
Though investors tend to chase attractive returns, the experts caution against the temptation. "Moving your money into a Japan fund is a pretty volatile thing to do, since the yen has already moved up very strongly," Mr. Headley said. "It could turn around at any time and weaken 15 percent."
Though in general he recommended diversifying investments by putting money overseas, Mr. Headley said he would be cautious about moving money into international markets now. If any of them dropped 5 percent or so, he said, it would be a good time to move in. For those who have already invested overseas, his advice was simple: "Sit tight."

HEADLINE: Archer Cole, New Jersey Leader For Organized Labor, Dies at 77

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Archer Cole, who spent more than 50 years in the American labor movement, the last 10 as president of the New Jersey Industrial Union Council, died on Saturday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 77 and lived in Roselle, N.J.
The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 At his death, he was also director of organization and assistant to the president of the International Union of Electrical and Electronic Workers. He helped draft the union's bargaining position for contract negotiations with the General Electric Corporation now under way in New York.
Mr. Cole, a native of New York City, graduated Phi Beta Kappa from City College. Since 1940 he served in many capacities, from shop steward to international representative to secretary to president of District 3 of the electrical workers, which covers New Jersey and New York.
"He was a great labor leader and just a wonderful human being and like a brother to me," said Bill Bywater, president of the union. "His only concern was for working people, and I never saw someone who spent so much time fighting for their interests."
 
Held Trenton Positions
 While Mr. Cole was head of the New Jersey Industrial Union Council, the membership reached 200,000 people.
He also held various public jobs. Gov. Brendan T. Byrne named him to the New Jersey Economic Recovery Commission in 1977. He was then chairman of the state's Employment Security Council through successive administrations in Trenton.
Gov. Thomas H. Kean recruited him in 1984 for a blue-ribbon Commission on Unemployment, which helped to revise the state's unemployment insurance program. He also taught labor studies at colleges, lectured and appeared on broadcast programs on behalf of organized labor.
While attending City College in the 1930's, Mr. Cole worked nights for Western Union. He was a shop steward from 1937 to 1941 before the electrical workers' union made him an organizer in Newark.
Mr. Cole is survived by his wife, Phyllis Salvato-Cole; four sons, Henry, of Upper Marlboro, Md., Fred, of New Brunswick, N.J., Stephen, of Chicago, and Theodore, of New York City; a brother, Jack Cohen of Fairfield, Conn.; a sister, Susan Kissler of Chicago, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Stocks Recover a Bit, Following the Dollar

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
After three punishing sessions in which the Dow Jones industrial average lost more than 100 points and nearly 3 percent of its value, the stock market recovered modestly yesterday as it awaited developments in the wandering course of the dollar and of commodities prices, especially for oil.
The dollar fell on Tuesday to a post-World War II record of below 100 yen to the dollar. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said yesterday that the United States and its allies were monitoring the course of the dollar and would "act as appropriate." 
 Mr. Bentsen was presumably referring to a market intervention of buying dollars to raise the dollar's value. The Federal Reserve and at least 10 European central banks did so on May 4, but the brake in the dollar's fall was temporary. Some currency traders said Mr. Bentsen's statement was too little, too late.
 
 
'Complex Situation'
 Nonetheless, the dollar rose eight-tenths of a yen yesterday, to 101.10 yen, apparently because enough traders were impressed by Mr. Bentsen's statement as well as by overnight intervention by the Japanese central bank to support the dollar.
And the stock market followed. "This is a complex situation," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers, "but for now, the stock market is following the dollar."
The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 16.80 points, to 3,724.77, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 1.75 points, to 453.09. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 3.95 points, to 712.74.
Stock traders still appeared to be largely on the sidelines. Trading volume fell to 251.1 million shares yesterday from 298.7 million shares on Tuesday. Yesterday's turnover was about 15 percent below this year's average daily volume of 295 million shares.
Some technical analysts say the low volume may indicate that selling pressure is dissipating, but other analysts say fewer and fewer potential buyers are willing to commit themselves as the market environment grows more and more complicated.
 
 
'Game of Differentials'
 For example, a strong economy normally translates to a strong currency so, at first glance, the weakness of the dollar is puzzling.
"But the markets are anticipatory," said David DeRosa, a director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. "They see Europe going from recession to turning the corner, and they see the United States going from a very strong economy to just a strong economy. So the dollar falls and the others rise in this game of differentials."
Meanwhile, the United States inflation picture grows more complex. The closely watched Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 3.42 points, to 230.87, on declining futures prices for cocoa, pork bellies and silver.
But the price of oil, which has a greater inflationary effect on the economy than agricultural goods, remains high. After spiking past $20 a barrel on June 17, August crude oil closed down 1 cent, at $19.37 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday.
 
 
Oil Supplies
 Oil prices are rising, in part, because of continued tight production quotas by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and apparent tight supplies of oil in the Midwestern United States. Refineries in the landlocked Midwest are most vulnerable to spot oil shortages because they are farther away from seaports for oil tankers.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.87 point, to 249.97, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining issues by 1,266 to 862. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.35 points, to 433.22.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 20 increased, led by I.B.M., which gained 1, to 62.
The most active stock, at 5.2 million shares, was Microsoft, which fell 1 1/8, to 51 1/2, despite Tuesday's announcement of a legal settlement in its patent dispute with Stac Electronics on important disk-compression technology.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boeing and Airbus Split Big Order

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 22

 BODY:
Splitting a potentially huge purchase between the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie, Singapore Airlines said today that it had placed orders and taken options for 52 jetliners worth as much as $10.3 billion.
The deal was seen as a blow to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. 
 More than half of the $10.3 billion figure represented options rather than firm orders. Nevertheless, analysts said Singapore Airlines' large purchase represented a vote of confidence for the long-beleaguered airline industry. "From an airline and airliner provider point of view, it's another indication that the long winter of recession is gradually turning into spring," Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with BT Securities in New York, said. "It's not overwhelmingly warm yet, but the ice is beginning to break."
Singapore Airlines placed firm orders for 11 Boeing 747-400 jumbo jets, with options for 11 more of the same model. The airline ordered 10 Airbus A340-300E's, with options for an additional 20 of the midsized four-engine aircraft. The Boeing planes will be powered by Pratt & Whitney engines, while the Airbus aircraft will use engines manufactured in France by a General Electric/Snecma joint venture. Airbus is a consortium of Aerospatiale of France, Deutsche Aerospace, British Aerospace and Construcciones Aeronauticas S.A. of Spain.
Today's order exceeded Singapore Airlines' 1990 order of $8.3 billion worth or aircraft, parts and services.
Boeing shares closed up 25 cents, at $48.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said the small movement in the stock reflected both anticipation of the deal for several months, and the fact that many of the planes ordered today would not be delivered until the turn of the century.
Deliveries of the aircraft are scheduled for the period from 1996 to 2003, and are intended for growth as well as for replacement of older 747's, according to Singapore Airlines. The airline expects to grow by 8 to 10 percent a year through the decade. The order "is an expression of our faith in the long-term health of the aviation industry and the promising future for S.I.A.," Dr. Cheong Choong Kons, the airline's director, said in a statement. Singapore Airlines, which currently operates 43 Boeing 747's, announced in February that it was evaluating various aircraft and engines to meet its needs for expansion. Singapore's fleet of 63 aircraft also includes 19 Airbus A310's.
"This order complements Singapore's existing fleet," Howard Rubel, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company, said. "It's a nice order in a rotten market, and it demonstrates that the 747 has some continuity beyond the immediately foreseeable future. In a day and age where there's a paucity of orders, an ordinary one becomes extraordinary."
In making today's order, Singapore Airlines retained the right to change its mind. The airline also has the flexibility to convert the optional order to other aircraft types: the Boeing 747-400 options may be converted to any of the three Boeing 777 models, the new twin-engine long-range plane, while the Airbus A340-300E options may be converted to A330's, a twin-engine plane of similar capacity, or A340-200's, which are smaller.
"As usual, Singapore has done a first rate job of negotiating an attractive and very flexible package of bookings without really committing to an unrealistic period of time," Mr. Demisch of BT Securities said. "The main disappointment in this is for McDonnell Douglas, which had also upgraded the MD-11 to be fully acceptable to Singapore and doesn't appear to have even been in contention."
The MD-11 is McDonnell Douglas's triple-engine, midsized aircraft. In order to fly nonstop from Singapore to Europe, both the MD-11 and the Airbus A340 had to be modified to carry more fuel.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Closely Watched Index Falls As Commodity Prices Drop

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Declining prices for commodities ranging from grains to gold caused a steep drop yesterday in a closely watched index of raw materials prices.
The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities, which recently jumped to a three-and-a-half-year high, skidded for the third consecutive day, sinking 3.42 points, to 230.87. The index dropped on declines in grain prices, livestock, cotton, coffee, cocoa, sugar, energy and precious metals. 
 Copper, however, managed to surge.
 "This is not a good day to be a bull in the commodity markets," said Jeff Wilson, editor of the Brock Report, a farm marketing newsletter.
 "A big negative factor is the increased chance of rain across the U.S. Corn Belt for the next five days," Mr. Wilson said, referring to a steep drop in grain prices this week.
 Another factor important to commodity traders, as well as the financial markets, was the stabilization of the dollar in foreign exchange trading. The dollar had tumbled to a record low against the Japanese yen on Tuesday, causing some nervous investors to buy gold. A weak dollar tends to push up gold prices.
"A slightly firmer U.S. dollar after recent sharp losses also contributed to widespread commodity market deflationary trends today," Mr. Wilson said.
 At the Chicago Board of Trade, forecasts for more rain across the Grain Belt this week drove July soybeans down 9.5 cents a bushel, to $6.67. Corn, oats and wheat also fell sharply.
"It's going to take a lot of convincing to get people to buy this market again after the shellacking it's taken," said Steve Bruce, a grain analyst at Geldermann Inc.
Mr. Bruce said previously bullish commodity funds appeared to be pulling out of the market. "Look at meats, there's general commodity liquidation," he said.
The lowest prices for wholesale beef since late 1987 set off selling at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, where live cattle for August delivery fell eight-tenths of a cent, to 62.80 cents a pound, near a six-year low set earlier this month.
The selloff in agricultural commodities means that "inflation concerns appear to be on the back burner for the time being," said Rusty Vanneman, an analyst at Pegasus Econometrics.
The easing inflation concerns also hurt precious metal prices. After rising close to 10-month highs on Monday, gold for August delivery sank $4.80 an ounce, to $389.50 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. July silver declined 22.3 cents, to $5.368.
Bucking the deflationary trend was copper, which rallied on signs of a rejuvenated Japanese economy. September copper rose 1.65 cents, to 113.6 cents a pound at the Comex.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Back to the days of expensive oil? Don't top off your tank yet.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
OIL for $20 a barrel? Is OPEC on the march again?
It would be precipitous to rush to the corner gas station to top off the tank. The surge that has raised crude oil prices by one-sixth in two weeks is largely being written off as a speculative bubble, another symptom of Wall Street's current inclination to discover inflation lurking under every bed. 
 But the oil boomlet is a reminder that the cheap fuel enjoyed by consumers over the last decade is not guaranteed by the laws of economics or nature. Indeed, some experts are convinced that the long-term trend is toward higher prices. "We've turned the corner in the cycle," said Daniel Yergin, the president of Cambridge Energy research Associates.
One recent projection, offered by the business-oriented World Energy Council in London, suggests that oil consumption will press against available supply by early in the next century. And last week the Economist magazine published a lengthy jeremiad explaining why "world energy markets will soon be roiled by surging demand."
Those inclined to such pessimism focus on projected demand from the developing countries. According to the International Energy Agency in Paris, urbanization alone sharply increases consumption, as people abandon animal power for the internal combustion engine and discover the joys of central heating. The I.E.A. believes industrializing countries will increase their energy consumption by 4 percent annually through the year 2010, compared with about 1 percent in the rest of the world.
China, the world's sixth-largest oil producer, has just become a net oil importer. Over all, Cambridge Energy Research Associates predicts, Asia will increase consumption by some eight million barrels by the year 2005 -- as much oil as is currently produced by Saudi Arabia.
There is certainly plenty of fossil fuel left below ground to meet rising demand. A good proportion of it, however, is coal, which emits roughly twice as much greenhouse-inducing carbon dioxide per unit of heat as oil or natural gas. Renewable forms of energy, like hydropower, could yield a lot more power, but at high cost. Likewise nuclear energy, whose future would be bleak even if Chernobyl was still just another anonymous provincial city in the former Soviet Union.
There is also plenty of oil and gas left, much of it extractable at low cost. The catch is that the cheap stuff is almost all in the Persian Gulf, where development and production are largely determined by geopolitics and maneuvering within the OPEC cartel. Figuring how much oil Iran, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia will sell is thus as much "a problem in game theory," as it is a question of supply and demand, notes Dale Jorgenson, an economist at Harvard.
Convinced now that prices are headed up? Morris Adelman, an economist of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, begs to differ. "It's an old story," he says; "industry opinion just doesn't take account of basic economics."
For starters, he is skeptical of the assumption that rapid economic growth in China, India and Latin America will sharply accelerate world demand for oil. As these regulation-hobbled economies modernize, he argues, they are likely to allow energy prices to rise to free market levels, which in turn, will induce conservation of energy. "The more the third world develops," he said, "the less it acts like the third world."
Then there is the question of energy supply from outside the Mideast. Lots of oil remains to be found and extracted in Russia, China, Colombia, Mexico, Vietnam and even Australia. And while capital for investing in these new areas is not plentiful at the moment, Mr. Adelman is confident that countries yearning for oil royalties are growing more realistic about sharing the risks of development with the international oil companies.
Despite differences in opinion about the future of the oil market, it is possible to find some common ground. Almost no one is predicting a rerun of the 1970's oil shocks anytime in the foreseeable future. By the same token, almost everyone agrees with William Hogan, an economist at the Kennedy School at Harvard, "that the combination of low prices and rising demand can only be sustained over the next few decades with the cooperation of the Persian Gulf producers."
In essence, then, the key difference between the optimists and the pessimists is how they expect the low-cost producers in general and Saudi Arabia in particular to behave. Mr. Adelman doubts that the Saudis have the will or the way to follow a high-price strategy. Mr. Hogan doubts that Mr. Adelman or anyone else can predict the oil producers' response to current events. "With cartels," he said, "we just don't know what we're talking about."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International A2-10
 
AWACS TO FLY THE ANDES AGAIN

HEADLINE: As Drought Looms, Farmers In California Blame Politics

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FIREBAUGH, Calif.

 BODY:
A few hundred yards from the Edmund G. (Pat) Brown Aqueduct, an old cotton trailer sits alongside Interstate 5, which slices through the parched hills and verdant rectangles of California's San Joaquin Valley. The wire mesh wagon is empty, and over it is draped a large green banner.
"NO WATER, NO FARMING. NO FARMING, NO FOOD," the sign says. It is one of several along the highway between Los Banos and Bakersfield, in letters large enough to be seen by motorists on the Interstate, the main artery between Northern and Southern California. 
 This year, as the sign suggests, the rains have once again stopped falling on California, the nation's largest producer of fruits and vegetables, and a drought watch has been declared in what water officials say will be one of the century's driest years.
But the members of the Central Valley Family Farm Alliance, which is responsible for the banners, are not imploring the heavens for rain, though that would be nice. What frustrates them are not the acts of God but those of politicians, bureaucrats and environmentalists.
California's mountain reservoirs remain nearly 90 percent full, a reflection of last year's heavy rains and conservation efforts. But farmers in the Central Valley, particularly on its more arid western side, are receiving only a fraction of the water they generally receive from Federal and state sources, in some cases only one-third, and their livelihoods are drying up along with the land.
The state's farmers have always received the largest portion of California's limited water supply, usually about 80 percent of it. But recent Federal environmental regulations have mandated that billions of gallons of water be withheld in rivers and streams to protect the dwindling supply of winter-run salmon, delta smelt and other fish decimated by the dams and water diversions of the Federal Central Valley Project.
The Endangered Species Act stipulates that large amounts of water be released from reservoirs into rivers and allowed to flow out to sea, and the Central Valley Improvement Act of 1992 will commit more water to restoring fish and wildlife and their natural habitats.
The farmers contend that the Government has broken its covenant to provide them with the water they need and has thus produced a man-made drought, impervious to natural cycles.
"A drought is O.K.; we can handle a drought," said Jim McLeod, 65, who has grown apricots and walnuts in Tracy, 65 miles east of San Francisco, for most of his life. "But this new drought is an environmental drought, a political drought, not a Mother Nature drought. The Government wanted a good, reliable source of food, and we did it. We're eating better than anybody in history. And now we're destroying it."
To conservationists, however, the changes in water allocation corrected a long-term imbalance that allowed farmers to waste heavily subsidized water on some crops and to grow other crops ill-suited to the arid terrain. The newly struck balance, these people believe, atones for environmental hubris in California -- a state that "has gone to extravagant lengths to deny that it is a desert," Marc Reisner, the author of "Cadillac Desert: The American West and Its Disappearing Water" (Penguin Books), has written.
Fishermen said the historical imbalance has crippled the state's once-thriving fishing industry. "A lot of us feel the water was stolen," said Zeke Grader, executive director of the Pacific Coast Federation of Fishermen's Associations. "Fish is a food product, too."
Officials say the tug of war is a reminder of the political complexity of water, an issue that historically pitted farmers and cities against conservationists but over which farmers now stand largely alone.
 
Few Signs of Drought
 "The pendulum has shifted quite abruptly, and they've not had the time to make the adjustment," said Douglas P. Wheeler, the state secretary of resources.
Farmers concede their power is eroding. "The scary thing is the transition between now and then, and the number of people's lives that get trampled in the process," said Jason Peltier of the Central Valley Project Water Association, a growers' group in Sacramento.
Driving into Firebaugh, a sun-baked agricultural community of 5,000 about 120 miles southeast of San Francisco, there are few signs of any drought, natural or legislated. Fields of onions and garlic destined to become powdered condiments and fields of tomatoes earmarked for ketchup and pizza sauce shimmer in the late afternoon sun, nourished by sprinklers spitting out what was once the mountain snow pack.
But here and in surrounding towns on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley, where only five-and-a-half inches of rain fall in an average year, hundreds of thousands of acres that once produced cotton, tomatoes and cantaloupes have reverted to sagebrush and tumbleweed.
Chris Hurd, who grows almonds, onions and cotton, said that 600 of his 2,000 acres near Firebaugh lie fallow this year, and that his property has lost half its value since 1989. "I'm only hiring the minimum amount of people because I don't want to turn around and lay them off," he said. "I have no long-range plans, except three things: no risk, no debt, no growth."
Asked to predict the area's future, Mr. Hurd, 43 years old, replied: "More and more depressed. More and more foreclosures. People migrating out."
In Firebaugh, named for the Scotsman whose ferry forded what was once the San Joaquin River and is now a riparian corpse, unemployment, mainly of migrant workers, stands at 43 percent. At least a third of that is attributable to diminished water, contended Dr. Marcia Sablan, the town's Mayor.
A riot broke out last summer when hundreds of job applicants descended on the N. T. Gargulio tomato-packing plant in Firebaugh. Last year, for the first time, federally financed housing for migrant workers did not fill up.
Fifteen years ago, the town had 20 bars; now there are 3. And as Louis Thomason, the John Deere dealer, and John West, who handles Case-International tractors, are having trouble selling equipment, Firebaugh is losing a major source of sales tax. "I don't think the town will ever go back to the boom era of the 60's and 70's," Dr. Sablan said.
 
An Urban Shift
 For California agriculture, the mid-20th century was a time of plenty. There was plenty of political power, plenty of profits and plenty of water, once Federal and state authorities channeled it from one end of the state to the other. The Central Valley Project, begun in the 1930's, evolved into an intricate network of dams, reservoirs, pumping stations and canals: 600 miles of silver ribbons bringing water to 20,000 farmers and three million acres of once arid land.
But agriculture's influence here has diminished greatly. The state is increasingly urbanized, with fewer financial or sentimental attachments to the land, particularly to the huge agribusiness holdings of the Central Valley.
As Californians have concentrated in cities, they have come to care more about the country. Urban interests, which once joined with farmers to build more dams, now align themselves with conservationists.
"We concluded that the environmental problems are real, and that you don't have to ruin the California economy to solve them," said Timothy H. Quinn of the Metropolitan Water District, which serves Los Angeles. "We don't think the core of the problem is that we haven't poured enough concrete."
 
The Fish Story
 Nowadays, the pumps that once lifted water over the hills of Central and Southern California are running at only partial capacity; horsepower has been replaced by fish power.
The Central Valley Project Improvement Act of 1992, signed by President George Bush over heated opposition by Gov. Pete Wilson of California, will channel between one-fifth and one-sixth of project water to rivers, estuaries and habitats in the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta for the restoration of fish and wildlife.
Still more could be diverted under more stringent water quality standards promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency last December that will require that additional fresh water be flushed through to reduce salinity in the delta.
Mr. Wilson denounced those standards, which he said threatened the state's agricultural economy, and asked state officials to devise an alternative. Last month, at the behest of farmers in the Western San Joaquin Valley, a Federal judge in Fresno enjoined enforcement of the Central Valley Improvement Act. Both topics were discussed at a hearing yesterday of the subcommittee on water and power of Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, whose chairman is Senator Bill Bradley.
 
A Partisan Issue
 The conflicting demands of California's farmers, conservationists and cities could become an issue in this fall's election, though water clearly flows across party lines. Environmentalists feel betrayed by Mr. Wilson, who appealed for their support during his 1990 campaign and is running for re-election now. "He essentially turned his back on most of the environmental community," said Tom Graff of the Environmental Defense Fund in Oakland.
But they are not yet comfortable with Mr. Wilson's Democratic rival, State Treasurer Kathleen Brown, whose father was an architect of the state water system and whose brother, Edmund G. Brown Jr., pushed unsuccessfully for the Peripheral Canal, a mammoth public works project that would have diverted yet more water from the delta.
Over the last 10 years, 100,000 acres in the Central Valley have been converted from grains, barley and other water-thirsty crops to more efficient row crops like tomatoes or melons. Farmers have also improved irrigation.
Phillip L. Isenberg, a Democratic state assemblyman from Sacramento and an authority on water policy, called the dispute "one of last gasps of an agriculture-dominated society."
"The world that they, their grandfathers and great-grandfathers knew," he said, "isn't around anymore -- and can never return."

HEADLINE: Korean Talks: Looking for Options

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Now that the North Koreans and the United States have finally agreed to hold high-level negotiations, the Clinton Administration confronts a difficult problem: defining what the talks are supposed to accomplish and how.
The agreement to hold the talks, and North Korea's agreement to freeze its nuclear program as long as the negotiations are under way, has removed the immediate sense of crisis and reduced tensions on the Korean peninsula. It has also enabled the White House to focus again on its domestic agenda and to insulate the Administration from charges that it is allowing the North Korean nuclear program to proceed apace. 
 But while the Administration has defined its goals to prevent North Korea from becoming a nuclear power in broad terms, officials concede that Washington must still confront a number of critical issues between now and when the talks resume in early July.
"A lot of work has been done, but we need to take a fresh look at the issues on the table," said a senior Administration official. "We need to look at both sides of the equation: what we want to see from the North and what we are willing to do on our side."
 
Problems and Benefits
 These are some of the key issues:
*How does Washington make the temporary freeze of the North Korean nuclear program, which was agreed on this week, a permanent one?
*How hard does Washington press the North Koreans to learn about its past efforts to divert plutonium? North Korea has already destroyed the best evidence about its past plutonium production.
*What financial and diplomatic benefits does Washington offer in return? The North Koreans say they want light-water reactors, but the Administration has yet to work out a plan detailing which nation might provide the nuclear technology and who would pay for them. Washington also has to decide how to respond to the North Korean demand that the United States formally pledge not to use nuclear weapons if fighting breaks out.
The resumption of the high-level negotiations, which will be held in Geneva, has been under discussion for months.
 
Looking at Possibilities
 North Korea had long offered to freeze its nuclear program if the talks were held. Until last week, however, the Administration believed that a freeze was not a sufficient basis for resuming the negotiations, insisting instead that North Korea preserve evidence that would reveal any prior diversion of nuclear material.
But with the North Koreans poised to leap forward on the nuclear front and the Administration confronting resistance in marshaling economic sanctions, the White House decided to see if former President Jimmy Carter's visit to Pyongyang offered a possibility for a breakthrough.
In seeking the talks, the Administration is not proceeding on blind faith. It received North Korean assurance that it will agree to a "verifiable" freeze on key elements of its nuclear program.
Under the freeze, the North Koreans will allow inspectors to monitor the nuclear fuel it has removed from its Yongbyon reactor and put in a cooling pond. They also promised to refrain from reprocessing the fuel to make plutonium and pledged not to reload the reactor.
But the North Koreans have only promised to freeze their program through the next round of the high-level talks. Also putting pressure on Washington is an important technical consideration.
The nuclear fuel rods that the North Koreans have removed from their reactor are in a cooling pond. The rods are covered with a magnesium oxide cladding that deteriorates over time. American officials fear that the North Koreans may insist after the round of high-level talks that the rods be taken for safety reasons to their reprocessing plant.
 
Concern Over Fuel Rods
 Nations that have joined the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty are allowed to reprocess spent fuel and produce plutonium if it is done under international controls.
Administration officials say that it may take six months to a year before the rods have deteriorated to the point where they have to be moved. And some advanced nuclear nations, like Britain, have learned how to keep the rods in ponds for years.
But the North Koreans told Selig Harrison, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace who recently visited North Korea, that the rods need to be removed in about two months.
The concern over the fuel rods has raised some key questions: how much negotiating capital does Mr. Clinton want to expend to prevent the North Koreans from expanding their program, and how much to determine the amount of plutonium it diverted in the past years? And if progress is made, what happens to the fuel rods?
The issue of how much emphasis to put on past diversion of plutonium already divides Pentagon officials, who are most concerned with preventing the North Koreans from making new bombs, and State Department officials, who stress the need to strengthen the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty by uncovering the exact state of the North Korean program.

HEADLINE: Emerging Plan Is Still Costly, Still Complex

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The health care proposal being developed within the Senate Finance Committee, like President Clinton's plan, is technically complicated, difficult to administer and expensive, health policy experts said today.
The proposal relies on changes in insurance regulations, taxes on some businesses, subsidies to low-income people and a provision that could require people to buy insurance if they did not get it through their employers. 
 The new proposal, devised by conservative Democrats and moderate Republicans, calls for Federal regulation of health insurance practices and other changes to make insurance more available. If more than 5 percent of Americans -- about 12 million people -- still lacked coverage in the year 2002, an independent agency would recommend further steps that Congress could take to provide coverage for them.
If Congress did not act within six months of receiving those recommendations, an "individual mandate" would go into effect, requiring people to buy insurance for themselves. The Government would subsidize premiums for people with low and moderate incomes. The subsidies would be financed, in part, by taxing the insurance benefits offered by the most generous employers.
Concerns about the proposal fall into several areas.
COUNTING THE UNINSURED It sounds easy, but no one has a reliable way of counting the people who have no health insurance. The Census Bureau does an annual survey, but it is flawed because people surveyed often do not distinguish between being without coverage at a specific time and being without it for an entire year.
Moreover, health policy experts say, if people are required to carry health insurance and there are penalties to enforce that requirement, they will have a strong incentive to say they have coverage even if they do not.
TAXES The proposal under discussion in the Finance Committee would impose a new Federal tax on "high-cost health insurance plans." But tax lawyers say it is very difficult to measure the cost and value of health benefits. Costs vary with the age of the worker, family size, place of residence and other factors. Medical care for older blue-collar workers in high-risk industries like mining is more expensive than care for young white-collar workers in safe, clean industries like data processing.
The new taxes would almost surely be passed on to consumers, economists say. Moreover, a tax on high-cost plans would often be a tax on traditional fee-for-service medicine, which tends to be more expensive than health maintenance organizations. Such organizations provide care for a fixed monthly premium but often limit the patients' choices of doctors.
SUBSIDIES Insurance for a family can cost $4,000 or $6,000 a year, and if subsidies were not large enough, people would be unable to afford it. However, if the subsidies were generous, they would be expensive for the Government. It is not clear that backers of the new proposal are willing to spend the amounts needed.
Further, if the Government offers substantial subsidies but does not require employers to buy insurance for workers, it creates a strong incentive for employers to drop coverage they now provide, experts say. That would raise the cost of the subsidies even further because more people would need them.
Marilyn Moon, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, said, "The success of this proposal will rise or fall on the generosity of the subsidies."
Joshua M. Wiener, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, explained: "If subsidies are limited to very low-income people, you don't solve the problem of the uninsured. If subsidies are not so limited, they become very expensive, and it will be attractive for employers to drop coverage. Employers will ask why they should pay for health insurance if the Government will pay for it."
The proposal being developed in the Senate Finance Committee would provide subsidies to people with incomes 2.4 times the official poverty level. For a family of four, the income ceiling would be $35,433 a year.
The proposal to require people to buy health insurance if coverage does not reach a specified goal is known as a trigger.
Richard I. Smith, director of health policy at the Association of Private Pension and Welfare Plans, a trade group composed mainly of Fortune 500 companies, said: "In all likelihood, the triggers would be pulled. Voluntary efforts are unlikely to get coverage up to 95 percent, unless the subsidies are extremely generous and hence expensive."
One purpose of the changes in regulations contained in the proposal is to make insurance more affordable for small businesses. But there is no guarantee such a result would occur. Mr. Wiener, a health policy expert at the Brookings Institution, said, "If you reform the health insurance market so that everyone can get coverage, many sick and disabled people will come into the insurance pool, raising the price." If premiums rise, healthy young people may drop their coverage.
William S. Custer, research director of the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a nonpartisan organization whose members include businesses and labor unions, said, "Premiums may go up for small employers who already have insurance if you put them in a pool with nonworkers and Medicaid recipients," who tend to have higher health care costs.
President Clinton's proposal would require employers to pay at least 80 percent of the cost of health insurance for their workers. Employees would pay a maximum of 20 percent. The Finance Committee group would not require employers to pay anything; the employees' share could be much more than 20 percent, and the cost of Government subsidies could grow accordingly.
Subsidies under the Clinton plan would cost more than $100 billion a year. Under the proposal emerging from the Finance Committee, the subsidies would presumably be more expensive because employers would contribute less.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Tries to Fill Strikers' Jobs

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EAST PEORIA, Ill., June 23

 BODY:
Managers, supervisors and other white-collar employees of Caterpillar Inc. began toiling on assembly lines this morning, confident that they could build at least a few engines, bulldozers, road graders and other heavy machines while the company's 14,000 union workers were on strike outside.
On the picket lines, members of the United Automobile Workers were openly contemptuous of Caterpillar's ability to operate factories long without them. About a dozen plants are on strike. 
 "It would take someone two years to learn how to operate my press," said Rocky Dewitt, 44, explaining how he adjusts 20 tons of pressure to turn powdered metal into a solid part. "The last time they tried this, the foremen wrecked some of the machines. No way unskilled people can put out quality parts the way we do."
His statements fit the tone of more than two years of labor-management acrimony and work stoppages. On Monday, union members walked off the job over working conditions and compensation. Both sides were posturing a bit, trying to improve morale in the face of what labor and union spokesmen concede could be a long strike after a short negotiating session among the U.A.W., Caterpillar officials and Federal mediators in Indianapolis made no progress.
"Most labor conflicts are controlled conflicts," said Harry Katz, a professor of labor relations at Cornell University. "This looks like it could be a fight to the death."
 
Bitter History
 Caterpillar has had miserable labor relations for decades, experiencing 14 strikes with its last 16 labor contracts. Relations have sunk to a new low in recent months as union workers and supervisors have increasingly wrangled over incidents of petty harassment, work slowdowns and displays of union activism on the factory floor.
By assigning engineers and accountants to do the work of assembly workers, Caterpillar is trying to demonstrate that it is strong enough to operate despite a strike. Indeed, 1993 was a banner year financially, and the board recently doubled the dividend on common stock. By hiring new workers and inviting striking workers to cross the picket line, Caterpillar may exert enough pressure on U.A.W. leaders to force them to negotiate economic issues that will lower labor costs and allow the union to save face.
In 1991, Caterpillar raised the idea of two-tiered wages to save money for the company. Some workers would be paid about $8 to start, compared with the current minimum of $17 an hour. Caterpillar also wants to spend less on medical benefits by having employees join a preferred-provider plan. That type of insurance costs less than plans that allow free choices of doctors and hospitals.
In making that proposal, Caterpillar was rejecting the standard contract signed by other equipment manufacturers, a move that stunned labor relations experts and brought on a bitter five-month strike in late 1991. During that strike, it operated factories with management workers and some union members who crossed picket lines. Caterpillar also began accepting applications for replacement workers, badly frightening union workers and encouraging the union to call off the strike in the spring of 1992.
 
Debate in the Senate
 Current law permits the hiring of replacements during a strike over economic issues but forbids replacement workers in strikes over unfair labor practices. The Senate is set to debate a bill, strongly supported by unions, that would also forbid the hiring of replacements during strikes over unfair labor practices. A Peoria Journal Star editorial this morning questioned whether the Caterpillar walkout might have been timed by the union to coincide with the Senate debate, an idea a U.A.W. spokesman dismissed as "ridiculous."
The prospect that Caterpillar may once more move to replace union workers has caused the union to portray the current walkout as a dispute over unfair labor practices, not over compensation or pattern bargaining, the practice of negotiating one standard contract for all companies in an industry. "All you do is wear a little button and the foremen tell you to stop doing union business," said a picket who declined to give his name. "They're like the communists."
Terry Thorstenson, a Caterpillar spokesman, said the company was hiring permanent workers. But he has been careful not to use the word "replacement," he said. An increasing number of union workers have crossed picket lines since Tuesday, he said, when it was estimated that 26 percent of the 7,500 workers in the Peoria area had shown up for work. The company has declined to provide numbers since then.
A U.A.W. spokesman disputed Mr. Thorstenson's estimate of how many had crossed the picket line. "They're backing off the numbers game. We are rock-solid."
Mr. Thorstenson accused some workers of mischief designed to disrupt the plant, but the union denies that.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As Caterpillar's white-collar workers began working on the assembly lines, members of the striking United Automobile Workers scorned the company's long-term ability to run the factories without them. As rain fell yesterday near Aurora, Ill., pickets yelled at a passing motorist near the entrance to the Caterpillar plant. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Skippy Maker Follows Crowd and Revamps

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
CPC International Inc., the maker of Skippy peanut butter, said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of $227 million in the second quarter to close several plants and cut its work force by 2,600 people, or nearly 7 percent.
CPC, which also makes Hellmann's mayonnaise, Thomas' English muffins and Knorr soups, said the cost of the revamping after taxes would be $137 million, or 92 cents a share, and would not change the company's expected earnings for the year. 
 The moves come as many of CPC's competitors, like the Sara Lee Corporation, the Procter & Gamble Company, and the Quaker Oats Company, have also announced reorganization plans. Like them, CPC is healthy -- its earnings grew by 6.1 percent last year before adjustments for several one-time charges -- and the economic recovery in both the United States and Europe should increase its sales this year. But CPC insisted that it must cut costs to remain competitive.
"We see the business improving," Charles R. Shoemate, chairman and chief executive of CPC, said in an interview. "But we also see a very competitive industry where everyone is trying to improve."
Several industry analysts agreed. "They are not doing this because earnings are going south, but because they want to make sure that they will continue to go north," said Nomi Ghez, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Ms. Ghez said that despite some recent factory closings, including six in the United States during the last four years, the company still had more than the number of manufacturing operations in Europe and the United States than was justified by the anemic sales growth and rising competition in those markets.
"It's essentially a slow-growth business," Ms. Ghez said. "I would not be surprised to see more food companies taking restructuring charges in this environment."
Mr. Shoemate said the bulk of the job losses would come from the company's two biggest units: the consumer products divisions in the United States and Europe. A CPC spokesman said the cuts would be in rough proportion to the geographic distribution of the company's global sales.
About 40 percent of CPC's $6.7 billion in revenue last year came from Europe, while 36 percent came from the United States and 17 percent came from Latin America. The company, based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has bakeries in the Bronx and Greenwich, Conn., as well as three other plants and a research and development operation in New Jersey.
Mr. Shoemate said the lowering of trade barriers in North America, South America and Europe had also been a catalyst for the reorganization. As a result, he said, the company can consolidate the production of various product lines across borders rather than make the same item in several different countries.
About two-thirds of the charge for the reorganization will be used to write off assets, including some plant closings, during the next 18 months to two years. The remaining money will be used to reduce the staff of 39,000.
Shares of CPC were unchanged, at $50.875, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
In the past, Mr. Shoemate has expressed frustration that CPC's share price was not higher even though the company's financial performance was positive. In the interview yesterday, he said he had been satisfied with the stock's performance during the bear market this year. But he also said he expected to lift the company's earnings above the current position, near the middle of CPC's main rivals in the United States food industry.
