HEADLINE: Council Chief Wheels and Deals, And New York's Budget Is Passed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
In the hours before the City Council voted yesterday to approve New York City's new budget, Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone invited a number of his fellow Democrats into his City Hall office. One by one, he beseeched them to ignore their misgivings and to support Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's austere $31.6 billion budget.
But he did more than plead. To some he promised perks for their districts; to others assignments to prestigious committees. And to those who still resisted, he promised a brand of rebuke only the Speaker himself could unleash -- loss of money for their districts and perks for themselves. 
 The strategy paid off handsomely, and the Speaker won a 43-to-8 victory, with only 8 of the Council's 44 Democrats opposing a budget that largely reflected the priorities of the city's new Republican Mayor.
As Speaker, Mr. Vallone controls a $4 million discretionary fund that finances community-based organizations in members' districts and adds to his persuasive powers. Each member who supported the budget received at least $80,000 from the fund. Those who voted against it received about $50,000.
In addition, he parceled out several millions more for small construction projects in the district. Also, Council members said the Speaker's staff had made clear that committee chairmanships -- which can add anywhere between $2,000 and $24,000 to their annual base salaries of $55,000 -- were also at risk with a vote against the budget, although no Council members have yet been stripped of their positions.
Mr. Vallone insisted that the payments were not used to penalize opponents but rather to reward supporters. "But that doesn't mean that if you vote against the budget, you're going to be rewarded," he said. "The only thing that makes a political party work is loyalty. It has to stand for something. And of course you're going to be rewarded with political perks."
One of those being rewarded yesterday was Lloyd Henry, who represents East Flatbush, Brooklyn. When the budget was being considered, he had deep misgivings about how heavy the cuts would fall on his mostly black, working-class constituents.
"I was being lobbied from all sides," he said. "The unions wanted a no vote and the Speaker's staff, of course, wanted me to go along with them."
What persuaded Mr. Henry to vote for the budget were promises by the Speaker's staff for an additional $52,000 for senior-citizen and youth-service centers in his district, plus the promise of added money for a Caribbean cultural center at Medgar Evers College.
"As a junior member of the Council who was just elected last year, I wanted to be able to bring something back home to my district," Mr. Henry said. "By voting no, I risked losing everything at my first time at bat."
 
Much Soul-Searching
 Even so, there was much soul-searching among Council Democrats yesterday as they pondered their reasons for supporting a budget that, even they acknowledged, could cripple some of the basic services that their neediest constituents depend upon.
And the lopsided vote left many Council members and Democratic officials outside of City Hall questioning whether Mr. Giuliani would face any significant opposition in the future.
"It says that, as Democrats, as a counter-voice to Mayor Giuliani, we're in trouble," said Joan Griffin McCabe, a Councilwoman from Brooklyn, who was one of the eight Democrats who voted against the budget. "It says that many of my colleagues need to recognize the responsibility we have been charged with and, as a group of Democrats, we are missing it big time."
In their speeches on the floor of the Council chamber before the vote, many liberal Democrats voiced clear disdain for a budget that slashes funds for public hospitals and social services while leaving the Police Department untouched. They included the overwhelming majority of the Council's black and Hispanic caucus, who only a few months ago stated firmly that they would not support a budget that hurt their constituents.
 
'Difficult Decision'
 In supporting it, many maintained that it was one of the most agonizing decisions of their legislative careers. "It was a tremendourly difficult decision for me," said Una Clarke, who represents part of the Flatbush and Crown Heights neighborhoods in Brooklyn. "But for the residents of my district, a no vote would have been an irresponsible act on my part."
To Mr. Vallone, the political maneuvering in the budget vote is an annual drama, a test of his ability to display unity among the Council members and a means of demonstrating to the Mayor -- whether a Republican or a Democrat -- that the Speaker is a major force in the city's leadership who can command the allegiance of the Council on votes he considers crucial.
"This is what I consider a key institutional vote," Mr. Vallone said in an interview yesterday. "It sends a message to the Mayor and to the city that despite our grievances, we can put aside our differences in party, in color, in economic background, and figure out what's best for the city."
But even with the pressure, some members could not set aside the differences. C. Virginia Fields, the Councilwoman who represents most of Harlem and the Upper West Side of Manhattan, was the subject of some of the most intense lobbying late Wednesday night, not only from Mr. Vallone but also from her fellow black Council members.
Just before the meeting, several black legislators tried to persuade her to support the budget and not risk her position as chairwoman of one of the Council's land-use subcommittees.
"In the final analysis, I just couldn't vote for a budget that had such a severe impact on health care, on education and on social services in my district," said Ms. Fields. She said that although none of Mr. Vallone's aides had discussed her position as head of the subcommittee, she was prepared to lose the spot, for which she is paid an additional $7,500 a year. But she said her allocation of so-called member items, too, was reduced to $50,000 from the $80,000 she typically receives.
Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, who represents the Upper West Side of Manhattan, said her allocation of discretionary funds was similarly cut. She also said she was prepared for Mr. Vallone to ask her to step down as chairwoman of the Council's contracts committee.
 
'Their Loss'
 "If they take it, they take it," she said. "It will be their loss. I'm constantly surprised by how important these positions are to some people in the Council. But it really is a question of integrity. The Speaker asked me to vote for it. But I just can't vote for something I oppose."
In addition to Ms. Eldridge, Ms. Fields and Ms. McCabe, Council members opposing the budget were Sal F. Albanese and Annette M. Robinson of Brooklyn, Thomas K. Duane, Guillermo Linares and Adam Clayton Powell 4th of Manhattan.
In the Council meeting, several of its 21-member black and Hispanic caucus took pains to defend their decision to vote in favor of the budget, although they each contended that Mr. Giuliani's fiscal plan was likely to be felt most severely by black and Hispanic New Yorkers.
Some caucus members said they voted for the bill because it included restorations of some projects initially eliminated by Mr. Giuliani -- money for designing a new police academy in the Bronx and funds for youth programs, for example.
Mr. Linares, who represents Washington Heights in Manhattan, said that even though he was in the minority by voting against the budget, he could easily understand the pressures felt by his colleagues. "This was a difficult decision for each of us," he said. "Everyone had something to weigh, some feeling of conflict, some reason to spend time deliberating this. In some way, it was kind of a defining moment for all of us."

HEADLINE: The Market Gives Back Earlier Gain

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market gave back all of the previous day's gains and more yesterday, despite a stable dollar, nearly steady bond prices and falling commodities prices, which are normally conditions for a market rally.
Still, some analysts said they were optimistic about an upturn in the market. "The market will stumble upward," said Alfred Goldman, director of market analysis for A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. 
 Mr. Goldman said the Dow Jones industrial average had risen about 200 points in the last five weeks, but in the last few days, had given back more than half the gains. "People are going to understand this is an opportunity market," he said. "When stocks are being thrown out of windows, it behooves you to hold a basket underneath and selectively catch some."
Still, traders appear to have some reason to worry about the three main factors that move markets, which are inflation, interest rates and corporate earnings. Inflation appears to be tame, but the weakened dollar has increased pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to attract foreign investors to United States assets, including stocks.
Moreover, there was scattered anxiety among traders about the prospect of a slowing economy, brought about by the Fed's previous increases in interest rates, leading to lower second-quarter earnings. Companies start reporting financial results in two weeks or so. Recently, Lotus Development, Unisys and Cheyenne Software warned that their earnings were likely to disappoint Wall Street.
Yesterday, the Dow fell below 3,700 for the first time since May 16. The Dow dropped 25.68 points, to 3,699.09. On Wednesday, it rose nearly 17 points. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 3.46 points, to 449.63, after rising 1.75 points on Wednesday. Sears, Roebuck, General Motors, Philip Morris, I.B.M. and Coca-Cola all fell.
Especially hard hit was the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index, which fell 11.89 points, to 700.85, a decline of nearly 1.7 percent. Computer technology stocks like Microsoft, Cisco Systems, Oracle and Intel all fell amid concern that a slower economy would hurt the demand for computers and related products.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.68 points, to 248.29, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining stocks by 720 to 1,424. The American Stock Exchange market value index was off 1.97 points, to 431.25.
The most active stock, at 14.6 million shares, was Cisco Systems, a computer-networking company, which fell 2 1/2, to 21, on concern among Wall Street analysts that the company's earnings would be hurt by a slowing economy.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Pause After Recent Turmoil

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed in quiet trading yesterday, as the currency market took a breather from the volatility that had sent the American currency plunging to a record low against the Japanese yen earlier this week.
For a second day, the Federal Reserve and other central banks failed to intervene in the market to support the dollar. But traders' continuing fears of possible central bank intervention helped prevent the heavy selling that shook the market on Tuesday, when the dollar fell below 100 yen in New York trading. 
 "The market is playing it close to the vest in case there's an intervention," said Kevin Lawrie, manager of foreign exchange for Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
 
 
Little Changed Against Yen
 Yesterday, the dollar showed little change against the yen. In late New York trading, it was quoted at 101.40 yen, up slightly from 101.10 yen Wednesday.
The dollar also slipped to 1.6025 German marks from 1.6050 marks.
The dollar traded in a narrow range for much of the day. It rose briefly in early trading on rumors that the Fed was buying dollars, but it fell back when the rumors were denied.
Only the Bank of Japan has intervened in the market this week to keep the yen from surging against the dollar.
In Europe, the German central bank's decision not to reduce key interest rates quashed a late dollar rally in a market that had been expecting a cut. Lower German interest rates would have brought European rates closer to American rates and stimulated capital flows into dollar-denominated investments.
"In terms of the week we've had, today has been a nonevent," said Paul Alley, an associate at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan's New York office.
But analysts warned that the dollar's volatility did not appear to be over.
 
 
Agitated Market
 "The potential exists for some reasonably wide swings in the next couple of days," Mr. Alley said. "The market definitely appears to be agitated, and when that happens it takes a while before things settle down.
"We're still sitting on the edge of the dollar going into a total abyss against the yen; we're still in a downtrend."
Traders said the currency market showed little reaction to a Government report that factory orders for durable goods surged nine-tenths of 1 percent in May, providing further evidence of the strength of the American economy.
Among other currencies, the British pound rose to $1.5395 in New York, from $1.5315 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: New Signs Of Slowdown In Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Fresh evidence of a decelerating economy appeared today as a moderate overall rise in new orders for durable goods was accompanied by the fourth consecutive decline in orders for equipment to be used by nonmilitary manufacturers.
Orders for durable goods -- items from toasters to helicopters designed to last at least three years -- climbed nine-tenths of 1 percent in May, aided by another double-digit gain in military contracts, Commerce Department figures show. While this advance was somewhat bigger than expected, many analysts regarded the report over all as pointing to a slackening of economic growth. 
 "The economy continues to expand modestly, slowing from the rapid-fire growth of six months ago," said Robert D. Barr, deputy chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce.
He added that durable goods, generally big-ticket items requiring financing, might be an early casualty of the rise in interest rates, which began last fall and was accelerated by the Federal Reserve in February.
 
 
Jobless Benefits Edge Up
 In a separate report, the Labor Department said today that first-time claims for unemployment benefits inched up 3,000, to 352,000, last week. On a four-week average, initial claims edged down to 355,000, a bit lower than in late spring but otherwise the highest in more than a year, according to Merrill Lynch & Company.
The reports released today will likely serve as further evidence for the Federal Reserve that the economy, while still expanding, is cooling, and that it need not rush to raise rates again to head off inflation.
"Here's an indicator that's steady but not out of control," said Patrick J. Moriarty, chief investment officer at Bank Julius Baer in New York, referring to the report on durable goods. The May rise, he noted, was the result of increases for military goods, which is not likely to continue, and in orders for commercial jets, which are delivered over long periods.
 
 
Economy Showing Strength
 At the same time, the economy seems strong enough to withstand another Fed tightening if it should decide higher interest rates are needed to support the dollar in international current markets.
The advance in durable good orders for May, to $148.4 billion, included a 2.2 percent jump for transportation equipment, a 4.7 percent rise for the much smaller primary metals group and a negligible one-tenth of 1 percent rise for industrial machinery and equipment.
On the other hand, new orders for electronic and other electrical equipment skidded 5 percent, a result thought by some to be an anomaly in light of a long period of robust growth.
Excluding military goods, orders were up four-tenths of 1 percent, less than half the overall gain, the report showed.
Within capital goods industries, orders for durable goods rose 1.1 percent over all but were down eight-tenths of 1 percent -- the fourth consecutive decline -- when tanks, planes and other military items were excluded. Military orders alone soared 11.9 percent, to $7.1 billion, after a 28.7 percent leap in April and a 20.1 percent drop in March.
Nonmilitary capital goods excluding aircraft and parts -- a gauge of underlying investment by business -- slumped 2.5 percent after a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in April.

HEADLINE: Will a Falling Dollar Bring Inflation? Not Necessarily

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Inflation fears fanned by the dollar's fall this week are overblown, many economists say. Despite all the talk about the global economy, they say, the United States is more insulated than most countries against such shocks.
A popular rule of thumb among specialists is that a 10 percent drop in the dollar against the rest of the world's currencies would add no more than one percentage point to the inflation rate over the next year or two. The rule is based partly on the fact that imports account for only a tenth of all goods and services sold in the United States, so changes in their prices are heavily diluted. 
 But some economists now question even this figure, saying that the actual effect may be much less. In fact, they say, it may be negligible for the 3 percent drop in the dollar against the yen and German mark in the last two weeks.
"There's enough downspin to inflation still that even with this, you still have a good chance of coming in under last year's increase" in consumer prices, said David C. Munro, a longtime White House economic forecaster who now works for High Frequency Economics in Manhattan.
Mr. Munro, who is anticipating more interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve to keep inflation under control, estimated that even a 5 percent fall in the value of the yen and the mark would increase consumer prices in the United States by only four-hundredths of a percentage point.
Indeed, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, played down the globalization of the economy on Wednesday, during Congressional testimony. "At this point, we have little aggregate evidence that the increased openness of the United States economy over the past several decades has substantially altered the process of domestic price formation," he said.
Mr. Munro and other economists point out that foreign companies have passed on less and less of their losses from exchange rate movements in recent years, choosing instead to try to keep prices low and preserve their market shares. This means American companies have had less opportunity to raise their own prices.
 
Imports Priced in Dollars
 Economists also note that more of America's imports are coming from oil-producing countries that price their shipments in dollars or from East Asian and Latin American countries that tie their currencies informally to the dollar.
In the short run, a drop in the dollar against the yen or German mark has little effect on this growing share of American trade, although specialists caution that in the longer term, a drop might provoke Middle Eastern countries to raise oil prices to assure that it still takes the same number of barrels of oil to buy a Mercedes or a Sony television.
The dollar has simultaneously been strengthening in recent weeks against a few currencies, notably the Canadian dollar, said Jeffrey J. Schott, an economist at the Institute for International Economics. American imports last year from Canada nearly equaled imports from Japan and Germany combined.
Moreover, as dramatic as a record low against the yen always seems, the dollar has not really fallen very much in the last two weeks. Inflation depends on the size of the drop, not whether a yen is worth a penny for the first time. So inflation is unlikely to rise just because a dollar now buys 101 yen instead of 104 at the beginning of last week, or buys 1.6 German marks instead of 1.65 marks.
Yet such calculations, by themselves, are not likely to reassure the Federal Reserve, many economists say. The central bank has already raised interest rates four times this year so as to forestall the possibility of inflationary increases. And like falling bond prices, a falling exchange rate may be a clue that investors, expecting higher inflation ahead, are moving into other currencies first. In that case, most economists concur, higher interest rates are needed.
"If the falling dollar is the first sign of inflation, like the approaching clouds of a hurricane that you can see if you have a sharp eye, then a little bit of intervention in the exchange markets is not the right response at all," said William Poole, a Brown University monetary economist often mentioned as a future Republican nominee to the Federal Reserve.
 
Big Indirect Effect
 Other economists who rely on big computer models remain convinced that a falling dollar does have a big effect on inflation. They focus not on the direct effect of rising import prices, but rather on the indirect effect that a lower dollar may have in encouraging American exports. Cheaper dollars allow people in Germany or Japan to pay fewer marks or yen for a new Buick, and when the economy is already operating at or near full capacity, as it is now, growing exports could cause the economy to overheat, feeding inflation.
"The U.S. economy is in a more inflation-prone condition now than it was two or three years ago," said Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers. "The vulnerability to inflation from a sustained drop in the dollar now would be greater."
But there is little agreement on exactly how vulnerable. While DRI/ McGraw-Hill, in Lexington, Mass., assumes that the indirect effect outweighs the direct effects, Mr. Munro said that the indirect effect was too small even to be measured.
The strongest consensus is that the falling dollar will most affect Americans who go to Europe or Japan and find the restaurants and hotels much more expensive in dollar terms. "It's terrible," said Patrick J. Conway, an associate professor of economics at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. "I'm leaving on Saturday and I'm lucky, I'm jumping right over Europe and Japan to Central Asia, where the dollar still stands tall."

HEADLINE: American Love Affair With the Auto May Doom Magnetic Rail;
New York's Progress

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your June 13 article on the ambivalent relationship of the United States with magnetic levitation technology does not note that New York State has gone further than any other state toward building a maglev system. 
 In the 1994-95 budget passed this month, $22 million has been appropriated for high-speed ground transportation. Of that, $2 million will go into the development of United States maglev technology at Stewart Airport in Orange County. New York's maglev rail system will work in tandem with a more sophisticated conventional high-speed rail system from Niagara Falls to New York City.
When completed, the maglev portion of the system will go from New York City to Albany, and eventually from Albany through Massachusetts to Boston. When operational, one will be able to travel from downtown New York to downtown Boston in less time than it takes to travel by air.
Maglev technology is an energy-efficient transportation system. Investing in high-speed rail presents New York with an opportunity to be the first state to develop the intercity transportation system of the future, one that does not pollute our air and that is not dependent on foreign sources of energy.
You point out that the Federal Government has been unenthusiastic about investing in maglev technology, with the exception of the Cassandra-like urgings of New York's Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
However, although Germany and Japan are ahead of us in their development, it is not too late for the United States to make up ground. Federal funds for maglev could give United States industry the opportunity to develop and export high-speed ground transportation systems that could reinvigorate United States industry. This is a technology that is ideally suited for defense industries that have drastically cut their work forces and that can only thrive in a post-defense industry economy by finding innovative niches in civilian technologies.
New York has committed substantial public resources to the development of a meaningful high-speed ground transportation network. It's time that the Federal Government follows Senator Moynihan's lead and does the same.
 
SAM HOYT
Chairman, Assembly Subcommittee
on High Speed Rail
and Magnetic Levitation
Albany, June 15, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Clinton Tries to Head Off Senate on Bosnia Embargo

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration began a furious diplomatic and lobbying campaign today to head off a Senate bill that orders the President to ignore the United Nations and unilaterally end United States participation in the arms embargo against Bosnia.
In league with the Administration, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia rounded up four European military officials to testify today against lifting the embargo. But Senator Nunn's tactic only escalated emotions in the already fractious debate. 
 It prompted his colleagues on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee who want the embargo lifted to stage another hearing in the afternoon. Top Administration officials responded by testifying against lifting the embargo.
Those who favor defying the United Nations embargo say the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government, which is outgunned by the Bosnian Serbs, would be better able to defend itself after a lifting of the arms embargo, which was imposed by the Security Council in September 1991 and applies throughout the old Yugoslav federation.
 
A Plea to Lift Sanctions
 "We want the change because we are dying," Ejup Ganic, a Bosnian Vice President, told the panel. "We are not asking for your troops to fight for us on the ground. That is our job and our task. But please, do not combine any more big words with small deeds."
He said a better-armed Bosnian Army would improve the Government's chances of negotiating a settlement with the Serbs, who control about 70 percent of the country.
The Administration is fighting the Congressional move even as it hints to the Serbs that the major powers would back a United Nations resolution lifting the arms embargo if the Serbs reject the latest international peace plan for Bosnia. At the same time, the major powers, including the United States and Russia, are threatening to ease a separate economic embargo against Serb-dominated Yugoslavia, which supports the Bosnian Serbs, if the Bosnian Government rejects the plan.
One senior official said the Administration might propose a compromise amendment that would defy the arms embargo if the Serbs rejected the peace plan.
 
A Loss of Credibility?
 Those who oppose the unilateral violation of the embargo say it would wreck the credibility of the United States at the United Nations; strain the NATO alliance, whose principal members all support the embargo; wreak havoc in the Balkans, and increase the bloodshed, not reduce it.
Senator Nunn said that if the United States reneged on this embargo, it would have no authority in other cases, such as North Korea. "The broader picture is what throws me," he said.
Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, said he understood the desire to lift the embargo, saying it was "rooted in frustration and outrage" that the war had persisted for so long. But he warned that doing so unilaterally would jeopardize the peace talks now under way and would ultimately backfire by drawing the United States in deeper.
The Senate is preparing to vote early next week on a bipartisan amendment to the defense authorization bill that calls for the United States to defy the embargo.
Two United States Navy ships are among the 20 ships from 11 countries enforcing the embargo in the Adriatic. But since signing a federation agreement with Bosnian Croats in March, the Bosnian Government is reported to have received substantial new supplies of weapons through Croatia.
The Senate in May passed a measure calling on the United States to defy the embargo, but only by one vote. At the same time, it passed a second measure, also by one vote, urging that the United States not act alone but urge its allies to end the embargo together. On June 9, the House voted 244 to 178 to violate the embargo unilaterally, sending the issue back to the Senate for resolution.
 
Attached to Defense Bill
 Administration officials have said President Clinton would veto a bill that called for unilateral defiance of the embargo. But the Senate bill, which does just that, is attached to the defense authorization bill. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, who is sponsoring the measure with Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas and the minority leader, said it would be difficult for the President to veto the entire defense bill because of this measure.
But he also acknowledged that pressure from the Administration against the bill was intense. Its supporters had planned for the Senate to vote today but postponed it until early next week. While sentiment seems to be running high in Congress to lift the embargo, some top Congressional aides suggest that once Senators realize that this vote is "for real," as one put it, they might back off.
The Europeans testified this morning that unilateral defiance by the United States of the embargo would throw NATO into chaos, disrupt the fragile cease-fires that have been established, end the humanitarian aid, hurt peace negotiations and widen the war.
Moreover, they said, the United States would automatically assume "moral responsibility" for what would follow, meaning America would be drawn into the conflict.
Those testifying were defense official Anders Troldborg of Denmark, Jean-Claude Mallet of France, Gen. Juan Martinez Esparza of Spain and Maj. Gen. Rupert Smith of Britain. France, Britain and Spain are major contributors to the United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia.
In an unusual outburst, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, interrupted Senator Nunn to object to the fact that no one from the country under discussion had been invited to testify. "Too bad we can't get the views of any of the people getting killed," said a seething Mr. McCain.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 25, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about lobbying against a Senate proposal to lift the arms embargo on the Bosnians misstated Senator Sam Nunn's committee affiliation. He is the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, which held a hearing on Bosnia; he is not a member of the Foreign Relations Committee.

HEADLINE: Risk Where Least Expected

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA 

 BODY:
Smart investors know to brace themselves for wild rides in certain kinds of mutual funds, because the small-stock fund or overseas fund from which they profit today could cause a migraine tomorrow.
But in the case of the funds that invest in short-term Government bonds, no such worry seemed warranted. Or so it would seem from advertising by brokerage firms and mutual fund companies that trumpeted their short-term fixed-income funds as safe alternatives to lower-yielding money market funds and certificates of deposits in the early 1990's. The ads promised higher yields without much more risk. 
 One source of reassurance was the fact that the funds invested in Government bonds, which did not carry the risk of default or bankruptcy like bonds issued by companies. The other attraction was short maturities, which, though not as short as money market funds, still held out the likelihood that even if interest rates moved up they would not be whipsawed as much as longer-term securities.
 
 
Now, the Reality
 The reality has been somewhat different. After having gained 3.39 percent in net asset value in the eight months that ended Jan. 31, short-term Government bond funds turned into dogs as rising interest rates devastated the bond market earlier this year. The 104 funds in one short-term category tracked by Lipper Analytical Services Inc. lost an average of 2.08 percent in the five months through May 31. Worst of all was the Piper Jaffray Institutional Government Income Portfolio Fund, which plummeted 23.91 percent in that period. Next was the Fundamental U.S. Government Strategic Income Fund, down 16.19 percent.
The short-term bond funds -- which generally include Government securities like Treasury bonds, and Government agency bonds including those of the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, and the Government National Mortgage Association, or Ginnie Mae -- have been enormously popular in recent years. Nearly $10 billion in new money poured into the short-term bond category in 1991, followed by $11.4 billion in 1992 -- the peak year for the short-term bond funds.
Many print advertisements for the funds have stressed stability of principal as a big plus: "An investment that performs . . . whether interest rates go up or down," read the headline in a magazine advertisement in early 1992 for the Franklin Adjustable U.S. Government Securities Fund -- down 4.7 percent in net asset value since March 1993.
A "high-quality portfolio is managed to help minimize price fluctuation," read the copy of an advertisement for the Scudder Short Term Bond Fund, down 6 percent since Dec. 28.
While fund companies pitched the short-term bond funds at investors looking for ultrasafe products -- "Why renew your low-yielding C.D.?" asked an advertisement for Fidelity Short-Term Bond Portfolio -- they rarely explained prominently that investors might suffer a loss of principal. The Fidelity Short-Term Bond Portfolio, for example, has lost 6 percent of its net asset value since Jan. 12. "It is carefully managed by Fidelity for a high degree of share price stability," the ad said.
At Scudder, James Smith, vice president for marketing, said he would still be comfortable running the same advertisement, because the ads prompt investors to call Scudder's information lines, where details of risk are "fleshed out." Greg Johnson, the head of marketing at Franklin/Templeton, said that Franklin's sales brochures and prospectus clearly stated the risks, and that investors in the fund had not lost principal when dividend payments were factored in.
At Fidelity, Neal Litvak, executive vice president for marketing, also said that while investors in the short-term bond fund might have seen net asset value fall, they were not losers on balance when reinvestment of dividends was factored in. He added that phone representatives at Fidelity questioned callers extensively about their risk tolerance.
The Fidelity, Franklin and Scudder short-term funds are on the Lipper list of 104 companies because they fall in different short-term fund categories, and are evaluated by Lipper elsewhere.
Some investors might have been better served had they understood the differences between the safety of principal in their certificates of deposit and the safety of principal in the short-term funds, John Teall, a spokesman for Lipper, said. "I think there was some perception that the short-term Government funds gave you some extra return without a great deal more risk," he said. "In the case of some funds, that was absolutely true. But in some cases, as we've seen, there was substantially more risk."
 
 
'Look at Returns'
 Mr. Teall said that investors could have used relatively simple techniques to gauge whether the fund they were considering fell into the risky or stable category. "The easiest way to tell is to look at returns," he explained. "If your returns are substantially different from everyone else in the group, your portfolio manager is probably taking risks that others are not willing to take."
Thus, little surprise that Piper Jaffray's fund, the worst of the 104 funds in the January-May period, was the No. 1 short-term bond fund between May 31, 1993, and Jan. 31. Piper Jaffray's fund suffered greatly because an esoteric mortgage security called an inverse floater proved a disaster as interest rates rose -- and unexpectedly illiquid as a result of the selling panic that ensued.
Inverse floaters are one of several categories of esoteric securities that Wall Street firms create out of pools of home mortgages. These bonds, whose interest payments go up as rates fall and go down as rates rise, are a particularly aggressive way to place a bet on interest rates -- they rise and fall more sharply than more conservative fixed-income securities.
 Funds that crashed from their top spots did so for a variety of reasons. The Fundamental U.S. Government Strategic Income Fund took its 16.19 percent hit in large part as a result of a position in inverse floaters. The fund's portfolio managers had thought that it was adequately hedged against unfavorable movements by the inverse floaters, a spokesman said. But its hedges in the bond futures and options markets did not work as planned during the unexpectedly quick rise in interest rates earlier this year, he said.
More common is the sort of problem that the Franklin Adjustable fund ran into: its large position in adjustable-rate mortgages stunned the portfolio because of the lag effect of the resetting of adjustable-rate mortgages. "You have a period of up to six months before an adjustable mortgage resets to the higher rates," Mr. Johnson said, explaining that the mortgages in which the funds invested were temporarily paying below-market rates.
Lipper's Mr. Teall noted that as is frequently the case in mutual fund selection, the plodders among short-term bond funds tended to have been the best selections when all was said and done. "Average returns may not be exciting on the way up, but on the way down it's nice to get that 2.5 percent instead of losing 20 percent," he said. "Most people are happiest in funds that return average numbers. You pick your risks, you pick your rewards."
As for the one-time high-fliers, not even a settling down of the fixed-income market may be enough to prevent future turbulence. When the bond market came apart this spring, many fund managers were forced to unload securities in order to meet the redemption requests of disgusted shareholders, Mr. Teall said. "But they got rid of the best and easiest-to-sell pieces first," he added. "And what they're left with now is the hardest, almost diabolical pieces. We suspect what's left is the worst."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 5, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on June 24 about the risks in short-term Government bond funds misstated the form in which Lipper Analytical Services Inc. tracks the Franklin Adjustable U.S. Government Securities Fund, the Scudder Short Term Bond Fund and the Fidelity Short-Term Bond Portfolio. The three mutual funds are evaluated separately by Lipper; they are not included in Lipper's list of 104 short-term Government bond funds.

HEADLINE: OPPOSITION FORCES JAPANESE PREMIER TO LEAVE OFFICE

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Saturday, June 25

 BODY:
A year after being ousted from power, Japan's Liberal Democratic Party took its revenge on the defectors who brought it down, forcing Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata to resign this morning rather than face certain defeat in a no-confidence resolution.
Mr. Hata's announcement at 11:15 A.M. (10:15 P.M. New York time) touched off a scramble for power that could, under some scenarios, see the Liberal Democrats return to power as the leading party in a new coalition government. They ran the country for 38 years until countless scandals forced them out last summer as part of a drive to reform both the political system and an overregulated, faltering economy. 
 If the Liberal Democrats succeeded in forming a coalition government of their own -- by combining with some of the small parties that have split with the coalition -- many political analysts believe that the wide range of reforms begun last year could grind to a stop.
But Mr. Hata's allies vowed they would try to reassemble the fractured and embittered coalition they cobbled together last July to create the first non-Liberal Democratic government here since 1955. Under one scenario, Mr. Hata could even be installed again, though with a very different Cabinet.
Whatever the outcome, the weeks of confusion ahead seem bound to hamper the Clinton Administration's ability to reach a broad range of trade agreements with Japan before the summit meeting of the seven largest industrialized democracies in Naples, Italy, in early July. In fact, it could place Mr. Clinton in the same position he was in at last year's meeting in Tokyo: He may be negotiating with a Prime Minister who is certain to be out of a job in weeks.
Mr. Hata would attend the summit meeting as a caretaker unless another Prime Minister is elected by the Parliament. If he is replaced in the next three days -- Parliament is scheduled to go out of session Wednesday -- he would hold the dubious record as the Japanese Prime Minister who served the shortest term in office under the post-war constitution.
Oddly enough, political chaos in Japan could continue the strengthening of the yen and the weakening of the dollar that has shaken financial markets in recent days. The markets may conclude that the Japanese Government is in no position to help narrow the trade surplus with the United States. Many economist believe the surplus is a major factor driving the dollar down.
"It is an urgent task to form a stable government," Mr. Hata said, with a grim smile, as he appeared before reporters this morning. Citing the pressing problems of exchange rates and the nuclear standoff with North Korea he added, "We should stop the power struggles. Otherwise, the people's distrust of politics will grow."
Mr. Hata's decision to, in his words, "leave the establishment of a new government to the will of the Diet," followed two days of fruitless negotiations with the Socialist party, which he hoped could save him from defeat in the no-confidence resolution.
The Socialists, once the largest party in the coalition government, abandoned Mr. Hata as soon as he took office 62 days ago, declaring that he and his allies were plotting to exclude them from power. Today, they said their conditions for returning to the fold, which would have once again given the coalition a majority in Parliament, had not been met.
The Socialists differ with the largely conservative coalition on a wide variety of policy issues, from the role of the Japanese military to the conservative's hopes to increase sales taxes as Japan's population ages.
 
Pride Is the Issue
 But the major issue was one of pride: The Socialist have resented the behind-the-scenes power of Ichiro Ozawa, Mr. Hata's closest ally and Japan's most powerful politician. He has made no secret of his desire to cast them out of the government as soon as he finds more ideologically compatible replacements. The leader of the Socialists, Tomiichi Murayama, said today that Mr. Hata "had responded fairly" to the demands from his party that he step down, and he said he was willing to try to re-create last year's coalition government "and pick the prime minister in a democratic manner."
But Mr. Ozawa is a wily political operator, and he has been working furiously behind the scenes to rid himself of the Socialists and split the faction-ridden Liberal Democrats, in which he was once among the most powerful players. He has been trying to lure away younger members of the party, telling them that the L.D.P. is a political dinosaur, out of touch with the country and unwilling to make the changes needed in the way Japan governs itself and takes part in global affairs.
He has also dangled the premiership in front of a Liberal Democratic party elder, Michio Watanabe. Mr. Watanabe is widely believed to be suffering from cancer, and this may be his last chance at the top job. To get it, though, he has to deliver dozens of new L.D.P. defectors to Mr. Ozawa.
Ultimately, Mr. Ozawa has a clear goal: To create two conservative parties in Japan of roughly equal power, each able to take over the reigns of government.
Getting there, however, will require broad realignments of political forces that have been fractured ever since the L.D.P. began to crack apart last year. Today, loyalty to parties and factions means nothing. Each member of parliament has become a free agent as the country's once rock-solid party system shatters like glass.
Mr. Hata could have dissolved the Parliament and called for a new election. He had done so, the election would have been held under the country's old election laws and districts, because a new system authorized by Parliament a number of months ago -- the main political reform accomplishment of the coalition governments -- is not yet in place.
Mr. Hata and Mr. Ozawa decided, apparently, that they had a better chance at keeping the Liberal Democrats at bay through backroom politics than by risking another election under a system that is biased toward the older party's traditional strengths in Japan's rural areas.

HEADLINE: THE BATTERED DOLLAR: OVERVIEW;
A GLOBAL EFFORT ON DOLLAR FAILS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
A multibillion-dollar global buying spree today by the Federal Reserve and 15 other central banks to prop up the dollar in the face of a new onslaught from currency traders failed to prevent the dollar from again slipping against the Japanese yen and the German mark.
The coordinated central bank operation, led by the Clinton Administration, initially stemmed the dollar's slide against both the mark and the yen, but only briefly, as the American currency resumed its drop, falling by late in the day to 1.585 marks, its lowest level in more than a year, and to 100.65 yen, just above the record low of 99.90 yen that it touched briefly on Tuesday. 
 The actual fall of the dollar today against the mark and the yen was small. But what worries some currency traders as well as some American officials is not the size of the decline, but the symbolic statement that the continued slide makes about investors' attitudes toward the American economy now, as well as the fact that traders were not afraid to sell the dollar even in the face of 16 central banks moving in the other direction.
Indeed, the mood among currency traders remained downbeat about the dollar, with many dismissing the Administration's defense of the currency as lame.
The fact that the 16-nation intervention, which involved about $5 billion in dollar purchases, did not particularly impress the markets would seem to increase the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will conclude that it has to raise interest rates once again, either at the next meeting of its policy committee, on July 5-6, or before then. By raising rates, the Federal Reserve could further dampen any fears of inflation, as well as make returns on American bank accounts and securities more attractive, so that investors would want to put their money in dollars.
Another interest rate increase would hardly be good for domestic growth. But if intervention is ineffective, the only weapon left to the United States to support the dollar in the short term would seem to be for the Federal Reserve to raise the Federal funds rate, the interest rate that banks charge each other, for the fifth time this year.
This short-term rate currently stands at 4.25 percent after beginning the year at 3 percent. Traders say nothing other than higher interest rates seems likely to impress the currency market, where there still seems to be some feeling that the threat of inflation in the United States justifies another rise in rates.
President Clinton said today in an interview on a St. Louis radio station that he and others were puzzled by the dollar's continued decline, given the fact that the long-term prognosis for the American economy is actually quite healthy.
"This is a development that is puzzling a lot of economists," Mr. Clinton said. Noting that the economy "is performing so well," Mr. Clinton said that "in a funny way the currency values are running in the opposite direction of economic strength."
Currency traders and market analysts say the President may be right about the long-run health of the American economy, but the problem is that in today's lightning-fast financial markets, there is no long run anymore. For many traders, particularly those who deal in the most liquid asset of all -- currencies -- there is only the short run.
What ails the dollar, traders say, is the coming together of a number of factors that make the yen and the mark relatively more attractive than the American currency. Germany and Japan are both clearly coming out of recession and both are perceived as having a greater chance of keeping their inflation rates under control. Also, both those nations have clearly slowed the pace of their own interest rate reductions for now, making their bank deposits and bonds relatively more attractive.
 
Reversal of Perceptions
 "U.S. assets, relatively speaking, simply don't appeal to the very fleet-footed international investors right now, and they are voting with their feet," Richard Witten, a senior currency trader at Goldman, Sachs, said. "Last year American stocks and bonds could do no wrong. This year it is the opposite. Why? Because no one has a credible argument as to why the American stock or bond market should bottom here. There is some uncertainty about our growth, while there is less uncertainty about Japan's and Germany's.
"Remember, the currency markets do not feed on absolutes, but on relative valuations, and right now -- on a relative basis, the United States looks worse to a lot of investors, and Japan and Germany better. Every day capital becomes more mobile, so those relative valuations matter."
The danger for President Clinton is that Republicans have begun to seize on the fall of the dollar to discredi what has been the Administration's most effective policy area -- its handling of the economy. Actually, despite the recent decline in the dollar, the American currency has actually risen 1 percent against the German mark since Mr. Clinton's election and it has not fallen against the Japanese yen any more steeply than it did under the Bush Administration.
Nevertheless, that has not discouraged Republicans from taking advantage of the headlines, with Senator Pete Domenici of New Mexico saying in a speech on the Senate floor today that the dollar's slide was a "global vote of no confidence" in the Clinton Administration's economic policies.
A senior Clinton Treasury official responded, "The dollar's modest fall over the last several months is no more a referendum on this President's economic policy than were the declines of more than 10 percent over several intervals during the previous Administration a referendum on the Bush Administration's policies."
Still, while the Administration's intervention in the foreign currency markets was a substantive move, its public statements backing up the dollar have been seen as weak. Earlier this year, the Administration had said clearly and publicly that it was not seeking to push the dollar down further to help increase exports, a statement that was absent this week. Some traders say there is something almost half-hearted about the Administration's statements.
Today's move was the third time this year that the United States along with other major central banks has intervened in the markets by selling other currencies and buying dollars.
Germany, Japan and other nations do not want a further decline in the dollar because that makes American products cheaper and easier to sell abroad and makes foreign exports to the United States and other places more expensive and harder to sell.
The United States does not want the dollar to keep falling because that makes many imports more expensive. Economists estimate that every decline of 10 percent in the dollar's value against the other major currencies could add as much as one percentage point to the annual inflation rate, although some say the actual effect has been less.
But some economists also point out that while the dollar has been falling against the yen and the mark, it has held steady, or even risen, against other currencies whose countries trade as much or more with the United States as do Germany and Japan.
Mr. Clinton took note of this today, saying, "The American dollar is actually stronger against a lot of other currencies in the world than it was a year ago."

HEADLINE: Doctors Slow to Join H.M.O.'s Now Often Find Doors Shut

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
In January, the once-bustling offices of the Brook-Island Pediatric Group in Bensonhurst turned much quieter, as the number of appointments suddenly dropped by 40 percent. Was it the fierce winter weather? Or, perhaps, the mild flu season? The five doctors searched for explanations.
Over the next two months they discovered the answer: in December, when many companies allow employees to change health insurance programs, a large number of families in the practice switched to health maintenance organizations or other forms of managed care. 
 "We had resisted getting into H.M.O.'s and networks and we felt we could afford to since we had an old practice and a strong practice," said Dr. Veronica Santilli, a senior member of the group. "But by February we were very, very scared."
So scared, in fact, that the private doctors, who had spurned H.M.O.'s as cumbersome and intrusive bureaucracies that would limit their fees and meddle with their medical decisions, tried to join the local H.M.O.'s. They were dismayed, however, to find that managed-care groups were no longer interested in recruiting them.
The predicament these doctors find themselves in is one of the latest twists in the changing world of American medicine. It highlights the growing problems for those who cannot, or will not, adjust quickly enough as the nation increasingly embraces managed care as a way of containing medical costs.
Many private doctors, who say they will now take H.M.O. rates and play by their rules, are hoping that new laws will insure their access to H.M.O's. Across the country physician groups have lined up behind legislation proposed in Congress and numerous state legislatures that would effectively require H.M.O.'s to accept any doctor or health professional who meets standards for training, skills and credentials. They say that the networks' unwillingness to open their doors has already ripped apart countless longstanding doctor-patient relationships.
But executives at H.M.O.'s say that to maintain tight control over the cost and quality of care in their organizations, they must limit the number of doctors who can join. What's more, they point out that several years ago they fruitlessly begged these same doctors to join their networks. Back then, it was the younger doctors who joined the networks in an effort to build practices, while established doctors resisted and are now largely left out.
"When I hear all the complaining, it reminds me of the story of the Little Red Hen," said Steve Wilkins, president and chief executive officer of Oxford Health Plans, the fastest-growing H.M.O. in the metropolitan region. "When she asked the other animals to help her plant grains of wheat, they said no; when she asked them to help water them, they said no. But when they grew and she made them into bread, they wanted to eat it. And she said: 'No, you were not involved in making this.' "
 
'You're Frozen Out'
 The New York metropolitan region has until recently been one of the last strongholds of the traditional medical system centered on doctors in private practice, and has lagged behind the rest of the country in adopting managed care. But increasingly doctors here are finding that they too must join H.M.O.'s to survive. At the same time, the region's surplus of doctors -- particularly specialists -- means that spots in the networks are scarce or nearly impossible to find.
"In many categories of medical practice you're frozen out -- it's extremely difficult if not impossible to get into any plan," said Dr. Morton Kurtz, a general practitioner in Queens who is past president of the New York State Medical Society.
Industry analysts say that forcing H.M.O.'s to accept more doctors than they want or need will only inflate premiums. And they add that the region's patients have voted with their feet by enrolling in managed care, indicating that they are willing to sacrifice their physicians to gain affordable health care.
Douglas B. Sherlock, president of the Sherlock Company, which does financial consulting for H.M.O.'s, said: "The doctor told patients, 'Join at your own risk because I'm not going to join.' And ultimately Mrs. Smith said, 'Sorry, doctor, it's a good deal.' So now he's in trouble and trying to get the legislature to protect him from a poor decision he made a few years ago. It's rather arrogant, don't you think?"
 
Growing Rapidly in New York
 The war between doctors and networks is being fought nationwide, but the battle in New York has been particularly virulent, since the state's H.M.O.'s have only recently captured a hefty chunk the health care market. Between March 1993 and January 1994, H.M.O. enrollment in New York grew by 20 percent to more than 4.3 million members, and a number of plans have witnessed even more spectacular growth since then. Oxford expects to enroll more than 150,000 New Yorkers this year, doubling its membership. In the first quarter of 1994, U.S. Healthcare, which has more than 400,000 patients in New York, increased its membership 30 percent. Almost 20 percent of state residents are now enrolled in H.M.O.'s, and about 15 percent in New York City.
"When managed-care penetration gets up around 15 percent, then doctors start to feel it," said Dr. Peter Kongstvedt, a former H.M.O. executive who is now with the consulting firm of Ernst & Young in Washington. "When physicians see a number of patients get copies of their records and go, then it's real."
Many private doctors initially avoided H.M.O.'s because they were reluctant to cede control over medical decisions and the plans paid far less than traditional insurers. But that reluctance has waned recently since being part of networks now offers the economic advantage in many neighborhoods, as more patients move into managed care.
 
How Free a Choice?
 Doctors and H.M.O.'s argue over whether patients are freely choosing H.M.O.'s or are being forced in by employers. Doctors' groups maintain that more of their patients are being forced into the networks, so private doctors should be given more rights to join H.M.O.'s. But the pawns in the battle are patients.
Anna Carpenter had taken her two children to Brook-Island Pediatrics for eight years, until her husband's company switched its employees into managed care in January 1993. The pediatricians were not interested in joining plans at that time.
Although Mrs. Carpenter initially decided to try the network's doctors, she lost confidence in the nearest network pediatrician after an incorrect diagnosis. For several months, she went to the H.M.O. doctor for routine checks and immunizations, returning to her old pediatrician when her children were ill. But then the H.M.O. doctor called her to say she would no longer see the children unless Mrs. Carpenter would trust her medical judgment for all types of care. She now pays to see Dr. Santilli.
And Mrs. Carpenter is luckier than many: her H.M.O. pays 75 percent of the cost for out-of-network care related to illness and her private pediatrician has been willing to play tag-team with the doctor at the H.M.O. Many private doctors resent patients who have deserted them for plans returning on an ad hoc basis when they run into trouble.
 
'Very Discouraging'
 Although Dr. Santilli has tried to join Mrs. Carpenter's plan, she says she has been rebuffed by that one and others.
"It's been very discouraging, to say they least," Dr. Santilli said. "They don't return calls. They say they'll send an application, which never arrives. Some tell us straight out that the network is closed."
The closing of networks has affected specialists far more than primary care doctors, since H.M.O.'s tend to rely heavily on generalists and severely restrict the number of specialists they employ. That is particularly true in places like the metropolitan area where there is a glut of highly trained physicians.
Dr. Robert Bergmann, the chief of the department of ophthalmology at Brunswick Hospital in Amityville, L.I., came late to the world of networks and has been turned away by five plans, each of which has enough eye specialists. "The H.M.O.'s have been knocking themselves out in Nassau County, and my practice has gone from a lovely mix of young and old to basically a Medicare practice," said Dr. Bergmann, who has been in practice 40 years. "A few years ago I was booked three months in advance. I'm still busy, and I think I'll be able to weather this storm. But if not I'll just retire."
Health policy experts say that given the shortage of primary care doctors in the region, qualified internists, pediatricians and family doctors should have no trouble finding slots. But physicians in the trenches, like Dr. Kurtz and Dr. Santilli, say their experience belies that wisdom.
 
Supply and Demand
 H.M.O. executives say they must be careful to add doctors only where there is demand. If an H.M.O. enrolls 1,000 people in Brooklyn, for example, it might not want more than 20 general doctors in the borough. They say it is more efficient for them to deal with 20 doctors, each treating 200 members, than 400 doctors, each treating 10, and many require that member doctors agree to accept at least 100 patients.
"The more business a doctor does with a managed-care organization, the more he will pay attention to its needs," said Dr. Kongstvedt. "If he only see one patients from the H.M.O. every two weeks, neither he nor his office staff will have enough business to understand its quality management or to pay attention to its administrative processes."
H.M.O.'s add that many of the doctors now applying to them as generalists do not meet their training requirements or are underemployed specialists, like cardiologists, now willing to do primary care. But Mr. Wilkins said that such doctors often had little up-to-date experience in general medicine and took it on begrudgingly as a back-door route to specialty referrals.
What's more, he said, an H.M.O. might in some cases reasonably refuse to hire qualified physicians as a business decision, if they would compete against doctors already in the plan: "If you have two medical groups five miles from each other and both are high quality, you're naturally going to support the people who took a risk and supported you early on," he said.
Doctors' groups say the issue is not about money, but fairness for professionals and, ultimately, patient care. The American Medical Association stops just short of insisting that H.M.O.'s be required to include all capable doctors, but insists that plans should reveal their selection standards, so that doctors may fight back if turned down.
"Doctors are excluded based on some kind of financial analysis they don't even have access to; it's disturbing and abusive," said Kirk Johnson, general council of the A.M.A. "After all, this is not just about business. It's about a relationship between a doctor and a patient."

The Battered Dollar
The Federal Reserve and 15 other central banks failed to prevent the dollar from slipping again, despite a multibillion-dollar global buying spree to prop up the American currency. [Page 1.] 
 The dollar moved lower against the Japanese yen and German mark after an unsuccessful effort to reverse its slide. [46.]
Currency intervention is a subtle game, and one that does not always work. [46.]
Turmoil in global markets has laid to rest doubts about how interconnected those markets have become, and how powerful an effect they can have on the course of world economies. [46.]
 
Markets
Stocks fell far, fast and early on the decline of the dollar. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 62.15 points, to 3,636.94. [39.]
Bond prices tumbled, falling in sympathy with the dollar. [49.]
Lumber fell for the fifth time in six days as the prospect of rising interest rates caused demand to slump. [51.]
 
International
Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata was forced to resign this morning as Japan's Liberal Democratic Party wrought its revenge on the defectors who brought it down last year. [1.]
Japan's graduating students say they are victims of the country's lifetime employment system. Needing to reduce their staffs as the economy slumps, but unable to discharge existing workers, companies are cutting back on hiring. [39.]
 
 Companies
General Motors is offering some idled hourly workers up to $60,000 to move to four plants where jobs are available. The offer is an attempt by G.M. to plug a drain on its coffers: members of the auto workers union who draw full wages for not working. [39.]
John Sculley has accepted a part-time job as a marketing consultant to Kodak's electronic imaging division. [39.]
A Texas appeals court threw out a tentative settlement that would have given $1,000 coupons to owners of the G.M. pickups that are suspected of posing a fire hazard in side collisions. [41.]
Keycorp and Bank of Boston agreed to a deal under which Keycorp will acquire the bank's affiliates in Maine and Vermont. [41.]
Kidder, Peabody has received $550 million in new capital since April to firm up its finances and reassure regulators and trading partners of its financial strength. [41.]
Itel agreed to sell its interest in a fleet of 70,000 rail cars to a group of New York investors for $204 million in cash and notes. [49.]
Prudential Securities has reorganized several units after the departure of its investment banking and strategy chief. [49.]
 
The Economy
The Supreme Court placed new limits on the ability of governments to require land owners to set aside part of their property for environmental or other public uses, a ruling that is a substantial victory for advocates of private property rights. [1.]
California officials are groping for solutions to prevent an insurance crisis that could derail the state's economic recovery, as more insurance companies cut back or abandon their homeowners business because of earthquake risks. [39.]
 
Your Money
Many closed-end bond funds known as term trusts are selling at large discounts to the value of their underlying securities. [37.]
Few workers are taking advantage of new guidelines on 401(k) retirement plans that are greatly expanding the investment choices for people who put money in these employer-sponsored plans. [37.]
 Errors in computing a mutual fund's real price are rising, as the business booms and funds hold more exotic investments. [38.]

HEADLINE: THE BATTERED DOLLAR;
Buying Forays Transformed A Sluggish Summer Friday

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The dollar continued its decline against the Japanese yen and German mark yesterday, despite a concerted but not overly vigorous effort by the Federal Reserve and other central banks to reverse its recent slide on world currency markets.
The currency market intervention by the Fed and other banks, including the Bank of Japan and the Bundesbank of Germany, transformed what otherwise probably would have been a sluggish summer Friday into a very active trading session. 
 Dealers said the Fed made its initial foray around 9:30 A.M. in New York, buying dollars for yen and marks after the dollar declined against both in Asian and European currency markets. The dollar quickly shot up to 101.85 yen, but soon gave up most of its gains.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar had fallen as low as 100.05 yen, not far above its record low of 99.90 yen that it briefly touched on Tuesday.
 
Second Round Aims at Mark

The Fed was back again early in the afternoon, but traders said the second round was solely in support of the dollar against the mark.
Nevertheless, the dollar ended lower. By late yesterday it was quoted at 100.65 yen, down from 101.40 on Thursday. And it fell nearly two pfennigs against the mark, to 1.5850 marks, its lowest level in more than a year, from 1.6025 marks on Thursday.
Initially, though, the intervention strategy had its intended effect, as the dollar bounced off its lows against both currencies. But the gains were short-lived.
"Those that had an interest in selling the dollar but were waiting for the intervention to come sold it after the dollar bounced," one trader said. "And once the intervention went away, the dollar's basic weakness reasserted itself."
This intervention was the third time this year and the first since May 4 that the Fed and other central banks acted in concert to support the dollar. Until yesterday, only the Bank of Japan had acted this week to keep the yen from surging.
 
A Good Day for Intervening
 Traders and analysts said the central banks had picked the best day of the week to try to influence the value of the dollar. Trading volume is generally light on a Friday and dealers are reluctant to take on new positions in advance of a weekend. But they just as quickly rattled off a long list of reasons for the inability of yesterday's intervention to calm financial markets, let alone reverse the dollar's course.
Perhaps most important, traders said, was that the market had been expecting such a move.
After the dollar fell to new post-World War II lows against the yen on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bensten said they were monitoring developments in financial markets carefully.
Currency traders and analysts looked at those remarks -- as well as the dollar's weakness -- and started waiting for the central banks.
"The beast was out there in the jungle, and we sort of expected it," the trader said. "The intervention came in a market when nobody was leaning the wrong way."
Interventions are most often successful when they surprise speculators betting on further weakness in the dollar. But even though the market has been remarkably pessimistic about the dollar for some time, traders said speculators had mostly stayed on the sidelines.
In addition, the calendar adversely affected the ability of intervention to alter market psychology.
At the moment, financial market participants are acutely uncertain about how to interpret recent economic trends in the United States, Japan and Europe. Based on the most recent data, it appears that growth prospects in Germany and Japan are increasing even as they are cooling in the United States. That sense is providing an incentive to move money.
"There is a very negative perception about U.S. assets, and the investing community is reflecting that," said Richard E. Witten, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "In this building, people are equally negative on the 29th floor, where equities are traded, on the 26th floor, where we trade bonds, and on the sixth floor, where we trade currencies."
But those perceptions could change drastically in the next 10 days to two weeks. On July 8, for example, the Labor Department is expected to release June employment data. A strong jobs report would go far to dispel the notion of a cooling American economy, could force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates and would probably provide support for the dollar.
Yesterday's currency intervention may not have stemmed the dollar's fall, but traders said they expected the central banks to be back at it again, and probably soon.
"Neither the Japanese or the Germans want their currencies to appreciate any further," said Scott Pardee, chairman of Yamaichi International America.

HEADLINE: Stocks Tumble With Dollar as Dow Falls 62.15

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stocks fell far, fast and early yesterday, as currency intervention by the United States and other nations failed to stop the decline of the dollar. Bond prices plunged, worsening the stock market's decline.
The dollar's drop again raised the prospect that the Federal Reserve would be forced to raise interest rates to make dollar-denominated assets more attractive, particularly to foreign investors. 
 But traders are already concerned that the Fed's four previous rate increases this year have hurt corporate earnings, and therefore stocks. The Fed's policy-making committee is scheduled to meet on July 5 to consider long-term monetary policy.
 
 
Political Crisis in Japan
 Moreover, fresh doubts were raised about the future of the Japanese Government and the course of trade talks between the United States and Japan. Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata, who was facing a no-confidence vote, said today in Tokyo that he would resign. Before his announcement, analysts had predicted that the dollar would drop further if he was forced from office.
Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 62.15 points, to 3,636.94, the steepest one-day drop since March 30. On that date the Dow plunged more than 72 points after falling on the four previous trading days; the March declines came after the Fed raised short-term interest rates a second time.
Some traders who say the market is in a bearish mode trace the beginnings of the bearishness to late March. But even though stock prices have fallen to more attractive levels, many traders seem to be staying on the sidelines. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal, with 261.3 million shares changing hands. By contrast, the decline on March 30 involved volume of 390 million shares.
For the week, the Dow lost nearly 140 points.
After rising sharply after the central bank purchases yesterday morning, the dollar settled at 100.65 Japanese yen, near post-World War II lows, and 1.58 German marks, the lowest level against the mark in more than a year.
 The dollar's decline discourages foreign investors from buying American assets, including stocks, because dollar-denominated assets lose value when they are converted back into home currencies. The rise of 4.19 percent in the Dow for the last 12 months, for example, would translate to a loss of 3.48 percent in Japanese yen and a loss of 3.25 percent in German marks.
 
 
Months of Aftershocks
 Yesterday's decline in stocks was part of a continuing aftershock from the Fed's initial decision to raise interest rates on Feb. 4. The responses of the stock and bond markets have gone beyond what either the Fed or most traders had expected. Stock and bond traders began looking for signs of inflation in every freshly released economic report, even though nearly five months of economic data have indicated scant inflation.
Still, traders successfully pressured the Fed into three more rate increases, which have served to slow the economy, analysts say, and called into question the strength of companies' second-quarter earnings, to be reported next month.
Meanwhile, currency traders had noticed the slowing United States economy and the recovering European economies. Traders bet heavily on European currencies, especially the German mark, and against the dollar, lowering its value.
While currency intervention has important psychological ramifications, it has little practical effect. Even if the Treasury Department and the Fed spent all of the United States' foreign exchange reserves of about $44 billion, it would have little effect on a currency market with a daily trading volume that may exceed $1 trillion.
Spending all of the United States' reserves would be the equivalent of less than a nickel for every dollar traded in the currency markets. "Intervention is a Band-Aid when you need a tourniquet," said Chris Madell, a former currency trader who now heads Government bond trading at First Chicago Capital Markets.
The bond market also buckled yesterday. The price of the benchmark 30-year bond dropped sharply and the yield rose to 7.52 percent, from 7.40 percent on Thursday, the largest one-day rise since May 23.
But most of the rubble was in the stock market. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 6.83 points, to 442.80, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 7.06 points, to 693.79. The last time the Nasdaq index closed below 700 was on July 22, 1993, when it ended at 695.52.
 
 
Grim From the Start
 News of the dollar's weakness sent the stock market tumbling at the opening of the session. All leading indexes plunged in the first half-hour of trading. Shortly after 11 A.M., the Dow fell more than 50 points, setting off the New York Stock Exchange's "circuit breakers" -- rules intended to slow high-speed computer-guided trading and cool off the market.
The New York Stock Exchange composite fell 3.74 points, to 244.55, with advancing stocks lagging behind declining issues by 383 to 1,896. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 4.95 points, to 426.30.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 26 declined, led by the Aluminum Company of America, which fell 2 1/4, to 72 1/2, on no immediate news that would account for the decline. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 424 declined, led by AT&T, which fell 1 1/8, to 53 3/4, on no apparent news.
The most active stock, at 9.1 million shares, was Oracle Systems, a software developer, which rose 2, to 36 5/8, after reporting strong fourth-quarter earnings.
 In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 273.46 points, or 1.30 percent, to 20,766.75.
