HEADLINE: A Thinking Person's Guide to University Grades

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Many of those both inside and outside of America's premier universities complain almost Calvinistically about the supposedly undeserved grades that are awarded to today's top students -- as, for example, in your letters columns of June 18 ("Graduate Students Give Grades a Boost") and June 12 ("Students Care Far Too Much About Grades"), all in response to "Making the Grades" (editorial, June 5).
But these complaints often overlook two important points.
First, it is wrongheaded to castigate students for relying, as all of us do every day, on settled expectations. Students at a given university get a sense of what sort of grades they ought to expect, and there is a certain haughty arbitrariness in suddenly stopping on a dime to inform the B student that he or she is "really" only a C student. 
 This solution is almost as unfair as protesting inflation by suddenly deciding to pay one's employees in wages that are pegged to the value the dollar held in 1950. Should I soon expect to pick up The New York Times for a nickel?
The second problem is that grades are subjective social constructs, not objective standards metaphysically woven into the fabric of the universe.
What, after all, does the grade of C indicate? Those who think today's grades are too high would argue that it should be taken to mean "average," while those less upset by grade inflation take it to mean "mediocre."
This choice obviously has important ramifications. Suppose every single one of your students is basically topnotch, as often holds in advanced undergraduate courses or graduate seminars. In this case excellence is average.
So do they all get A's or C's? The choice seems arbitrary to me, so opting to give them all C's has less to do with academic integrity than with a sort of neurotic stinginess.
This last year I served as a graduate preceptor for two courses that were offered by the department of politics at Princeton University, one of them on the history of political philosophy and the other on American constitutional interpretation. I had 45 students all told, approximately 1 percent of Princeton's undergraduate population.
Most of them were good writers, a few were bad, and a few were fantastic. So perhaps I should have given all of the "good" papers a C for "average." But wait! Doesn't "good" translate into a B, according to the classic grading rubric?
You see the problem, I hope. The average student at a university like Princeton or Stanford is good, so it is very easy for graders like me to settle on a B mean, especially where C is widely taken to mean not "average" but "mediocre." The B mean provides for few C's, but still allows ample room for the recognition of different levels of achievement.
For example, in my sections most of the students got B's and a few got B+'s. A grade of A- was very hard to get, and A's were rare indeed. Real problems of meaningless praise only ensue if professors start refusing to give anything less than an A- even in large classes where there are substantial differences in the quality of student writing, as does happen from time to time.
I think that the general recourse to a broad B mean is accurate and fair at a place like Princeton.
Of course, if this system still seems too lax, I suppose we could argue for a recalibration within each elite university, so that all of the country's best students -- who are obviously "average" compared with one another -- get C's. But I suspect that Western civilization will survive if we accept the B mean that I recommend and, having done so, turn away from this fetish and worry about grander things.
 
JAMES KYLE HUDSON
Princeton, N.J., June 14, 1994

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
Rankings reflect sales figures, for the week ending June 11, at 3,050 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 28,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent sales in all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.
CALLED OUT, by A.G. Mojtabai. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.) An abstract, intelligent novel, ostensibly about a jet crash in a small town, that renders the reactions of the witnesses to a random disaster in beautiful, somber prose.
 
CIGARETTES ARE SUBLIME, by Richard Klein. (Duke University, $21.95.) People smoke them because they are dangerous, and for a lot of other reasons as well, according to this polemical, analytical, lit-critical, theoretical, political ode to deathweed by an up-to-date professor of French.
 
COLORED PEOPLE: A Memoir, by Henry Louis Gates Jr. (Knopf, $22.) A distinguished American scholar's intricate, captivating account of the rich family and community life of black people in Piedmont, W.Va., on the eve of desegregation.
 
A JOURNEY THROUGH ECONOMIC TIME: A Firsthand View, by John Kenneth Galbraith. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Born in 1908, the preternaturally lucid and articulate Mr. Galbraith has kept his eyes open ever since and seen a great deal he didn't care for.
 
JUSTICE LEWIS F. POWELL JR., by John C. Jeffries Jr. (Scribners, $30.) An illuminating biography of a pivotal Justice of the Supreme Court whose instinctive conservatism was always tempered by his respect for the rule of law and his willingness to listen hard.
 
MOSES SUPPOSES, by Ellen Currie. (Simon & Schuster, $20.) A welcome first collection of Ms. Currie's short stories, new and old; in relationships gone wrong, in everyday objects, she discerns hints of large meanings and glimmers of submerged mysteries.
 
ROOMMATES: My Grandfather's Story, by Max Apple. (Warner, $19.95.) An enthralling novelistic memoir of the infinitely durable Herman (Rocky) Goodstein, who at 93 accompanied Mr. Apple to college and proved, in the long run, to be worth all the trouble he caused.
 
SHOT IN THE HEART, by Mikal Gilmore. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Fifteen years after Norman Mailer's "Executioner's Song," Gary Gilmore's youngest brother reclaims his own life in this highly personal account of his family.
 
THE STRUGGLE FOR RUSSIA, by Boris Yeltsin. (Belka Publishing/Times Books/Random House, $25.) Russia's first democratically elected leader shows himself more thoughtful, more observant, more sensitive to nuances of other people's behavior than at first he appeared.
 
THE WATERWORKS, by E.L. Doctorow. (Random House, $23.) An intellectual ripping yarn in which a grim, smoke-stained New York City of 1871 is the principal character; the novel's poetic flow of myth gracefully sustains its burden of ideas, of which there are plenty.
 
A WAY IN THE WORLD, by V.S. Naipaul. (Knopf, $23.) A brilliant, probing autobiographical meditation on empire and inheritance by a mind at the peak of its powers, made of complementary narratives about characters from the author to Sir Walter Raleigh.

PUB-DATE: June 26, 1994

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2602 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Doesn't Anybody Want This Job?

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER 

 BODY:
WANTED: CHARMING, erudite executive with the diplomatic skills of a foreign service officer, the financial skills of an investment banker and the social skills of a 1950's wife. Position requires the academic background of a serious scholar, with the willingness to let most of this knowledge go unused in favor of poring over budgets and staffing issues. Long hours, low pay and the chance to see your name in the papers every time you make even the slightest wrong move.
The job, of course, is running an art museum. Right now 13 museums in the United States are looking for directors, including three of the most prestigious: the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. Running any of them would seem like a dream job. But as art museums have evolved into huge institutions playing host to millions, the job has become more a matter of politics than of art. Who runs art museums may seem like a matter of little concern to art lovers. But it gets to the very heart of the question of what museums should be. And like so many other nonprofit cultural institutions, museums are struggling over the question of whether they should turn their fate over to professional managers or keep it in the hands of the specialists who have been in charge until now. 
 For all the aura of power that surrounds the running of a major museum, the day-to-day reality can be a matter of contentious staffs, financial pressures, public scrutiny that comes with the public funds most museums say they need to survive, and trustees who are often reluctant to let the director have a free hand in management. The one thing many directors say they have no time to think about is art.
"Directors are like classy beggars with golden cups," said Robert Buck, director of the Brooklyn Museum, who says he spends "150 percent" of his time raising money. "The whole game of keeping these institutions alive has become high stakes."
And once directors have mastered the juggling act of keeping trustees, donors, curators, the public and the press happy, they seem less inclined now to push their luck and try it all over again somewhere else. One of the Modern's brightest prospects, Peter Marzio, director of the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, decided last month that he did not want to be considered for the post; the Modern had been told the same thing some months earlier by James Wood, the director of the Art Institute of Chicago. Richard E. Oldenburg, who had planned to retire as the Mod ern's director this month, has agreed to extend his tenure to the end of the year, and the board is gamely continuing its search.
While it's hardly the case that no one wants to run an art museum -- hundreds of them are run successfully by people who enjoy their jobs -- there is no question that over the last two decades, running the larger institutions has become less a matter of supervising artistic matters than of managing diverse and competing constituencies.
"You could argue that Wall Street is a more meritocratic place today than most nonprofit institutions," said Malcolm McKay, a partner in the executive search firm of Russell Reynolds Associates who specializes in finding heads for nonprofit organizations. With large, diverse boards, Mr. McKay said, the search process encourages bureaucrats and compromisers. "Intelligence and knowledge are less important than character and personality."
 
The Transformation
Populist Museums, Newly Rich Trustees
 A museum director's job is different today because museums themselves are different. They are as popular as they are scholarly, and they cut a far wider swath across society than they did a generation ago.
Then, museums tended to be run by art historians, curators who had risen from the ranks, and trustees were likely to limit their role to providing philanthropic support. Museums saw their constituencies as committed art lovers who trod calm and placid galleries: connoisseurship, not popular appeal, was the ideal.
All that changed dramatically in the 1970's, as museums began to see their mission as attracting a wider public. Blockbuster exhibitions, often sponsored by corporations eager to burnish their reputations by connecting their names to art, brought in masses of tourists and others who rarely, if ever, had visited museums before, and public support arrived in the form of state arts council and National Endowment for the Arts grants.
But this new money came with strings attached: both corporations and the government put pressure on museums to direct their programming to a broad sampling of society. Art became marketing, and museums talked in terms of box office.
Many became caught up in a frenzy of growth that had something other than the democratization of art as its goal. Building museums became a badge of success for cities, and for people who had grown rich in the 1980's. New blood, often newly rich blood, joined old museum boards. Museums got bigger and more expensive to maintain, which in turn required them to find ways of keeping attendance high to pay mounting bills. Many seemed victims of their own success, caught in a spiral of expanding audiences, expanded facilities and the need for ever more money to support them.
 
The Predicament
Musical Chairs In Reverse
 Few were prepared for the effects of these changes on the nature of the museum -- or for the predicament that many museums face now, when the lavish flow of private and corporate dollars has dried up and government support has been cut back sharply. Museums are left with huge overhead, high social expectations and less money.
"Trustees who made a lot of money fast tend to see the museum as just a business, and see its problems as just a turnaround situation," said J. Carter Brown, the former director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington. "But a museum is a delicate ecology. It needs to serve intellectual and esthetic goals, and it can't be put to the paradigm of another field. When you get a roomful of trustees who are used to getting their way by pounding the table in their own board rooms, it gets very difficult."
These new trustees have become notoriously fickle. Five of the present vacancies for museum directors are the result of directors' having been asked to resign by their boards, as was the vacancy that existed until recently at the Dallas Museum of Art. Michael Shapiro, the last director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, lasted a mere 10 months; the same board that hired him in 1992 fired him in 1993 after deciding that the museum's serious financial and personnel troubles needed an administrator, not a curator, at the helm.
Michael Mezzatesta did not even get Mr. Shapiro's brief chance. The board of the Walters Art Gallery in Baltimore hired him as its director last year, then changed its mind before he had even started. Mr. Mezzatesta, who was given a financial settlement and went back to his old job running the museum at Duke University, was said to have differed with the board over what the Walters should become. But why such a major conflict did not emerge during interviews has not been explained.
Many museums have turned the process of finding a director over to executive search firms like Mr. McKay's, which can make the search resemble the corporate world all the more. But museum directors have never been paid like the corporate executives they are being asked to act like. Most directors of major museums are paid between $150,000 and $200,000 a year, small potatoes by corporate standards. (One exception is Edmund P. Pillsbury, director of the private Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, whose $448,997 salary is paid by the Kimbell Art Foundation, which runs the museum.)
"For $200,000 a year, you get a fourth-rate administrator who could do better at General Electric," said Richard L. Feigen, the New York art dealer. "But that's what the job description calls for, administration and fund raising, since in most museums the trustees want to hold onto all the real power."
One of the few new-style directors who has managed to hold onto significant power himself, even with a strong board, is Thomas Krens of the Guggenheim Museum. But the entrepreneurial, deal-oriented Mr. Krens did it by leading his board into a whole new kind of museum management: aggressive expansion financed by aggressive borrowing. The Guggenheim borrowed so heavily that it even took the unusual step of allowing its art collection to be used as collateral against its loans.
The art hasn't been given up to the banks, but the results of the Guggenheim's leveraged expansion aren't encouraging. The museum had to lay off staff members this spring, and attendance at its new SoHo branch has been too low to cover expenses. No one knows yet whether the trustees are inclined to treat the expansion as just another business deal in need of fixing. But the board is made up heavily of rich entrepreneurs, not old-line philanthropists, and they tend to view the museum differently from the arts patrons of another era.
According to Ricky Abzug, associate director of the Program on Nonprofit Institutions at Yale University, who has tracked the evolution of the boards of museums in six major cities, more than half the trustees were listed in the Social Register in 1931. By 1961 this number had declined to 30 percent, and by 1991 it was under 10 percent.
 
The Candidates
'You Expect The Museum Messiah'
 The shift in the museum's identity over the last couple of generations, from private, cloistered institution to aggressively public one, has only begun to yield a generation of leaders equipped to handle the demands of the new institution. There are young directors who have garnered high marks in both management and curatorship, like Maxwell Anderson of the Michael C. Carlos Museum in Atlanta, who has been mentioned for both the Modern and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, and Charles Moffett of the Phillips Collection in Washington.
But the progression from small to medium-size to major is no longer something talented directors are certain they want. It isn't merely fear of the political and economic stresses that directing a major museum can bring; it is also a matter of the rising profile of many regional museums, which means that directors who have achieved success elsewhere no longer feel that they need the prestige of an institution like the Modern as a capstone to their careers.
Women are becoming more conspicuous in the once largely male preserve of museum directorships. (The Philadelphia Museum of Art, headed by Anne d'Harnoncourt, who has also been mentioned as a possibility for the Modern, and the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in Richmond, headed by Katharine Lee, are the largest museums run by women.) University museums, a kind of training ground, have historically been encouraging to women, and they continue to provide opportunities for curators to move up.
The J. Paul Getty Trust, which controls a major museum, the Getty in Los Angeles, has tried to step into the training void with a program in museum administration. While that program has earned high marks for its efforts to combine curatorial values with management training, it is too early to measure its results. But even if the program succeeds, the question remains whether a large museum can actually be run by one person. Three major institutions, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Art Institute of Chicago, have decided that it cannot, and have been operating for years with dual leadership: a director who oversees matters related to the collections and exhibitions, and a president who handles administration and finance.
 
The Modern's Search
Switching Gears And Coming Up Dry
 The Museum of Modern Art flirted with that idea when it began its search for a new director last year and started looking for a paid president to take over many administrative and fund-raising duties and work alongside Mr. Oldenburg. When Mr. Oldenburg decided to step down, the board abruptly switched gears and started interviewing only people who were now running other museums -- a limited search that may be broadened again, sources close to the board say, because the museum has so far come up dry in its march through the roster of directors of other museums.
The Modern's search has been all the more frustrating because its unusual length has heightened expectations. "You expect the museum Messiah by now, and I'm not sure anyone can live up to that," said one person close to the museum. Making things worse, such a long period with a lame-duck director takes a toll on day-to-day operations and makes long-range planning nearly impossible. Several important posts are vacant and the museum has not rushed to fill them.
The Modern has always moved with a certain hesitation, of course. It stood largely aside from the attempts to redefine and expand that altered many institutions in the 1980's, and it has suffered neither the extreme financial pressures of the Guggenheim nor the virulent press attacks directed at the Whitney Museum and its two most recent directors, David Ross and Tom Armstrong.
The Modern's board is headed by Agnes Gund, an enthusiastic collector whose belief in contemporary art has pushed the museum, in mood at least, away from the somewhat dry, corporate tone it occasionally took on in the last generation. If the board has traditionally been somewhat torn between the museum's role as a historic institution and its commitment to the new, Ms. Gund's passions for new art have been a refreshing change.
But they have not brought the museum as an institution any closer to a sense of who should be leading it.
 
The Prognosis
The Secret Is to Delegate
 In the end, the key issue is one of curatorial values versus management. Everyone connected with a museum wants it to be headed by a trained art historian, just as universities believe they should be headed by scholars, newspapers expect to be run by journalists and hospitals want to be headed by doctors. But increasingly the director's curatorial credentials are little more than a symbol, a way of reminding the world that the museum is an art institution and not a corporation.
"Boards are criticized if they choose someone without a strong art history background," said Mr. McKay, "but the curatorial pool is not strong for people wanting to manage. It attracts people who love objects."
Most directors who have tried to devote significant portions of their time to organizing exhibitions have found that they can do so only at the cost of performing their management duties well. At least one recent candidacy for the directorship of a major museum foundered on the person's insistence that he be permitted to devote a substantial amount of time to mounting exhibitions. The board said no.
Is it just as difficult for a museum director to spend significant time with works of art as it is for, say, the president of a large university to teach? Probably so, and it isn't an entirely new problem. Alfred Barr, the legendary first director of the Museum of Modern Art, was removed by the trustees in 1943 largely because they thought he had neglected management in favor of curatorial work.
Yet as one trustee of the Modern said: "The secret of a good leader is delegating authority. What is most important is that the director be a cultivated person -- a person who speaks with great authority about the 20th century and its culture."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Julie Applebaum, Gregory G. Flynn

 BODY:
Julie Ellen Applebaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey M. Applebaum of Washington, was married there last evening to Gregory Grant Flynn, the son of Roberta Flynn of Ross, Calif., and Donald Flynn of Sandy, Ore. Judge Theodore Tannenwald of the United States Tax Court in Washington performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
Mrs. Flynn, 27, graduated cum laude from Yale University and received a law degree earlier this month from Stanford University. In the fall she is to become an associate at Morrison & Foerster, a law firm in San Francisco. Her father is a partner in Covington & Burling, the Washington law firm. Her mother, Elizabeth B. Applebaum, is the program coordinator at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington. 
 Mr. Flynn, 30, graduated magna cum laude from Brown University and received a master's degree in economics from the University of Queensland in Brisbane, Australia, and a master's degree in American history from Yale. He received an M.B.A. earlier this month from Stanford. His mother is a writer in Ross. His father is the chairman of Flynn Industries, a San Francisco real estate developer.

HEADLINE: The Hudson Waterfront: What's Next?

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
RIBBONS will not be cut for the grandest projects until early in the next century -- if then -- but plans for Manhattan's Hudson River waterfront are advancing on several fronts this summer, with tangible results promised next year.
Federal and state highway officials are nearing a final choice of design for the reconstruction of Route 9A from Battery Place to 59th Street. They are likely to heed the preference of transportation engineers for a $380 million "urban boulevard" with six to eight lanes of traffic, a 19-foot-wide median and a parallel bikeway and walkway. The decision could come next month. 
 July may also see a groundbreaking for the rebuilding of the Chelsea Piers, between 18th and 22d Streets, as a combination sports complex and movie and television studio. Roland W. Betts, one of the developers, said the project would be complete by the end of 1995.
Also in July, design will begin on a waterfront park from Battery Park City to 59th Street. It will be built by the Hudson River Park Conservancy, a subsidiary of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, whose board voted Tuesday to approve Quennell Rothschild Associates/Signe Nielsen as the landscape architects.
They were chosen by the conservancy in April and are already working on what one of the architects, Peter Rothschild, calls "modest, tentative improvements" for a few spots along the river, including a canoe and kayak launch on Pier 26, just north of Battery Park City. These temporary projects may be ready next spring.
Officials have also accelerated their assessment of a plan to move the West Side heliport from 30th Street to a surplus Navy helicopter carrier, the Guadalcanal, which would be anchored along the end of the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum on Pier 86, at 46th Street.
"Things are beginning to happen," said Tom Fox, president of the conservancy. As well they might, since the Westway project along the same route was scuttled in 1985. Mr. Fox thinks the result was worth the wait.
"We will have a boulevard instead of a highway and a world-class park," he said. "For nine years of debate and discussion, that's not a bad result. I think it's a triumph of community participation."
But this summer's mileposts are regarded warily by critics who believe that the highway will provide infrastructure to spur intense development along the Hudson River and that "park" is a misnomer for what is more like a string of waterfront commercial projects.
"They keep referring to everything as park," said Assemblywoman Deborah J. Glick, Democrat of Manhattan, "but what's being offered are vest pockets in the midst of fairly intense commercial development."
On Pier 76, opposite the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, Mr. Fox envisions a terminal for the ferries operated by Arthur E. Imperatore, which now dock at Pier 78; restaurants, meeting rooms and a three-acre park.
Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, who oversees land-use issues for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said City Hall supported the general idea for Pier 76. "It's subject to a lot of negotiation," she said, "but in theory we like it."
Mr. Fox said the tow pound that is now on the pier could be removed to a block bounded by 11th and 12th Avenues, 33d and 34th Streets. That block might also be used for an addition to the convention center. A parcel on the 11th Avenue side would be made available to a development team headed by Julien J. Studley Inc., which was designated in 1987 to build a 1,560-room hotel on Pier 76, called Hudson River Center.
An inherent tension in the Hudson River Park project, as conceived by state officials, is the need for revenue-generating sources along the waterfront to finance the park itself. This is illustrated by the Pier 76 proposal, in which only half the area would be set aside as public open space.
"The purist in me says, 'Take it all and we'd have six more acres for the park,' " said Mr. Fox, who was once executive director of the Neighborhood Open Space Coalition. "But the realist in me says that we have to find an income generator that complements the park and allows us to maintain this pier."
THE search for new uses on old piers includes the Passenger Ship Terminal, Piers 88 through 92, from 48th to 52d Street. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey may quit the terminal when its lease expires at the end of the year.
The authority and the city's Economic Development Corporation began a search last year for proposals to exploit the terminal's unused capacity. Chris O. Ward, a senior vice president of the city development agency, said responses included amusement, recreation and entertainment ventures, as well as "modest commercial development."
Now, the economic development agency hopes to find an operator for the cruise-ship terminal, as well as a developer, so that the city would not lose money should it have to take over the complex, Mr. Ward said.
For its sheer size, as well as its prominence on the West Village waterfront, Pier 40 may be the biggest challenge and the site of the most pitched battles.
Not some slender finger in the water, Pier 40 has a surface area of about 14 acres -- roughly the size of Carl Schurz Park on the Upper East Side. The 32-year-old pier shed, originally a passenger and freight terminal for the Holland-America Line, has more than 1 million square feet of floor area
A neighborhood alliance called the Federation to Preserve the Greenwich Village Waterfront and Great Port believes the pier should be a Community Green, designed "by the people who will use it."
This proposal is supported by Community Board 2, said its chairwoman, Carol Feinman, which favors demolition of the existing shed to clear areas for sitting, bicycling, ball playing and Frisbee tossing.
But Mr. Fox said it would cost at least $75 million to raze the structure and build a park. Instead, as one alternative, he sees the three-level shed being used as studios for glassblowers, carvers, weavers, sculptors and other artisans. There would be a gift shop and restaurants, ball courts in the six-acre courtyard at the center of the building and a promenade on the eight-acre rooftop.
The cumulative result of such proposals, Assemblywoman Glick said, is that "there is very little area that the average person would recognize as open space or park."
"It's not a hidden agenda," she said. "To hear Tom Fox talk about the possibilities for commercial or retail development -- it's on the surface. The only artifice is that he keeps saying it's a park. Presumably, if you say it enough, people will believe it's a reality."
Critics say that if the plans were scaled back, the park could be built sooner and would be easier to finance.
"We'd rather have something simple we could enjoy now than a beautifully designed thing after we're dead," said Marcy Benstock, executive director of the New York City Clean Air Campaign. "The funds are available right now. Not all of it, maybe, but enough to do wonderful things."
Money is at the heart of the key unresolved issue: who will own and control the Hudson River waterfront -- that is, the area west of Route 9A, stretching from land's edge over water to the pierhead line, that was to have been the Westway right-of-way?
The property between Harrison and 35th Streets belongs to New York State. (The rest is owned by the city.) It was acquired with $81 million in Federal assistance, as Westway was to have been part of the interstate system. Now that it is not, local officials must either pay back the Government or obtain a waiver by persuading the Federal Highway Administration that the new uses would be related to transportation.
While the Government regards transportation enhancements broadly enough to include a bicycle path, pedestrian walkway and open space for scenic purposes, it would not allow elements like ball fields, marine facilities, food carts or benches.
Several Democratic legislators from Manhattan, including State Senator Franz S. Leichter and Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, have been pushing to designate the property as parkland. But they acknowledged that there were too many unresolved issues to expect parkland legislation in the current legislative session.
Instead, Mr. Gottfried said: "What's now on the table is to prohibit any residential, commercial office space or hotel development along the water. That would be an enormous step forward."
IF that happened, Mr. Fox said, "we should repay the Federal Government and get them out, because the state legislative protections are more onerous than a waiver." But Ms. Benstock charged that a payback would merely "clear the way for a complete takeover of the right-of-way by the Urban Development Corporation."
Deputy Mayor Reiter said the Giuliani administration supported the idea of a payback if the $40 million share owed by New York City came back in the form of $40 million in Federal transportation aid.
"We would like to see it mapped as parkland if the legislation handles it properly," Ms. Reiter said. "We have to have some limited but appropriate economic development and allow for the siting of a small amount of potential municipal facilities. The notion of it all being a park is something we're all agreed will never happen."
While these issues are thrashed out, the team charged with designing the waterfront park will begin its work. Besides Mr. Rothschild, Nicholas Quennell and Ms. Nielsen, the team includes the firms of Beyer Blinder Belle and Saccardi & Schiff.
Mr. Rothschild said it would take about two years to prepare an environmental impact statement and get approval on the final park design. The first step, he said, would be meeting with community boards, advocacy groups and neighborhood leaders to learn what they want in a park. "We are kind of agents, if you will, or ombudsmen of the public will," Mr. Rothschild said.
As a temporary measure to "get people down to the waterfront," Mr. Quennell said, several modest projects will be undertaken:
* Pier 26, near North Moore Street -- a canoe and kayak launch.
* Pier 45, at West 10th Street -- two 40-by-250-foot sunbathing areas, with grass or sand, raised 16 to 18 inches from the deck to provide bench-like seating.
* Pier 54, at 13th Street -- an outdoor museum of maritime artifacts salvaged from the waterfront, like bollards, chocks and cleats, framed by the remains of the Cunard Piers headhouse.
These temporary projects are not meant to presage the ultimate nature of the park, Mr. Quennell said, although they might provide some cues if they proved to popular.
Construction of the ultimate waterfront park would accompany that of Route 9A, which is to be built in 10 stages over the course of seven and a half years. As many as five stages may be under way at any time.
The Route 9A project reached a critical crossroads with the publication earlier this month of a final environmental impact statement that identifies the highway design preferred by transportation engineers.
They chose what is called an "enhanced basic reconstruction" of the existing roadway, the least expensive of four alternative construction possibilities. It seems virtually certain that this choice will be ratified by state and Federal officials.
"WE'VE worked very, very closely with the decision makers," said Robert J. Ronayne, executive director of the Route 9A project for the state Transportation Department. "I'd be very surprised if they didn't choose it."
Mr. Ronayne said the preferred highway had the qualified support of all but one of the four affected community boards.
"We've supported, from very early on, the enhanced basic reconstruction," said Ross Graham, chairwoman of Community Board 4, whose area runs from 14th to 59th Street. "Bob Ronayne seems to have a genuine commitment to doing a good road."
A key feature of Route 9A would be the straightening of a notorious S-curve at 23d Street. This would involve clipping a bit of Thomas F. Smith Park and acquiring a privately owned building at 621 West 23d Street. The plan also calls for the widening of 24th Street west of 11th Avenue, which would require the acquisition of the rest of the privately owned properties on that block.
Land acquired by the state but not used for roadways would be combined with the existing park across 23d Street, which would be closed btween Route 9A and 11th Avenue.
The creation of the Chelsea Waterside Park, as Ms. Graham called it, would eradicate one of the last vestiges of "Chelsea" itself, the country estate deeded in 1750 to Captain Thomas Clarke and renowed as the home of Clement Clarke Moore.
The four-story industrial building at 621 West 23d Street, which dates from the 1920's, is owned by a corporation headed by Richard W. Moore, a lawyer and great-great-great-great grandson of Clement Clarke Moore.
Mr. Moore declined to comment on the prospect of condemnation. But Mr. Ronayne, imagining the landmarks implications of any association with Mr. Moore's ancestor, said, "Luckily for us, he didn't write 'Night Before Christmas' in that building."

HEADLINE: The Evolution Of the SoHo District

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Here at the Landmarks Preservation Commission we all enjoyed your May 8 article on the evolution of SoHo. For those of us who remember SoHo in the 1960's and 1970's, its transformation has been truly remarkable. 
 But we also remember that it was the city's designation of the entire SoHo-Cast-Iron Historic District, from Crosby to West Broadway and Canal to Houston, that was instrumental in protecting the world's greatest concentration of cast-iron fronted buildings from demolition for the proposed Lower Manhattan Expressway. It was that battle for historic preservation, together with the campaign for legalized artists' working/living space, that kept SoHo from being leveled, and made possible whatever successes it has since sustained.
Today, the SoHo, TriBeca and Ladies' Mile historic districts have become breeders of the kind of economic development that this city needs so badly. The role of historic preservation in creating that development shouldn't be underestimated, or overlooked.
 
LAURIE BECKELMAN
Manhattan
 
The writer is chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Hemmerdinger Approach;
Carrots, Not Sticks; Improvement, Not Growth

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
H. DALE HEMMERDINGER uses the carrot, not the stick. When too many executives at ATCO Properties, his real estate services company, were getting pudgy, he offered them $100 a pound to lose weight. When he read about the benefits of aerobics exercise, he began paying a $500 year-end bonus to any employee who climbed the 16 flights to ATCO's offices, $250 for anyone who walked halfway up. A smoker quits, it's worth $500.
One result of all this gentle bribery is that very few fat people work at ATCO's headquarters at 555 Fifth Avenue, at 46th Street. And Mr. Hemmerdinger has offered the one holdout smoker a mink coat to quit. 
 "Dale knows what drives people," said Peter L. DiCapua, ATCO's senior vice president, who has lost $5,400 worth of pounds.
Mr. Hemmerdinger, 49, apparently believes that much can be accomplished with a dollop of cash and a ton of psychology. And that includes making money in a tough real estate market.
The Hemmerdinger family owns five office buildings and two apartment buildings in New York and Mr. Hemmerdinger has crunched the numbers. Any way you cut it, he says, the taxes and operating costs in those buildings will be higher than the income they generate for a long, long time.
Mr. Hemmerdinger is certain that his plight is typical. So he is setting up a private hedge fund to sell real estate short. He and his partners will make most of their money if the real estate investment trusts -- known as REITs -- and other real estate-related stocks they pick lose value.
"All this recent misplaced optimism about a recovery stems from a lack of understanding about real estate as a market," Mr. Hemmerdinger said.
Craig A. Drill, a Manhattan hedge fund manager who will run the fund, is certain that jaundiced view has huge profit potential. "Unsophisticated buyers spend billions on REITs," he said. "Dale can spot which REITs will cut dividends and lose money."
Contrariness is nothing new for Mr. Hemmerdinger. He spent the last half of the 80's, when most other developers were building on every square inch of dirt, bailing out of real estate all over the country.
"We no longer felt that owning a hodgepodge of properties was the best way to get a good return on our money," he said.
Mr. Hemmerdinger sold more than a dozen properties. He used some of the proceeds to pay off the mortgages on the buildings he kept. The rest he invested in a bank that does not make real estate loans and in a portfolio of stocks unrelated to real estate.
In 1992 he formed Atlas Partners, a consulting firm to help banks, insurance companies and other "accidental owners" figure out what to do with their properties.
"Dale offers the vantage point of an owner, and at highly competitive fees," said Harrison J. Goldin, the former City Comptroller who hired Mr. Hemmerdinger to gauge the prospects of some properties involved in a bankruptcy in which Mr. Goldin is a trustee.
Mr. Hemmerdinger makes no apologies for switching from bricks and mortar to advice and passive investment.
"MY mother used to rail at me, say, 'Look what Donald Trump is doing -- why can't you grow our business like that?' " Mr. Hemmerdinger recalled. "Well, we entered the 1990's debt free and our investments have been profitable every year since."
Still, Mr. Hemmerdinger's current businesses mark a real departure from the Hemmerdinger family development legacy.
Back in 1922, Dale Hemmerdinger's grandfather, Henry, bought Atlas Terminals, a four-building industrial complex in Glenwood, Queens, to house his rag-recycling business. First, he leased out space he didn't use. Soon, he was building new buildings. Today there are 38 buildings in what has become a thriving industrial park.
The park did so well that Mr. Hemmerdinger's father, Monroe, who died in 1962, sold the recycling business and became a full-time developer. By the end of the 1950's he had built numerous industrial buildings in Miami and New York and two Manhattan office towers, 555 Fifth and 630 Third Avenue, at 41st Street.
"My grandfather viewed real estate as an investment," Mr. Hemmerdinger recalled. "My father made it the family business."
Dale Hemmerdinger almost sidestepped that business. He majored in fine arts at New York University, then entered a masters program in government. His plan was to join the Foreign Service.
Then, in 1967, a trustee of his father's estate invited him to lunch, told him the business was foundering and begged him to take over. He did, dismissed the five people working for it, changed its name from Hemmerdinger Estate Corporation to Hemmerdinger Corporation and formed ATCO (an acronym for Atlas Terminals Corporation) as the company's management and construction arm.
Early on he hired Mr. DiCapua, fresh out of the Merchant Marine and as young and inexperienced as Mr. Hemmerdinger. The second to be hired was Alan Rosenbluth, a lawyer who is now ATCO's head administrator. Neither man has equity in the company, but both can invest in Mr. Hemmerdinger's deals with no mark-ups or caveats.
"When they have their own money up, I know I'm getting their best opinion on whether to do a deal," Mr. Hemmerdinger said.
The team has made its share of mistakes. Take, for example, the luxury condominiums they built in Montauk, L.I.
"We put in all kinds of fancy fixtures," Mr. DiCapua said. "Our competitors recognized that customers were happy with $30 doors from the local home-improvement store." ATCO and its executives lost money.
Still, the ATCO connection has clearly been satisfying and lucrative for both Mr. DiCapua and Mr. Rosenbluth, in that both are still with the company.
"Dale is not detail-oriented, and that's a weakness," Mr. DiCapua said. "But he never second-guesses people he trusts."
That list includes few outsiders. ATCO does its own construction because Mr. Hemmerdinger feels that contractors cut too many corners on tenant build-out work. He employs his own leasing people, lest outsiders who don't have to face the owner each day push through unprofitable deals to get commissions.
And he ticks off whole categories of properties that he will never again buy or build because they are subject to outside forces:
Shopping centers are too dependent on anchor stores. One-family homes are too dependent on individuals. Mr. Hemmerdinger is even chary of office buildings where too many leases roll over at the same time.
"I ONCE lost a 350,000-square-foot tenant for reasons I couldn't control, and I don't want to be that dependent on one tenant ever again," said Mr. Hemmerdinger, who tries to write deals so that about 10 percent of the leases in his buildings roll over each year.
For now, except for a discount mall near London that he has bought into, no new real estate investment seems enticing. Instead, Mr. Hemmerdinger is concentrating on improving the buildings he already owns.
"Depreciation isn't just an accounting issue," he said. "Keeping buildings in shape is critical to keeping tenants."
He has been redoing lobbies, elevators and windows at all his office buildings. And he has refurbished 40 Central Park South, the family-owned rental building where he lives with his playwright wife, Elizabeth.
The rehabs, along with Mr. Hemmerdinger's habit of frequently lunching with tenants, have won ATCO tenant loyalty.
"Lighting, windows, a concierge desk -- they seem to always be improving something," said Stanley Blindman, a partner in the law firm Blindman, Uram & Swords, which just renewed its lease at 630 Third. "I could probably have struck a harder deal elsewhere, but the nonadversarial relationship with ATCO is worth a little extra rent."
Mr. Hemmerdinger is not quite as adamant about staying put as is his tenant. Whether he continues to devote his energy and his family's wealth to real estate will depend on whether his children -- Damon, 23, and Katherine, 20 -- join the business. And that, Mr. Hemmerdinger expects, will depend on whether New York City's economy and quality of life improves.
A self-described old-school Democrat, Mr. Hemmerdinger is nonetheless hoping that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will accomplish what his Democratic predecessors could not.
"Business improvement districts and incentives to keep companies from moving aren't the answer," he said. "If we don't get low taxes and safe streets and better education, businesses will flee this town. And I wouldn't be surprised if my children do, as well."

LENGTH: 1244 words

HEADLINE: New Jersey Q & A: George R. Zoffinger;
Behind the Campaign for the World Cup

BYLINE: By TOM TOOLEN 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
THOUGH George R. Zoffinger is still disturbed at the way the United States Postal Service slighted New Jersey by leaving the state's name off the official World Cup souvenir postal card, the anger has subsided somewhat because of the success of the first World Cup game, which was played last weekend at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford.
Mr. Zoffinger was one of the 74,000 fans who watched Ireland defeat Italy 1 to 0 in the first of seven World Cup games at the stadium. 
 "Seeing how well the game went and how much fun everyone had has taken some of the sting out of being slighted on the stamps," he said.
Mr. Zoffinger, 46, the co-chairman of the New Jersey World Cup Host Committee, tried a stop-the-stamp campaign before the postal cards carrying three different World Cup stamps was issued on May 26.
"It's just another example of how New Jersey gets discriminated against in the larger picture, and that is why it was so important to bring the World Cup games to Giant Stadium," he said. "We will make sure everyone knows the games are being played in New Jersey."
Many officials, including Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, sent letters asking that the souvenir cards be amended to include New Jersey's name, but postal officials said it was too late. Officials of the International World Cup Organization in New York apologized for the omission, and so did the postal officials.
Mr. Zoffinger is also chairman of the Corestates New Jersey National Bank, in New Brunswick. At his office, he said the World Cup was bringing millions of dollars into the state's coffers, with people from around the world visiting New Jersey.
Half a million people are expected to see the seven games at Giants Stadium, and millions more will be seeing the games across the nation. The games will last five weeks, with the finals in Los Angeles.
Q. Why is the World Cup so important to New Jersey?
A. The World Cup will attract more than $800 million of revenue into the metropolitan area, and half of that will be spent in New Jersey. In addition, over all, more than two billion people will watch the finals via satellite on TV around the world. It will go a long way in putting New Jersey on the map because the World Cup is a mega-event and most of the world is crazy about soccer.
Q. How did you get the campaign to get the World Cup started?
A. I was with Gov. Jim Florio in a Portuguese restaurant in the Ironbound section of Newark in 1990, and a giant roar came up from the other room. The Governor asked me what the noise was, and I told him it was a bunch of people watching the World Cup. That was my opening to ask the Governor if we could attempt to bring the World Cup to New Jersey.
He was very enthusiastic when he saw how excited the people were getting about the games. The Governor said that if that much emotion is involved, then New Jersey should give it a try and try to attract the World Cup in 1994. After all, New Jersey has deep ethnic ties to the sport, he said, and don't forget the New York Cosmos had played their games in Giants Stadium.
Q. You were never discouraged about bringing the games to New Jersey?
A. No, I guess I'm not that type of person. I know that if we work hard enough, good things will happen. There will be banana peels along the way, but you don't have to step on them.
Q. What was the biggest problem?
A. I guess the fact that we had to find a way to replace the artificial grass in the stadium with real grass. International soccer rules say that the World Cup games must be played on real grass. But there was no real problem since the folks at the New Jersey Meadowlands Sports and Exposition Authority found a way to lay the real grass over the artificial turf.
Q. Any other problems?
A. Well, many people were skeptical about us being able to pull it off. Who would have imagined when we first started that the teams with the two largest ethnic followings in the state -- Italy and Ireland -- would be playing on June 18? But they did.
Q. You're still fuming about the omission of New Jersey by the Postal Service?
A. Well, it was a mistake, an honest mistake, I understand that, but it's a mistake that happens too often to New Jersey. For instance, when the United States Open golf tournament was being played at Baltusrol, a great New Jersey golf course in Springfield, all the TV announcers were talking about was the New York skyline and showing the World Trade Center. They should have been talking about New Jersey and showing the Jersey Shore or some other state attractions.
Q. Do you think the World Cup will help change the image of New Jersey in the eyes of outsiders?
A. I think it will. It will show the world that we have a great stadium in East Rutherford, and we have great attractions in the state. It will be a boon for the state -- that's for sure.
Q. How did you win approval for the World Cup?
A. It began when I was head of the Department of Commerce and Economic Development for the state, an agency designed to create jobs and attract business to New Jersey. What greater attraction than the World Cup? I assigned a lawyer to assess potential sites and draw up a no-frills proposal. The lawyer took the $250,000 application fee that was required to apply for the World Cup out of the department's advertising budget. Incidentally, we eventually got the deposit back, and we got the World Cup games too.
Q. How did you convince the World Cup officials that New Jersey was the place to play seven games?
A. We convinced them that we would change over to grass with no problem and we would adhere to the wider field that soccer is played on. They were impressed with the fact that the largest soccer crowd in history had seen Pele play in Giants Stadium, a North American record that stood for nearly a decade.
Q. How many others were bidding to be host to the World Cup games?
A. We beat out 35 competitors to be one of the nine sites for the World Cup play. And we have the most games played here in New Jersey than the other sites: Washington, Dallas, Detroit, Chicago, San Francisco, Orlando, Austin and the finals in Los Angeles.
Q. What do you say to the New Jersey detractors now?
A. I say that the whole world found Lillehammer, Norway, for the Olympics, and I'm sure they have found East Rutherford, N.J., for the World Cup.
Q. What was the most rewarding part of seeing the first game?
A. Exhilaration, excitement and relief. I was exhilarated to see the fruits of our long months of labor. I was excited at the well-played soccer game. I was relieved there was a great feeling of fun among the spectators. There was virtually no trouble at all, and for that I was very relieved. I think that shows that New Jersey was the right choice to host the games.
 
Profile

Born: Feb. 24, 1948, in New York City; grew up in East Meadow, L.I.
Education: B.A. in economics, Pennsylvania State University, 1969; M.B.A. in finance, New York University, 1973.
Career: Assistant vice president of finance, later vice president of finance, Irving Trust Company, 1971 to 1976; executive vice president, First Fidelity Bank, 1976 to 1990; New Jersey Commissioner of Commerce, 1990 to 1992; chairman, Corestates, New Jersey National Bank, 1992 to present; co-chairman of the New Jersey Host Committee of the World Cup '94.
Family: Married to Judy Zoffinger; three children, Cristine, 22; Richard, 20, and Bryan, 15.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 13; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 924 words

HEADLINE: A SENSE OF PLACE

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins 

 BODY:
THEY are tough. They are resourceful. And they are everywhere: one of New Jersey's most abundant natural resources. Yet they get absolutely no respect.
Talk-show hosts make jokes about them; government authorities favor their elimination. Worse, they breed wild speculation and outright rumor. And so, at long last, some hard-hitting truths about the New Jersey mosquito. 
 Is the New Jersey mosquito the state bird?
Absolutely not. This silly, New Jersey-bashing deceit was first launched as a joke by Johnny Carson on the "Tonight" show in 1964 and has been perpetrated by Jay Leno and David Letterman. As readers of the scandal sheets must know by now, the state bird of New Jersey is the killer bee.
Should state residents be defensive about the notorious New Jersey mosquito?
Beware, citizens: mosquito guilt is an insidious condition. It has been fostered by the Anti-New Jersey Promotional Authority, a national hate group that has long placed New Jersey-mocking jokes in Hollywood movies and in the hands of stand-up comedians. Before its mosquito campaign, the authority kept busy spreading the rumor that Jimmy Hoffa is buried in the Garden State.
How are mosquitoes a positive asset for New Jersey?
Residents should be justifiably proud of that these legendary residents are actually a vital New Jersey resource.
1. They are responsible for maintaining the nationally recognized diversity of the bird population of the state.
2. They have been a spur to the pesticide refinery-plant industry that has for decades contributed so much to the ambiance of the New Jersey Turnpike.
3. Most importantly, the New Jersey mosquito has single-handedly deterred hordes of unmannerly out-of-staters from despoiling our favorite beaches, forest lands and hiking preserves. Home-grown mosquitoes have even been known to intimidate indomitable Mainers heading to the Jersey Shore to escape the stinging bites of black flies.
Can the bite of a New Jersey mosquito be fatal?
Unlike the aggressive urban mosquitoes of neighboring states, well-mannered New Jersey insects rarely engage in drive-by bitings or insect wilding, and for the most part they practice safe sting.
What attracts mosquitoes to their victims?
Scientists used to believe that mosquites were attracted to the carbon monoxide, warmth and moisture of the breathing mammal. But that was based on studies of unsophisticated out-of-state insects. New Jersey mosquitoes are much more selective; they prefer to dine on trendier New Jerseyans who have consumed Brie, sun-dried tomatoes, pignoli nuts, jicama slices and Zima alcoholic beverage.
Are New Jersey mosquitoes the largest in America?
No, although die-hard New Jersey boosters would certainly feel a surge of pride if the state ever held the record. But Alaska has larger mosquitoes by far. The record-holder was a 2.3-pound Anopheles captured with 10-pound monofilament line and a standard reel at Point Barrow on Sept. 29, 1982.
The largest New Jersey mosquito on record was a mere 1.3 pounds, captured in a swampy region of Wawayanda State Park the night of July 3, 1979.
The magnificent specimen was caught only because it was carrying a flashlight, and it has been placed on permanent exhibition in the legendary "Garden State Hall of the Mosquito" display next to the change machine near the snack-bar corner of the Molly Pitcher Service Area on the New Jersey Turnpike.
How many mosquitoes are there in New Jersey?
Happily, according to statistics released by the New Jersey Bureau of the Mosquito Census, the mosquito population has grown by leaps and bounds in the last decade. The current species are larger, healthier and stronger than ever before, thanks to the decades-long efforts of the New Jersey Mosquito Control Commission. The number has increased 5.1 percent, to 44,912,024,000 mosquitos productively living, working and contributing to the state's economy.
What is the position of New Jersey mosquitoes on the possible move of the New York Yankees to the Garden State?
The Mosquito Trades Council, Local 1020, has unanimously voted to support all attempts to bring more people, Yankees or otherwise, to the Meadowlands. Members especially wish to personally welcome George Steinbrenner.
What is the state's official stance toward the New Jersey mosquito?
A bill, S.L. 345Hi(A), nicknamed the "bloodsucker bill," would impose a graduated income tax upon all 44 billion working mosquitoes in the state. Mosquito-rights groups have vowed to protest the measure to the last bite.
How can the New Jersey mosquito best be repelled?
Although commercially available sprays may be effective, the most successful strategy is to just say no. In fact, a loud, firm "no," when aimed at a cruising Garden State mosquito, can be effective since New Jersey species are highly intelligent.
What is the future of the mosquito in New Jersey?
The Native Jerseyan Mosquito Coalition has instituted a lawsuit challenging mosquito-eradication efforts in the state. The suit argues that mosquitoes have inhabited New Jersey since shortly after the extinction of the dinosaurs. Therefore, the suit says, mosquitoes have the right of citizenship in the state. The suit would designate humans as legal prey.
Why do New Jersey mosquitoes hum?
The humming noise was long thought to be a powerful sexual attractant of the male mosquito for the female. But researchers have discovered the true reason that mosquitoes hum: they are really happy with their work.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 13; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 900 words

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Riding the Roller Coaster in Europe

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
IN the European bond markets, last week was a doozy, even by the tumultuous standards of the last several months.
It started with a bang on Monday. With the dollar plunging and inflation fears intensifying, investors dumped bonds as fast as they could into a market where buyers, to the extent that there were any, were growing increasingly reluctant at any price. Prices plunged. Yields soared. Traders began worrying about a major market meltdown. 
 As the week progressed, relative calm descended. The dollar stabilized against the German mark and the Japanese yen. Stock prices recovered somewhat. Bond yields edged down.
Then on Friday, the markets grew anxious again, sending stocks and bonds tumbling. Intervention by central banks on Friday to prop up the dollar soothed the worst of the anxieties in the markets but by no means put them to rest.
The yield on the benchmark 10-year German Government bond, the Bund, rose to 7.19 percent on Monday, up from 7.12 percent on the day and up from about 5.6 percent at the beginning of this year. It fell back to around 7 percent on Thursday, and then spiked upward again on Friday, closing at 7.05 percent.
Government bond yields in most other European nations have risen even more steeply since the beginning of the year. The benchmark Italian 10-year bond was yielding 9.438 percent at the close on Friday, up from 9.331 percent on Thursday.
Given the generally strong economic fundamentals in Europe -- and the prospect of further official interest rate cuts in Germany -- some investors and analysts began wondering whether the bear market in bonds was just about over, and whether there was not some value at current prices.
"We certainly take the view that the market is being far too pessimistic, particularly in continental Europe, about the likely path of economic growth and inflation," said Ros Lifton, an economist at Nomura Research.
Yet Ms. Lifton, like most analysts and economists, was far from ready to call a turn in the market. The fundamentals are strong, but the negative market psychology seems stronger, and investors in Europe appear likely to remain extremely sensitive to signs of incipient inflation and dollar weakness, and to take their cues from rising interest rates in the United States.
European bond prices have been falling since February, when the Federal Reserve began raising interest rates in the United States, puncturing the belief that rates would continue falling or remain at historical lows even as the world's economies picked up.
Hedge funds and other big institutional investors that loaded up on bonds during 1993 in a bet on falling rates found themselves selling frantically to minimize losses on their positions -- and each bout of selling pushed prices down further, creating even more selling pressure and driving away buyers.
Evidence of economic recovery in the United States and Europe has only served to further fuel inflation fears, even though inflation remains remarkably well tamed on both sides of the Atlantic.
The markets got a glimmer of good news last week. A key measure of the German money supply fell somewhat in May, the Bundesbank announced, raising hopes that the powerful German central bank might be able to reduce official interest rates again later this summer. The money supply figure, M3, rose at an annualized rate of 13.7 percent in May on a seasonally adjusted basis -- well above the Bundesbank's target of 4 percent to 6 percent, but below what the markets had expected and down from the 15.4 percent rise in April.
In a report to clients last week, Salomon Brothers in London said it expected further reductions in M3 growth and steady reductions in inflation.
"The substantial deceleration in M3 from the current pace will enable the Bundesbank to embark on another easing move without raising fears of future inflationary pressures," Salomon Brothers said. "Near term, bearish sentiment could push Bund yields up further. However, with M3 and inflation slowing, Bunds should prove an attractive buying opportunity later this year."
Part of the Bundesbank's monetary strategy in recent months has been to cut short-term interest rates in the hopes of encouraging savers to move money from savings accounts -- where it is included in M3 -- into long-term investments such as bonds. Brian V. Mullaney, an economist at Morgan Stanley in London, said that the role of domestic investors in the European bond markets would be crucial, but that in Germany, for example, domestic demand for bonds has not yet improved significantly.
"So far, local investor interest has been, and remains, insufficient to prevent further increases in bond yields, as increasingly risk-averse international investors scale back their exposure," Mr. Mullaney said in a report last week.
Mr. Mullaney said long-term bond yields are just now reaching their average over the last 20 years of 7.5 percent in Germany, and that real yields -- the difference between absolute yields and the level of inflation -- are still below their historical average of 4 percent to 4.5 percent.
"But although market valuations now look less expensive than before, they are still not cheap," Mr. Mullaney said. "So bond market performance still depends primarily on the outlook for short-term interest rates, which in turn depends on the outlook for inflation and economic recovery."
